Title I - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
CHAPTER 1-1. - CODE ESTABLISHED, ETC. 

Sec. 1-1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following titles, chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, City of Amarillo, Texas" and may be so cited. This Code may also be cited as the "Amarillo Municipal Code." 
(Code 1960, § 1-1) 
State Law reference- Ordinance codification, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 53.001 et seq. 
Sec. 1-1-2. - Provisions considered as continuations of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as ordinances existing at the time of the adoption of this Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
Sec. 1-1-3. - Ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance: 
(1)  Promising or guaranteeing the payment of money by or to the City, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the City or any evidence of the City's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the City; 
(2)  Appropriating funds or establishing or relating to the annual budget; 
(3)  Imposing taxes which are not inconsistent with this Code; 
(4)  Establishing positions, classifying employees or setting salaries not codified in this Code; 
(5)  Dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening or vacating any Street or public way; 
(6)  Establishing or prescribing Street Grades; 
(7)  Providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor; 
(8)  Prescribing through Streets, parking prohibitions, parking limitations, one-way Streets, speed limits, load limits or loading zones not inconsistent with this Code; 
(9)  Which rezones specific property or adopts a Zoning Map; 
(10)  Dedicating, accepting or rejecting any Plat or Subdivision; 
(11)  Annexing or deannexing property; 
(12)  Relating to cable television; 
(13)  Whose purpose has been accomplished; 
(14)  Which is special although permanent in effect; 
(15)  Which is temporary although general in effect. 
All such ordinances are recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
Sec. 1-1-4. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
(b)  The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or allowing any use or the continuance of any use of a Structure or Premises in violation of any ordinance of this City in effect on the date of adoption of this Code. 
Sec. 1-1-5. - General penalty; continuing violations; civil parking penalties. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the City an act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or wherever in this Code or any ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance shall be punished by a fine of not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) except as provided in subsection (b) of this section. Each day any violation of this Code or of any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Violation of any provision of this Code regulating fire safety, zoning, public health and sanitation, or dumping of refuse shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). Each day any such violation of this Code shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  A director, officer, employee or other person authorized to act in behalf of a corporation or association having responsibility for the discharge of a duty to act imposed by law on a corporation or association is criminally responsible for a violation under this Code to the same extent as if such person were criminally responsible under this Code. 
(d)  From paragraph (a) above are specifically excepted the offenses of failure to restrain an Animal under section 8-2-5(a)(1) (however, if such unrestrained animal commits an unprovoked attack on or aggressive threatening behavior toward a human or other animal, then this exception to paragraph (a) shall not apply), permit disturbing noise by an Animal under section 8-2-5(a)(4), failure to vaccinate an Animal under section 8-2-8, failure to display a current rabies vaccination tag under section 8-2-9, and failure to confine a female in heat under section 8-2-11 of the Amarillo Municipal Code for which the maximum fine shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. 
(e)  Certain Stopping, Standing and Parking related violations; civil. 
(1)  Scope . All violations described in subsections (i) through (iii) below are hereby declared to be civil offenses within the City limits of Amarillo. This subsection applies to any violation arising out of: 
a.  An overtime parking violation in an unpaid parking space with posted time limits; 
b.  An overtime parking violation in a paid parking space or zone as provided in Chapter 16-5, Article 1; 
c.  Other stopping, standing, parking violations established by this Code of Ordinances, Chapter 16-3, Article V (sections 16-3-176 to 16-3-250, and as amended) or in Texas Transportation Code, sections 545.301 and 545.302. 
However, this subsection (e) does not apply to or include these offenses: (A) the several offenses provided in Texas Transportation Code, section 681.011, as amended, which relates to or arises out of disabled/handicap parking, and upon conviction of any such offense shall remain punishable as a criminal offense in accordance with state law and subsections (a)-(d) above; and (B) parking in a designated fire lane, and upon conviction for such offense shall remain punishable in accordance with subsections (a)-(d) above or state law as applicable. 
(2)  Enforcement . Pursuant to both the City's home rule authority and the specific provision of Texas Transportation Code, section 681.010 as amended, the City Manager or designee is authorized to appoint City employees or volunteers to issue citations or notices of violation for the enforcement of parking regulations in the City. 
(3)  Civil penalty imposed; Administrative hearing. 
a.  Offenses described in subsection (e)(1) are hereby declared to be a civil nuisance and is punishable by a civil penalty of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per violation. Within twelve (12) days after the date of issuance of the notice of violation, the owner or operator must either pay that civil penalty or request an administrative hearing as provided in Chapter 2-8, Article VI of this Code of Ordinances. If such initial penalty is not timely paid or hearing requested, then such penalty is declared to be past due and the penal amount due is enhanced to fifty dollars ($50.00) and shall be payable by the close of business on the 30 th day after the notice of violation was issued. If such enhanced penalty is not timely paid, then the penalty is declared to be delinquent and shall double to one hundred dollars ($100.00). In the event the City of Amarillo offices are closed on a day when a payment shall be due, then the deadline for that payment is extended to the next business day on which City offices are open. 
b.  If the owner or operator requests an administrative hearing during the initial twelve (12) days, then such will be scheduled and notice provided pursuant to Chapter 2-8, Article VI. If the hearing officer determines that the offense occurred and the initial penalty and costs is due and payable within twelve (12) days. Both the initial twelve (12) days allowed for payment and any applicable Late or Delinquent penalties as specified above shall be calculated from the date of the hearing officer's determination. If there is an appeal of the hearing officer's determination, then payment is suspended pending such appeal. The maximum civil penalty for an offense under this subsection (e), whether set by a hearing officer or municipal judge shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
c.  All civil penalties and assessed costs collected under this section shall be deposited into the city treasury general fund for the use and benefit of the city. 
(4)  Collection . The civil penalties assessed by this ordinance, a hearing officer, or municipal judge shall be enforceable and collectible as provided in section 2-8-203 of this Code of Ordinances or as otherwise provided by state law. 
(Ord. No. 5554, § 1, 11-5-85; Ord. No. 5709, § 1, 9-15-87; Ord. No. 5746, § 1, 5-17-88; Ord. No. 6971, § 1, 7-25-06; Ord. No. 7779, § 1, 3-26-2019) 
Cross reference- Municipal court, Ch. 2-8; credit for jail term, § 2-8-116. 
State Law reference- Penalties for ordinance violations, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.001. 
Sec. 1-1-6. - Culpable mental state. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance an act or failure to act is prohibited or is declared to be an offense, and such provision does not expressly require proof of a culpable mental state, then proof of culpability is not required for conviction, it being the intent of the City Council to dispense with the requirement of a culpable mental state. Provided however, that if an offense is punishable by a fine in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00), then a person does not commit an offense unless it is shown that the actor acted recklessly. 
(b)  If State law prescribes a specific culpable mental state, higher than recklessness, in order to convict for an offense under this Code or an ordinance, then such prescribed culpable mental state shall be applied and no person shall be convicted without proof satisfying the State requirement. 
(c)  Proof of a higher degree of culpability than that required or charged constitutes proof of the lesser culpability required or charged. 
(Ord. No. 6858, § 1, 10-18-2005; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
CHAPTER 1-2. - DEFINITIONS, RULES OF CONSTRUCTION, ETC. 

Sec. 1-2-1. - Scope and effect of definitions. 
    Whenever in this Code a term is defined, the definition applies to such term throughout this Code. 
Sec. 1-2-2. - General definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    Charter. The word "Charter" shall mean the City Charter of the City of Amarillo, Texas, as from time to time amended. 
    City. The word "City" shall be construed as if the words "of Amarillo, Texas" followed. 
    City Council. Whenever the words "City Council" are used, they shall be construed to mean the City Council of the City of Amarillo, Texas. 
    City Manager. The words "City Manager" shall mean the City Manager of the City of Amarillo, Texas or his authorized deputy, agent or representative. 
    Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day on which such notice is given, or such act is done shall not be counted in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had shall be counted. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only may extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one (1) person and thing. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
(Ord. No. 5569, § 1, 2-25-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Sec. 1-2-3. - Catchlines of sections; history notes, etc.; references to Code. 
(a)  The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type and the italicized lead lines of subsections are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section or subsection and shall not be deemed or taken to be the titles nor as any part of the section or subsection, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections or subsections, including the catchlines and italicized lead lines, are amended or reenacted. 
(b)  The history or source notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. Cross references and state law references which appear after sections or subsections of this Code or which otherwise appear in footnote form are provided for the convenience of the user of this Code and have no legal effect. 
(c)  All references to titles, chapters, articles or sections are to the titles, chapters, articles and sections of this Code unless otherwise specified. 
(Code 1960, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-2-4. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any conflicting ordinances which were in force before or at the time the ordinance which is repealed took effect. When an ordinance which repealed another shall itself be repealed, the previous or repealed ordinance shall not be revived without express words to that effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1960, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-2-5. - Severability. 
    The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable. If any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1960, § 1-5) 
Title II - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Bi-city-county health department, § 8-5-21 et seq. 

CHAPTER 2-1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 2-1-1. - Elections. 
    All municipal elections shall be governed by the Charter and the Election Code. 
(Code 1960, § 1-8) 
CHAPTER 2-2. - CITY COUNCIL 

Sec. 2-2-1. - Regular and special meetings. 
(a)  The City Council shall hold regular meetings on Tuesday of each week at the regular meeting place of the City Council, unless otherwise determined by the City Council. 
(b)  All regular and special meetings of the City Council shall be held in the City Council chambers in City Hall unless otherwise determined by the City Council. 
(c)  The Mayor, or in his absence the Mayor pro tem, two (2) members of the City Council or the City Manager may call special meetings of the City Council. Notice of any special meeting shall be given to each member of the City Council either in writing or by telephone message. 
(d)  The presiding officer of the City Council shall be the Mayor, or in his absence the Mayor pro tem. The presiding officer of the City Council shall preserve strict order and decorum at all regular and special meetings. He shall state every question coming before the City Council, announce the decision on all questions and decide all questions of order. He shall sign all ordinances, resolutions and minutes of the City Council. 
(e)  Proceedings of the City Council shall be governed by and conducted according to the latest edition of Robert's Rules of Order, as modified by the City Council, unless in conflict with this Section or with applicable state law. 
(f)  A motion to adjourn shall always be in order and decided without debate. 
(g)  All meetings of the City Council shall be held in compliance with the Texas Open Meetings Act, as now or hereafter amended. 
(h)  While the City Council is in session, the members of the Council must preserve order and decorum, and no member of the City Council or any citizen shall by conversation, or otherwise, delay or interrupt the proceedings or peace of the City Council, or disturb any member while speaking, or refuse to obey the orders of the presiding officer of the City Council. Any person making personal, impertinent or slanderous remarks, or who shall become boisterous while addressing the City Council, or any person who shall refuse to abide by the orders of the presiding officer of the City Council shall forthwith be barred from further audience before the City Council. 
(i)  The Chief of Police of the City, or such members of the Police Department as he may designate, shall be the sergeant-at-arms of the City Council meetings. He or his representative shall carry out all orders and instructions given by the presiding officer for the purpose of maintaining order and decorum at the City Council meetings. Upon instructions of the presiding officer, it shall be the duty of the sergeant-at-arms to remove from the City Council room any person who violates the order and decorum of the meeting or who refuses to obey the orders of the presiding officer of the City Council. 
(Code 1960, § 2-1; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 7658, §§ 1, 2, 3-14-17) 
Sec. 2-2-2. - Agenda; order of business; submission of ordinances, etc. 
(a)  All reports, communications, ordinances, resolutions, descriptions of contract documents or other matters to be submitted to the City Council shall be delivered by the City Manager to each member of the City Council and the City Attorney prior to the date of the City Council meeting and as far in advance of the meeting as time for preparation will permit. 
(b)  All ordinances, resolutions and contract documents shall be submitted to the City Attorney for his approval prior to presentation to the City Council. The City Attorney shall either approve or give his written legal objection to the passage of any ordinance submitted to the City Council. 
(c)  Ordinances may be introduced by the City Council by reading a description of the caption only; provided, however, that any member may require the reading in full of any proposed ordinance. 
(Code 1960, § 2-2; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Sec. 2-2-3. - Order of business. 
    The City Manager and City Secretary shall, in coordination with the Mayor, prepare an agenda for each meeting of the City Council, separately listing each matter to be considered or acted upon. Upon majority vote of the Council members present at a meeting, the sequence of the agenda items may be rearranged. 
(Code 1960, § 2-3(a); Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 6562, § 1, 10-23-2001; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Sec. 2-2-4. - Records; minutes. 
(a)  Record of proceedings. Proceedings before the City Council shall be recorded by electronic recording device and preserved in the office of the City Secretary for a period of ten (10) years. All recordings more than ten (10) years old may be destroyed by the City Secretary. The electronic recordings of the proceedings before the City Council shall be for informational purposes only, and such recordings shall never be considered to be a part of the minutes of the City Council. 
(b)  Journal of proceedings. The City Secretary shall keep a journal of the proceedings of the City Council which shall be known as the minutes of the City Council. The minutes of the City Council shall be as brief as possible, stating only a brief synopsis of the questions presented to the City Council and the motion or decision of the City Council thereon, together with the vote of the City Council. 
(c)  Record of protests. Any member of the City Council may have the reasons for his dissent from or his protest against any action of the City Council entered in the minutes of the City Council. 
(d)  Handling of ordinances. Ordinances submitted to the City Council shall be assigned the next numerical ordinance number by the City Secretary prior to submission to the City Council. All ordinances shall be preserved for permanent record by the City Secretary whether passed by the City Council or rejected. Upon the passage of an ordinance by the City Council only the number of the ordinance and the caption thereof shall be recorded in the minutes of the City Council. 
(e)  Handling of resolutions. Resolutions submitted to the City Council shall be assigned a resolution number by the City Secretary prior to submission to the City Council, which number shall correspond to the month, day and year of passage, followed by the numerical number of the resolution as shown in the agenda for the City Council meeting, to wit: 9-20-66-1 for first resolution, 9-20-66-2 for second resolution and 9-20-66-3 for third resolution. Only the number of the resolution and the caption or brief statement of the contents of the resolution shall be entered in the minutes of the City Council. All resolutions shall be preserved for permanent record by the City Secretary. 
(f)  Minutes of other boards and commissions. Boards and commissions of the City shall record their minutes in substantially the same form as prescribed for the minutes of the City Council. 
(Code 1960, § 2-3(b); Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, Ch. 2-6. 
CHAPTER 2-3. - LEGAL REPRESENTATIVES 

Sec. 2-3-1. - City Attorney generally. 
(a)  Appointment; term. The City Attorney shall be appointed by the City Manager with the advice and consent of the City Council. The City Attorney shall hold office at the will of the City Manager. 
(b)  Compensation. The compensation for the City Attorney shall be by salary, payable monthly in the amount fixed by the City Council, and shall be subject to change at the discretion of the City Council. 
(c)  Bond. Before entering upon the duties of his office the City Attorney shall make a bond, if required by the City Manager, in such sum as the City Manager may prescribe and conditioned as he may deem best. 
(d)  Oath. The City Attorney shall take and subscribe to the oath prescribed by the constitution and laws for members of the City Council. 
(Code 1960, §§ 2-4, 2-5; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Sec. 2-3-2. - Duties of City Attorney. 
    The City Attorney shall be the legal advisor and attorney for the City Council and all officers and departments of the City. The City Attorney shall: 
(1)  Represent the City in all litigation and legal proceedings; 
(2)  Prepare or approve all proposed ordinances; 
(3)  Inspect and pass upon all papers, documents, contracts and other instruments in which the City is a party or in which it may be interested; 
(4)  On the request of the City Council or the City Manager, furnish a written opinion upon any question of law pertaining to the City government or involving the powers and duties of any officer, board, employee or department of the City government; 
(5)  Attend meetings of the City Council; 
(6)  Conduct all prosecutions in the Municipal Court and appeals therefrom; 
(7)  Attend meetings of boards of the City when requested; 
(8)  Perform such other duties as the City Council or the City Manager may direct. 
(Code 1960, § 2-8; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Sec. 2-3-3. - Assistant and Deputy City Attorney. 
(a)  Appointment; term; duties generally. Subject to the City Manager's authority, the City Attorney may appoint such Assistant City Attorneys as may be authorized in the City budget. Such Assistant City Attorneys shall have the power and authority to perform all the acts and duties of the City Attorney within their assigned duties. One (1) Assistant City Attorney may be designated as the Deputy City Attorney who shall have and exercise the same authority as the City Attorney over any matter or duty coming before the City Attorney, when the City Attorney is unavailable, unwilling or unable to act for any reason. 
(b)  Compensation. The compensation of such Assistant City Attorneys shall be fixed by the City Council, subject to change at its discretion. 
(c)  Oath. Each Assistant City Attorney shall take and subscribe to the oath prescribed by the constitution and laws for members of the City Council. 
(Code 1960, § 2-6; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 7309, § 2, 1-17-2012; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Sec. 2-3-4. - Engaging other attorneys. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to abridge or in any way restrict the power of the City Manager, with the advice and consent of the City Council, to employ such other attorneys as he may see fit, to advise the City Council or the City Manager or represent the City in any action pending or prospective. 
(Ord. No. 5572, § 1(2-7), 3-4-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Sec. 2-3-5. - Releasing judgment liens. 
    The City Attorney or his assistant is hereby authorized to represent the City in releasing judgment liens taken for delinquent taxes which have been paid or on which a release would be in order. 
(Code 1960, § 2-9; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86) 
Sec. 2-3-6. - Administering oaths. 
    The City Attorney and his assistants shall have the power and authority to administer oaths and affirmations. 
(Code 1960, § 2-10; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86) 
CHAPTER 2-4. - RECORDS AND FINANCE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Records generally, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 181.001 et seq.; municipal finance, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 101.021 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-4-1. - Fiscal year. 
    There is hereby established as the fiscal year for the City the period of time commencing on October 1 of each year and ending with the close of business on September 30 of the next succeeding year. 
(Code 1960, § 2-11; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86) 
Sec. 2-4-2. - Annual budget. 
    The City Manager shall prepare and submit the annual budget of the City to the City Council. Public hearings shall be had thereon and such budget shall be considered, corrected and adopted by the City Council in all things as provided under the terms and provisions of the laws of this state. 
(Code 1960, § 2-12; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
State Law reference- Municipal budgets, V.T.C.A. Local Government Code § 102.001 et seq. 
Sec. 2-4-3. - Dues accruing to City payable in current money. 
(a)  Taxes levied to defray the current expenses of City government, and all licenses and occupation taxes levied, and all fines, forfeitures, penalties and other dues accruing to the City shall be payable in current money. 
(b)  A charge of thirty dollars ($30.00) will be assessed on all returned checks or drafts, dishonored money orders, dishonored credit card transactions, bank debits, and all other payments made through electronic means. 
(Code 1960, § 1-7; Ord. No. 5569, § 1, 2-25-86; Ord. No. 7188, § 21, 9-15-2009; Ord. No. 7363, § 5, 9-18-2012; Ord. No. 7688, § 4, 9-12-17) 
Editor's note- At the city's instruction, Ord. No. 7188, § 21, adopted Sept. 15, 2009 was placed as subsection (b) of Section 2-4-3. 
Sec. 2-4-4. - Immunity-Garnishment. 
    No funds of the City shall be subject to garnishment and the City shall never be required to answer in any garnishment proceedings. 
(Code 1960, § 1-9) 
State Law reference- Authority to so provide, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 101.023. 
Sec. 2-4-5. - Same-Execution. 
    No public property or any other character of property owned or held by the City shall be subject to any execution of any kind or nature. 
(Code 1960, § 1-10) 
Sec. 2-4-6. - Liability of city for damages upon prior notice of defective conditions in public ways. 
    It is hereby specially ordained and decreed that hereafter the City shall not be liable in damages to any person for any injury to persons or property caused by or arising from any obstruction, unevenness, depression, excavation, ditch or any other character of defect whatsoever in any Street, Alley, Sidewalk or other public places within the City, unless and until the City Manager or superintendent of the Streets of the City shall have actual notice of such obstruction, unevenness, depression, excavation, ditch or any other character of defect in the Streets, Alleys or other public places within the City for a period of forty-eight (48) hours next immediately preceding the date of the injury complained of. 
(Code 1960, § 1-11; Ord. No. 5569, § 1, 2-25-86) 
State Law reference- Texas Tort Claims Act, V.T.C.A., Civil Practice and Remedies Code § 101.001 et seq. 
Sec. 2-4-7. - Claims for injury, damage; written notice. 
    Any person who claims injury or damage to his person or property shall give notice in writing to the City Manager of such injury or damage within thirty (30) days from its inception. The written notice shall state when, where and how the damage occurred, the apparent extent of such injury, the amount of damage sustained, the location of the occurrence by Street and number, and the names and addresses of all witnesses upon whom the claimant expects to rely to establish the claim for such damage or injury. 
(Code 1960, § 1-12; Ord. No. 5569, § 1, 2-25-86) 
State Law reference- Texas Tort Claims Act, V.T.C.A., Civil Practice and Remedies Code § 101.001 et seq. 
Sec. 2-4-8. - Seal. 
    The seal of the City shall be circular in form and shall contain the words "City of Amarillo, Potter and Randall Counties, Texas" in the periphery of the seal with a five-point star in the center. 
(Code 1960, § 1-15; Ord. No. 5569, § 3, 2-25-86) 
Sec. 2-4-9. - Microfilming and records retention. 
(a)  The Municipal Office Services Department shall be responsible for the retention and microfilming of all public records except those in the charge of the City Secretary. The head of Municipal Office Services is responsible for designing and implementing a centralized microfilming program for all City departments. 
(b)  City records which are to be microfilmed shall be microfilmed in an accurate and permanent manner and in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  City department heads shall maintain indices to records under their supervision, which have been microphotographed. 
(2)  Microfilm shall meet the requirements of the United States of America Institute for archival quality, density, resolution and definition. 
(3)  Department heads or their appointees shall check and certify that each microfilm record is a true and correct duplication of the original public record. 
(4)  The public shall have access to information in such microphotographs, microfilm or other records to which they are entitled under the law. 
(c)  The head of Municipal Office Services shall ensure that the retention and disposal of City records is done in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  The records retention periods recommended by the Local Records Division of the Texas State Library in the Texas Municipal Records Manual are hereby adopted as the records retention periods for records of the City. 
(2)  The head of Municipal Office Services shall have the necessary authority to microphotograph, store, transfer, destroy or take other actions as necessary to protect, preserve and destroy the records according to the schedules hereby adopted. The head of Municipal Office Services is hereby directed to notify the Texas State Library as to the disposition of records under his control or the control of the City Secretary as may be required by law. 
(Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 5609, § 1, 7-8-86) 
State Law reference- Microfilming of municipal records, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §§ 181.001 et seq., 201.001 et seq. 
Sec. 2-4-10. - Time limits for responding to certain requests. 
(a)  Annual time limit. Pursuant to Texas Government Code §§ 552.275(a) and (b), thirty-six (36) hours is the reasonable limit on the amount of time that personnel of the City are required to spend producing public information for inspection or duplication by a requestor or providing copies of public information to a requestor in any given twelve-month period commencing on October 1 of each year, without recovering the City's costs attributable to that personnel time. 
(b)  Monthly time limit. Pursuant to Texas Government Code §§ 552.275(a) and (b), fifteen (15) hours is the reasonable limit on the amount of time that personnel of the City are required to spend producing public information for inspection or duplication by a requestor or providing copies of public information to a requestor in any given monthly period commencing on the 1st date of each month, without recovering the City's costs attributable to that personnel time. 
(c)  Records of time spent fulfilling requests. The City Secretary or his or her designee shall be responsible for maintaining records of the cumulative amount of personnel time spent complying with requests for public information from each individual requestor. 
(d)  Charges for personnel time spent in excess of time limits. Notwithstanding any provision of this section to the contrary, any requestor of public information will be charged personnel costs in accordance with Texas Government Code § 552.275 for all time in excess of thirty-six (36) hours in any given twelve-month period commencing on October 1 of each year or fifteen (15) hours in a given monthly period commencing on the 1st date of each month, spent by personnel of the City in producing public information for inspection or duplication by a requestor, or providing copies of public information to a requestor. The City Secretary shall be responsible for providing all notices to the requestor as required by law, including written statements of accrued time required by Texas Government Code § 552.275(d) and written estimates of charges required by Texas Government Code § 552.275(e). 
(e)  "Requestor" defined. For purposes of this section, "Requestor" shall have the meaning set forth in Texas Government Code § 552.003(6). 
(Ord. No. 7717, § 1, 3-6-18) 
Secs. 2-4-11-2-4-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFICERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Personnel administration, § 2-4-21 et seq. 

Sec. 2-4-21. - Offices created. 
    There is hereby created the following offices of the City: 
(1)  City Secretary; 
(2)  City Tax Assessor and Collector; 
(3)  City Auditor. 
(Code 1960, § 2-13; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86) 
Sec. 2-4-22. - Appointment; term. 
    The offices created in section 2-4-21 shall be filled by appointment by the City Manager, with the advice, consent and approval of the City Council. The appointees shall hold office at the will of the City Manager, subject to preemptory removal and discharge. 
(Code 1960, § 2-14; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Sec. 2-4-23. - Compensation. 
    The compensation of the officers appointed to fill the positions created in section 2-4-21 shall be by salary in a sum and amount to be fixed by the City Council subject to change from time to time at the direction of the City Council. 
(Code 1960, § 2-15; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Sec. 2-4-24. - Bond. 
    The appointees who fill the offices created in section 2-4-21 shall give a bond in some regularly accredited surety company, authorized to do business under the laws of the State. The bond shall be for the amount prescribed by the City Council, conditioned for the faithful discharge and performance by the appointee of his duties and for the faithful accounting of all moneys, credits and things of value coming into his hands. The premium for the bond shall be paid by the City. 
(Code 1960, § 2-16; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Sec. 2-4-25. - City Secretary-General duties. 
    The City Secretary shall do and perform any and all duties directed by the City Manager and such other duties as may properly pertain to his office or as may be prescribed by this Code and the laws of the State in addition to the duties specified in section 2-4-26. 
(Code 1960, § 2-17; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86) 
Sec. 2-4-26. - Same-Duties specified. 
    It shall be the duty of the City Secretary to: 
(1)  Meetings: Attend every meeting of the City Council. 
(2)  Minutes: Keep full and accurate minutes of the proceedings and transcribe same into a permanent minute book or electronic record. 
(3)  Ordinances: Enroll and engross all laws, resolutions and ordinances passed by the City Council in a permanent book or electronic record. 
(4)  Seal: Keep the corporate seal. 
(5)  Records: Take charge of and preserve all of the books, records, papers, documents and files of the City Council. 
(6)  Retention of public records by electronic storage and other technology: Copy or reproduce public records in an accurate and permanent manner and in accordance with the following provisions: 
a.  All ordinances, resolutions, contracts, deeds, easements and all other instruments filed with the City Secretary which pertain to real property, or otherwise created by a City department for official business, may be recorded in an electronic storage or record management system. All previous methods, mediums, and means that were employed to preserve records prior to the enactment of this ordinance (such as but not limited to paper files, books, microfilm, microfiche, and electronic record storage) are hereby ratified and approved. However, as determined by the City Secretary in consultation with the City Manager and Director of Information Technology, as technology develops and is acquired by the City, the storage or preservation of such prior records together with all current and future records may be stored in or transferred to the then-current approved technological methods, mediums, and means then available, so as to assure continued preservation of and convenient access to the records of the City by the most modern methods, mediums, and means that are reliable and available to the City, subject to subsection c. 
b.  The City Secretary shall maintain such indices and search capabilities as is necessary and convenient to locate records. 
c.  All methods, mediums, and means of record storage, preservation, and access shall meet the requirements of, and be in accordance with, State law as amended, or other duly approved certification or standard, as amended, that is applicable to storage of and access to municipal records. 
d.  The City Secretary or designee shall check and certify that each record is a true and correct duplication of the original public document. 
e.  The public shall have access to information to which they are entitled under law. Upon request, the City Secretary or designee shall provide a copy or print of information that is electronically stored, subject to then applicable charges, if any, for cost thereof. 
f.  Original public records which have been electronically stored and preserved as provided in this section may be destroyed in accordance with the applicable records retention law. 
(7)  Prepare notices: Prepare all notices required under resolution, regulation or ordinance of the City. 
(8)  Countersign and record: Countersign all warrants and keep an accurate account thereof. 
(9)  Contracts: Carefully keep and preserve all contracts made by the City Council in accordance with this section. 
(Code 1960, § 2-18; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 7380, § 1, 12-11-2012; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Sec. 2-4-27. - City Tax Assessor and Collector. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the City Tax Assessor and Collector to assess and collect City taxes in accordance with the provisions of this Code and laws of this State. 
(b)  In addition, he shall do and perform any and all duties directed by the City Manager and such other duties as may be prescribed by this Code and the laws of this State. 
(Code 1960, § 2-19; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86) 
Sec. 2-4-28. - City Auditor-General accounting duties. 
    The City Auditor shall be the general accountant of the corporation and shall: 
(1)  Account books: Keep accurate and regular accounts of the receipts and disbursements of the City, its grants and trusts, and shall enter, separately under proper heads, each cause of such receipt and disbursement. 
(2)  Individual accounts: Keep accounts with each person, including officers, who have money transactions with the City, crediting amounts allowed by proper authority, and specifying the particular transaction to which entries apply. 
(3)  Examination of accounts: Examine the books and records of the several offices and employees of the City. 
(4)  Warrants: Draw all warrants upon the City funds as authorized by the City Council. 
(5)  Deposits: Receive all sums of money paid to the City and daily deposit it to the proper account in the City depository. 
(6)  Receipts generally: Execute a proper receipt to every person paying money or delivering property to the accounts of the City. 
(7)  Accounting procedures: Generally maintain such accounting procedure and system as may be prescribed by the City Manager. 
(Code 1960, § 2-20; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Sec. 2-4-29. - Same-Accounting procedures; monthly itemized report; annual publication. 
    The City Auditor shall: 
(1)  Devise and maintain procedures: With the advice and assistance of the City Manager, the City Council, and such expert assistance as the City Council may see fit to provide, devise and maintain accounting procedures adequate to record in detail all transactions affecting the acquisition, custodianship and disposition of values, including cash receipts, credit transactions and disbursements. 
(2)  Monthly itemized reports: Cause to be created such monthly financial reports covering the period since the last reports and distinctly showing: 
a.  Receipts: Those amounts received on the City's account, specifying the source. 
b.  Disbursements; vouchers: Those sums paid out, specifying by what authority and accompanied by all vouchers on which money was paid out. 
c.  Public utilities: Separate summaries and schedules for each public utility owned and operated by the City. 
d.  Other details: Such other details as the City Council may direct. 
(3)  Weekly voucher list: Create list of disbursements weekly. 
(4)  Annual publication; financial statement: 
a.  Annual report shall be examined and approved by the City Council and City Manager and certified by the accountant employed by the City Council to conduct the annual audit. 
b.  Prepare and have published in some newspaper published in the City a sworn annual financial statement for each fiscal year ending September 30, showing the finances of the City for each fund of the City government including each public utility owned and operated by the City. 
(5)  Other duties: The City Auditor shall, in addition to the particular duties and powers set forth in this article, perform such duties and have such powers as may properly pertain to his office. 
(Code 1960, § 2-21; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Secs. 2-4-30-2-4-34. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PURCHASES, CONTRACTS, BIDDING; AND DISPOSAL OF SURPLUS OR OBSOLETE PROPERTY 

Sec. 2-4-35. - Contracts or transactions with debtors. 
(a)  In this section these words have the meaning indicated: 
1.  "Person" means and includes an individual, sole proprietorship, association, corporation, non-profit corporation, partnership (of any kind), joint venture, limited liability company, and any other business entity. 
2.  "Debt" means and includes, money owed, indebtedness, fee, fine, assessment, lien, judgment, or other legally enforceable obligation owed by a person to the City of Amarillo which is in arrears. 
(b)  For contracts or transactions subject to competitive bidding or proposals, pursuant to Chapter 252, Subchapter B, of the Texas Local Government Code or other applicable law, a person who owes a debt to the City as of the date that the bid or proposal is opened shall not be eligible to win the bid or be awarded a contract or have the transaction approved, even if the person presents the apparent low bid, successful proposal, or best offer, unless such person shall within three (3) business days satisfy the debt owed to the City. 
(c)  For all other contracts or transactions not subject to competitive bidding or proposals, the authorized City official or City Council may refuse to enter into a contract or approve a transaction with a person, based upon that person's indebtedness to the City. 
(d)  In deciding whether to enter into the contract or approve a transaction, the authorized official or City Council may consider the amount of the indebtedness, the age of the indebtedness, the number of debts or transactions for which the person owes, and any other circumstances surrounding the indebtedness or proposed transaction that the official or City Council deems material and relevant to the financial responsibility of the person. 
(Ord. No. 6706, §§ 1, 2, 1-20-2004; Ord. No. 7273, § 1, 3-29-2011; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Secs. 2-4-36-2-4-44. - Reserved. 
Sec. 2-4-45. - Disposition of Surplus or Obsolete Personal Property. 
(a)  Generally . The City Purchasing Agent or designee is authorized to dispose of municipal equipment, vehicles, and supplies which are obsolete, surplus, or otherwise no longer useful to the City, by way of: sale, exchange, trade-in, auction, reverse auction, or as otherwise provided in this section or by state law. 
(b)  Firearms . The City Purchasing Agent or designee shall, as to firearms that are in safe and operable condition, work with the City Attorney to cause either: (i) the transfer of such firearm for use by a City Department having a bona fide official use for such; (ii) destruction of such, pursuant to a court order; or, (iii) it to be transferred upon consignment to a federally licensed firearm dealer for the public sale of such firearms. 
(c)  Rubbish . The Purchasing Agent or designee may authorize the abandonment or destruction of obsolete or surplus City equipment, vehicle, or supply which has no remaining commercial value or, for which the estimated cost of continued care, handling, repair, maintenance or storage would exceed the estimated commercial value. 
(d)  Transfer . Upon a determination by the Purchasing Agent that the best interests of the public would be served, the Purchasing Agent or designee may transfer surplus equipment, vehicle, or supplies to another governmental unit; first responder organization; or a charitable, civic, or nonprofit organization, with the consent of the City Manager and upon terms acceptable to the City Attorney. Provided, however, where the estimated fair market value of an item to be so transferred exceeds fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), then the transfer may occur only after approval by the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 7783, § 1, 4-23-2019) 
Secs. 2-4-46-2-4-49. - Reserved.

ARTICLE II. - CIVIL SERVICE 

Sec. 2-5-21. - System adopted for classified employees. 
    There is hereby adopted a civil service system for classified employees of the City excluding firefighters and police officers which shall be governed by the Civil Service Commission as provided under Article VI of the Charter. 
(Code 1960, § 2-23; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86) 
Sec. 2-5-22. - System adopted for classified fire-fighters and classified police officers. 
    There is hereby adopted a civil service system for firefighters and police officers of the City which shall be governed by the Civil Service Commission as provided under V.T.C.A., Local Government Code Ch. 143 [§ 143.001 et seq.] (formerly V.A.C.S. art. 1269m as adopted by election on December 16, 1947). 
(Code 1960, § 2-24; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86) 
Sec. 2-5-23. - Types of service; unclassified and classified. 
    All civil service positions shall be separated into unclassified and classified service as defined by section 4 of Article VI of the Charter. 
(Code 1960, § 2-25; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86) 
Sec. 2-5-24. - Civil Service Commission-Created. 
    The Civil Service Commission is created, with membership, duties, powers and administrative provisions stated in Chapter 2-6 of this Code, and in accordance with authority established through the City Charter per the adoption of civil service by election of voters per V.A.C.S. article 1269m and its subsequent recodification as, Texas Local Government Code, chapter 143, and this article. 
(Code 1960, § 2-22; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 7520, § 1, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-5-25. - Same-Powers and duties. 
    The Civil Service Commission shall be vested with all the powers and duties empowered through the City Charter and, Texas Local Government Code Ch. 143 and Chapter 2-6 of this Code. 
(Code 1960, § 2-34; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 7520, § 1, 3-17-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7520, § 1, adopted March 17, 2015, repealed the former § 2-5-25 and renumbered the former § 2-5-28 as § 2-5-25 as herein setout. The former § 2-5-25 pertained to composition of the Civil Service Commission and derived from the Code of 1960, § 2-26; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, adopted March 4, 1986. The historical notation of the former § 2-5-28 has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Secs. 2-5-26-2-5-27. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7520, § 1, adopted March 17, 2015, repealed §§ 2-5-26, 2-5-27, which pertained to members of the Civil Service Commission and rules and regulations of the Civil Service Commission, respectively, and derived from the Code of 1960, § 2-27-2-32; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, adopted March 4, 1986. 
Sec. 2-5-28. - Same-Powers and duties. 
    The Civil Service Commission shall be vested with all the powers and duties empowered through Article VI of the Charter and V.T.C.A., Local Government Code Ch. 143 [§ 143.001 et seq.]. 
(Code 1960, § 2-34; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86) 
Sec. 2-5-29. - Removal, suspension of employees. 
    The rules and regulations as set forth by the Civil Service Commission shall prescribe the grounds for demotion, removal or suspension of City employees. 
(Code 1960, § 2-33; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86) 
Sec. 2-5-30. - Director of Civil Service. 
    The Director of Personnel for the City shall serve as the Director of Civil Service subject to approval of the Civil Service Commission. The Director of Civil Service shall administer the civil service merit systems in accordance with Article VI of the Charter and V.T.C.A., Local Government Code Ch. 143 [§ 143.001 et seq.]. 
(Code 1960, § 2-35; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86) 
State Law reference- Civil service director, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 143.012. 
Sec. 2-5-31. - Investigations and inspections. 
    The Civil Service Commission may make investigations concerning, and report upon, all matters touching the enforcement and effect of the provisions of Article VI of the Charter and V.T.C.A., Local Government Code Ch. 143 [§ 143.001 et seq.], and the rules and regulations prescribed hereunder; shall inspect all institutions, departments, offices, places, positions and employment affected by Article VI of the Charter and V.T.C.A., Local Government Code Ch. 143 [§ 143.001 et seq.]. Such investigations may be made by the Civil Service Commission or by any commissioner designated by the Civil Service Commission for that purpose. 
(Code 1960, § 2-36; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 143.009. 
Sec. 2-5-32. - Oaths; subpoenas. 
    In the course of investigations, the Civil Service Commission or the designated commissioner shall have the power to administer oaths, issue subpoenas requiring the attendance of witnesses and the production of books, papers, documents and accounts pertaining to the investigation, and cause the deposition of witnesses residing within or without the State to be taken in the manner prescribed by the law for like depositions in civil actions in the courts of original and unlimited jurisdiction in civil suits of the United States. The oaths administered hereunder and the subpoenas issued hereunder shall have the same force and effect as the oaths administered by a magistrate in his judicial capacity, and the failure on the part of any person so subpoenaed to comply with the provisions of this section shall be deemed a violation of this section subject to the penalty afforded under law. 
(Code 1960, § 2-37; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 143.009. 
Sec. 2-5-33. - Merit system investigation. 
    The Civil Service Commission may, at its discretion, investigate all positions within the classified service to ensure that employees are appointed to those classifications in conformance with merit system standards and are performing the appropriate duties and responsibilities as designated within job descriptions which have been reviewed and approved by the Director of Civil Service. 
(Code 1960, § 2-38; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86) 
State Law reference- Investigations, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 143.009 et seq. 
Sec. 2-5-34. - Active political participation by employees. 
    City employees shall not take an active part in any political campaign of any person for an elective position. The term "active part" includes making political speeches, passing out cards or other political literature, writing letters, signing petitions, actively and openly soliciting votes, and the making of public derogatory remarks about candidates for such elective positions. Any willful violation of this section shall be sufficient grounds to authorize the discharge of any employee in the classified service. Where the application of this section for firefighters and police officers is found in any part to be in conflict with V.T.C.A. Local Government Code Ch. 143 [§ 143.001 et seq.], applicable provisions of state law prohibiting political participation for firefighters and police officers shall prevail and have precedence over this section. 
(Code 1960, § 2-39; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86) 
State Law reference- Political activities, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 143.086. 
Sec. 2-5-35. - Engaging in strikes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any employee of the classified service of the City to engage in a strike against the City. Any employee who has been found by the Civil Service Commission to be guilty of a violation of the provisions of this section shall be discharged from the classified service. 
(Code 1960, § 2-40; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86) 
State Law reference- Strikes, V.A.C.S. art. 5154c, § 3; V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, § 143.087. 
Secs. 2-5-36-2-5-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SOCIAL SECURITY AND RETIREMENT 

Sec. 2-5-51. - Social security. 
(a)  Commission authorized to act. The City Council acting for and on behalf of the City shall enter into all necessary agreements with the Employees Retirement System of Texas for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of V.A.C.S. art. 695g and Public Law 734, Eighty-first Congress, Ch. 809, 2d, H.R. 6000. 
(b)  City Manager appointed agent. The City Manager is hereby appointed as agent of the City Council and of the City to execute all necessary agreements and instruments for and in behalf of the City Council and the City. 
(c)  City Auditor; accounts and reports. The City Auditor is hereby directed to be the person responsible for making assessments, collections, payments and reports, as required by the Employee Retirement System of Texas. 
(d)  Allocation and designation of fund. A sufficient sum of money shall be allocated and set aside from available funds for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of the acts cited in subsection (a). Such money so allocated and set aside shall be known as the City of Amarillo Social Security Fund, which fund shall be set aside and maintained in the regular City depository. 
(e)  Effective date. This section was made effective as of the opening of business June 1, 1957. 
(Code 1960, §§ 2-44-2-48; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Sec. 2-5-52. - Municipal retirement system. 
(a)  City elects to participate; fire department excepted. The City Council hereby exercises its option and elects to have the City and all of the employees of all departments, except the fire department, participate in the Texas Municipal Retirement System. Elective benefits and obligations of such system may hereafter be approved by the City Council. 
(b)  Employees included. Each person who becomes a full-time permanent employee of any participating department on or after the effective date of participation of such department shall be included within and subject to the provisions of the Texas Municipal Retirement System beginning upon the date such person becomes an employee. Temporary or part-time employees shall not be included. 
(Code 1960, §§ 2-41, 2-42; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
State Law reference- Texas Municipal Retirement System, V.A.C.S. Tit. 110B, § 61.001 et seq. 
Sec. 2-5-53. - Fire department retirement. 
    All employees of the fire department are participants of the Firemen's Relief and Retirement Fund of Amarillo. Benefits and obligations are as specified in the Firemen's Relief and Retirement Law of the State of Texas. 
(Code 1960, § 2-43; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, 3-4-86) 
State Law reference- Firemen's relief and retirement fund, V.A.C.S. art. 6243e.

No. 6182, § 1, 9-5-1995; Ord. No. 6207, § 1, 12-12-1995; Ord. No. 6489, § 1, 6-27-2000; Ord. No. 6590, § 1, 4-16-2002; Ord. No. 6939, § 1, 5-23-2006; Ord. No. 7019, § 1, 1-30-2007; Ord. Cross reference- Minutes of boards and commission, § 2-2-4; zoning board of adjustment, § 4-10-36; public health board, § 8-5-3. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-6-1. - Scope; definitions; purpose and roles. 
(a)  Scope. The provisions of this Article I shall apply to and be effective as to all boards, unless otherwise stated in the article or section for a particular board. 
(b)  Definitions. In this Chapter, the term "board" shall refer to and include every kind of appointed body, whether such is called a board, commission, or committee. Every board is advisory in nature, unless state law prescribes quasi-judicial or final decision authority to a board. 
(c)  Purpose and roles. It shall be the purpose and role of every board to research and advise the City Council on matters assigned to a board by this Chapter or referred to the board by the City Council. Corporate and statutory boards shall discharge their roles as assigned by law and provided in this Chapter. No board has authority to bind the City to any contract, agreement, or expenditure. Except for the Civil Service Commission, no board shall have authority or seek to investigate, reprimand, or censure any City employee, but shall refer any personnel-related concern to the City Manager. A board to which state law ascribes quasi-judicial or final decision-making authority shall discharge such authority as required by law and is not advisory when exercising such statutory authority, as distinguished from any other advisory role assigned to it by this Chapter. 
(d)  The City Council may appoint ad hoc boards as desired. Such are governed by and sunset according to the resolution creating them, and are not listed in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 1, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-2. - Appointments; compensation. 
(a)  Appointments. Appointments to the boards authorized in this chapter shall be made by the City Council unless otherwise provided. In the event of a vacancy, the City Council shall appoint a member to serve the unexpired term. A member shall serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies for office. Subject to state open meetings law, the discussion or evaluation of potential appointees to a board having, in whole or in part, final decision-making or quasi-judicial authority, may occur in a closed session. 
(b)  Compensation. Members of City boards shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 1, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-3. - Qualifications. 
    Members of City boards shall be, and continue to be during the period of board service: a registered voters-of the City, and shall not be indebted to the City contrary to the provisions of section 4 of Article V of the Charter. The City Manager is hereby directed to inform the City Council whether or not a prospective appointee to or currently serving member of a board is or becomes indebted to the City. Board members shall also possess such expertise as the Council may require by this Chapter for service on a particular board or as desired by the Council. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 1, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-4. - Quorum; rules; motions; voting; training. 
(a)  A majority of the members of a City board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. A majority vote of the members present shall constitute approval of motions made in the conduct of all business unless another percentage is required by law. 
(b)  Each City board may adopt such reasonable rules and procedures as it deems necessary to govern its action, provided such rules are not inconsistent with this Code, State or federal law. 
(c)  To the greatest extent feasible, motions should be worded in the affirmative not the negative. Making a motion or second does not obligate a member to vote for the motion, but such is a formality to place it before the body for deliberation and action. 
(d)  Each member of a board is entitled to vote, unless the member must abstain due to a conflict of interest, or is an alternate member and a full slate of regular members is present for the meeting. All decisions shall be made by simple majority favorable vote, unless a higher percentage vote is required by ordinance or state law. 
(e)  Each member shall complete orientation conducted by staff liaison for new members and, within ninety (90) days of appointment complete the training on Texas Open Meetings Act as provided by the Attorney General's Office, Texas Municipal League, or other certified trainer per the Open Meetings Act as amended. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 1, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-5. - Conduct of members. 
    Board members shall: 
(a)  Endeavor to be impartial, fair, open-minded and willing to listen to all points of view in the course of developing recommendations or making decisions. 
(b)  Treat other members, the public, and staff with respect without prejudice based on race, gender, national origin, religion, disability, sexual orientation, or other unlawful basis. 
(c)  Be honest in dealings with each other, the public and staff. 
(d)  Avoid actual conflicts of interest and the appearance of impropriety in approaching business of the board that potentially or actually affects the personal, business, or familial interests of the member. Members shall consult with the City Attorney's Office for assistance in analyzing conflicts of interest or other ethical questions. 
(e)  Be regular in attendance at all meetings and hearings of the board. Each member shall attend seventy-five (75) percent of the regularly scheduled meetings of a board or may be subject to replacement. 
(f)  During a meeting, each member is responsible for promoting proper decorum. Members are encouraged to limit non-emergency interruptions and use of electronic devices, such as checking email, text messaging, non-emergency calls, etc. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 1, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-6. - Terms. 
(a)  Members of City boards and commissions shall serve staggered terms of three (3) years, unless otherwise provided by law, with terms being staggered among the number of members as roughly equally as possible. 
(b)  Appointments to all City boards and commissions whose membership is appointed by the City Council, Mayor or City Manager shall be made in November of each year, with terms of service to commence upon qualification of the member, unless otherwise provided in other law governing a particular board or commission. 
(c)  Appointments to fill vacancies may be made at any time, and will be for the unexpired term. 
(d)  To accommodate a transition to staggered terms, length of terms, dates of appointment and effective dates of service, members serving at the time this section becomes effective may have their terms of office extended or shortened. 
(e)  Insofar as allowed by law, this section shall repeal previous ordinances and resolutions in conflict herewith. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 1, 3-17-15; Ord. No. 7691A, § 1, 12-5-17) 
Sec. 2-6-7. - Organization. 
    Each City board shall annually elect a chairman and vice-chairman from among its members, unless such appointment is reserved by this Chapter to the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 1, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-8. - Liaison; ex-officio members; secretary; records of meetings. 
(a)  The City Manager or designee shall assign appropriate staff the responsibilities of staff liaison and ex-officio member of each board. This staff person or designee shall serve as secretary to the board. 
(b)  Minutes of each meeting of a City board shall be made, and include attendance in tabular form. A copy of all approved Minutes shall be forwarded to the City Secretary. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 1, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-9. - Agendas. 
    The agenda and notice of same shall be prepared by or at the direction of the staff liaison in cooperation with the board chair. A quorum of members shall not deliberate agenda preparation outside of a duly noticed meeting and agenda item for that purpose. However, when staff liaison is contacted by a number of members that equals the number that is one less than a majority of the board (or a greater number of members), with each requesting the same topic be placed on the agenda, then the staff liaison shall place such topic on the next available agenda consistent with the state open meetings law. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 1, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-10. - Frequency of meetings; places. 
(a)  Each board shall meet as frequently as is necessary in order to timely and properly discharge the business coming before the board. If a board has no business necessitating a meeting during a year, then it shall conduct an annual meeting in October of such year in order to verify membership, review by-laws, elect officers, any other administrative matter, and any routine business of the board. 
(b)  When possible, every board shall establish a regular meeting place in some public building owned by the City. Every regular, special called meeting or work session shall comply with the provisions of the Texas Open Meetings Act. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 1, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-11. - Removal without cause; forfeiture of position for cause. 
(a)  Members are appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the City Council and may be removed at any time with or without cause unless this Code of Ordinances or state law mandate otherwise for a particular board. Subject to state open meetings law, the discussion or evaluation of board member performance or replacement of a member may occur in a closed session. 
(b)  Any member of a board who becomes disqualified for board service during a term per the requirements of section 2-6-3 or does not comply with sections 2-6-4(e), 2-6-5, or other applicable provisions of this chapter, shall immediately forfeit the board appointment upon the finding of such disqualification or noncompliance by the City Council. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 1, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-12. - Legal counsel and other staff support. 
    City boards are a component unit of and advisory to the municipal government, therefore boards shall be provided appropriate legal advice and consultation as needed by the City Attorney's Office. The staff liaison for each board shall assure that other City departments shall promptly provide to City boards such professional and technical expertise and consultation as is appropriate and needed by a board to perform its business. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 1, 3-17-15) 
Secs. 2-6-13-2-6-25. - Reserved.
