ARTICLE V. - TRAFFIC ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-6-50. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a Traffic Advisory Board for the City. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 5, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-51. - Members. 
    This Board shall consist of seven (7) members. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 5, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-52. - Powers and duties. 
    This Board shall have the following powers and duties: 
(a)  All provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(b)  To review studies and make recommendations concerning: 
(1)  School safety, including bicycle and pedestrian safety; 
(2)  Education and publicity, including coordination of activities to promote traffic safety; 
(3)  Request and review traffic engineering studies, including speed studies, parking regulations, one-way or two-way streets, traffic-control devices and similar studies; 
(4)  To make recommendations to the Mayor and City Council for ways and means of improving traffic conditions. 
(c)  Upon request of the Traffic Engineer, City Council, or as required by law, to conduct public hearings. 
(d)  From time to time, members of the City Council may appoint a member of this board to serve as the citizen advisory committee for purposes of the Photographic Signal Traffic Enforcement System, per Texas Transportation Code Chapter 707 as amended or successor statute. 
(e)  Other powers, duties, exceptions, privileges, and immunities accorded by applicable law and any assignments or delegations by the City to this board. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 5, 3-17-15) 
Secs. 2-6-53-2-6-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - LIBRARY BOARD 

Sec. 2-6-56. - Created. 
    There is hereby created an Amarillo Library Board. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 6, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-57. - Members. 
    This Board shall consist of five (5) members. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 6, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-58. - Powers and duties. 
    This Board shall have the following powers and duties: 
(a)  All provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(b)  The Amarillo Library Board shall make general recommendations to the Mayor and City Council concerning the policies, programs and development of the public library. 
(c)  Other powers, duties, exceptions, privileges, and immunities accorded by applicable law and any assignments or delegations by the City to this board. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 6, 3-17-15) 
Secs. 2-6-59-2-6-61. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-6-62. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a Planning and Zoning Commission for the City. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 7, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-63. - Members. 
    The Planning and Zoning Commission shall consist of seven (7) members. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 7, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-64. - Powers and duties. 
    This Board The Planning and Zoning Commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(a)  All provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(b)  Act in accordance with the provisions of Texas Local Government Code Chapters 42, 43, 211, 212, 371, and all other applicable laws, as amended; 
(c)  Make an annual report to the City Council concerning the preceding year's activities and recommendations for future projects; 
(d)  Perform special studies and make recommendations on issues and recommend a comprehensive plan for the physical development of the City which may be related to the comprehensive planning process of the City; 
(e)  Review and approve Subdivision Plats and the dedication and vacation of Streets, Alleys, Easements and other public facilities associated with Plats; 
(f)  Prepare and recommend a Zoning Map and exercise authorities and powers granted by the state zoning enabling act; 
(g)  Make recommendations for public improvements; 
(h)  Make recommendations through the City Council to any public authorities, corporations or individuals in the City or in the extraterritorial jurisdiction concerning the relocation of building structures or works to be erected or constructed by them; 
(i)  Prepare studies and make recommendations on annexations. 
(j)  Other powers, duties, exceptions, privileges, and immunities accorded by applicable law and any assignments or delegations by the City to this board. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 7, 3-17-15) 
Secs. 2-6-65-2-6-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - CONSTRUCTION ADVISORY AND APPEALS COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7693, § 1, adopted Sept. 19, 2017, amended Art. VIII in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. VIII, §§ 2-6-70-2-6-74, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 7519, § 8, 3-17-15. 

Sec. 2-6-70. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a Construction Advisory and Appeals Commission for the City. 
(Ord. No. 7693, § 1, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 2-6-71. - Members. 
    This Commission shall consist of nine (9) voting members selected as follows: 
(a)  One (1) registered architect. 
(b)  One (1) registered professional engineer with experience in structural design, electrical engineering, or the design of plumbing or HVAC systems for buildings. 
(c)  One (1) building contractor with experience in commercial or industrial building construction. 
(d)  One (1) building contractor with experience in housing construction. 
(e)  One (1) electrical contractor who is licensed by the City as a Master Electrician who has experience in electrical contracting in building construction. 
(f)  One (1) heating and air conditioning contractor who is licensed by the State as an Air Conditioning Contractor. 
(g)  One (1) plumbing contractor who is licensed by the State as a Master Plumber and who has experience in plumbing contracting in building construction. 
(h)  One (1) insurance fire and casualty recording agent. 
(i)  One (1) citizen who has no direct financial interest in the building construction industry; real estate development, sales, or management; or a utility company, except as he or she may have as an owner or occupant of a dwelling. 
(Ord. No. 7693, § 1, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 2-6-72. - Powers and duties. 
    This Commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(a)  All provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(b)  Hear appeals of decisions of the Building Official concerning the Building, Electrical, Mechanical and Plumbing Codes adopted by the City; determine the suitability of alternate materials and alternate types of construction; establish licensing regulations; and interpret and recommend changes in the requirements of the Building, Electrical, Mechanical and Plumbing Codes adopted by the City; Condemnation hearings related to substandard or dangerous structures pursuant to Section 4-3-3 of the Code. 
(1)  The Condemnation Appeals Commission will be directly appointed by the City Council from the Commission members for the purpose of hearing cases related to substandard or dangerous structures and shall be composed of five (5) members that shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years. 
(2)  The City Council may remove a Condemnation Appeals Commission member appointed upon written charge and only after a public hearing on the matter if a hearing is requested by the commission member subject to the removal action. 
(3)  The City Council may provide for the appointment of additional alternate members of the Condemnation Appeal Commission from the members of the Construction Advisory and Appeals Commission. 
(c)  Hear appeals of decisions by the Fire Marshal; determine the suitability of alternate materials and alternate types of construction; and interpret and recommend changes in the requirements of the Uniform Fire Code as adopted by the City Council. 
(d)  Develop recommendations to the City Council for amendments of the Building, Electrical, Mechanical, Plumbing, and Codes adopted by the City, the Construction Advisory and Appeals Commission. The Commission may create subcommittees to review and make recommendations to the Commission for proposed amendments of those chapters or for the adoption of later editions of the codes adopted in those chapters. The Commission shall specify the task assigned to and the term of each subcommittee, and shall disband each subcommittee once the subcommittee's task is completed. 
(1)  Each subcommittee shall consist of five (5) members, one (1) of which shall be a member of the Construction Advisory and Appeals Commission who shall act as chairman of the subcommittee and who shall report the findings of the subcommittee to the Commission. The remaining four (4) members may be chosen from the Commission, or may be chosen from the general public on the basis of their specialized knowledge or experience in a trade related to the chapter or topic under consideration, or a combination. The staff liaison or designee shall serve as an ex officio member and secretary to each subcommittee. 
(2)  Members of the general public appointed to serve on subcommittees shall be subject to all of the requirements of this Chapter and the State as though they were members of the Commission. 
(e)  Other powers, duties, exceptions, privileges, and immunities accorded by applicable law and any assignments or delegations by the City to the Commission. 
(Ord. No. 7693, § 1, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 2-6-73. - Requests for Commission consideration. 
    Except for appeals related to substandard or dangerous structures, any person who desires to schedule any item before the Construction Advisory and Appeals Commission shall submit a written request to the staff liaison. Appeals of decisions of the Building Official or Fire Marshal shall also include a fifty-dollar ($50.00) application fee. Such written request shall include justification for the action requested of the Board. Appeals related to substandard or dangerous structures shall be held in accordance with Chapter 4-3 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 7693, § 1, 9-19-17) 
Sec. 2-6-74. - Appeals from the Construction Advisory and Appeals Commission. 
    Unless provided otherwise in the Code, any person who is dissatisfied with a decision of the Construction Advisory and Appeals Board may appeal to the City Council within ten (10) days from the date of notification of the Commission's ruling by filing a written request with the City Secretary that the appeal be heard by the City Council. Upon appeal the staff liaison shall transmit to the City Council all papers constituting the record of the appealed action. The City Secretary shall thereupon fix a time for a hearing before the City Council and shall notify those known to be interested. The decision of the City Council concerning the appeal shall be final. Appeals from the decision of the Condemnation Appeals Commission shall be appealed in accordance with Section 4-3-3(i) of the Amarillo Municipal Code as amended. 
(Ord. No. 7693, § 1, 9-19-17) 
Secs. 2-6-75-2-6-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - BOARD OF REVIEW FOR LANDMARKS, HISTORIC DISTRICTS, AND DOWNTOWN DESIGN[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7769, § 1, adopted Feb. 5, 2019, repealed the former Art. IX, §§ 2-6-80-2-6-83, and enacted a new Art. IX as set out herein. The former Art. IX pertained to Downtown Design Urban Review Board and derived from Ord. No. 7519, § 9, 3-17-15. 

Sec. 2-6-80. - Created. 
    There is hereby created the Board of Review for Landmarks, Historic Districts, and Downtown Design (the "Board" in this Article). 
(Ord. No. 7769, § 1, 2-5-2019) 
Sec. 2-6-81. - Members. 
(a)  Number and Quorum . The Board will consist of seven (7) members and one (1) alternate, and a quorum of the Board shall be four (4) members. 
(b)  Qualifications . This Board membership must reflect a diversity of interests and knowledge pertinent to the redevelopment of downtown and historic preservation city-wide. Accordingly, each regular member and alternate must be a member of one (1) of these categories in order to serve: 
(1)  Registered architect with a minimum of ten (10) years' experience; 
(2)  Building contractor with a minimum of ten (10) years' experience in housing construction; 
(3)  Land use or planning professional; 
(4)  Downtown business owner or manager; 
(5)  Downtown resident; 
(6)  Licensed real estate broker; 
(7)  Representative of the banking or savings and loan industry; 
(8)  Owner or resident of a historic property; 
(9)  History teacher or professor; or 
(10)  Historian or preservation consultant. 
It is not the intent of this section that each or all of these professions or interests must be seated at all times on the Board, but an approximate balance of interests shall be sought in appointments. 
(c)  Alternates . The alternate member shall serve when a voting Board member is unable or unwilling to attend or participate. 
(d)  Historic Preservation Officer . The Board may appoint a non-voting, ex officio member to serve as Historic Preservation Officer. The duties of the Historic Preservation Officer are: 
(1)  Develop policies and procedures to implement the City's adopted historic preservation ordinance and related ordinances. 
(2)  Review Certificate of Appropriateness applications for completeness, perform administrative reviews where applicable, and submit recommendations to the Board. 
(3)  Create community outreach programs to support the City's historic preservation program. 
(4)  Review and help coordinate the city's preservation and urban design activities with those of local, state, and federal agencies and with local, state, and national preservation organizations in the private sector. 
(Ord. No. 7769, § 1, 2-5-2019) 
Sec. 2-6-82. - Power and duties. 
(a)  The Board will have the following powers and duties with regard to downtown design review: 
(1)  All powers and duties contained in Article I of this Chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(2)  Interpret and enforce the Downtown Urban Design Standards for new construction and major renovations by hearing and deciding applications for a certificate of appropriateness in accordance with Title IV, Chapter 4-10, Article IV, Division 3 of this Code of Ordinances; 
(3)  Hear items referred to the Board by City staff concerning the Downtown Urban Design Standards; 
(4)  Propose to the City Council amendments to the Downtown Urban Design Standards; 
(5)  Grant variances under the Downtown Urban Design Standards adopted pursuant to Title IV, Chapter 4-10, Article IV, Division 3 of this Code, and in accordance with section 2-6-83 below, when such will not be contrary to the public interest where, owing to special conditions, a literal enforcement of the Downtown Urban Design Standards will result in unnecessary hardship, and so that the spirit of such Standards shall be observed and substantial justice done. 
(6)  Other powers, duties, exceptions, privileges, and immunities accorded by the applicable law and any assignments or delegations by the City Council to this Board. 
(b)  The Board will have the following powers and duties with regard to review of landmarks and historic districts: 
(1)  All powers and duties contained in Article I of this Chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(2)  Hold hearings to review applications for reconstruction, alteration, relocation, new construction, or demolition affecting proposed or designated landmarks, objects, sites, and structures within historic districts, and to determine whether a certificate of appropriateness should be issued for such actions based on guidelines developed by the Board; 
(3)  Recommend specific design guidelines for the restoration, rehabilitation, alteration, construction, reconstruction, or relocation of objects, sites, and structures within historic districts and landmarks; 
(4)  Recommend guidelines for signage, street furniture, appurtenances, advertising devices, and landscaping for each landmark and historic district; 
(5)  Conduct surveys to identify and catalog districts, objects, sites, and structures displaying significant historic, architectural, archaeological, or cultural value; 
(6)  Recommend incentives and tax abatement programs for landmarks and historic districts; 
(7)  Make recommendations concerning the utilization of state, federal, municipal, or private funds to promote the preservation and restoration of landmarks and historic districts; 
(8)  Recommend the acquisition of landmark structures by the City where preservation is essential and where private preservation is not feasible; 
(9)  Testify before all boards and commissions on any matter affecting historically, culturally, or archaeologically exceptional or significant objects, sites, structures, or historic districts; 
(10)  Inform and educate the citizens concerning distinctive and important elements of the City's and State's historical, cultural, architectural, archaeological, social, economic, ethnic, and political history; 
(11)  Recognize the owners of landmarks, objects, sites, or structures within historic districts by means of certificates, plaques, or markers; 
(12)  Recommend to the Planning and Zoning Commission any ordinance amendments appropriate for the preservation, restoration, and protection of landmarks, objects, sites, and structures within historic districts; 
(13)  Create committees of no more than three (3) persons from among its membership to meet at times other than regular Board meetings, to consider specified categories of applications and to make recommendations to the full Board for ratification; 
(14)  Prepare and submit to the Planning and Zoning Commission and the City Council a report summarizing the work of the Board during the previous calendar year; 
(15)  Based on a finding of available time of the Planning Department staff and of funds set aside for the specific purpose, recommend special studies or projects to further the purposes of subsection (b)(i); 
(16)  Other powers, duties, exceptions, privileges, and immunities accorded by applicable law, City ordinance, and any assignments or delegations by the City Council to this Board. 
(Ord. No. 7769, § 1, 2-5-2019) 
Sec. 2-6-83. - Variances. 
(a)  In authorizing a variance under Section 2-6-82(a)(v) above, the Board must find and show in its minutes such facts or special conditions by which each of the following conditions has been satisfied: 
(1)  Special circumstances exist on the property on which the application is made relating to its size, area, topography, location, or surrounding conditions that do not apply generally to the other property in the same area and the Downtown Urban Design District; and 
(2)  A variance, if granted, will be of no material detriment to the public safety or welfare or injury to the use, enjoyment, or value of the property in the vicinity. 
(b)  In exercising such authority, the Board may not grant a variance where the variance would operate to relieve the applicant of a condition or circumstance: 
(1)  That is not inherent in the property itself, but rather is the result of the use or development of the property; 
(2)  That was otherwise self-imposed by the present or a previous owner; or 
(3)  That is founded solely upon the opportunity to make the property more profitable or to reduce expense to owner. 
(Ord. No. 7769, § 1, 2-5-2019) 
Sec. 2-6-84. - Decisions; Effect of Decisions; Requests for Board Consideration. 
(a)  A majority affirmative vote by Board members participating in the decision shall be required to take any authorized action. 
(b)  Unless appealed, the determinations of the Board on all certificate of appropriateness applications are final. Actions taken or recommendations made by the Board that are subject to review by the Planning and Zoning Commission or the City Council are not binding on those bodies, and the reviewing body or bodies may decide a matter contrary to the recommendations or actions of the Board. 
(c)  Any person who desires to schedule any item applicable under this Article before the Board may provide appropriate written requests to the planning director. 
(Ord. No. 7769, § 1, 2-5-2019) 
ARTICLE X. - CONVENTION AND VISITORS COUNCIL 

Sec. 2-6-85. - Created. 
    The Convention and Visitors Council is hereby created. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 10, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-86 - Members. 
    This board shall consist of seventeen (17) members serving staggered two (2) year terms: 
(a)  The City Council shall appoint to the board one (1) City Council member; and five (5) members as follows: one (1) interested citizen and four (4) citizens representing the lodging Industry, restaurant Industry, and area attractions; and 
(b)  The Chamber of Commerce shall appoint to the board five (5) members as follows: one (1) to serve as the chair of this board; one (1) from the Chamber's executive committee; and three (3) other members. 
(c)  The four (4) committee chairs of the Convention and Visitors Council shall each serve as a board member. 
(d)  The Amarillo Civic Center manager and the executive director of Center City of Amarillo, Inc. shall each serve as a member of the board. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 10, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-87. - Duties and powers. 
    This board shall have and exercise the following duties and powers: 
(a)  As to City appointed members, all provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(b)  Promote Amarillo to convention and tourism groups, and visitors. 
(c)  Recommend programming to the Chamber of Commerce board of directors and the City Council. 
(d)  Other powers, duties, exceptions, privileges, and immunities accorded by applicable law and any agreements between the Chamber of Commerce and City pertaining to the board and its mission, administration, funding, and related matters. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 10, 3-17-15) 
Secs. 2-6-88-2-6-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-6-90. - Created. 
    Pursuant to the approval of voters in accordance with state law in or about 1947, the City Charter, and chapter 143, Texas Local Government Code, There is hereby created the Civil Service Commission. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 11, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-91. - Members; appointment; qualifications; removal. 
(a)  In accordance with section 143.006, Texas Local Government Code, the commission consists of three (3) members appointed by the City's chief executive officer, the City Manager. Each member must be of good moral character; a citizen of the United States; a resident of the City for more than three (3) years; be over the age of twenty-five (25) years; not have held a public office within the preceding three (3) years; sympathetic to the principles of the merit system, and who meet the qualifications of sec. 2-6-3 of this Chapter. 
(b)  The members serve staggered three (3) year terms. 
(c)  In accordance with Chapter 143, a commission member may be reappointed to consecutive terms; however, an appointment of a member to a fourth or more consecutive term shall be confirmed by a two-thirds vote of the City Council. Appointees are exempt from the term limit provision of Sec. 2-6-6. 
(d)  The City Council may remove a member in accordance with section 143.007. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 11, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-92. - Duties and powers. 
    The Commission shall have and exercise the following duties and powers: 
(a)  All provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(b)  Each January the members shall select a chairman and vice chairman. 
(c)  To administer and enforce both the statutory fire and police civil service and, the civilian civil service of the City of Amarillo. 
(d)  Such rules and regulations for the conduct of business as it shall find necessary and expedient. 
(e)  No rules or regulations shall ever be adopted which will permit the appointment or employment of any person incompetent to discharge the duties of such employment. 
(f)  All other duties, powers, rights, privileges, exemptions, immunities, granted by chapter 143, Texas Local Government Code; the Amarillo City Charter; and, Chapter 2-5, Article II of this Code of Ordinances, and other applicable law, each as amended. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 11, 3-17-15) 
Secs. 2-6-93-2-6-94. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT ADVISORY COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-6-95. - Created. 
    There is hereby created the Community Development Advisory Committee. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 12, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-96. - Members; qualifications. 
    This committee shall consist of 11 members meeting the requirements of Section 2-6-3. Moreover, the membership shall consist of two (2) members from each of the four (4) geographic areas of the city, plus two (2) members at-large, and a Chairperson also selected at-large. The area that members represent must consist of fifty-one (51) percent or more low to moderate income households. Appointments to this board are exempt from the term limit stated in Sec. 2-6-6. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 12, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-97. - Duties and powers. 
    This committee shall have and exercise these powers and duties: 
(a)  All provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(b)  Receive and review funding requests from local non-profit and governmental organizations for allocations from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development federal programs and Texas Department of Housing and Community Affairs. 
(c)  Conduct public meetings and hearings as needed. 
(d)  Coordinates citizen participation in the development of the CDBG, HOME and ESG programs. 
(e)  Annually recommend to the City Council an allocation/reallocation of available the Community Development Block Grant program, HOME Investment Partnership program, and state of Texas funding for the Emergency Solutions Grant program. 
(f)  Other powers, duties, exceptions, privileges, and immunities accorded by applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 12, 3-17-15) 
Secs. 2-6-98-2-6-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - ADVISORY COMMITTEE FOR PEOPLE WITH DISABILITIES 

Sec. 2-6-100. - Created. 
    There is hereby created the Advisory Committee for People with Disabilities. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 13, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-101. - Members. 
    This Committee shall consist of five (5) members. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 13, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-102. - Powers and duties. 
    This Committee shall have and exercise these duties and powers: 
(a)  All provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(b)  Compile statistical data relating to people with disabilities in Amarillo. 
(c)  Promote the elimination of architectural and mechanical barriers to people with disabilities in public and private accommodations and transportation. 
(d)  Review State and Federal legislation relating to people with disabilities. 
(e)  Advise the City Council of its studies and recommendations. Such studies shall contain a fiscal note advising the City Council of the anticipated costs and impact upon the public and private sectors of executing the recommendations. 
(f)  Develop a local network of people to work on issues of importance to people with disabilities. 
(g)  Promote local understanding of the implementation of the Americans with Disabilities Act. 
(h)  Provide recognition and award programming. 
(i)  Promote employment of people with disabilities. 
(j)  Other powers, duties, exceptions, privileges, and immunities accorded by applicable law and any assignments or delegations by the City to this board. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 13, 3-17-15) 
Secs. 2-6-103-2-6-104. - Reserved.

ARTICLE XV. - BOARD OF DIRECTORS OF AMARILLO HOSPITAL DISTRICT 

Sec. 2-6-115. - Created. 
    Pursuant to Article IX, Sec. 5 of the Texas Constitution and certain enabling legislation now codified at chapter 1001 of the Texas Special District Local Laws Code, there is hereby created the Board of Directors of the Amarillo Hospital District. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 15, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-116. - Appointment; term. 
    The board of managers of the Amarillo Hospital District shall consist of not less than five(5) nor more than seven (7) in number and shall be appointed by the City Council for two (2) year staggered terms beginning on April 1 and October 1, so that as nearly as possible, no more than 3 members' terms shall expire on either of those dates. Each member shall serve until a replacement shall have been appointed. Appointments to this board are exempt from the term limit stated in Sec. 2-6-6. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 15, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-117. - Duties and powers. 
    This Board shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  All provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(2)  The board shall provide or contract for the provision of health care to indigent residents of the hospital district. 
(3)  All powers, duties, privileges, exemptions, immunities, authority accorded by Article IX, Sec. 5 of the Texas Constitution and chapter 1001, Texas Special District Local Laws Code and other applicable law, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 15, 3-17-15) 
Secs. 2-6-118-2-6-119. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - EMERGENCY CARE ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-6-120. - Created. 
    There is now created the Emergency Care Advisory Board. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 16, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-121. - Members; terms. 
(a)  The board shall consist of: 
(1)  One (1) representative from the Amarillo City Council; 
(2)  One (1) representative from the Amarillo Hospital Board of Managers; 
(3)  One (1) representative who shall be either the Amarillo/Potter/Randall Public Health Authority or Deputy Public Health Authority; 
(4)  One representative from: (a) each of the hospitals in Amarillo who serve as EMS Service receiving primary care hospitals. Appointees under this category must be currently serving as a Physician in their respective hospital; and (b) the federally owned Veterans Administration hospital in Amarillo; 
(5)  One (1) representative from the Agency permitted to provide EMS Ambulance service in Amarillo, who shall be the local operations manager of said permittee; and, 
(6)  One (1) representative from the Amarillo Fire Department 
(b)  Members shall serve staggered three (3) year terms as provided in section 2-6-6, provided however, the representatives from the EMS Agency and the Amarillo Fire Department are not subject to term limitations. The City Council may modify the composition of the ECAB upon consultation with the holder of the permit to provide ambulance service in the city. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 16, 3-17-15; Ord. No. 7532, § 1, 5-26-15) 
Sec. 2-6-122. - Duties and powers. 
    The board shall have and exercise the following duties and powers: 
(1)  All provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(2)  To provide oversight and direction to the Medical Director on matters and issues related to quality of patient care; medical treatment, protocols, equipment use; personnel licensing or certifications; and other medical related issues affecting delivery of emergency medical service by the City's fire department and agency holding the ambulance permit in the city. 
(3)  To establish written guidelines under which the Board shall conduct its business. 
(4)  To make advisory, non-binding recommendations to the City's Medical Director for emergency medical services, the City and the agency holding the ambulance permit in the city as to the matters stated in subsection (1), above, as may be brought before the Board by either the Medical Director or at least three (3) members of the Board requesting a matter be placed on an agenda. 
(5)  The ECAB may operate in a manner so as to qualify for any quality improvement and/or peer review related privileges under applicable laws. 
(6)  To review any decision by the Medical Director suspending, revoking, or otherwise impairing an individual's privilege to practice under the Medical Director's physician license, when review is timely requested by the affected party (EMT-B, -I, or -P) employed by the City Fire Department or the agency holding the permit to provide ambulance service. In such a review, the ECAB's role: (1) remains advisory to the Medical Director, City, and agency holding the ambulance permit; (2) is solely limited to review of the Medical Director's decision or action on the licensing, certification, or practice of the employee as same bears upon patient care; medical treatment, protocols, equipment use; and other medical related issues; and (3) excludes consideration of any other form, nature, or type of complaint, grievance, or discipline other than the licensing, certification or practice matter described in this subsection; such other matters must be referred to the EMT's employer to be dealt with by the employer, if at all, as provided by that employer's practices, policies, and procedures. 
(7)  Other powers, duties, exceptions, privileges, and immunities accorded by applicable law and other duties as the City Council may assign or refer to the Board. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 16, 3-17-15) 
Secs. 2-6-123-2-6-124. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVII. - PUBLIC IMPROVEMENT DISTRICT BOARDS 

Sec. 2-6-125. - Created. 
    There is hereby created an advisory board for each public improvement district (PID) within the City. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 17, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-126. - General provisions. 
    The following provisions shall be applicable to all PID advisory boards, unless otherwise specifically provided for a particular PID in this section. 
(a)  Definitions. In this section these terms have the meaning indicated: 
    "Five Year Plan" means the ongoing (rolling) service plan described in section 372.013, Texas Local Government Code. 
    "Formation documents" means the petition and exhibits, findings, governing body resolution creating a PID and exhibits, as described in sections 372.005, 372.006, and 372.010, Texas Local Government Code. 
(b)  Members and terms. A board shall consist of three to five members as specified in the Formation documents as recommended to the City Council by the developer, owner, property owners association, or some combination. Members are appointed by the City Council to serve staggered three (3) year terms. Board members must be either a developer, owner, or lot owner, of property within the PID. Every board member has one (1) vote. 
(c)  Duties and powers. Each PID board shall have and exercise the following duties and powers for and on behalf of its PID: 
(1)  All provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(2)  All duties, powers, rights, exceptions, immunities accorded to an advisory board by chapter 372, Texas Local Government Code. 
(3)  All duties and powers stated in the Formation documents for the board's PID. 
(4)  Each year it shall recommend to both the property owners association and the City Council an annual service plan covering a continual five (5) year period, and a budget, each setting forth in detail the proposed services and the projected costs of services, improvements, Maintenance and Administrative costs for the PID. 
(5)  Upon reasonable notice, conduct at least one annual public hearing in the PID to gather information from PID property owners to aid in development of the service plan before presenting same to the City Council. 
(6)  Communicate with and promote awareness amongst property owners of the benefits accrued by the PID and responsibilities and processes of the PID. 
(d)  Administration. Each PID shall be jointly administered by the staff liaison(s) or designee. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 17, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-127. - Specific PID provisions. 
(a)  Colonies. In accordance with the Formation documents, the board shall be composed of five (5) members: two (2) members who are lot owners in the PID, other than the developer; two (2) who are recommended by the developer; and, one (1) who is recommended by the Owners; moreover, after the property has been fully developed, the members recommended by Developer and Owners shall be recommended by the Association. 
(b)  Greenways. In accordance with the Formation documents, the board shall be composed of five (5) members: two (2) members who are lot owners in the PID, other than the developer; two (2) who are recommended by the developer; and, one (1) who is recommended by the Trust; moreover, after the property has been fully developed, the members recommended by Developer and Trust shall be recommended by the Association. 
(c)  Point West. In accordance with the Formation documents, the board shall be composed of five (5) members: two (2) members who are lot owners in the PID, other than the developer; two (2) who are recommended by the developer; and, one (1) who is recommended by the Trust; moreover, after the property has been fully developed, the members recommended by Developer and Trust shall be recommended by the Association. 
(d)  Quail Creek. In accordance with the Formation documents, the board shall be composed of three (3) members: two (2) members who are lot owners in the PID, other than the developer and, one (1) who is recommended by the developer; moreover, after the property has been fully developed, the member recommended by Developer shall be recommended by the Association. 
(e)  Redstone. In accordance with the Formation documents, the board shall be composed as follows: (1) until more than 200 acres of the Property have been platted, Owner will serve as the sole member of the board; (2) after more than 200 acres have been platted, the board shall consist of: Owner, a lot owner recommended by Owner, and a lot owner designated by the City; (3) after the Owner no longer owns any of the Property, the board shall consist of two (2) residential lot owners, one (1) designated by the City, one (1) from the multi-Family tract, and one (1) Commercial Property owner; 
(f)  Tutbury. In accordance with the Formation documents, the board shall be composed of three (3) members: two (2) members who are lot owners in the PID, other than the developer; one (1) who is recommended by the developer; moreover, after the property has been fully developed, the members recommended by Developer shall be recommended by the Association. 
(g)  Vineyards. In accordance with the Formation documents, the board shall be composed of five (5) members: two (2) members who are lot owners in the PID, other than the developer; two (2) who are recommended by the developer; and, one (1) who is recommended by the Owner; moreover, after the property has been fully developed, the members recommended by Developer and Owner shall be recommended by the Association. 
(h)  Town Square. In accordance with the Formation documents, the initial board shall be composed of three (3) members selected by the developer, assignee or successor. After the first year, the board shall be composed of five (5) members: two (2) recommended by the property owner's Association; two (2) recommended by the Developer; and one (1) member recommended by the land Owner. After the property has been fully developed, the members recommended by Developer and Owner shall be recommended by the Association. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 17, 3-17-15) 
Secs. 2-6-128-2-6-129. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVIII. - TAX INCREMENT REINVESTMENT ZONE NO. 1 

Sec. 2-6-130. - Created. 
    There is hereby created the Board of Directors for the Tax Increment Reinvestment Zone No. 1 for the City of Amarillo. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 18, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-131. - Members. 
(a)  This Board shall consist of ten (10) members. Potter County shall appoint three (3) members and each taxing unit that levies real estate taxes, other than the City, may appoint one (1) member, if it desires to do so. The City Council shall appoint whatever number of members is necessary to fill the remaining positions on the board. City appointees may be members of the City Council. In addition to the qualifications of sec. 2-6-3 of this chapter, members shall also be and remain eligible under Texas Tax Code section 311.009. City Council appointees serve at the pleasure of the City Council. 
(b)  The City Council shall annually designate a member of the Board to serve as chairperson of the Board, and the Board shall elect from its members a vice chairperson and other officers as it considers appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 18, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-132. - Duties and powers. 
    The Board shall have and exercise the following duties and powers: 
(a)  All provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(b)  The Board shall make recommendations to the City Council concerning the administration, management and operation of the Zone. The Board shall prepare and adopt a project plan and a reinvestment zone financing plan for the Zone and submit such plans to the City for its approval. The Board shall perform all duties imposed upon it by Chapter 311 of the Texas Tax Code and all other applicable laws. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary herein, the Board shall not be authorized to (1) issue bonds; (2) impose taxes or fees: (3) exercise the power of eminent domain, or (4) give final approval to the Zone's project plan or financing plan. 
(c)  All defenses immunities, exceptions, and privileges accorded by Texas law. This subsection shall not be construed to grant new or additional powers or authority to the board beyond the scope set forth in Ordinance No. 7012. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 18, 3-17-15) 
Secs. 2-6-133-2-6-134. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIX. - COMPREHENSIVE PLAN ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-6-135. - Created. 
    There is hereby created the Comprehensive Plan Advisory Committee. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 19, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-136. - Members. 
(a)  The committee shall consist of seven (7) members. A quorum shall be five (5) members present. 
(b)  The committee shall elect from its members a chair, vice chair and other officers as it considers appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 19, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-137. - Duties and powers. 
    This committee shall have and exercise the following duties and powers: 
(1)  All provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(2)  The Committee shall assist City staff, Planning & Zoning Commission and the City Council as follows: (1) identify an orderly, logical, and effective sequence in which various elements or goals of the adopted 2010 Comprehensive Plan should be implemented; (2) provide comments and assist in evaluating staff recommendations on specific proposed aspects of the Plan in order to produce viable proposed amendments to ordinances and policies to implement the goals and objectives as identified by the adopted 2010 Comprehensive Plan; and, (3) facilitate involvement from citizens in the process of amending various ordinances and policies as needed in order to implement adopted 2010 Comprehensive Plan. 
(3)  To perform other similar tasks as assigned by the City Council or City Manager related to comprehensive planning by performing appropriate research, conducting public hearings or surveys, and formulating recommendations on such tasks. 
(4)  Other powers, duties, exceptions, privileges, and immunities accorded by applicable law and any assignments or delegations by the City to this board. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 19, 3-17-15) 
Secs. 2-6-138, 2-6-139. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XX. - BI-CITY-COUNTY HEALTH DISTRICT 

Sec. 2-6-140. - Created. 
    There is hereby created the Bi-City-County Health District Board. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 20, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-141. - Members; director 
    Pursuant to the interlocal cooperation agreement dated April 1, 1997 and subchapter E, chapter 121, Texas Health and Safety Code, the board shall consist of: 
(a)  The Board shall consist of seven (7) voting members, each being a resident of Potter or Randall county for a period of three (3) years, to serve for staggered three (3) year terms, as follows: two (2) members appointed by the City; one (1) appointed by the City of Canyon; two (2) appointed by Randall County; and, two (2) appointed by Potter County. Each is appointed by and serves at the pleasure of the majority of the appointing authority; and, 
(b)  The following are ex officio members without a vote: the County judge of Potter and Randall county respectively; City Manager of Amarillo and Canyon, respectively; and the director of the Bi-City-County Health District. 
(c)  As required by the participation agreement and state law, the City designates that the director of the District, and staff liaison, shall be the City of Amarillo Director of Public Health. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 20, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-142. - Duties and powers. 
    The board shall have and exercise the following duties and powers: 
(1)  As to appointees of the City, all provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(2)  Be an advisory board to the governing bodies of the participating entities. 
(3)  Make recommendations to the participating entities, through the minutes of its meetings, on matters pertaining to public health within the district. 
(4)  Advise the director of public health on such matters and the administration of the public health district created by the interlocal agreement. 
(5)  All other powers, duties, exceptions, privileges, and immunities accorded by applicable law and interlocal agreements that created the board and the district it oversees. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 20, 3-17-15) 
Secs. 2-6-143-2-6-144. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXI. - ZONING BOARD OF ADJUSTMENT 

Sec. 2-6-145. - Created. 
    The Zoning Board of Adjustment is hereby created. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 21, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-146. - Members. 
    The Board shall consist of five (5) members appointed by the City Council for a term of two (2) years. Moreover, the City Council may appoint up to four (4) alternate members of the Board who shall serve in the absence of one (1) or more regular members when requested to do so by the Building Official, as the case may be. All cases to be heard by the Board will always be heard by a minimum of four (4) members. Any member may be removed for cause by the Mayor or City Manager upon written charges and after a public hearing. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 21, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-147. - Duties and powers. 
    This Board shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  All provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(2)  In appropriate cases and subject to appropriate conditions and safeguards, make special exceptions to the terms of this chapter in harmony with its general purpose and intent and in accordance with general or specific provisions of this Code of Ordinances and other applicable law. 
(3)  To adopt rules to govern its proceedings, provided that such rules are not inconsistent with this Code, State or federal law. 
(4)  To administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses, by the chair or vice chair. 
(5)  To hear and decide appeals where it is alleged there is error in any order, requirement, decision or determination made by the Building Official in the enforcement of this chapter or applicable State law. 
(6)  To hear appeals from decisions of the Downtown Design Review Board as provided for in Chapter 4-10, Article IV, Division 3. 
(7)  To hear appeals concerning and act as the Airport Zoning Board of Adjustment as provided for in Chapter 4-9, Article II, Division 3. 
(8)  All other duties, powers, rights, exceptions, immunities provided by state law, city charter, and other provisions of this Code of Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 21, 3-17-15) 
Secs. 2-6-148-2-6-149. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XXII. - CORPORATE AND STATUTORY BOARDS 

Sec. 2-6-150. - General. 
(a)  The purpose of this Article is to acknowledge the several Corporate and Statutory Boards, the existence of which are independent of this chapter. The boards in this article are those whose legal existence as a corporation or district arises under state law. The appointment power to these boards may be shared with other appointing entities. The inclusion of corporate and statutory boards in this article is for administrative convenience of the City and ready-access to essential information about each board and its duties. This Article is intended to be non-substantive, neither broadening nor narrowing the purposes, scope, rights, duties, powers, funding, defenses, or immunities of such boards. Thus, in the event of a conflict between this Article and the Formation documents, the Formation documents shall control. The inclusion of a board in this Article does not substitute for each board maintaining its requisite corporate formalities and lawful status as either a corporation or a statutory body in accordance with applicable law and the Foundation documents of that board or entity. 
(b)  In this Article, the term "Foundation documents" means, as applicable, the corporate charter, by-laws, enabling statutes as amended, and any authorizing ordinance or resolution of the City creating or authorizing such corporation or statutory board, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 22, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-151. - Amarillo economic development corporation. 
(a)  Created pursuant to Resolution No. 1-16-90-2 (1990) under the statutory authority of Texas Revised Civil Statutes, article 5190.6, now Texas Local Government Code, chapters 501, 502, and 504. It is a type A corporation. 
(b)  The board consists of five (5) members, each of whom is appointed and serves at the pleasure of the City Council. The board shall select such officers as designated in the bylaws. 
(c)  The board shall have and exercise the following duties and powers: 
(1)  All provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(2)  Promote and effect the expansion and diversification of the Amarillo economy; promote the development, location, and expansion of industrial and manufacturing facilities and other basic economic enterprise facilities; to undertake projects defined by state law in order to reduce unemployment and underemployment; expand and diversify the economic base; and, encourage employment and the public welfare of, for, and on behalf of the City. 
(3)  To annually prepare a budget and obtain approval of the City Council for same. 
(4)  To issue debt for authorized purposes with the approval of the City Council. 
(5)  Keep the City Council reasonably informed of the status of various projects. 
(6)  All powers necessary or appropriate to effect any or all of the purposes for which the Corporation is organized which powers shall at all times be subject to the control of the City Council as the sponsoring governmental entity of the Corporation. 
(7)  All duties, powers, rights, privileges, exceptions, and immunities accorded by the Foundation documents. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 22, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-152. - Amarillo firemen's relief and retirement fund board. 
(a)  Created pursuant to the authority of Texas Local Fire Fighters Retirement Act (TLFFRA), Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes, article 6243e. 
(b)  The board consists of seven (7) members: the Mayor or designee; Chief Financial Officer of the City or designee; three (3) firefighters elected by participating members of the Fund; and, two (2) citizens of the City or its extraterritorial jurisdiction, who are not officers or employees of the City or any political subdivision, elected by Fund participants. This board shall meet monthly. 
(c)  The board shall have and exercise the following duties and powers: 
(1)  All provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(2)  Receive, handle, control, manage, and disburse the fund for the retirement system. 
(3)  Hear and determine all applications for retirement and disability claims (partial or total). 
(4)  Designate participants and beneficiaries as provided in the Act. 
(5)  Issue a subpoena to compel attendance of witnesses and production of books, records, and documents, and to swear witnesses. 
(6)  All other duties, powers, rights, privileges, exceptions, and immunities accorded by TLFFRA, any bylaws or rules of the Fund, and other applicable law, as amended, and as necessary or convenient to accomplish the statutory purposes for which the Fund and Board are created. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 22, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-153. - Amarillo health facilities corporation. 
(a)  Created pursuant to Resolution No. 12-4-81-3 (1981) under the statutory authority of Texas Revised Civil Statutes, article 1528j, now Texas Health and Safety Code, chapter 221. 
(b)  The board must consist of not less than three (3) members, and now has three (3) members, each of whom is appointed and serves at the pleasure of the City Council. The board shall select such officers as designated in the Foundation documents (president, vice president, secretary, assistant secretary, and treasurer). 
(c)  The board shall have and exercise the following duties and powers: 
(1)  All provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(2)  To issue bonds and otherwise borrow money as tax-exempt rates to the extent permitted by the Internal revenue Code; to loan such money to providers of health care services in order to finance the acquisition, construction, enlargement, remodeling, renovation, improvement, furnishing, or equipping of facilities which are found by the board to be required, necessary, or convenient for health care, research, and education, any one or more of these purposes within the State of Texas, all to assist the maintenance of public health. 
(3)  To further provide, improve, finance and refinance any real, personal or mixed property or any interest of the types and for the purposes described in the preceding subsection (2); 
(4)  All other powers necessary or appropriate to effect any or all of the purposes for which the Corporation is organized, subject to the Formation documents. 
(5)  All duties, powers, rights, privileges, exceptions, and immunities accorded by the Foundation documents. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 22, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-154. - Amarillo housing corporation. 
(a)  Created pursuant to Resolution No. 12-12-78-1 (1978) under the statutory authority of Texas Revised Civil Statutes, article 1269L, article 1269L-4, now Texas Local Government Code, chapter 393, and article 1269L-5, now Texas Government Code, chapter 2304. 
(b)  Effective January 1, 2015, the City Council has withdrawn authority for this board, and directs that the corporation be promptly dissolved in accordance with state law, and to conduct no further business except as necessary to wrap-up and accomplish dissolution. This action does not prejudice any future re-authorization and creation of the same or similar entity. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 22, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-155. - Amarillo housing finance corporation. 
(a)  Created pursuant to Resolution No. 12-21-79-1 (1979) under the statutory authority of now Texas Local Government Code, chapter 394. 
(b)  The board may consist of any number of members and now consists of five (5), each of whom is appointed and serves at the pleasure of the City Council. The board shall select such officers as designated in the Foundation documents. 
(c)  The board shall have and exercise the following duties and powers: 
(1)  All provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(2)  To benefit and accomplish the public purpose of, and on behalf of the City, by financing the cost of residential ownership and development that will provide decent, safe, sanitary housing for residents of the City at affordable prices. 
(3)  Assist persons of low and moderate income in acquiring and owning housing described in the preceding subsection (2). 
(4)  All other powers necessary or appropriate to effect any or all of the purposes for which the Corporation is organized, subject to the Formation documents. 
(5)  All duties, powers, rights, privileges, exceptions, and immunities accorded by the Foundation documents. 
(d)  Immediately upon all financial obligations existing as of January 1, 2015 shall be paid off, then the authorization for this board shall sunset and the corporation shall proceed to dissolution in accordance with law. The board is not authorized to conduct any business other than to pay existing obligations and to then wind up the affairs of the corporation expediently. This subsection does not prejudice the future creation of a same or similar corporation. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 22, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-156. - Amarillo local government corporation. 
(a)  Created pursuant to Resolution No. 03-22-11-2 (2011) under the statutory authority of Chapter 431, Subchapter D of the Texas Transportation Code. 
(b)  The board consists of seven (7) members, each of whom is appointed and serves at the pleasure of the City Council. The board shall select such officers as designated in the Foundation documents. 
(c)  The board shall have and exercise the following duties and powers: 
(1)  All provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(2)  Aiding, assisting, and acting on behalf of the City of Amarillo, Texas (the "City") in the performance of its governmental functions to promote the common good and general welfare of the City, including, without limitation: to promote the development of the geographic area of the City, including but not limited to the vicinity of the downtown area, in furtherance of the promotion, development, encouragement, and maintenance of employment, commerce, convention and meeting activity, tourism, and economic development in the City and lawful purposes of the municipal government. 
(3)  Explore the feasibility of Projects identified in the Foundation documents; and, expedite and facilitate construction of such Projects; realize savings in construction costs; and accomplish these and other activities, as permitted by the Act, in furtherance of the Projects; 
(4)  All rights, powers, privileges, authority, functions given by the general laws of Texas to non-profit corporations and the Texas Transportation Code for local government corporations. 
(5)  All duties, powers, rights, privileges, exceptions, and immunities accorded by the Foundation documents. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 22, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-157. - Amarillo-potter events venue district board of directors. 
(a)  Created pursuant to the authority of chapter 335 of the Texas Local Government Code, a public election, and Resolution No. 9-23-97-1 (1997); amended by No. 10-13-98-2 (1998), there is hereby created the Amarillo-Potter Events Venue District Board of Directors. 
(b)  The Board consists of seven (7) members, with four (4) being appointed by the Mayor and three (3) being appointed by the Potter County Judge. Directors shall serve staggered two (2) year terms. Directors appointed by a mayor may be removed by a Mayor at anytime without cause, and Directors appointed by a County Judge may be removed by a County Judge at anytime without cause. Removal shall be in accordance with chapter 178, Texas Local Government Code. Each Director shall be a resident of the appointing political subdivision and meet the further requirements of Texas Local Government Code, chapter 335 and City appointees shall further meet the qualifications of Section 2-6-3 of this Code of Ordinances. City appointments to this board are exempt from the term limit stated in Sec. 2-6-6. 
(c)  The Board shall have the following duties and powers: 
(1)  All provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(2)  All powers and duties, venue projects, code of conduct, rights, privileges, exemptions, immunities and other provisions of chapter 335, Texas Local Government Code and other law applicable to the business and purposes for which the Venue District exists and as approved by voters. 
(3)  Adopt bylaws. 
(4)  To issue bonds or other obligations as approved by the governing body of the City and Potter County, and to pledge revenues approved by voters, such as but not limited to hotel occupancy tax and short term motor vehicle rental tax. 
(5)  To perform all covenants and obligations of lawfully issued obligations of the District. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 22, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-158. - Canadian river municipal water authority. 
(a)  Created pursuant to the results of a public election as recognized in City of Amarillo Resolution No. 93-57 (1957), which was conducted under the authority of Article XVI, section 59 of the Texas Constitution and enabling legislation at Texas Revised Civil Statutes, article 8280-154 (Acts 1953), as amended. 
(b)  The board consists of members appointed by the governing bodies of member participants, of which Amarillo may appoint two (2) members, who cannot be a member of the City Council or employed by the City. Board member terms are for two (2) years. Each is appointed by and serves at the pleasure of the City Council. Appointments to this board are exempt from the term limit stated in section 2-6-6. The board elects such officers as designated in the Foundation documents. 
(c)  The board shall have and exercise the following duties and powers: 
(1)  As to members appointed by the City all provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(2)  All duties, powers, rights, privileges, exceptions, and immunities accorded by the Foundation documents to further the lawful purposes of the board. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 22, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-159. - Metropolitan planning organization, policy committee. 
(a)  Created pursuant to Resolution No. 5-27-75-3 (1975), and Chapter 472, Subchapter D of the Texas Transportation Code, and applicable federal law. See also, State Department of Highways and Public Transportation Minute Order No. 76787 (1980). All metropolitan areas of 50,000 population or greater are required to have an MPO. 
(b)  The committee consists of: 
(1)  Eleven (11) voting members: Amarillo Mayor, City Councilmember, and City Manager; the Texas Department of Transportation, Amarillo District Engineer and the Amarillo District Director of Transportation Planning; the County Judge and a Commissioner from each of Potter and Randall Counties; one (1) citizen representative from the Amarillo Chamber of Commerce; and, one (1) citizen representative from the Panhandle Regional Planning Commission. 
(2)  Nine (9) ex-officio members without votes: City of Canyon Mayor and City Manager, Executive Director of the Panhandle Regional Planning Commission, Representative of Federal Highway Administration, Representative of TxDOT, US Representative, 13 th Congressional District, State Senator, 31 st District, State Representative, 86 th District, and State Representative, 87 th District. 
(c)  The board shall have and exercise the following duties and powers: 
(1)  As to City appointed members, all provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(2)  Develop and maintain the Metropolitan Transportation Plan through a continuing, comprehensive, cooperative planning process. 
(3)  The biennial development of a program for highway and transit improvements (the Transportation Improvement Program). 
(4)  The annual adoption of a comprehensive one-year planning program, the Unified Planning Work Program, describing and coordinating the individual transportation planning activities of all agencies in the area. 
(5)  Other tasks and activities reasonably necessary or convenient for maintaining eligibility for federal funding for highway, transit, and transportation projects in the area. 
(6)  All other duties, powers, rights, privileges, exceptions, and immunities accorded by the Foundation documents to further the lawful purposes of the board. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 22, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-160. - Potter Randall County Emergency Communications District. 
(a)  Created pursuant to subchapter D, chapter 772, section 772.306(b) of the Texas Health and Safety Code. 
(b)  The board consist of seven (7) members: one (1) member appointed by each participating commissioners court; two (2) members form the most populous city in the district; one (1) member from the second most populous city; one (1) member to represent all other municipalities in the district, all serving two (2) year staggered terms. The Amarillo City Council appoints two (2) members. The board selects its own officers. Appointments to this board are exempt from the term limit stated in Sec. 2-6-6. 
(c)  The board shall have and exercise the following duties and powers: 
(1)  As to City appointees, all provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(2)  Provide 9-1-1 service to each participating entity that meets all minimum statutory requirements. 
(3)  Recommend minimum standards for 9-1-1 service. 
(4)  Appoint and supervise a director for the district. 
(5)  Direct the preparation of an annual budget for submission to participating entities. 
(6)  To fund the district and have an independent annual audit conducted. 
(7)  All other duties, powers, rights, privileges, exceptions, and immunities accorded by the Foundation documents to further the lawful purposes of the board. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 22, 3-17-15) 
Sec. 2-6-161. - Texas panhandle centers for behavioral and developmental health. 
(a)  Created in 1966 as the Amarillo Community Mental Health and Mental Retardation Center, pursuant to Resolution No. 2-8-66-1 and Revised Civil Statutes, article 5547-203, now chapter 534, Texas Health and Safety Code, as a solely municipal agency. However by Resolution No. 9-11-73-2 (1973) the City agency was converted to a regional MH-MR center, the Texas Panhandle Mental Health and Mental Retardation. It worked in association with the Amarillo State Center. In 2000, the two were merged, and adopted the current name, and does business as Texas Panhandle Centers. 
(b)  In accordance with section 534.003, Texas Health and Safety Code, the Board consists of not less than five (5) nor more than thirteen (13) members; the City now appoints three (3) of those members, who serve two (2) year terms. City appointments to this board are exempt from the term limit stated in Sec. 2-6-6. 
(c)  The powers and duties of the board of the board are: 
(1)  As to the City appointed members, all provisions of Article I of this chapter that are not in conflict with this Article. 
(2)  Serve persons with mental illness, intellectual and developmental disabilities and children with developmental delays from birth to age three (3). 
(3)  All other duties, powers, rights, privileges, exceptions, and immunities accorded by the Foundation documents to further the lawful purposes of the board. 
(Ord. No. 7519, § 22, 3-17-15) 
CHAPTER 2-7. - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[1] 
  
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7077, § 1, adopted Nov. 13, 2007, amended the former Ch. 2-7, §§ 2-7-1-2-7-10, and enacted a new Ch. 2-7 as set out herein. The former Ch. 2-7 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1960, §§ 2-76-2-84; Ord. No. 5572, § 1, adopted Mar. 4, 1986; ; Ord. No. 5891, § 1, adopted Oct. 16, 1990; Ord. No. 5920, § 1, adopted July 9, 1991; Ord. No. 6845, §§ 1, 2, adopted Sept. 13, 2005. 
State Law reference- Texas Director Act of 1975, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.001 et seq.; local emergency management, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - GENERAL 

Sec. 2-7-1. - Offices created; composition. 
(a)  There is hereby created the Department of Emergency Administration as follows: 
(1)  It shall be headed by the Manager of Emergency Administration, who shall be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the City Manager; 
(2)  Primary responsibilities include: 
a.  Oversight of the Office of Emergency Management; 
b.  Manager of the city's communications systems, personnel, and assets; 
c.  Point of contact and manager for all Homeland Security grants and Amarillo MMRS programs; 
d.  Upgrade project(s) of the emergency operations center; 
e.  Other duties as assigned. 
(b)  There is hereby created the Office of Emergency Management of the City which shall consist of the following: 
(1)  Mayor, who is the Emergency Management Director; 
(2)  The City Manager or City Manager's designee, who shall be the Deputy Emergency Management Director; 
(3)  The Emergency Management Coordinator of the City who shall be charged with the day-to-day operation of the Office of Emergency Management, warnings and ensuring the readiness of the Emergency Operations Center and such other duties as the City Manager may prescribe. The Coordinator, designated by the Emergency Management Director shall be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the City Manager. The Coordinator will report to the Manager of Emergency Administration. 
(4)  The directors of divisions and chiefs of services as may be designated by the Deputy Emergency Management Director. 
(5)  The Manager of Emergency Administration. 
(Ord. No. 7077, § 1, 11-13-2007) 
Sec. 2-7-2. - Operational organization; powers, duties of Mayor. 
(a)  The operational Emergency Management organization of the City shall consist of the Mayor and such staff members and employees of the City so designated by the Deputy Emergency Management Director, as well as designated organized volunteer groups. 
(b)  The powers and duties of the Mayor shall include the following: 
(1)  Authority to declare a local state of disaster or emergency. The declaration may not be continued or renewed for a period in excess of seven (7) days except by or with the consent of the City Council. Any order or proclamation declaring, continuing or terminating a local state of disaster shall be given prompt and general publicity and shall be filed promptly with the City Secretary. 
(2)  Issuance of necessary proclamations, regulations or directives which are necessary for carrying out the purposes of this chapter. Such proclamations, regulations or directives shall be disseminated promptly by means calculated to bring its contents to the attention of the general public and, unless circumstances attendant on the disaster prevent or impede, promptly filed with the City Secretary. 
(3)  Determination of all questions of authority and responsibility that may arise within the emergency management organization for the City. 
(4)  Maintenance of liaison with other municipal, county, district, state, regional or federal emergency management organizations. This duty may be delegated to the Deputy Emergency Management Director and Emergency Management Coordinator. 
(5)  During a declared disaster, the Mayor may expend or commit public funds of the City when deemed prudent and necessary for the protection of health, life or property. 
(6)  Authorizing of agreements, after approval by the City Attorney, for use of private property for public shelter and other public purposes. 
(7)  Authorizing mutual aid to be sent to a requesting entity after consulting with the Deputy Emergency Management Director as to availability of personnel and equipment and any anticipated need for such within the city limits. The Mayor may also delegate this task and authority to the Deputy Emergency Management Director to act when the Mayor is not reasonably or timely available. 
(8)  Other powers, duties, and requirements as specified in Texas Disaster Act 1975, as amended [V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.001 et seq.]. 
(Ord. No. 7077, § 1, 11-13-2007; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Sec. 2-7-3. - Deputy Emergency Management Director. 
    The powers and duties of the Deputy Emergency Management Director shall include the following: 
(a)  Surveying actual or potential hazards which threaten life and property within the City and identify and recommend the implementation of measures to prevent the occurrence or reduce the impact of such hazards if a disaster did occur. 
(b)  Supervision of the development and approval of an emergency management plan for the City, and may recommend for adoption by the City Council all mutual aid arrangements deemed necessary for the implementation of such plan. 
(c)  Direction and control of the operations of the Emergency Management organization as well as the training of Emergency Management personnel. 
(d)  Marshaling of all necessary personnel, equipment or supplies from any department of the City to aid in the carrying out of the provisions of the Emergency Management plan. 
(e)  Supervision of the drafting and execution of mutual aid agreements in cooperation with the representatives of the State and of other local political subdivisions of the State, and the organization, if authorized by the City Council of a joint office of Emergency Management. 
(f)  Supervision of and final authorization for the procurement of all necessary supplies and equipment, including acceptance of private contributions which may be offered for the purpose of improving emergency management within the City. 
(g)  Surveying of the availability of existing personnel, equipment, supplies and services which could be used during a disaster, as provided in this chapter. 
(h)  Delegation of such enumerated powers to the Manager of Emergency Administration or Emergency Management Coordinator as the Deputy director deems proper. 
(Ord. No. 7077, § 1, 11-13-2007; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Sec. 2-7-4. - Joint emergency management program. 
    The City Council may join with any group or groups of governmental units in order to provide for the formation of a joint office of emergency management. 
(Ord. No. 7077, § 1, 11-13-2007; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Sec. 2-7-5. - Emergency management plan; duty of other city departments. 
(a)  A comprehensive emergency management plan shall be developed and maintained. The plan shall set forth the form of the organization; establish and designate divisions and functions; assign responsibilities, tasks, duties and powers; and designate staff and employees to carry out the provisions of this chapter. The plan shall also include an "all risk" component that provides for continuity of operations and succession of leadership for all city departments. As provided by State law, the plan shall follow the standards and criteria established by the Division of Emergency Management of the State. Insofar as possible, the form of organization, titles and terminology shall conform to the recommendations of the State Division of Emergency Management. It shall be the duty of all departments and agencies to perform the functions assigned by the plan and to maintain their portion of the plan in a current state of readiness. The emergency management plan shall be considered supplementary to this chapter. 
(b)  All persons employed in every division, department, and unit of the City of Amarillo shall fully cooperate with the Department of Emergency Administration and Office of Emergency Management in every phase of preparing for, planning for, responding to and recovery from an emergency. If a unit of the City government does not have an explicitly assigned duty, then its personnel and resources shall be made available to assist other departments. 
(Ord. No. 7077, § 1, 11-13-2007) 
Sec. 2-7-6. - Declaration of a state of emergency. 
(a)  The terms "disaster" and "state of an emergency" are used interchangeably in this chapter with the intent that the definition of same includes all conditions described in Texas Government Code, chapter 418 and 433, which includes but is not limited to: the occurrence or imminent threat of widespread or severe damage, injury or loss of life or property resulting from any natural or manmade cause, including fire, flood, earthquake, wind storm, volcanic activity, epidemic, air contamination, blight, drought, infestation, explosion, riot, clear and present danger of the use of violence, hostile military or paramilitary action, or terrorism, including nuclear, biological or chemical warfare, other public calamity requiring emergency action, or an energy emergency. 
(b)  The Deputy Emergency Management Director, the Manager of Emergency Administration and the Emergency Management Coordinator each will have the authority to request the declaration of the existence of an emergency or disaster by the City Council during the time of such as defined above. If it is deemed necessary to declare the existence of an emergency without delay, the Mayor may, if the City Council is not in session, do so. Such action shall be subject to ratification by the City Council at its next meeting. In no event will such a declaration by the Mayor continue or be renewed for a period in excess of seven (7) days except by or with the consent of the City Council. 
(c)  The Deputy Emergency Management Director will, after the declaration of the existence of an emergency, issue all necessary directives for the operational effectiveness of the emergency management operations plan and have prepared for immediate submission to the City Council an ordinance invoking and applying all the powers reasonably necessary to protect the health, security, peace, life and property of the City and its inhabitants during the period of such civil emergency. Such powers are set out more particularly in V.T.C.A.. Government Code, chapters 433 and 418, and other applicable state law. 
(Ord. No. 7077, § 1, 11-13-2007; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-17) 
Sec. 2-7-7. - Exemption from liability for death or injury. 
    This chapter is an exercise by the City of its governmental functions for the protection of the public peace, health and safety; neither the City, the agents and representatives of the City nor any individual, receiver, firm, partnership, corporation, association or trustee, or any of the agents thereof, in good faith carrying out, complying with or attempting to comply with any order, rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall be liable for any injury sustained to persons or damage to property as the result of such activity. 
(Ord. No. 7077, § 1, 11-13-2007) 
State Law reference- Declaration of local disaster, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 418.108. 
Sec. 2-7-8. - Unlawful acts. 
(a)  No person shall have the right to expend any public funds of the City in carrying out any emergency management activity authorized by this chapter without prior approval by the City Manager, nor shall any person have any right to bind the City by contract, agreement or otherwise without prior and specific approval of the City Manager. 
(b)  Any person who shall willfully obstruct, hinder or delay any member of the emergency management organization in the enforcement of any rule or regulation issued pursuant to this chapter, or to do any act forbidden by any rule or regulation issued pursuant to the authority contained in this chapter, commits an offense. 
(c)  Any person who shall wear, carry or display any emblem, insignia or other means of identification as a member of the Emergency Management organization of the City, or who verbally identifies himself or who holds himself out to be a member of the Emergency Management organization of the City without express authority to do so, commits an offense. 
(d)  Any unauthorized person who shall operate a siren or other device so as to simulate a warning signal or the termination of a warning commits an offense.
