It shall be unlawful and an offense for a parent or guardian of a child (meaning, a person under the age of seventeen (17) years old) for such parent or guardian to intentionally, knowingly, recklessly or with criminal negligence permit such child to create graffiti on tangible property of another. 
(j)  Possession of aerosol paint by minor: offense. It shall be unlawful and an offense for a child (meaning, a person under the age of seventeen (17) years old) to possess aerosol paint of any sort or character, an engraving device, or an indelible marker (hereafter in this subsection, jointly and severally as. "item"). It shall be an affirmative defense to a violation under this subsection that, at the time of possession, the child: 
1.  Was accompanied or supervised by the child's parent, guardian, or teacher in connection with a bona fide school project, or by a supervisor in the course of the minor's employment; 
2.  Possessed the item on and at the property where the child resides; 
3.  Possessed the item in the immediate course and scope of an organized event sponsored or supervised by a governmental entity, school, religious organization, or other recognized youth organization; or 
4.  Was transporting the item for a lawful purpose on behalf of or at the direction of the parent or guardian of the child. 
(k)  Notices. Notices permitted or required by this section will be given by one (1) of the following methods. The validity of a notice given by mail is not affected if the United States Postal Service returns the notice as "refused" or "unclaimed." 
1.  Preferred methods. Personal delivery in writing to the owner, in which case the date the owner receives the notice is the date of the notice: or, sending it by certified mail, addressed to the owner at the owner's address as contained in the records of the Potter-Randall Appraisal District, in which case the date of the notice is deemed to be three (3) days after the date of mailing. 
2.  Alternative methods. If the notice cannot be made by a preferred method, then the notice shall be given by either: publication at least once in a newspaper of general circulation in the City, in which case the date of the notice is the date of publication: or, posting the notice on or near the front door on the property to which the graffiti exists, in which case the date of the notice is the date the notice was posted: or, by posting the notice on a placard attached to a stake driven into the ground on the property to which the notice relates, in which case the date of the notice is the date the notice was posted. 
(l)  Enforcement: affirmative defense. A person who is convicted of violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be fined an amount not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. It is an affirmative defense to prosecution under that a required notice was not given to the property owner in compliance with this section. 
(Ord. No. 7329, § 2, 4-24-2012) 
Secs. 10-3-18-10-3-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC SAFETY 

Sec. 10-3-26. - Discharging BB guns, air rifles, paintball guns. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot and discharge any shot, lead, nail, wire, steel, match, paintball or any other hard substance out of any BB gun, air rifle, paintball gun or any other rifle across, into or along any Alley or, Street or City park within the City limits. 
(Code 1960, § 14-4; Ord. No. 5641, § 1, 10-28-86; Ord. No. 6466, § 1A, 2-15-2000) 
Sec. 10-3-27. - Firearms. 
(a)  Discharging. It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any firearm within the City limits. In this Section, "firearm" means any device designed, made, or adapted to expel a projectile through a barrel by using the energy generated by an explosion or burning substance. 
(b)  Exceptions. This section and the offense defined above shall not apply to the discharge of a firearm in the following situations: 
(1)  Animal control authority. By an authorized employee of the Animal Control Department of the City in the performance of duties under the direction and control of the supervisor of the Animal Control Department in controlling the following: 
A.  Vicious animals; 
B.  Injured animal or birds; 
C.  Skunks or snakes where their apprehension is not feasible or possible; 
D.  Rabbits, pigeons, coyotes, birds and other animals after written approval from the Chief of Police. 
(2)  Shooting galleries, gun clubs, etc. Discharging a firearm within a shooting gallery that is constructed in accordance with the City Building Code or National Rifle Association Standards, whichever is more strict and, which is located in a properly zoned district of the City or, the discharge of firearms on facilities owned or operated by a gun or shooting club if done according to its rules and regulations and with its acquiescence. 
(3)  Preventing injury by animal. To prevent bodily injury or harm by an Animal to a human or another animal. 
(4)  State law. When the discharge is authorized by state law in defense of self or of a third party. 
(Code 1960, § 14-5; Ord. No. 5641, § 1, 10-28-86; Ord. No. 6208, § 1, 1-2-96; Ord. No. 6719, § 1, 3-9-2004) 
Sec. 10-3-28. - Slingshots and flippers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot or sling any stone, rock, lead, steel or any other kind of hard substance out of a slingshot, flipper or any other similar apparatus across, into or along any Street or Alley within the City limits. 
(Code 1960, § 14-6; Ord. No. 5641, § 1, 10-28-86) 
Secs. 10-3-29-10-3-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES INVOLVING PUBLIC PEACE AND ORDER 

Sec. 10-3-41. - Soliciting in street. 
(a)  No person shall stand in a Street or highway and solicit, or attempt to solicit, employment, business or contributions from the occupant of any vehicle. 
(b)  The prohibition in subsection (a) above does not apply to a person soliciting contributions for a charitable organization which has been issued a permit under this section and who is in compliance with state law and other provisions of this section. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, the following terms have the meaning stated here: "charitable organization;" or "organization" means an entity that the United States Internal Revenue Service recognizes to be a charitable organization or a church. "Contribution" means currency, coin, or check. "Location" means the approaches to an intersection equipped with a traffic control signal light and within one hundred (100) feet of such an intersection. 
(d)  In order to solicit contributions while standing in a Street or highway, a charitable organization must comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Not less than eleven (11) days prior to the date desired for soliciting, submit a complete application to the City Police Chief or designee for a permit. The Police Department shall create a form and review procedure for this purpose. The form shall require the name of the charitable organization; a point of contact for the organization (meaning the name and phone number of the individual seeking the permit for the organization); the desired date(s), time(s) and specific location(s) for soliciting; the name, address, phone number and age of each individual who may solicit contributions on behalf of the organization and, an agreement of the organization indemnifying the city and holding it harmless from any and all claims, suits, demands, damages and attorney fees arising out of or related to the acts or omissions of persons soliciting for the organization. The form may require further information that is reasonably necessary to the direct enforcement of this section and the purposes of this article. 
(2)  At the time of submitting a completed application, the organization shall also submit the following items and failure to do so renders the application incomplete: 
a.  Fee payment in the sum of four hundred dollars ($400.00) (cash or money order only) to defray the City's costs of both processing the application, advertising, and compliance monitoring on the Street. This fee is nonrefundable, unless the permit is denied. 
b.  Provide written proof of liability insurance in the minimum amount of: One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) to cover damages that may arise from the solicitation. The insurance must provide coverage against claims against the applicant and claims against the City. The City must be an additional insured on the policy and specify that such insurance is primary and the City's insurance is secondary. The insurance policy must be issued by a company authorized by the State Department of Insurance to do business in Texas and, have an effective date that covers the date(s) of street soliciting. 
c.  Provide written proof that the organization is a charitable organization, along with a copy of the organization's charter (or if a foreign organization, then a copy of its certificate of authority to do business in Texas). 
(3)  No more than one (1) permit per calendar year may be issued to an organization. For purposes of this subsection, local chapters of a state, national or international organization are deemed separate organizations, but committees or other subdivisions of an organization are not so deemed. 
(4)  A permit shall authorize street soliciting only for three (3) consecutive calendar days, between the period of 9:00 a.m. and one (1) hour prior to sunset, at the approved location(s) specified in the application. 
(5)  The Police Chief or designee shall not issue an organization a permit for a given date(s) or location(s) if a permit has already been issued to another organization for such date(s) and location(s). 
(6)  The Police Chief or designee shall grant or deny a permit solely on the basis of the information, documents, and requirements stated in the above subsections (1) through (5), inclusive. The Police Chief or designee shall advise the organization's point of contact of the decision to grant or deny the permit, not later than the tenth day after date of receiving the application and fee. 
(e)  If a permit is granted, it shall state the name of the organization, the names of the persons who will be soliciting contributions for the organization and, the approved date(s), time(s) and location(s). The organization shall at its expense make sufficient copies of the permit to have a copy at each approved location and, shall readily present such copy for inspection upon demand by any person. The chief shall also cause to be published a newspaper notice of approximately two (2) columns by five (5) inches in size, advising the motoring public to be alert to the presence of solicitors in the Street at the location(s) and date(s) approved in the permit. The notice shall also state the name of the organization. 
(f)  If a permit is denied, then the applicant may appeal to the City Council by filing a letter with the City Secretary indicating why the permit should be granted. This letter must be filed no later than three (3) business days after the notice of denial. The City Council shall decide the matter and advise the organization's point of contact of the decision no later than the fifteenth day after receiving the appeal letter. The City Council's decision is final. 
(g)  It is an offense for a person to solicit or attempt to solicit contributions, for a charitable organization that is issued a permit, and fail to: 
(1)  Be at least eighteen (18) years of age; or 
(2)  Be named on the organization's permit; or 
(3)  Wear a reflective orange or yellow visibility vest as the outer most garment; or 
(4)  Be in the Street or highway only when the controlling traffic signal light prohibits vehicle movement in that lane; or 
(5)  Remain within one hundred (100) feet of or from an intersection approved in the permit; or 
(6)  Place an orange traffic control cone, not less than twenty-four (24) inches in height, on the center stripe of each Street and highway approaching the intersection, at least one hundred (100) to one hundred fifty (150) feet from the intersection, to warn drivers of a hazard ahead; or 
(7)  Present for inspection a copy of the permit upon demand by any person. 
(h)  It is an offense for any person to obstruct, tamper with, alter, cover, or post any object on or to a traffic control device. Traffic control device includes but is not limited to: median markers, reflectors, signal control boxes, regulatory signs, directional signs, warning signs, and pedestrian walk lights. 
(i)  Any peace officer observing any violation of any requirement or prohibition of this section is authorized to issue a citation for the person to appear in municipal court to answer the charge. Upon issuance of the citation, such person shall immediately cease soliciting or attempting to solicit any charitable contribution under that organization's permit. However, it is not the intent of this provision to bar such person from participating in future charitable solicitations approved under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1960, § 14-1; Ord. No. 5641, § 1, 10-28-86; Ord. No. 6547, § 1, 8-21-2001; Ord. No. 6751, § 1, 7-13-2004; Ord. No. 6860, § 1, 10-18-2005; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6751, § 1, adopted July 13, 2004 removed "sunset provisions" from § 10-3-41. 
Sec. 10-3-42. - Urinating, defecating in public. 
    No person may urinate or defecate within public view or in any public place other than in an enclosure designed for such purposes. 
(Code 1960, § 14-5; Ord. No. 5641, § 1, 10-28-86) 
Sec. 10-3-43. - Consumption of alcoholic beverages in public places. 
    No person shall knowingly or intentionally consume an alcoholic beverage while in, upon or immediately adjacent to a motor vehicle in a public place or in any Public Right-of-Way or public parking area. The terms "alcoholic beverage," "motor vehicle," and "public place" shall have the definitions commonly applied by law, except that this section shall not apply to a Premises licensed for sale and consumption of alcoholic or within the closed area of a Block Party of Festival permitted under Chapter 16-3, of this Code. 
(Code 1960, § 14-9; Ord. No. 5641, § 1, 10-28-86; Ord. No. 6625, § 2, 9-24-2002) 
Sec. 10-3-44. - Open alcoholic beverage containers. 
(a)  Possession of an open alcoholic beverage container in a public place within the Central Business District including and between 5th and 8th Streets from Western to Forest and between 5th and 7th Streets between Forest and Washington/Adams, as well as between railroad tracks on the north and South 15th Streets between Washington/Adams Street and the railroad tracks on the east side of downtown, is prohibited. 
(1)  Open Alcoholic Beverage Container means what it says and includes a container into which an alcoholic beverage or a beverage containing an alcoholic content has been transferred and it also includes an alcoholic beverage container which has been previously opened or unsealed and reclosed. 
(2)  Public Place means, for purposes of this section, any public Street, Sidewalk, Alley, an outdoor public place as defined in law, and shall include a privately owned public parking area, but excludes: the inside of a motor vehicle; the inside of a building that is not owned or controlled by the municipality; and, residential structures, which includes a deck, patio, porch, or balcony thereof. 
(b)  Exemptions from the open container prohibition in subsection (a) may be granted as follows: 
(1)  Four (4) Festivals per calendar year for civic promotional functions, which shall not exceed twelve (12) hours in duration, in that portion of the Central Business District being along and between 5th and 7th Streets between Forest and Jackson Streets. Provided, however, if a Festival or a portion of a Festival is conducted or occurs between McMasters and Forest Streets, then no promoter, sponsor, participant or their agents shall either fence or charge admission for access to that segment of the Festival. This restriction on fencing does not affect lawful barricading of public streets in accordance with this Code. 
(2)  Eight (8) Festivals, per calendar year for civic promotional functions which shall not exceed twelve (12) hours in duration, in the remainder of the Central Business District. Provided however that under no circumstance shall the actual thoroughfares of South 3rd or South 10th Streets ever be closed for a Festival. 
(3)  To obtain an exemption under this subsection (b), the applicant organization must obtain a Festival permit from the Traffic Engineer pursuant to the requirements and procedures of Chapter 16-3 of the Amarillo Municipal Code. Any Festival permit issued Chapter 16-3 for the purposes of satisfying this section, shall contain and be subject to the conditions stated in this section. 
(c)  An exemption from the open container prohibition stated in subsection (a) shall be granted as a matter of right to a properly permitted restaurant that has a designated outdoor dining area for customers, and which is also licensed for on-premises consumption of alcohol, where the sale of alcoholic beverages constitutes no more than fifty (50) percent of the gross sales of that establishment. 
(Ord. No. 6380, § 1, 12-1-98; Ord. No. 6586, § 1, 3-5-2002; Ord. No. 6625, § 2, 9-24-2002; Ord. No. 7347, § 1, 8-7-2012) 
Sec. 10-3-45. - Camping on municipal facilities and public property. 
(a)  Definitions. The following term shall have the meaning shown. 
(1)  Camp or Camping means and includes to stay in, on, or at a Municipal Facility or upon Public Property between the hours of 12 midnight and 5:00 a.m., unless permission has been given by the entity that owns or controls such facility or property. There is no required or minimum equipment or supplies necessary to constitute the act of camping, vehicle. 
(2)  Municipal Facility shall mean and include, for purposes of this section, every structure, building, or land owned by the City of Amarillo for the purposes of conducting any business or operation of municipal government, and includes all accessory areas such as, but not limited to porch, steps, ramps, grounds, walks, lawn, yard, plaza, parking lot. It includes, but is not limited to City Hall, the Simms Building, libraries, police and fire stations, civic/convention center complex; fleet service center, water towers, water and sewage treatment plants. For purposes of this section, the term does not include a park. 
(3)  Public property means such places as are described in (2) above, but which are owned or controlled by another governmental entity. 
(4)  Available beds means the available and specifically designated as sleeping quarters for persons who are homeless. The Amarillo Homeless Management Information System (AHMIS) Report shall establish the number of Available Beds for each reporting year. 
(5)  Shelter Space is synonymous with Available Beds. 
(6)  Unsheltered Person means an individual with a primary nighttime residence that is a public or private place not designed for or ordinarily used as a regular sleeping accommodation for human beings, including a car, park, abandoned building, bus or train station, airport, or camping ground. 
(7)  Unsheltered Population means the number of persons determined to be unsheltered in the City by the most recent annual Point-in-Time count required by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development. 
(b)  Offense. It is hereby declared to be a class C misdemeanor offense for a person to Camp: 
(1)  In, upon, or at a Municipal Facility; (excluding designated areas provided for public employees or volunteers for their use within the scope of their duties); or 
(2)  In, upon, or at a public right-of-way including a sidewalk, street, alley, highway, culvert, or any other Public property. 
(c)  Abatement. Camping in, upon, or at a Municipal Facility or Public Property in violation of this section is a nuisance that may be abated by summary removal of tents, bedding, and other personal belongings and equipment. 
(d)  Affirmative Defenses. It is an affirmative defense that a person was Camping: 
(1)  By temporarily parking a recreational vehicle, bus, pick-up camper, travel trailer, or similar vehicle or trailer: (i) in a lawful manner, time, and place on a public street in accordance with applicable state law and City ordinance, or (ii) in a parking lot adjacent to the Amarillo Civic/Convention Center for the duration of an event at the Amarillo Civic/Convention Center Complex (including set up and take down for such an event), provided that such person: is a vendor, tenant, producer, cast, crew, or exhibitor for such an event; and who obtains a permit from the Director of the Civic/Convention Center Complex; and, complies with all applicable rules and rents established by the Director; or, (iii) in, on, or at such other location that is owned or under the control of another governmental entity, when and as may be permitted by that entity, 
(2)  In a public park if, when, and as such activity may be allowed by park rules and in strict compliance with the terms thereof. 
(3)  If a person is an Unsheltered Person and if sufficient Shelter Space is unavailable because there are inadequate Available Beds for the Unsheltered Population, as determined by the Annual Report of Available Beds. 
(e)  Annual Report of Available Beds. The Health and Human Services Director or designee shall prepare and maintain a complete listing of all service providers for Unsheltered Persons within the corporate limits of the City. Each service provider shall provide their total available beds and these shall be determined to be the total "available beds" as defined by this section. The annual report shall be maintained in the official records of the City, and shall be available for public review. The annual report may be revised by the Health and Human Services director or designee in the event a service provider materially changes the total available beds provided. 
(f)  Intent. 
(1)  This section is not intended to deny or to unduly restrict any person's temporary use of a public sidewalk or other traditional public forum for demonstrations, pickets, marches, and other lawful expressive activity, provided that such person does not Camp in violation of this section, obstruct passage to other persons or vehicles, or otherwise violate applicable state law or city ordinance. 
(2)  This section is not intended to deem the status of involuntary homelessness (whether temporary or permanent) as a violation of this or any other City ordinance, but to make the prohibited acts defined in this section subject to reasonable and prudent enforcement to protect the public, health, safety and welfare. 
(3)  Nothing herein shall be deemed to authorize or allow a person or persons to camp, stand, sit, or lie in or upon a Municipal Facility, or Public Property, or a public right-of-way in such a way as to interfere with the use or operation of such Municipal Facility or Public Property or public right-of-way for the intended purposes and to carry on public business, and for the benefit of the public desiring to peaceably enter a Municipal Facility or Public Property for its intended purposes. 
(Ord. No. 7333, § 1, 6-5-2012; Ord. No. 7596, § 1, 4-12-16, eff. 5-2-16) 
Secs. 10-3-46-10-3-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC MORALS 

Sec. 10-3-61. - Soliciting prostitution. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to remain in or adjacent to any public place in a manner and under circumstances manifesting the purpose of inducing, enticing, soliciting or procuring another to commit an act of prostitution. 
(b)  Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether such purpose is manifested are that such person is a known prostitute or panderer and repeatedly beckons to, stops or attempts to stop, or engages passersby in conversation or repeatedly stops or attempts to stop motor vehicle operators by hailing, waving of arms or any other bodily gesture. No arrest shall be made for a violation of this subsection unless the arresting officer first affords such person an opportunity to explain such conduct, and no one shall be convicted of violating this subsection if it appears at trial that the explanation for such conduct discloses a lawful purpose. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section, a known prostitute or panderer is a person who, within one (1) year previous to the date of arrest for violation of this section, has within the knowledge of the arresting officer been convicted of prostitution, promotion of prostitution, aggravated promotion of prostitution or compelling prostitution as those terms are defined by the Texas Penal Code. 
(Code 1960, § 14-7; Ord. No. 5641, § 1, 10-28-86) 
State Law reference- Prostitution, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 43.01 et seq. 
Sec. 10-3-62. - Abetting prostitution. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to spend time in a public place or within public view for the purpose of inducing, soliciting or procuring another to: 
(1)  Commit an act of prostitution; 
(2)  Patronize a prostitute. 
(b)  Proof of a person's intent to engage in conduct made unlawful by this section may be inferred from actions that include but are not limited to the following: 
(1)  That such person repeatedly beckons to, stops or attempts to stop passersby; 
(2)  That such person engages passersby in conversation which indicates that such person is a prostitute or which inquires if the passerby is interested in companionship in exchange for money; 
(3)  That such person repeatedly stops or attempts to stop motor vehicle operators by hailing, waving of arms or other bodily gesture. 
(c)  For the purposes of (b)(1) or (3) above, the suspected person's conduct must be such as to demonstrate a specific intent to induce, entice, solicit or procure another to commit an act of prostitution. 
(Code 1960, § 14-8; Ord. No. 5641, § 1, 10-28-86) 
State Law reference- Prostitution, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 43.01 et seq. 
Secs. 10-3-63-10-3-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - CURFEW HOURS FOR MINORS 

Sec. 10-3-71. - Definitions. 
    [As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meaning ascribed thereto:] 
    Curfew Hours means 12:01 a.m. until 6:00 a.m. daily. 
    Emergency means an unforeseen combination of circumstances or the resulting state that calls for immediate action. The term includes, but is not limited to, a fire, a natural disaster, an automobile accident, or any situation requiring immediate action to prevent serious bodily injury or loss of life. 
    Establishment means any privately-owned place of business operated for a profit to which the public is invited, including but not limited to any place of amusement or entertainment 
    Guardian means: 
(1)  a person who, under court order, is the guardian of the person of a minor; or 
(2)  a public or private agency with whom a minor has been placed by a court. 
    Minor means any person under seventeen (17) years of age. 
    Operator means any individual, firm, association, partnership, or corporation operating, managing, or conducting any establishment. The term includes the members or partners of an association or partnership and the officers of a corporation. 
    Parent means a person who is: 
(1)  a natural parent, adoptive parent, or step-parent of another person; or 
(2)  at least eighteen (18) years of age and authorized by a parent or guardian to have the care and custody of a minor. 
    Public Place means any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access and includes, but is not limited to, streets, highways, and the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, transport facilities, and shops. 
    Remain means to: 
(1)  linger or stay; or 
(2)  fail to leave premises when requested to do so by a police officer or the owner, operator, or other person in control of the premises. 
    Serious Bodily Injury means bodily injury that creates a substantial risk of death or that causes death, serious permanent disfigurement, or protracted loss or impairment of the function of any bodily member or organ. 
(Ord. No. 6131, § 1, 2-21-95; Ord. No. 6222, § 1, 3-19-96; Ord. No. 6516, § 1, 2-27-2001; Ord. No. 6710, § 1, 2-3-2004; Ord. No. 7022, § 1, 3-1-2007; Ord. No. 7392, § 1, 2-27-2013; Ord. No. 7587, § 1, 3-8-2016; Ord. No. 7775, § 1, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 10-3-72. - Offenses. 
(a)  A minor commits an offense if he remains in any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the City during curfew hours. 
(b)  A parent or guardian of a minor commits an offense if he knowingly permits, or by insufficient control allows, the minor to remain in any public place or on the premises of any establishment within the City during curfew hours. 
(c)  The owner, operator, or any employee of an establishment commits an offense if he knowingly allows a minor to remain upon the premises of the establishment during curfew hours. 
(Ord. No. 6131, § 1, 2-21-95; Ord. No. 6222, § 1, 3-19-96; Ord. No. 6516, § 1, 2-27-2001; Ord. No. 6710, § 1, 2-3-2004; Ord. No. 7022, § 1, 3-1-2007; Ord. No. 7392, § 1, 2-27-2013; Ord. No. 7587, § 1, 3-8-2016; Ord. No. 7775, § 1, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 10-3-73. - Defenses. 
(a)  It is a defense to prosecution under Offenses that the minor was: 
(1)  accompanied by the minor's parent or guardian; 
(2)  on an errand at the direction of the minor's parent or guardian, without any detour or stop; 
(3)  in a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel; 
(4)  engaged in an employment activity, or going to or returning home from an employment activity, without any detour or stop; 
(5)  involved in an emergency; 
(6)  on the sidewalk abutting the minor's residence or abutting the residence of a next door neighbor if the neighbor did not complain to the Police Department about the minor's presence; 
(7)  attending an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by the City of Amarillo, a civic organization, or another similar entity that has undertaken responsibility for the minor, or going to or returning home from such activity, without any detour or stop. 
(8)  exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and the right of assembly; or 
(9)  married or had been married or had disabilities of minority removed in accordance with Chapter 31 of the Texas Family Code. 
(b)  It is a defense to prosecution under Section 10-3-72-(C) that the owner, operator, or employee of an establishment promptly notified the Police Department that a minor was present on the premises of the establishment during curfew hours and refused to leave. 
(Ord. No. 6131, § 1, 2-21-95; Ord. No. 6222, § 1, 3-19-96; Ord. No. 6516, § 1, 2-27-2001; Ord. No. 6710, § 1, 2-3-2004; Ord. No. 7022, § 1, 3-1-2007; Ord. No. 7392, § 1, 2-27-2013; Ord. No. 7587, § 1, 3-8-2016; Ord. No. 7775, § 1, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 10-3-74. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Before taking any enforcement action under this Section, a police officer shall ask the apparent offender's age and reason for being in the public place. The officer shall not issue a citation or make an arrest under this Section unless the officer reasonably believes that an offense has occurred and that, based on any response and other circumstances, no defense in Section 10-3-73 is present. 
(Ord. No. 6131, § 1, 2-21-95; Ord. No. 6222, § 1, 3-19-96; Ord. No. 6516, § 1, 2-27-2001; Ord. No. 6710, § 1, 2-3-2004; Ord. No. 7022, § 1, 3-1-2007; Ord. No. 7392, § 1, 2-27-2013; Ord. No. 7587, § 1, 3-8-2016; Ord. No. 7775, § 1, 3-5-2019) 
Sec. 10-3-75. - Penalties. 
(a)  A person who violates a provision of this Chapter is guilty of a separate offense for each day or part of a day during which the violation is committed, continued, or permitted. Each offense, upon conviction, is punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(b)  When required by Section 51.08 of the Texas Family Code, as amended, the Municipal Court shall waive original jurisdiction over a minor who violates Section 10-3-72-(A) and shall refer the minor to juvenile court. 
(Ord. No. 6131, § 1, 2-21-95; Ord. No. 6222, § 1, 3-19-96; Ord. No. 6516, § 1, 2-27-2001; Ord. No. 6710, § 1, 2-3-2004; Ord. No. 7022, § 1, 3-1-2007; Ord. No. 7392, § 1, 2-27-2013; Ord. No. 7587, § 1, 3-8-2016; Ord. No. 7775, § 1, 3-5-2019) 
Secs. 10-3-76-10-3-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - NON-CONSENSUAL TOWING OF MOTOR VEHICLE 
DIVISION 1. - FROM PRIVATE PROPERTY 

Sec. 10-3-100. - Purpose and authority. 
    This article is enacted pursuant to Texas Occupations Code Section 2308.208 and the general police powers of a home-rule municipality. The purpose of this Division is: 
(1)  To assure the rights: of property owners to have unattended and unwanted motor vehicles removed from their property; of towing companies to collect a fair fee for service; and, of vehicle owners to receive fair notice of restricted parking and the expeditious recovery of their vehicle for a fair fee; 
(2)  To assure prompt processing and reporting of non-consent tows by towing companies and vehicle storage facilities, so that police resources are not economically burdened by unfounded reports of stolen cars; 
(3)  To prevent theft of vehicles by an unscrupulous towing company or property owner, and to promote quicker determination that a vehicle has indeed been stolen; and, 
(4)  This Division does not include or regulate non-consent tows initiated by a city police or code enforcement officer. 
(Ord. No. 6627, § 2, 10-15-2002; Ord. No. 7270, § 1, 3-8-2011) 
Sec. 10-3-101. - Definitions. 
    In this Division, words and phrases generally have their ordinary meaning or as may be assigned elsewhere in this Code of Ordinances. However, in this Division, the following words and phrases have the meaning indicated here: 
(a)  "Drop Fee" means the fee charged instead of a towing fee that allows a vehicle owner or operator to stop the tow at any time after the vehicle has been partially or wholly lifted from the ground, tilted, or in any way otherwise moved by the person operating the tow truck and before the vehicle has been removed from the parking facility or other private property. 
(b)  "Non-consent tow" or "Non-consensual towing" means the towing of a motor vehicle from a parking facility or other private property without the consent of the owner or operator of the vehicle. 
(c)  "Parking Facility" means public or private property used, in whole or in part, for either restricted or paid vehicle parking. The term includes: 
(1)  A restricted space on a portion of an otherwise unrestricted parking facility. 
(2)  A commercial parking lot, a parking garage, and a parking area serving or adjacent to a business, church, school, home, apartment complex, property governed by a property owner's association, or government-owned property leased to a private person. 
(3)  A portion of the right-of-way of a public roadway that is leased by a governmental entity to the parking facility owner. 
(4)  The area between the facility's property line abutting a public roadway or alley and the curb of the roadway or the centerline of the roadway's drainage-way, whichever is farther from the facility's property line. 
(d)  "Parking facility owner" means the owner or operator of a parking facility, including a lessee, employee, or agent of the owner. 
(e)  "Towing company" means a person operating a tow truck registered under Chapter 643, Texas Transportation Code and otherwise in compliance with all applicable Texas statutes and administrative regulations. The term includes each owner, operator, employee, agent, subcontractor, or borrowed servant of a towing company, but does not include a political subdivision of the State. 
(f)  "Unauthorized vehicle" means a vehicle parked, stored, or located on a parking facility without the consent of the parking facility owner. 
(g)  "Vehicle" means a device in, on, or by which persons or cargo may be transported upon a public roadway. The term includes an operable or inoperable automobile, truck, motorcycle, recreational vehicle, bus, or trailer. The term does not include a device designed to be propelled by human power. 
(h)  "Vehicle storage facility" means a facility operated by a person licensed under Texas Occupations Code, Chapter 2303. 
(Ord. No. 6627, § 2, 10-15-2002; Ord. No. 7270, § 1, 3-8-2011) 
Sec. 10-3-102. - Removal of certain vehicles prohibited. 
    A person commits an offense if he intentionally or knowingly removes or causes the removal of a vehicle from private property, unless it is an unauthorized vehicle or illegally parked vehicle, or at the direction of a police officer, fire marshal, animal control officer, or code enforcement officer. 
(Ord. No. 6627, § 2, 10-15-2002; Ord. No. 6861, § 3, 10-18-2005) 
Sec. 10-3-103. - Financial interests of private property owner and towing company prohibited. 
(a)  It is an offense for a towing company to: 
(1)  Directly or indirectly give anything of value, other than a sign or notice required to be posted under this chapter, to a parking facility owner in connection with the removal of a vehicle from the private property; or 
(2)  Have a direct or indirect monetary interest in private property from which the towing company removes an unauthorized vehicle for compensation. 
(b)  It is an offense for an owner of private property to: 
(1)  Accept anything of value, other than a sign or notice required to be posted under this chapter, from a towing company, in connection with the removal of a vehicle from the private property; or 
(2)  Have a direct or indirect monetary interest in a towing company that for a fee removes an unauthorized vehicle from the private property. 
(c)  It is a defense to prosecution under subsections (a)(2) and (b)(2) that the private property from which the vehicle is removed is a vehicle storage facility licensed under the Texas Vehicle Storage Facility Act. 
(Ord. No. 6627, § 2, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 10-3-104. - Requirements for posting signs. 
(a)  It is an offense for a person to remove or cause the removal of a vehicle from private property without signs being posted and maintained on the private property in accordance with this section for at least the twenty-four (24) hours prior to the non-consensual towing and at the time of towing. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if, on the same private property, he posts or allows the posting of a sign or signs indicating the name of more than one (1) towing company or the name, address, or telephone number of more than one (1) vehicle storage facility. 
(c)  A person commits an offense if he removes or obstructs, or allows the removal or obstruction of, a sign required by this section. It is a defense to prosecution that the removal or obstruction was caused by: 
(1)  A city employee in the performance of official duties; or 
(2)  The parking facility owner or the authorized towing company, for the purpose of repairing or maintaining the sign, or upon terminating a towing service agreement for the private property. 
(d)  A minor variation of a required or minimum height of a sign or lettering is not a violation of this chapter. 
(e)  It is a defense to prosecution under subsection (a) of this section that: 
(1)  Before the vehicle was removed, the property owner provided the owner or operator of the vehicle with notice complying with Section 2308.252 of the Texas Occupations Code, and the towing company received written verification from the property owner that the required notice was given; or 
(2)  The vehicle was removed by or under the direction of a police officer, fire marshal, animal control officer, or code enforcement officer. 
(Ord. No. 6627, § 2, 10-15-2002; Ord. No. 6861, § 4, 10-18-2005; Ord. No. 7270, § 1, 3-8-2011) 
Sec. 10-3-105. - Authorization for removal. 
    A person commits an offense if he removes or causes the removal of a vehicle from private property unless, at the time the vehicle is removed there is either: 
(1)  A written authorization for the removal of the particular vehicle by the towing company. 
A written authorization under this subsection must contain: 
a.  A description of the particular vehicle to be removed, including the year, make, model, color, state license plate number, and vehicle identification number of the vehicle; 
b.  The date and time of the vehicle's removal; 
c.  The location from which the vehicle is removed; 
d.  The reasons for removing the vehicle; and 
e.  The signature of the parking facility owner; or 
(2)  A current written agreement between the parking facility owner and the towing company which authorizes removal of illegally parked or unauthorized vehicles from the property, and a photograph is taken reasonably showing that the removed vehicle was unauthorized or illegally parked on the property. A written agreement under this subsection must: 
a.  Contain a clear statement as to whether the towing company is authorized to remove illegally parked and unauthorized vehicles from the property twenty-four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week or only during the normal business hours of the property owner; and 
b.  Be signed and dated by the parking facility owner, operator, or authorized agent. 
c.  Be renewed at least every two (2) years or whenever there is a change in ownership of the towing company or the parking facility, whichever occurs earlier. 
(Ord. No. 6627, § 2, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 10-3-106. - Release of a vehicle prior to removal. 
    A towing company, and the individual operating the tow truck, commits an offense if it or any one of them fails to immediately release a vehicle without charge to the vehicle owner or operator, or to the parking facility owner, if the release is requested before the vehicle has been partially or wholly lifted from the ground, tilted, or in any way otherwise moved by the person operating the tow truck. 
(Ord. No. 6627, § 2, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 10-3-107. - Removal of a vehicle with a wrecker. 
(a)  A parking facility owner commits an offense by causing a non-consent tow of a vehicle by means other than a properly equipped and licensed wrecker. 
(b)  A towing company, and the individual operating the wrecker, commits an offense by removing a vehicle from a parking facility without: 
(1)  Using a properly sized and equipped wrecker, or 
(2)  First completing every procedure required to secure the vehicle to the wrecker or wrecker equipment, including the attachment of any safety chains, so that the vehicle may be safely removed from private property and onto a public roadway. 
(Ord. No. 6627, § 2, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 10-3-108. - Notification of police department. 
(a)  It is an offense for a towing company to fail or refuse to notify the police department within one (1) hour after the removal of each vehicle from any private property. 
(b)  When notifying the police department, the towing company shall provide the following information: 
(1)  The trade name of the towing company; 
(2)  The location from which the vehicle was removed; 
(3)  The date and time of, and the reason for the removal; 
(4)  A description of the vehicle, including year, make, model, color, state license plate number, and vehicle identification number; and, 
(5)  The name and address of the vehicle storage facility to which the vehicle was taken, if different from the towing company. 
(c)  Upon delivering a vehicle to a vehicle storage facility, the towing company shall provide to the vehicle storage facility a copy of a wrecker slip or ticket containing all of the information required in subsection (b). 
(d)  A vehicle storage facility commits an offense if, within two (2) hours after accepting a non-consent towed vehicle from private property, it fails to report to the police department the information required by subsections (b)(2) through (5) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 6627, § 2, 10-15-2002) 
Sec. 10-3-109. - Notification of vehicle owner. 
(a)  A towing company shall provide the owner or operator of any non-consent towed vehicle with written notice of how and to whom a complaint concerning the vehicle's removal or a violation of this article can be made. The notice must specifically state that the vehicle owner has the right to challenge the legality of the tow under Chapter 2308, Texas Occupations Code, as amended, and describe the process required for the challenge. 
(b)  The notice required by this section must be printed in black type of not less than fourteen (14) points and on white paper. A complete and legible copy of this notice shall be handed to the owner or operator or their agent when he or she appears to inquire of or pay the fees for the release of the vehicle. 
(c)  If the vehicle storage facility is not owned or operated by the towing company which removed the vehicle, then the notice required by this section must be given by the vehicle storage facility as described in subsection (b). 
(Ord. No. 6627, § 2, 10-15-2002; Ord. No. 7270, § 1, 3-8-2011) 
Sec. 10-3-110. - Removal of vehicle to storage facility. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he removes or causes the removal of any vehicle from private property to: 
(1)  Any location other than the vehicle storage facility indicated on the signs posted on the private property; or 
(2)  A vehicle storage facility that: 
a.  Is not currently licensed under the Texas Vehicle Storage Facility Act, or is not in compliance with that act or any rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to that act; or 
b.  Is located outside the City, or is located inside the city but in violation of zoning or building ordinances of the City; or 
c.  Does not have a sign posted conspicuously at its entrance notifying the vehicle owner of the right to challenge the legality of the tow under Chapter 2308, Texas Occupations Code, as amended. 
(b)  It is an offense for a towing company, and the individual operating the tow truck to: 
(1)  Fail to deliver a vehicle from a parking facility to a vehicle storage facility by the most direct and expeditious route; or 
(2)  Stop at another location while transporting such a vehicle to a vehicle storage facility. 
(Ord. No. 6627, § 2, 10-15-2002; Ord. No. 7270, § 1, 3-8-2011) 
Sec. 10-3-111. - Maximum fee schedule. 
(a)  The maximum fee that a towing company may charge for vehicle tow service, regardless of whether a tilt-bed wrecker or a conventional wrecker is used, is: 
(1)  One hundred seventy-five dollars ($175.00) for towing a vehicle with a manufacturer's gross vehicle weight rating of not more than ten thousand (10,000) pounds or a Drop Fee of eighty-seven dollars and fifty cents ($87.50); and 
(2)  Two hundred dollars ($200.00) for towage of a vehicle with a manufacturer's gross vehicle weight rating of more than ten thousand (10,000) pounds but not more than twenty-four thousand nine hundred ninety-nine (24,999) pounds or a Drop Fee of one-hundred dollars ($100.00); and 
(3)  Four hundred fifty dollars ($450.00) for towage of a vehicle with a manufacturer's gross vehicle weight rating of twenty-five thousand (25,000) pounds or more, or a Drop Fee of two hundred twenty-five dollars ($225.00). 
(b)  No additional fee may be charged for linkage of a vehicle prior to a tow or for the use for dollies, go-jacks, or similar equipment. 
(c)  No person or company may charge, assess, or collect, or attempt to so do, any fee for vehicle storage, preservation or owner notification that is in excess of that allowed by state law. 
(d)  If a towing company tows a stolen vehicle, or a vehicle later determined to be stolen, the towing company may charge the lawful owner of the vehicle no more than the maximum fee for towage. Neither a towing company nor vehicle storage facility shall charge any fee to the police department if the police department takes custody of a stolen vehicle or a vehicle to be processed for evidence in connection with any felony crime, which was non-consensually towed from private property. 
(e)  A towing company, vehicle storage facility, and each individual involved commits an offense if it charges or attempts to charge: 
(1)  More than the maximum fee allowed by this section for the particular vehicle towed; or 
(2)  A storage, preservation, or notification fee in excess of that allowed under the state Vehicle Storage Facility Act, as amended. 
(f)  A towing company and vehicle storage facility shall provide a vehicle owner or operator the option of paying assessed fees by cash or a major credit card. 
(g)  The maximum fees set out in (a) above reflect the fair value of towing services. Towing fees may be reviewed by the City Council once bi-annually upon written request of a tow company which operates within the Amarillo City Limits. A towing fee study shall be performed in conjunction with this review. Based on the results of the City Council review, the towing fees set out in (a) above shall be changed by resolution of the City Council to reflect the current fair value of towing services. 
(Ord. No. 6627, § 2, 10-15-2002; Ord. No. 6861, § 2, 10-18-2005; Ord. No. 7270, § 1, 3-8-2011; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 10-3-112. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The police department shall receive and investigate complaints of alleged violations of this Division. 
(b)  A police officer upon observing a violation of this Division shall take necessary enforcement action to insure effective regulation of non-consent towing of vehicle and related storage of same. 
(c)  The City Attorney is authorized to pursue all available civil remedies, including injunctive relief, against any private property owner, parking facility owner, towing company, vehicle storage facility, or other person that fails or refuses to comply with this Division. 
(Ord. No. 6627, § 2, 10-15-2002; Ord. No. 7270, § 1, 3-8-2011) 
Sec. 10-3-113. - Offenses. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he violates a provision of this chapter (excluding provisions of Article VII, Division 2). A culpable mental state is not required for commission of an offense under this chapter unless the provision defining the conduct expressly requires a culpable mental state. A separate offense is committed each day in which an offense occurs. A separate offense occurs for each vehicle towed in violation of any provision of this Article VII, Division 1. An offense committed under this chapter is punishable by a fine of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). The minimum fine established in this subsection shall be doubled for the second conviction of the same offense within any 24-month period and trebled for the third and subsequent convictions of the same offense within any 24-month period. At no time shall the minimum fine exceed the maximum fine established in this subsection. 
(b)  Prosecution for an offense under subsection (a) does not prevent the use of civil enforcement remedies or procedures as to the person charged with the conduct involved in the offense. 
(Ord. No. 6627, § 2, 10-15-2002; Ord. No. 7270, § 1, 3-8-2011) 
Secs. 10-3-114, 10-3-115. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - POLICE DEPARTMENT ROTATION LOG CONTRACT 

Sec. 10-3-116. - Participation, Maximum fee schedule and Terms. 
(a)  Application for participation on the City of Amarillo Police Department's Rotation Contract will be limited to August 1 to August 15 (excluding weekends) of each year unless two or more tow companies participating on the Rotation Contract cease participation during any contract year in which case the City of Amarillo may, but is not required to, open applications to replace the lost participants. 
(b)  The maximum fee that a towing company may charge for vehicle tow services under the Rotation Contract is: 
(1)  For a vehicle with a manufacturer's gross vehicle weight rating of not more than ten thousand (10,000) pounds (i) one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) if the vehicle was involved in an accident and (ii) one hundred thirty-five dollars ($135.00) if the vehicle was not involved in an accident. 
(2)  For all other tows, other than tows of City owned vehicles, the maximum fee is the rate posted by the towing company with the Texas Department of Licensing and Regulation. 
(3)  Additional fees may be charged in accordance with the Rotation Contract. 
(c)  All other terms, conditions, and duties shall be as specified by the annual Rotation Contract, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 7270, § 1, 3-8-2011; Ord. No. 7606, § 1, 7-12-2016) 
CHAPTER 10-4. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[1] 
  
Art. I. In General, §§ 10-4-1-10-4-20 Art. II. Unclaimed Property, §§ 10-4-21-10-4-30 Art. III. Police Department Fees, §§ 10-4-31-10-4-35  
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Police department authorized, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 341.003; police training and qualifications, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 341.003; civil service for police, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 143.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-4-1. - Created. 
    There is hereby created and established a Police Department of the City. 
(Code 1960, § 18-1; Ord. No. 5605, § 1, 6-17-86) 
Sec. 10-4-2. - Composition. 
    The Police Department shall be composed of a Chief of Police and such other personnel as the City Council may from time to time deem necessary and proper. 
(Code 1960, § 18-2; Ord. No. 5605, § 1, 6-17-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 10-4-3. - Substitute chief of police. 
(a)  During the absence, sickness or inability to act on the part of the Chief of Police, the Assistant Chief of Police is hereby designated to act as Chief of Police during any such period of absence, sickness or inability to act and the Assistant Chief of Police shall exercise all rights, powers and perform all duties of the Chief of Police during such period. 
(b)  During the absence, sickness or inability to act on the part of both the Chief of Police and the Assistant Chief of Police, the City Manager shall designate some other member of the Police Department as acting Chief of Police during the period of such absence, sickness or inability to act, and such person shall exercise all rights, powers and perform all duties of the Chief of Police during such period. 
(Code 1960, § 18-4; Ord. No. 5605, § 1, 6-17-86) 
Sec. 10-4-4. - Compensation; oath. 
(a)  The compensation of the members of the Police Department shall be by salaries payable in a sum to be fixed by the City Council, subject to change from time to time at the discretion of the City Council. 
(b)  The members of the Police Department shall take and subscribe to the oath of office prescribed by the constitution of the State for county officials. 
(c)  A sworn police officer below and not including the rank of sergeant working as a dispatcher for the police department shall receive assignment pay for such duty in addition to a regular salary for the position occupied by such officer. Assignment pay shall be based on the years of experience as a dispatcher. An officer with ten (10) or more years' experience shall receive three hundred dollars ($300.00) per month, and an officer with between two (2) and ten (10) years' experience shall receive two hundred dollars ($200.00) per month. 
(Code 1960, § 18-5; Ord. No. 5605, § 1, 6-17-86; Ord. No. 5659, § 1, 12-30-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 10-4-5. - Chief of police-Appointment. 
    The Chief of Police shall be appointed by the City Manager, with the advice and consent of the City Council, and shall hold his office at the will of the City Manager. 
(Code 1960, § 18-3; Ord. No. 5605, § 1, 6-17-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 10-4-6. - Same-Supervision of department. 
    The Chief of Police shall be the chief police officer of the City, shall have supervision, subordinate to that of the City Manager, over the other members of the Police Department. 
(Code 1960, § 18-6; Ord. No. 5605, § 1, 6-17-86) 
Sec. 10-4-7. - Same-Authority re prevention of crime, arrests. 
    In the prevention and suppression of crime and the arrest of offenders within the City the Chief of Police shall have like power, authority and jurisdiction of a peace officer under the laws of the state. 
(Code 1960, § 18-7; Ord. No. 5605, § 1, 6-17-86) 
Sec. 10-4-8. - Accepting bail. 
    The Chief of Police shall have authority to take suitable and sufficient bail for the appearance before the Municipal Court of any person charged with an offense within the jurisdiction of the Court. 
(Code 1960, § 18-8; Ord. No. 5605, § 1, 6-17-86) 
Sec. 10-4-9. - Execution of writs. 
    The Chief of Police and other members of the Police Department may execute writs issued out of the Municipal Court. 
(Code 1960, § 18-9; Ord. No. 5605, § 1, 6-17-86) 
Sec. 10-4-10. - Issuance of notice to appear. 
(a)  Whenever a person is arrested for any violation of law punishable by a fine within the jurisdiction of the Municipal Court of the City, the arresting officer may prepare a written notice to appear which shall require the person to appear in Municipal Court within ten (10) days to answer the charges listed and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name of person arrested; 
(2)  Address of person arrested; 
(3)  Driver's license or other identification. 
(b)  The following information may be included for informational purposes, but shall not nullify any promise to appear: 
(1)  Date of violation; 
(2)  Place of violation; 
(3)  Offense charge; 
(4)  Name of arresting officer. 
This section shall not preclude the filing of any additional charges or different charges. 
(c)  The above notice to appear shall only be a promise to appear, and is not an admission of guilt. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for the arrested person to violate his written notice to appear in Municipal Court, regardless of the disposition of the charges upon which he was originally arrested. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person upon being issued a notice to appear to give the arresting officer other than his true name and correct address. 
(f)  The above procedure shall not be applicable when: 
(1)  The person arrested demands to be taken before a magistrate without unnecessary delay. 
(2)  The arrested person shall refuse to sign the notice to appear or furnish any of the information in subsection (a). 
(3)  The offense is a violation of the traffic laws or is covered by a specific provision of state law dictating the following of a procedure different from the above subsections. 
(g)  The above procedures in subsections (a) and (b) shall not be mandatory upon the arresting officer. The arresting officer shall have authority to consider all the circumstances relevant to the arrest and any Police Department regulations or policies in choosing whether or not to issue a notice to appear. 
(Code 1960, § 18-10; Ord. No. 5605, § 1, 6-17-86) 
Sec. 10-4-11. - Quelling riots, taking persons into custody. 
    The Chief of Police and all police officers shall be active in quelling riots, disorders and disturbances of the peace within the limits of the City. They shall take into custody all persons offending the public peace. 
(Code 1960, § 18-11; Ord. No. 5605, § 1, 6-17-86) 
Secs. 10-4-12-10-4-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - UNCLAIMED PROPERTY 

Sec. 10-4-21. - Custody of chief of police. 
    All property which may be left abandoned on the Streets of the City as well as all property which may come into the possession of the City by coming into the possession either of the Police Department or the other departments of the City belonging to persons unknown, shall be preserved, protected, stored and retained by the Chief of Police. 
(Code 1960, § 18-12; Ord. No. 5605, § 1, 6-17-86) 
Sec. 10-4-22. - Records. 
    The time and occasion of the acquisition of the property shall be carefully kept in a record book kept by the Chief of Police reflecting the description and manner of acquisition, as well as the manner of preservation, storage and ultimate disposition of the property of the proceeds therefrom. 
(Code 1960, § 18-13; Ord. No. 5605, § 1, 6-17-86) 
Sec. 10-4-23. - Public sale-Authorized; waiting period; date. 
(a)  If property belonging to persons unknown remains preserved, stored and unclaimed for a period of three (3) months, a public sale of such unclaimed property shall be held by the Police Department at the annual regular public sale date. 
(b)  The Chief of Police is hereby authorized to fix the date of the annual public sale. 
(c)  The Chief of Police may withhold from sale property which remains unclaimed after three (3) months and which could be placed into beneficial use by the Police Department. 
(Code 1960, § 18-14; Ord. No. 5605, § 1, 6-17-86) 
Sec. 10-4-24. - Same-Public notice. 
(a)  Before the public sale of unclaimed articles authorized in this article shall be held, a public notice shall be given for thirty (30) days. 
(b)  The public notice shall show the time and place of the sale and contain a brief description of the property and articles giving the nature and names of the articles to be sold. 
(c)  A copy of the public notice shall be posted at a public place in the Police Department and at the court house for at least thirty (30) days prior to date of the public sale. 
(d)  A copy of the public notice shall also be published one (1) time in a newspaper of general circulation in the City thirty (30) days prior to the date of public sale. 
(Code 1960, § 18-15; Ord. No. 5605, § 1, 6-17-86) 
Sec. 10-4-25. - Same-Sales to highest responsible bidder. 
    All sales of unclaimed property as authorized in this article shall be made to the highest responsible bidder. 
(Code 1960, § 18-16; Ord. No. 5605, § 1, 6-17-86) 
Sec. 10-4-26. - Same-Disposition of Proceeds. 
(a)  The proceeds of the sale of the unclaimed property shall be turned over by the Chief of Police to the City Auditor, together with his notations of the costs of the storage and preservation of the property. 
(b)  After the expiration of three (3) months subsequent to the date of the public sale, the City Auditor shall place the proceeds in the general fund of the City. 
(Code 1960, § 18-17; Ord. No. 5605, § 1, 6-17-86) 
Sec. 10-4-27. - Redemption by owner. 
(a)  If the rightful owner claims the property prior to the expiration of three (3) months from the date of acquisition by the Police Department, the property shall be returned to him upon his payment to the City Auditor of a sum of money equal to the costs of the preservation and storage of the property. 
(b)  If the rightful owner appears subsequent to the public sale and prior to the expiration of three (3) months after the public sale, the rightful owner shall be entitled to the proceeds of the sale, less the cost of the preservation and storage of the property. 
(c)  If a rightful owner shall claim the property for the first time after three (3) months have expired after date of the public sale, he shall have no claim whatsoever against the city. 
(Code 1960, § 18-18; Ord. No. 5605, § 1, 6-17-86) 
Secs. 10-4-28-10-4-30. - Reserved.

CHAPTER 12-2. - ADMINISTRATION 
  

Sec. 12-2-1. - Director of parks and recreation-Office created; appointment; term. 
(a)  The office of Director of Parks and Recreation is hereby created. 
(b)  The Director of Parks and Recreation shall be appointed by the City Manager, with the advice and consent of the City Council, and shall hold his office at the will of the City Manager. 
(Code 1960, § 15-1; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 12-2-2. - Same-Duties. 
    The Director of Parks and Recreation shall do and perform any and all duties directed by the City Manager and such other duties as may properly pertain to managing the public parks and recreation system or as may be prescribed by this Code. 
(Code 1960, § 15-2; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86) 
CHAPTER 12-3. - MUNICIPAL SWIMMING POOLS 

Sec. 12-3-1. - Part of the public park system. 
    The municipal swimming pools of the City are part of the public parks and recreation system and shall be subject to the rules and regulations provided by ordinance or resolution by the City Council or prescribed by the City Manager with the approval of the City Council. 
(Code 1960, § 15-3; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 12-3-2. - Prohibited items. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person entering on the Premises of any municipal swimming pool to carry thereon, use, or to exhibit thereon any beer or intoxicating liquor, glass containers, or tobacco products. 
(Code 1960, § 15-4; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86; Ord. No. 6868, § 1, 11-15-2005) 
Sec. 12-3-3. - Employees to eject violators. 
    Employees of the City engaged to assist in the maintenance and operation of any municipal swimming pool shall promptly eject any person violating an ordinance or violating any other rule or regulation prescribed by the City Manager or the City Council governing the maintenance and operation of the pool. 
(Code 1960, § 15-5; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017)

CHAPTER 12-4. - MUNICIPAL GOLF COURSES 
  

Sec. 12-4-1. - Part of parks and recreation system. 
    The premises of municipal golf courses are hereby declared to be public Premises and a part of the public parks and recreation system of the City. References herein to the golf course shall mean the Ross Rogers Municipal Golf Course or any other golf course the City may operate. 
(Code 1960, § 15-6; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86) 
Sec. 12-4-2. - Manager; appointment and duties. 
(a)  The City Manager, by and with the consent of the City Council, may appoint a Golf Course Manager who shall be an independent contractor, and who may hold the contractual right to operate golf course concessions including golf carts, merchandise, driving range, food and beverage, and other concessions as may be stipulated by contract. 
(b)  The Golf Course Manager shall have general charge and supervision of all golf playing and the use of golf course facilities, subject at all times to general supervision by the City. 
(Code 1960, § 15-7; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 12-4-3. - Workers employed by city; exceptions. 
    The City shall employ all workers required for the proper maintenance of each golf course and the maintenance and operation of each clubhouse, except such portions of such operations of each clubhouse as may be specifically placed under the care and responsibility of the Golf Course Manager. 
(Code 1960, § 15-8; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86; Ord. No. 7688, § 21, 9-12-2017) 
Sec. 12-4-4. - Annual pass. 
    The Golf Course Manager shall issue annual golf course playing passes at rates and with conditions as stated in Section 12-4-5 of this Code. 
(Code 1960, § 15-9; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86; Ord. No. 6847, § 10, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 7238, § 13, 9-14-2010; Ord. No. 7688, § 21, 9-12-2017)

Sec. 12-4-6. - United States Golf Association rules. 
    The general rules prescribed by the United States Golf Association shall be applicable to all persons playing golf upon each golf course. 
(Code 1960, § 15-11; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86) 
Sec. 12-4-7. - Tournaments; exclusion of non-participants. 
(a)  Promotion; City consent. The Golf Course Manager, with the consent of the City Manager, shall be privileged to promote golf tournaments. 
(b)  Limiting use of course to contestants. During golf tournaments all persons not participating in the tournament may be prohibited from playing golf upon the course by the Golf Course Manager. 
(Code 1960, § 15-12; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86) 
Sec. 12-4-8. - Violators; interference with players; ejection. 
(a)  Wilful interference. It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully interfere with others playing upon the golf course or enjoying facilities in connection therewith. 
(b)  Ejection. Any person who, after warning, persists in the violation of any rule or regulation pertaining to the operation of the golf course, or who violates any of the provisions of this chapter, may be ejected and excluded therefrom by the Golf Course Manager. 
(Code 1960, § 15-13; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86) 
Sec. 12-4-9. - Free passes and privileges; special occasions. 
(a)  The issuance of any free passes or free privileges for the playing of golf on the golf course is prohibited, except as may be authorized by this section or section 12-4-5. 
(b)  With the consent of the City Manager, the Director of Parks and Recreation Division may authorize the temporary reduction or remission of green fees or portions thereof, and otherwise offer discounts, incentives, or promotions intended to encourage increased play on each course. 
(Code 1960, § 15-14; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86; Ord. No. 7332, § 2, 5-8-2012) 
Sec. 12-4-10. - Golf Carts. 
    The use of privately owned golf carts not provided by the Golf Course Manager is prohibited on the golf course. 
(Code 1960, § 15-15; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86) 
CHAPTER 12-5. - DISEASED OR INFESTED VEGETATION ON PRIVATE PROPERTY[1] 
  

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to define and prohibit nuisances, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 217.042. 

Sec. 12-5-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter the following terms shall be construed to have the following meanings: 
    Infected With Disease: Any Tree, shrub or plant possessing a disease such as virus, Dutch elm disease, chestnut blight, cotton root rot and other similar organisms to such an extent as to render timely, recognized, standard control measures or treatment ineffective. 
    Infested With Insects: Any Tree, shrub or plant which has been attacked by insects to such an extent as to render timely, recognized, standard control measures ineffective. 
(Code 1960, § 15-16; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86) 
Cross reference- Definitions to apply throughout Code, § 1-2-1. 
Sec. 12-5-2. - Diseased vegetation a public nuisance. 
    Every person owning, leasing, possessing or controlling any private property within the City limits shall preserve any Tree, shrub or plant thereon in such manner as to prevent it from becoming Infested With Insects or Infected With Disease. Any Tree, shrub or plant which is or may become Infested with Insects or Infected With Disease is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. 
(Code 1960, § 15-17; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86) 
Sec. 12-5-3. - Right to enter property; duty to condemn vegetation. 
(a)  Inspections on private property. The Director of Parks and Recreation is hereby authorized to enter upon private property, during reasonable daylight hours, for the purpose of examining and, after examination, either approving, requiring treatment or condemning any Tree, shrub or plant located thereon. However, he shall not enter upon private property unless he has reason to believe that there is upon such private property a Tree, shrub or plant Infested With Insects or Infected With Disease. If the Director of Parks and Recreation is denied the right to inspect such vegetation, he may obtain an administrative Search Warrant. 
(b)  Conditions requiring condemnation. The Director of Parks and Recreation is required and authorized to condemn any Tree, shrub or plant which he may find upon inspection to be either Infested With Insects or Infected With Disease. 
(Code 1960, § 15-18; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86) 
Sec. 12-5-4. - Notice to treat. 
    If the Director of Parks and Recreation finds some Tree, shrub or plant on private property which is attacked with insects or possessed of disease, or both, but not to an extent that it cannot be cured or controlled by timely, recognized, standard treatment and control measures, the Director of Parks and Recreation shall give written notice to the person owning, leasing or controlling the Tree, shrub or plant so affected. Thereupon, it shall be the duty of the owner, possessor or person in control, either or all, to take timely, curative, standard and recognized control measures as are necessary to control the disease or infestation. 
(Code 1960, § 15-19; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86) 
Sec. 12-5-5. - Notice to destroy; time and method of disposal. 
(a)  The Director of Parks and Recreation shall give notice in writing to the owner or person in possession, either or both, of private property upon which the Director of Parks and Recreation may have condemned a Tree, shrub or plant, in the form of a notice of condemnation of a particular Tree, shrub or plant. The Director of Parks and Recreation shall specify the Tree, shrub or plant that is condemned in the written notice, together with a statement indicating whether the Tree, shrub or plant was condemned by reason of being Infested With Insects or Infected With Disease. 
(b)  Upon receipt of notice of condemnation, the owner or possessor of the private property shall, within ten (10) days from the receipt of the notice of condemnation, dig up the condemned Tree, shrub or plant and destroy the Tree, shrub or plant by removing it to the City disposal grounds. 
(c)  No person shall permit any condemned Tree, shrub or plant to remain on any parkway, Street or Alley abutting the private property which he owns or controls for more than ten (10) days after the date of the receipt of notice of condemnation. 
(Code 1960, § 15-20; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86) 
Sec. 12-5-6. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any owner having an objection to an order requiring him to destroy Trees or vegetation may appeal from the order to the City Parks and Recreation Commission at any time within ten (10) days from the date of service of notice upon him. 
(b)  Notice in writing of the appeal must be filed with the City Secretary and the filing thereof shall act as a stay of proceedings until the appeal has been heard and determined by the Parks and Recreation Commission. 
(Code 1960, § 15-21; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86) 
CHAPTER 12-6. - PARK MEDIANS AND ISLANDS 
  

Sec. 12-6-1. - Wilful interference. 
    No person shall, by any act done wilfully and purposely prevent, delay or interfere with the Director of Parks and Recreation, or any person working under his direction, in the planting, pruning, spraying or removing of a Tree, shrub or flower from the parks or landscaped medians or islands, or in the removal of stone, cement or other substances. 
(Code 1960, § 15-22; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86) 
Sec. 12-6-2. - Planting; approval required. 
    No shade Tree, shrub or flower shall be planted in any park median or island of the City until the Director of Parks and Recreation has approved the plant and the place where it is to be planted and until he has given written permission. 
(Code 1960, § 15-23; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86) 
Sec. 12-6-3. - Placement of stone and cement. 
    No person, without the written permission of the Director of Parks and Recreation, shall place or maintain any stone, cement or other substance upon the ground in a park or landscaped median or island. 
(Code 1960, § 15-24; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86) 
Sec. 12-6-4. - Specific acts prohibited; exception. 
(a)  Pruning, cutting and removing vegetation. No person, without the written permission of the Director of Parks and Recreation, shall cut, prune, break, climb with spurs, injure or remove any living Tree, shrub or flower in a park or landscaped median or island. 
(b)  Attaching signs and fixtures. No person shall place any rope, Sign, poster or other fixture on a Tree or guard in a park or landscaped median or island. 
(c)  Removing protective devices. No person shall injure, misuse or remove any device placed to protect a Tree, shrub or flowers on a park or landscaped median or island except in case of immediate necessity for the protection of the life of such property. 
(d)  Necessary trimming for wire clearance. This section shall not be construed to prohibit the proper and necessary trimming of trees for the reasonable clearance of wires being maintained in, on and over the parks or landscaped medians or islands of the City under the supervision of the Director of Parks and Recreation. 
(Code 1960, § 15-25; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86) 
Sec. 12-6-5. - Electrical wires. 
(a)  Attaching. No person, without the written permission of the Director of Parks and Recreation, shall attach any electric wires, insulator or any device for the holding of an electric wire to any Tree or shrub growing or planted upon any park or landscaped median or island of the City. 
(b)  Disconnection prior to trimming trees. The franchise electric utility may be required to disconnect electrical power for any line running through a park or landscaped median or island until Trees or shrubs have been trimmed away from such line. 
(Code 1960, §§ 15-26, 15-27; Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 4-1-86)
