Editor's note- Ord. No. 6868, § 2, adopted Nov. 15, 2005, amended the former Ch. 12-7, 12-7-1-12-7-8, and enacted a new Ch. 12-7 as set out herein. The former Ch. 12-7 pertained to similar subject matter. For complete derivation see the Code Comparative Table at the end of this volume. 

ARTICLE I. - GENERAL 

Sec. 12-7-1. - Title, captions, delegation. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the Amarillo Parks Conduct ordinance. Section and subsection titles and labels are primarily for convenience but may be used as an aid to interpretation and intent of the subsection. Every reference to the Director of Parks shall include the designee of the Director. 
(Ord. No. 6868, § 2, 11-15-2005) 
Sec. 12-7-2. - Respect for property. 
    No person in a park shall: 
(1)  Buildings and other property. Willfully mark, deface, disfigure, injure, tamper with or displace or remove any Building, bridge, table, bench, fireplace, railing, paving or paving material, water line or other public utility or part or appurtenance thereof, Sign, notice or placard, whether temporary or permanent, monument, stake, post or other boundary marker, or other structure or equipment, facility or park property or appurtenance whatsoever, either real or personal. 
(2)  Restrooms and washrooms. Litter a restroom or washroom or do anything to stop up commodes or lavatories, or deface walls of restrooms or washrooms. 
(3)  Trees, shrubbery, lawns. Remove any Tree or plant, or injure the bark, or pick the flowers or seeds of any Tree or plant: nor attach any rope, wire or other contrivance to any Tree or plant; nor dig in or otherwise disturb grass areas, or in any other way injure or impair the natural beauty or usefulness of any area. 
(4)  Erection or modification of Structures. Construct, modify, or erect any Building or Structure of whatever kind, whether permanent or temporary in character, or run or string any public service utility into, upon, or across such lands, except by a permit issued hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 6868, § 2, 11-15-2005) 
Sec. 12-7-3. - Traffic. 
    No person in a park shall: 
(1)  Operation confined to roads. Drive any vehicle on any area except the park roads or parking areas. All streets, drives and parking lots within City parks are hereby designated public ways and all applicable traffic ordinances shall apply. 
(2)  Parking. Park a vehicle on grass or in other than an established or designated parking area, and such use shall be in accordance with posted directions and with the instructions of any attendant who may be present. 
(3)  Self-propelled vehicles. Ride, drive or operate any self-propelled motor-driven vehicle in any City park on other than a regular vehicular road or path designated for that purpose. 
(4)  Temporary traffic areas. The Parks Director is authorized to designate specific areas as temporary roads, driveways, or parking areas, which vehicles may lawfully use as directed. 
(Ord. No. 6868, § 2, 11-15-2005) 
Cross reference- Traffic, Ch. 16-3. 
Sec. 12-7-4. - Behavior. 
    No person in a park shall: 
(1)  Fires. Build or attempt to build a fire except in approved areas and facilities, and under such regulations as may be designated by the Director or other lawful authority. 
(2)  Closed areas. Enter an area posted as "closed" or to use or abet the use of any area in violation of posted notices. 
(3)  Exhibit permits. Fail to produce and exhibit any permit from the Director he claims to have upon request of any person who shall desire to inspect the same for the purpose of determining compliance with any ordinance or rule. 
(4)  Interference with permittees. Disturb or interfere unreasonably with any person or party occupying any area or participating in any activity under authority of a permit. 
(5)  Hunting. Hunt, molest, harm, kill, trap, chase, tease, shoot or throw missiles at any Animal, reptile or bird; remove or have in his possession the young of any Wild Animal, or the eggs or nest or young of any reptile or bird; nor collect, remove, have in his possession, give away, sell or offer to sell, or buy or offer to buy, or accept as a gift any specimen alive or dead of any of the foregoing. Exception is made in that snakes known to be deadly poisonous, such as rattlesnakes, coral snakes, or other deadly reptiles may be killed on sight. 
(6)  Feeding. Give or offer, or attempt to give any animal or bird any tobacco, alcohol, or other known noxious substances. 
(7)  Camping. Set up tents, shacks or any other temporary shelter for the purpose of overnight camping; nor leave in a park after closing hours any movable Structure or, special vehicle to be used or that could be used for such purpose, such as house trailers, camp trailers, camp wagons or the like, unless specifically authorized by the Director. 
(8)  Horseback riding. Ride a horse in or on a designated Hike and Bike Trail, or a city park except on designated bridle trails. Where riding is permitted, horses shall be thoroughly broken and properly restrained and ridden with due care, not allowed to graze or go unattended, nor hitched to any rock, Tree or shrub. 
(9)  Walking dogs. Dogs shall be kept on a leash when a person is walking same in, on, or across any designated walking path, sidewalk, trail or a hike/bike trail. 
(10)  Glass containers. Possess, bring in, or use any glass container in any area of a park or athletic area. 
(11)  Alcohol and tobacco. Consume or use any alcoholic beverage or tobacco product during a game, event, or tournament involving an organized youth sport league or team. 
(Ord. No. 6868, § 2, 11-15-2005; Ord. No. 7070, § 1, 10-2-2007) 
Sec. 12-7-5. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HOURS OF OPERATION 

Sec. 12-7-6. - Park closing hours; special events or tournaments. 
(1)  No person shall enter into, remain in, or use any portion of a park or playground, including streets, parking areas within parks, streets or parking areas adjoining a park without a permit issued by the Director of Parks and Recreation, between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 5:00 a.m., unless otherwise provided in this Article. 
(2)  In addition to the closed hours restrictions stated in subsection (1), no person shall enter into, remain, or use any portion of a skate park facility during the dark hours which are defined as the periods from thirty (30) minutes before sunrise and thirty (30) minutes after sunset as stated by the national Weather Service. Provided however, if the Parks Department installs overhead lighting to illuminate the skate facility, then the hours of operation shall be the same as for the park in which the skate facility is located. 
(3)  Permits for special events or tournaments in parks or playgrounds to allow extended hours of use shall be obtained from the Director of Parks and Recreation in accordance with Article III of this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 6868, § 2, 11-15-2005) 
Sec. 12-7-7. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PERMITS 

Sec. 12-7-8. - Park operating policy; permits. 
(a)  (1)  Required. In order to prevent congestion, to provide maximum use for the comfort and convenience of users, and to otherwise protect the appearance and condition of parks facilities, permits for particular events, tournaments, or other activities may be required. Where this Chapter requires a permit or permission, same shall be applied for, issued, denied, or revoked in accordance with the terms of this Article. 
(2)  Any group, association or organization with fifty (50) or more members desiring to use any park facility for any reason, or any individual or group of any size desiring to use a park beyond normal hours of operation, or any other person required to obtain a permit by other terms of this Chapter, shall first obtain a permit from the Director of Parks and Recreation as follows: 
(b)  Application. A person seeking issuance of a permit hereunder shall file an application with the director. The application shall state: 
(1)  The name and address of applicant; 
(2)  The name and address of the person, corporation or association sponsoring the activity, if any; 
(3)  The day and hours for which the permit is desired; 
(4)  An accurate and truthful description of the activity, event or use for which the permit is sought; 
(5)  The park or portion thereof for which such permit is desired; 
(6)  An estimate of the anticipated attendance; 
(7)  Any other information which the Director shall find reasonably necessary to a fair determination as to whether a permit should be issued hereunder. 
(c)  Fees. Suitable fees to cover the cost of handling a permit or reservation may be charged, as well as fees for the use of various facilities as stated in Chapter 12-1 of this Code. 
(d)  Standards for issuance. The director shall issue a permit hereunder when he finds that: 
(1)  The proposed activity or use of the park will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the general public enjoyment of the park; 
(2)  The proposed activity and use will not unreasonably interfere with or detract from the promotion of public health, welfare, safety and recreation; 
(3)  The proposed activity or use is not reasonably anticipated to incite violence, crime or disorderly conduct; 
(4)  The proposed activity will not entail unusual, extraordinary or burdensome expense or police operation by the City; 
(5)  The facilities desired have not been reserved for other use at the day and hour required in the application. 
(e)  Appeal from denial. Within seven (7) days after receipt of an application the Director shall apprise an applicant in writing of his reasons for refusing a permit, and any aggrieved person shall have the right to appeal in writing within seven (7) days to the Parks and Recreation Commission, which shall consider the application under the standards set forth in subsection (3) hereof and sustain or overrule the Director's decision within seven (7) days. The decision of the Parks and Recreation Commission shall be final. 
(f)  Effect of permit. A permittee shall be bound by all park rules and regulations and all applicable ordinances fully as though the same were inserted in the permits. 
(g)  Liability of permittee. The person to whom a permit is issued shall be liable for any loss, damage or injury sustained by any person whatever by reasons of the negligence of the person to whom such permit shall have been issued. 
(h)  Revocation. The Director shall have the authority to revoke a permit upon finding deceptive, misleading, or incomplete information in the application, for violation of the terms of the permit, for violation of any rule or ordinance, or upon other good cause shown. 
(i)  Special Event. A Special Event shall be defined as an event requiring a permit as set forth in this section that involves a group of two hundred (200) persons or more. A twenty-five dollar ($25.00) processing fee shall be paid and must accompany a application qualifying as a Special Event as defined herein. 
(Ord. No. 6868, § 2, 11-15-2005; Ord. No. 7549, § 7, 9-15-15, eff. 10-1-15) 
Secs. 12-7-9, 12-7-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PARK SPECIFIC REGULATIONS 

Sec. 12-7-11. - Park specific rules. 
    The following rules and regulations shall apply to the specific parks designated. Except as otherwise provided or modified here, all other rules, duties, fees, and procedures, of this Chapter shall apply to the specific parks designated here. The purpose of this section is to provide additional rules or to modify the application of this Chapter to the parks designated in this Article. 
(a)  Amarillo Skate Park. In addition to all other park rules in this Chapter, all persons using the designated skate park facility at John Stiff (Southwest) Park or a designated skate facility constructed by the City in any other park, shall: 
(1)  Use only roller skates, skate boards, or bicycles in or on the facility. 
(2)  Be deemed to know that protective personal equipment (helmet, elbow and knee pads, wrist and ankle protection is strongly recommended at all times. 
(3)  Know your ability and skate accordingly. 
(4)  Use the skate park facility as designed. Modifications to the surface or features are prohibited. 
(5)  Skate or bike only on park structures designed specifically for these purposes. 
(6)  Not have pegs attached on any bicycle; bike pegs are prohibited allowed. 
(7)  Not use any skate park facility when the surface is wet. 
(8)  Not bring into or use any food, beverage, or tobacco products inside a skate park facility. 
(9)  Not bring into, use, or possess any glass beverage containers inside a skate park facility. 
(10)  Not bring into, use, or possess inside the skate park facility any pet, alcohol, drugs, profanity or play loud music. 
(11)  Not engage in reckless behavior. For purposes of this Article, a person acts recklessly with respect to his conduct or the results of his conduct when he is aware of but consciously disregards a substantial or unjustifiable risk of injury to any person or damage to any property. 
(b)  Rick Klein Sports Complex. In addition to all other park rules in this Chapter, all persons, groups, associations and other entities using the Rick Klein Sports Complex shall: 
(1)  Not erect any advertising banner, sign, or panel without a permit issued in accordance with Article III. 
(2)  Not use any playing field or diamond without first obtaining a permit in accordance with Article III. 
(3)  Not possess or use any alcoholic beverage or tobacco products inside the complex. 
(4)  Not bring into, use, or possess any glass beverage container inside the complex. 
(Ord. No. 6868, § 2, 11-15-2005) 
Secs. 12-7-12-12-7-14. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - VIOLATIONS AND REMEDIES 

Sec. 12-7-15. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in accordance with Section 1-1-5 of this Code of 
ordinances. Any such violation shall constitute a separate offense on each successive day continued. 
(b)  The criminal penalty provided in this section is independent of any other civil remedy, penalty, or permit revocation which may be available for any violation or threatened violation of any provision of this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 6868, § 2, 11-15-2005)

CHAPTER 14-2. - TAXATION[1] 
  
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal taxation generally, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 302.021 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-2-1. - Terms construed. 
(a)  Real and personal property. Real and personal property for the purpose of taxation shall be construed to mean and include the same things that are meant and included by such terms under the laws of this State. 
(b)  Monies, credits, other taxation terms. The terms "monies," "credits" and all other words and phrases when used in this chapter relating to taxation shall include the same things and have the same meaning that is given to such words and phrases under the laws of this State relating to taxation. 
(Code 1960, § 22-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions to apply throughout Code, § 1-2-1. 
Sec. 14-2-2. - Collection. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the Tax Assessor/Collector to collect all taxes levied and assessed against personal and real property in the City and any and all other taxes of every kind and character to be collected in favor of the City except fees and payments which are collected by the City Auditor. 
(b)  It shall be a reason for disqualification of any bidder or supplier in a public contract that such bidder or supplier is delinquent in the payment of any tax which inures to the benefit of the City. 
(Code 1960, § 22-8; Ord. No. 5650, § 2, 12 18-86) 
Sec. 14-2-3. - Receipts. 
(a)  Whenever any taxes are paid, the Tax Assessor/Collector or his deputy shall issue a receipt authorized by the Tax Code. 
(b)  Tax receipts shall specify the amount of the City ad valorem tax paid, the year for which such tax was levied and the property description as it appears on the tax roll. 
(Code 1960, § 22-10; Ord. No. 5864, § 1, 6-19-90) 
Sec. 14-2-4. - Telecommunications sales tax. 
(a)  The telecommunications sales tax exemption provided by V.T.C.A., Tax Code, § 312.210 is hereby repealed. 
(b)  There is hereby imposed and levied upon all telecommunications services sold in the City a sales tax at the same rate as is imposed by the City for all other local sales and use taxes authorized by the legislature of the State. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section, the sale of telecommunications services is consummated at the location of the telecommunications device from which the communication originates. 
(d)  If the point of origin cannot be determined then the sale is consummated at the address assigned by the telecommunications company to the telecommunications device. 
(e)  The tax provided for in this section shall not serve as an offset to be in lieu of or in any way reduce any amount payable to the City pursuant to any franchise, Street use ordinance, charter provision, statute or, without limitation by the foregoing enumeration, otherwise payable by any provider of telecommunications service; it being the express intent hereof that all such obligations, impositions and agreements of every kind and nature shall remain in full force and effect without reduction or limitation hereby. 
(Ord. No. 5680, § 1, 5-5-87) 
Secs. 14-2-5-14-2-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AD VALOREM TAXES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Property Tax Code, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 1.01 et seq. 

Sec. 14-2-21. - Annual levy. 
    The City Council shall before October 1, in each year fix by ordinance the annual levy of ad valorem taxes to be issued and collected for such year. 
(Code 1960, § 22-4; Ord. No. 5650, § 1, 12-18-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
State Law reference- Adoption of tax rate, V.T.C.A., Tax Code, § 26.05. 
Sec. 14-2-22. - Tax roll; duplicates. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the City Tax Assessor/Collector to keep and maintain a tax roll, in duplicate, of all real and personal property within the City limits subject to taxation. 
(b)  The City Council shall, upon recommendation of the Tax Assessor/Collector, make all necessary corrections to tax rolls existing for 1981 and prior years. 
(Code 1960, § 22-5; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 14-2-23. - Homestead exemption for persons sixty-five or older. 
(a)  Eight thousand six hundred dollars ($8,600.00) of the market value of residence homesteads of persons sixty-five (65) years of age or older shall be exempt from ad valorem taxes levied by the City including hospital district taxes, from and after January 1, 1978. 
(b)  A person claiming exemption under this section shall file his application for exemption in the manner prescribed by law. 
(c)  The exemption authorized hereby shall extend only to a residence homestead as defined by the laws of the State. 
(Code 1960, § 22-6) 
State Law reference- Homestead exemption authorized, V.C.T.A., Tax Code, § 11.13. 
Sec. 14-2-24. - Disability exemption. 
(a)  Eight thousand six hundred dollars ($8,600.00) of the market value of residence homesteads of disabled persons shall be exempt from ad valorem taxes, levied by the City, including hospital district taxes from and after January, 1981. 
(b)  A person claiming exemption under this section shall file his application for exemption in the manner prescribed by law. 
(c)  The exemption authorized hereby shall extend only to a residence homestead as defined by the laws of the State. 
(Code 1960, § 22-7; Ord. No. 6328, § 1, 12-2-97) 
State Law reference- Disability exemption, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.13. 
Sec. 14-2-25. - When to be paid. 
    It shall be the duty of every person to pay his taxes following the completion of the tax rolls either: 
(1)  Before February 1; or 
(2)  Between October 1, and July 1 if the tax payer has paid half of the taxes imposed on him on or before November 30 in accordance with law. 
(Code 1960, § 22-9) 
State Law reference- Due date of taxes, V.C.T.A., Tax Code § 31.01 et seq. 
Sec. 14-2-26. - Additional penalty; collection costs. 
(a)  Whenever any accounts for delinquent taxes owed the City given to its tax attorney for collection, on or after July 1 of the year they become delinquent, the Tax Assessor/Collector of the City shall be entitled to, and shall collect, an additional penalty of fifteen (15) percent of the delinquent taxes and penalty (including any interest owed) due on each delinquent property at the time of collection, either before or after suit and/or foreclosure sale, as provided by V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 33.07. 
(b)  In addition to the collection expenses provided for in subsection (a) above, the Tax Assessor/Collector shall be entitled to collect the actual expenses incurred by the City in providing all data and information as to the name, identity and location of necessary parties and the legal description of the property necessary to the filing of any suit for delinquent taxes. 
(Code 1960, § 22-11.1) 
Sec. 14-2-27. - List of delinquent taxpayers-When compiled. 
    The Tax Assessor/Collector shall make out, on forms to be furnished by the City Council for that purpose, between April 1 and May 1 of each year, or as soon thereafter as practical, a list of delinquent taxpayers. Such list, however, shall not absolve any taxpayer from the payment of taxes, but it shall be the duty of the Tax Assessor/Collector to use all necessary diligence to collect the amounts due on such lists. 
(Code 1960, § 22-12; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 14-2-28. - Same-Duplicates. 
    Duplicate copies of the delinquent tax list shall be made and the Tax Assessor/Collector shall provide for the retention of same in a safe and secure manner. 
(Code 1960, § 22-13) 
Sec. 14-2-29. - Conditions warranting suit; effect of failing to send or receive notices. 
(a)  The notice required by V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 33.04 shall also state that unless the owner of the property described therein shall pay the Tax Assessor/Collector the amount of taxes, interest, penalties and costs set forth in the notice within thirty (30) days from the date of notice, suit may be instituted for the collection of such monies and for the foreclosure of the lien against such property or such other remedies as the Tax Assessor/Collector may deem appropriate. 
(b)  Failure to send or receive the notice as required hereinabove shall be no defense to a suit brought for taxes. 
(Code 1960, § 22-15) 
Sec. 14-2-30. - Lien by operation of law; duration; priority. 
(a)  Municipal taxes due the City shall constitute a lien, charge and incumbrance upon the property so taxed, and shall be a prior lien to all other claims, sales, assignments, transfers, gifts and judicial writs. 
(b)  The lien shall exist from January 1 of each year until all such taxes have been paid. 
(c)  A lien shall exist against any real estate which, for any cause, has failed to be assessed for one (1) or more years and such lien shall be good and effective for every year for which assessment has so failed. 
(Code 1960, § 22-16) 
Sec. 14-2-31. - Right to levy and sell. 
    All real or personal property, held or owned by any person in this City, shall be liable for all City taxes due by the owner thereof, and the Tax Assessor/Collector may levy on any personal property whatsoever to be found in the City and shall sell the same in the manner provided by the laws of this State to satisfy any and all delinquent taxes. 
(Code 1960, § 22-17) 
State Law reference- Tax liens, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 32.01 et seq. 
Sec. 14-2-32. - Removal of fixtures-Unlawful unless taxes are paid. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone to remove or assist, aid or abet in removing a fixture from any realty within the City unless and until all taxes that may then be due on and against the realty be first paid in full to all taxing authorities of the county in which the property is located. 
(Code 1960, § 22-19; Ord. No. 6052, § 2(A), 12-7-93) 
Sec. 14-2-33. - Same-Permit; evidence that taxes are paid. 
    No permit for the moving of any fixture which is attached to realty against which realty there are unpaid and due taxes to either the City, the Amarillo Independent School District, the Amarillo Hospital District, the Amarillo Junior College District, or the county in which the property is located or to the State shall be granted, and no permit for the removal of any such fixture shall be issued until the applicant for the permit shall first submit a certificate evidencing that such taxes are fully paid and that none are due and unpaid. 
(Code 1960, § 22-20; Ord. No. 6052, § 2(B), 12-7-93) 
Sec. 14-2-34. - Freeport goods exemption; time extension for aircraft parts. 
(a)  Definitions. In this section, "freeport goods" means property that under Article VIII, Section 1-i of the Texas Constitution is not taxable. 
(b)  Exemption. Pursuant to Texas Tax Code, Chapter 11, as amended, a person is entitled to an exemption from taxation of the appraised value of that portion of the person's inventory or property consisting of freeport goods, and Subsection 11.251(k) specifically provides a freeport goods exemption to aircraft parts that are in the state for no longer than one hundred seventy-five (175) days. 
(c)  Extension. Pursuant to Texas Tax Code Subsection 11.251(l), the City hereby extends the date by which freeport goods that are aircraft parts must be transported outside the state to not later than the seven hundred thirtieth day after the date the person acquired or imported the property in this state. 
(d)  Effective. This extension applies only to the exemption from ad valorem taxation by the City and applies to the tax year in which this section is adopted and, to each tax year following the year of adoption of this section. 
(Ord. No. 7460, § 1, 5-20-2014) 
Secs. 14-2-35-14-2-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - HOTEL ROOM OCCUPANCY TAX[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Hotel occupancy tax, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.001 et seq. 

Sec. 14-2-51. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Consideration: The cost of the room, sleeping space, bed or dormitory space or other facility in a Hotel and shall not include the cost of any food served or personal services rendered to the Occupant not related to cleaning and readying such room for Occupancy and shall not include any tax assessed for occupancy therefor by any other governmental agency. 
    Hotel: Any Building, trailer or other facility in which a member or members of the public may, for a consideration, obtain sleeping accommodations. The term shall include Hotels, Motels, tourist homes, houses or courts, lodging houses, inns, roominghouses, trailer houses, trailer motels, dormitory space (regardless of whether the bed space is rented to individuals or groups), apartments and all other facilities where rooms or sleeping facilities or space are furnished for a consideration. The term "Hotel" shall not be defined so as to include hospitals, sanitariums or nursing homes. 
    Monthly Period: The regular calendar month of the year. 
    Occupancy: The use or possession or the right to use or possess any room, space or sleeping facility in a Hotel for any purpose. 
    Occupant: Anyone who for a consideration uses, possesses or has a right to use or possess any room or rooms or sleeping space or facility in a Hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license, contract or agreement. 
    Permanent Resident: Any Occupant who has or shall have the right to occupancy of any room or rooms or sleeping space or facility in a Hotel for at least thirty (30) consecutive days during the current calendar year or preceding year. 
    Person: Any individual, company, corporation or association owning, operating, managing or controlling any Hotel. 
    Tax Assessor/Collector: The Tax Assessor/Collector of the City. 
(Code 1960, § 22-21) 
Cross reference- Definitions to apply throughout Code, § 1-2-1. 
Sec. 14-2-52. - Levy of tax; rate; use of revenue. 
(a)  There is hereby levied a tax upon the cost of Occupancy of any room or space furnished by any Hotel where such cost of Occupancy is at the rate of two dollars ($2.00) or more per day, such tax to be equal to seven (7) percent of the Consideration paid by the Occupant for such room to such Hotel. 
(b)  Revenues derived from the Occupancy tax levied in subsection (a) above shall be used only to promote tourism and the convention and hotel industry, as provided in Chapter 351, Texas Tax Code, as now or hereafter amended. 
(c)  No tax shall be imposed upon a Permanent Resident or on an officer or employee of the United States, the State of Texas or its agencies, institutions, boards or commissions when traveling in the course of official duties for such governmental entity. An officer or employee of a public technical institute, public junior college, public senior college or university, medical or dental unit or other agency of higher education or of education in general is not exempt from the tax imposed by this section. Reports filed under section 14-2-54 will fully identify the exempt person by name, address, organization and date of occupancy, or the tax will be remitted just as if it had been collected. 
(Code 1960, § 22-22; Ord. No. 5650, § 3, 12-18-86; Ord. No. 5743, § 1, 4-26-88; Ord. No. 5822, § 1, 8-22-89; Ord. No. 6377, § 1, 11-17-98; Ord. No. 6849, § 1, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 7126, § 1, 9-23-2008; Ord. No. 7490, § 1, 9-30-2014; Ord. No. 7586, § 1, 3-1-2016) 
State Law reference- Tax authorized V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.002; maximum rate, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.003; use of revenue, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.101 et seq. 
Sec. 14-2-53. - Collection. 
(a)  Every person owning, operating, managing or controlling any Hotels shall collect the tax imposed in section 14-2-52 for the benefit of the City. 
(b)  Every person who collects the tax imposed by section 14-2-52 hereof may, upon payment of the tax in accordance with section 14-2-54, deduct and retain to defray expenses of collection and reporting an amount equal to one (1) percent of the amount collected and reported by such Person. 
(c)  Failure of file the reports required by section 14-2-54 or failure to deliver the tax collected in a timely manner shall require forfeiture of the one (1) percent collection expense. 
(d)  The City shall assess, and a person who uses a credit card to pay a tax imposed by this chapter shall pay to the City, a convenience fee in an amount periodically set by the Finance Director that is reasonably related to the City's expense in processing payment by credit card, not to exceed five (5) percent of the tax payment being paid, as authorized by Texas Tax Code chapter 132, as amended, and the City's then current agreement with its bank for credit card services, as amended. 
(Code 1960, § 22-23; Ord. No. 5650, § 4, 12-18-86; Ord. No. 7173, § 1, 7-7-2009) 
Sec. 14-2-54. - Reports. 
(a)  On or before the tenth day of each month every person required under this Article to collect the tax imposed herein shall file a report with the Tax Assessor/Collector showing any consideration paid for all room or sleeping space occupancies during the preceding month, the amount of tax collected on such occupancies and any other information as the Tax Assessor/Collector may require. Such report shall be in writing. Such person shall deliver the tax collected on such occupancies at the time the report is required to be filed. 
(b)  When the preceding month's hotel records are not available to file the report required herein, an estimated report and delivery of taxes collected shall be filed before the tenth day of the month to comply with these filing requirements. Such estimated reports and delivery of taxes collected shall be equivalent to the amount reported, not estimated, during the preceding month. Reports filed and tax collections delivered based on estimates shall be corrected and filed with the Tax Assessor/Collector on or before the tenth day of the month following the month in which the estimated report is filed. 
(c)  The person who is responsible for the day-to-day operation of a hotel or motel shall be responsible for compiling and filing reports and delivery of taxes collected as required in subsection (a) and (b) above, and such person shall be criminally liable for failure to timely file said reports. In absence of a designation of a local responsible person by the owner of the hotel or motel is shall be presumed that the local manager is the person who is responsible for day-to-day operations. 
(Code 1960, § 22-24; Ord. No. 5943, § 1, 1-7-92; Ord. No. 5958, § 1, 6-2-92) 
Sec. 14-2-55. - Adoption of procedures; access to books and records. 
    The Tax Assessor/Collector shall adopt such procedures, rules and regulations as are reasonably necessary effectively to collect the tax levied herein and shall, upon request of any person owning, operating, managing or controlling any Hotel, furnish a copy of such procedures, rules and regulations for the guidance of such person and facilitate the collection of such tax as such collection is required herein. Such procedures, rules and regulations shall be in writing and a copy thereof shall be placed on file with the City Secretary. The Tax Assessor/Collector shall be permitted to have access to books and records during reasonable business hours as shall be necessary to enable him to determine the correctness of the amount due under the provisions of this section, or to determine whether or not a report should have been filed and the amount, if necessary, of taxes due. 
(Code 1960, § 22-25) 
Sec. 14-2-56. - Penalties. 
(a)  If any person required by the provisions of this article to collect the tax imposed herein, or make reports required herein, and to pay the Tax Assessor/Collector the taxes imposed herein, shall fail to collect such taxes, file such report, or remit such taxes to the Tax Assessor/Collector, such person shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day any violation exists shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  If the operator of any Hotel shall fail to file a report for any period as required by this article, or shall fail to pay the tax for any period as required by this article, then the Tax Assessor/Collector is hereby authorized to make an assessment of the tax for such period. The tax assessed, together with any penalties provided by statute, shall be a prior and superior lien on all property of the Motel. 
(c)  If any person required by the provisions of this article to collect the tax imposed herein shall fail to file a report or shall fail to pay the tax when due, such person shall forfeit to the City a penalty of five (5) percent of the amount of the tax due. 
(d)  If any person required by the provisions of this article to collect the tax imposed herein shall fail to file a report or shall fail to pay the tax within thirty (30) days after the tax is due, such person shall forfeit to the City an additional penalty of five (5) percent of the amount of tax due. 
(Code 1960, § 22-26; Ord. No. 5650, § 5, 12-18-86; Ord. No. 5743, § 2, 4-26-88; Ord. No. 5771, § 3, 9-27-88) 
Sec. 14-2-57. - Interest. 
    A tax imposed under the provisions of this article which is not paid when due shall accrue interest at the rate of one (1) percent per month on the total amount of tax due. 
(Code 1960, § 22-27; Ord. No. 5650, § 6, 12-18-86) 
CHAPTER 14-3. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 
  

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Unless specially provided otherwise Alcoholic Beverage Code preemptive, V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code § 1.06. 

Sec. 14-3-1. - Hours of consumption, possession and sale. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the corporate limits of the City to consume any Alcoholic Beverage in any public place or for any person to possess any alcoholic beverage for the purpose of consuming the same in such public place at any time on Sundays between the hours of 2:15 a.m. and 12:00 noon, and on all other days at any time between the hours of 2:15 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person who shall hold a retail dealer's on-premises late hours license or mixed beverages late hours permit issued under the provisions of the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code to sell any Alcoholic Beverage or offer the same for sale: 
(1)  On Sunday at any time between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 12:00 noon. 
(2)  On any day except Sunday at any time between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person who shall not hold a retail dealer's on-premises late hours license or a mixed beverages late hours permit issued under the provisions of V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code to sell any alcoholic beverage or offer the same for sale: 
(1)  On Sunday at any time between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 12:00 noon. 
(2)  On any day except Sunday at any time between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. 
(d)  Private clubs located within the City holding a private club late hours permit issued by the provisions of V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code may permit persons to consume or be served Alcoholic Beverages on club Premises on Sundays between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 2:00 a.m. and on any day except Sunday between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 2:00 a.m. 
(e)  Violation of the above restrictions is punishable as a violation of V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code. 
(Code 1960, § 13-1; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
State Law reference- Hours of sale, etc., V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code §§ 105.03, 105.05; hours of consumption, V.T.C.A. Alcoholic Beverage Code § 105.06. 
Sec. 14-3-2. - Unlawful sales. 
    It shall be unlawful to: 
(1)  Offer for sale or to sell any Alcoholic Beverage except as designated by the Schedule of Uses, Section 4-10-82, [P], of this Code. 
(Code 1960, § 13-2; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 6708, § 3, 1-27-2004) 
Sec. 14-3-3. - Certificate of occupancy. 
    When applying for an original state license or state permit any person seeking to carry on a business within the City required to be licensed under the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code shall first obtain from the Building Official either a Certificate of Occupancy (for an existing structure to be used) or a Building Permit (for the construction, expansion, or modification of a structure) for the establishment. 
(Code 1960, § 13-3; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 5771, § 1, 6-14-88; Ord. No. 5951, § 1, 3-17-92; Ord. No. 5973, § 1, 9-8-92) 
Sec. 14-3-4. - License and permit fees. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided by V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code, each holder of a State Permit issued pursuant to the provisions of the Alcoholic Beverage Code shall pay to the City a fee equal to one-half the fee paid to the State for such permit. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided by V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code, each holder of a State license issued pursuant to the provisions of the Alcoholic Beverage Code shall pay to the City a fee equal to one-half the fee paid the State for such license. 
(c)  All fees levied by this section are due and payable at the time at which the State license and permit fees are due. 
(Code 1960, § 13-4; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
State Law reference- Local fees authorized, V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code §§ 11.38, 61.36. 
Sec. 14-3-5. - Proximity to churches, schools, public hospitals. 
    The sale of Alcoholic Beverages by any dealer is prohibited where the dealer's place of business is within three hundred (300) feet of any church, school or public hospital, measured in accordance with the measurement calculations of V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code. 
(Code 1960, § 13-5; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
State Law reference- Location restrictions authorized, V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code § 109.33. 
Sec. 14-3-6. - Civic center-Prohibited in; exception. 
    Except as may be permitted by valid ordinance, it shall be unlawful for any person attending any event or function at the civic center to bring or attempt to bring into the civic center, or any part hereof, any Alcoholic Beverage or "controlled substance" as defined by the Texas Controlled Substances Act [V.A.C.S. art. 4476-15]. 
(Code 1960, § 13-6; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-3-7. - Same-Dispensing pursuant to contractual agreement. 
    Any person, group or organization of any kind, having leased the civic center, or any portion thereof, shall be permitted to dispense Alcoholic Beverages pursuant to contractual agreement entered into with the civic center manager. 
(Code 1960, § 13-7; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-3-8. - Same-Sale of beer. 
    At any public event or function held at the civic center, beer may be sold only in specified areas physically separated from seating areas. 
(Code 1960, § 13-8; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 14-4-1-14-4-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TOPLESS ESTABLISHMENTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-4-16. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alcoholic Beverage: Any form of liquor, beer and wine or any beverage containing more than one-half of one (1) percent of alcohol by volume which is capable of use for beverage purposes, either alone or when diluted. 
    Applicant: Any person who submits or files an application or renewal application for a Topless Establishment license. 
    Dance or Dancing: The performance of any rhythmic and patterned succession of bodily movements, whether to music or not, and includes burlesque acts and performances such as striptease, fan and bubble Dances, go-go Dances or any other same or similar-type Dances by whatever name called where persons are topless. 
    Hotel or Motel: The Premises of an establishment where, for payment, lodging is furnished to persons and wherein are located at least five (5) separate rooms with sleeping facilities. 
    Licensee: The name of the person, association of persons or organization whose name appears on the Topless Establishment license. 
    Operator: The person who is the manager, agent, servant, employee, or any of them who controls, conducts or manages the operation of such Topless Establishment. 
    Premises: The grounds as well as all Buildings or portion of a Building and appurtenances pertaining thereto, and shall also include any adjacent Premises, directly or indirectly under the control of any Topless Establishment Licensee or Operator. 
    Topless: Any business activity whether it involves dancing or not, which offers the opportunity to view a male or female breast clothed in a manner that leaves uncovered or visible through less than opaque clothing any portion of the breast below the areola, while the genital areas and anus are covered by opaque covering. 
    Topless Establishment: The Premises or any establishment operated by any person, association of persons, or any organization, whether incorporated or unincorporated, including but not limited to a place licensed by the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Code for the on-premises consumption of Alcoholic Beverages, which routinely allows or permits natural persons to appear topless, either as a member, guest or business invitee, for pleasure or amusement, or which permits or allows any person who is an agent, representative, manager, servant, contractor, or employee of such establishment to appear topless, perform any Dance as an act, performance or attraction or which allows topless entertainment. 
(Code 1960, § 13-9; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 5726, § 1, 12-8-87; Ord. No. 6682, § 1, 9-30-2003) 
Cross reference- Definitions to apply throughout Code, § 1-2-1. 
Sec. 14-4-17. - Purpose and Scope. 
    This article shall be known as the Topless Establishment ordinance, shall be deemed an exercise of the police power of the City for the protection of the peace, health, safety and general welfare of the people of the City, and all its provisions shall be liberally construed for the accomplishment of that purpose. This article does not apply to theatrical production of copyrighted material which contains nudity when performed by a professional or amateur theatrical or musical company. 
(Code 1960, § 13-9; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 6682, § 1, 9-30-2003) 
Sec. 14-4-18. - Penalty; remedies cumulative. 
    Any violation of this article shall upon conviction subject the violator to a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day of such violation shall be treated as a separate offense. 
(Code 1960, § 13-19; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-4-19. - Enforcement. 
    It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police, Fire Chief, Building Official and Fire Marshal of the City and the Director of Public Health to require compliance with the terms of this article. 
(Code 1960, § 13-16; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-4-20. - Age and Operation. 
(a)  It is an offense for the owner, operator or manager of a Topless Establishment to allow a person on the premises who is less than eighteen (18) years of age, unless the Topless Establishment is a licensed premises by the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission in which event the minimum age for a patron is twenty-one (21) years old. 
(b)  Where a Topless Establishment is a premises licensed by the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission, such business shall comply with all applicable laws, ordinances and rules pertaining to alcohol, including but not limited to late hours permits. 
(Code 1960, § 13-14; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 5726, § 1, 12-8-87; Ord. No. 6132, § 1, 2-21-95; Ord. No. 6682, § 1, 9-30-2003) 
Sec. 14-4-21. - Operation regulations; grounds for license revocation, violations. 
    The licenses issued under this article may be revoked by the Building Official if the Chief of Police has investigated the establishment and has determined that the Licensee has violated, suffered or allowed the violation of any of the following acts within such Establishment which are hereby prohibited: 
(1)  No Topless Establishment shall permit any known prostitute, male or female procurer, to be employed at such Establishment or to be present at such Establishment. 
(2)  No Topless Establishment shall have in any way connected with it any room equipped or fitted in any way as sleeping rooms which are open to or let to any person without charge or at a charge less than the daily rate of a Hotel or Motel to its guests when such Topless Establishment is located in a Building principally maintained and used as a Hotel or Motel. 
(3)  In addition to being grounds for license revocation, it shall be unlawful for any person engaged in the operation of a Topless Establishment or any agent, servant, contractor or employee of such person, to engage in or to permit violations of state law on the Premises of the Establishment pertaining to: 
a.  Disorderly conduct. 
b.  Indecent exposure. 
c.  Public intoxication. 
d.  Prostitution or solicitating thereof. 
e.  Possession of any narcotics or controlled substances. 
f.  Possession of narcotics or drug paraphernalia. 
g.  Permitting any person to possess on the licensed Premises any narcotics or narcotics paraphernalia. 
h.  Sexual performance by a child or employment harmful to a child. 
(4)  Failing or refusing to comply with or failure or refusal to maintain the Topless Establishment Premises in accordance with the health laws or health provisions of the City or the State. 
(5)  The employment of a person by such Topless Establishment who has finally been convicted of any of the offenses listed in section 14-4-32(f)(2). 
(Code 1960, § 13-15; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 6682, § 1, 9-30-2003) 
Sec. 14-4-22. - Employing guard or watchman. 
    The Licensee or Operator of any Topless Establishment intending to employ, or permit to be employed, any guard or watchman to be on duty at public activity conducted by Licensee or operator, prior to the time of employment, shall furnish the Chief of Police with the name, date of birth, place of residence and occupation record for the preceding five (5) years of the person to be employed as guard or watchman. 
(Code 1960, § 13-17; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 6682, § 1, 9-30-2003) 
Secs. 14-4-23-14-4-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- General authority to license, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 215.075. 

Sec. 14-4-31. - Required; classification; fees; exemption. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct, allow, permit, aid or assist or perform any activity in any establishment regulated by this article within the corporate limits of the City without having first obtained an appropriate license as herein provided, which license shall at all times be displayed in some conspicuous public area within the licensed Premises of such establishment. 
(b)  Before any license required by this division shall be issued, the license fee required shall be paid to the Building Official of the City. 
(c)  The annual license fee for each Topless Establishment shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(d)  A Topless Establishment which is operating on the effective date [October 24, 2003] of this Ordinance with a Dance Establishment license is required to obtain a Topless Establishment license on or before the date for renewal of the Dance Establishment license. 
(Code 1960, § 13-10; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 6682, § 1, 9-30-2003; Ord. No. 7688, § 23, 9-12-17) 
Sec. 14-4-32. - Application; investigation; approval; issuance. 
(a)  Licenses provided for in this division shall be applied for and obtained from the Building Official of the City and any license issued under the terms of this division shall be subject to revocation as provided. 
(b)  An Applicant for an original Topless Establishment permit shall first obtain from the Building Official either a Certificate of Occupancy (for an existing structure to be used) or a Building Permit (for the construction, expansion, or modification of a structure) for the establishment. 
(c)  Any person desiring a license to operate a Topless Establishment shall file with the Building Official a written sworn application for a license, which application shall state: 
(1)  The location by Street and number of the Premises of such establishment; 
(2)  The name, date of birth and address of the Applicant; 
(3)  If the Premises are leased, the name of the lessor and the lessee; 
(4)  If the Applicant is an individual: 
a.  That he is a resident of the State and the length of his residence in the City; 
b.  The location by Street and number of Applicant's residence; 
c.  If the Applicant, or the spouse of such Applicant, has at any time during the three (3) years next preceding the filing of such application been finally convicted of a felony or any of the offenses listed in subsection (f)(2) of this section, and whether applicant or spouse is currently on parole, probation, deferred adjudication or community supervision for any of such offense; 
d.  The previous occupation or employment of the applicant and the spouse of such Applicant for a period of five (5) years next preceding the filing of such application; 
(5)  If the application is by a firm, association or partnership, all of the information required in subsection (c)(4) regarding individual Applicants shall be given as to each member of the firm, association or partnership; 
(6)  If the application is made on behalf of a corporation, then all of the information required in subsection (c)(4) regarding individual Applicants shall be given as to the manager, officer, trustee, receiver or person who is primarily responsible for the management of the Premises and in addition shall state when and where the corporation has been chartered and if requested by the Building Official shall give the name of each and every stockholder of such corporation; 
(7)  Such other and additional information that the City Council may from time to time deem proper and necessary as shall be determined by resolution of the City Council; 
(d)  The information given in such application required in this section is for the purpose of determining whether or not a license shall be granted, and any misrepresentation of any fact or statement made in such application shall be cause for denial or revocation in addition to other grounds for revocation as hereinafter provided. 
(e)  Investigation. Upon the filing of an application for a Topless Establishment permit, the Building Official shall promptly notify the Chief of Police who shall, within seven (7) business days investigate the Applicant and the spouse of such Applicant to determine that either of them has not been convicted of a felony or any of the offenses listed in subsection (f)(2) of this section, and the Chief of Police shall notify the Building Official of his findings and shall note thereon his recommendation for approval or disapproval. 
(f)  Issuance or denial shall be determined by the Building Official within three (3) business days after receipt of the Police Chief's recommendation. The Building Official's decision is governed by the following provisions: 
(1)  If the Building Official, after receiving the report of the Chief of Police, shall determine that the Applicant and the Premises of the proposed Topless Establishment complies with the requirements of this article and with the laws of the State relating to Topless Establishments, then a license shall be issued to the Applicant. 
(2)  The Building Official of the City shall refuse any original application or renewal for a Topless Establishment permit unless the Applicant shall supply a certificate evidencing payment of all taxes owed by the Applicant for the location to the City or any taxing authority whose taxes are levied, assessed and collected by the City or if he finds that there is any delinquent indebtedness due the City against the Applicant for the location, or if he finds that the Applicant or the spouse of any Applicant has at any time during three (3) years next preceding the filing of such application been convicted of a felony or any of the following offenses, or is currently on parole, probation, deferred adjudication or community supervision for a felony or any of the following: 
a.  Prostitution; 
b.  A crime involving moral turpitude; 
c.  Bookmaking; 
d.  Gambling (gaming); 
e.  Any offense involving narcotics or any other dangerous drugs; 
f.  Violations of V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code resulting in the cancellation of a license or permit or a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or more; 
g.  More than three (3) violations of V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code relating to minors; 
h.  Bootlegging; 
i.  Violation of penal laws involving firearms or other deadly weapons. 
(3)  The Building Official shall refuse an original application or renewal of a Topless Establishment permit if he finds that three (3) years have not elapsed since the termination of any sentence, parole or probation by the Applicant or spouse of such Applicant as the result of a felony prosecution or prosecution for any offense named or described above. 
(Code 1960, § 13-11, Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 5662, § 1, 1-20-87; Ord. No. 5951, § 1, 3-17-92; Ord. No. 5973, § 1, 9-8-92; Ord. No. 6682, § 1, 9-30-2003; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 14-4-33. - Denial by Building Official; appeal procedure. 
(a)  If the Building Official refuses to approve any renewal or application for license hereunder, the action of the Building Official in so refusing shall become final unless the Applicant shall within ten (10) business days after the refusal to grant such license file a written appeal addressed to the City Council with the City Secretary, requesting a hearing by the City Council upon the question as to whether or not the renewal or application shall be granted. 
(b)  The application shall be referred to the City Council by the City Secretary. The City Council shall set a date for a hearing not more than thirty (30) days from the date the written request was filed with the City Secretary. 
(c)  At the hearing the Applicant shall be required to appear before the City Council, and a full hearing on the application shall be had. The City Council shall, at such hearing, determine whether the application for the license shall be granted or refused. The action of the City Council thereon shall be final and conclusive. Any further review shall be by way of Applicant filing a suit in a district court of Potter or Randall County. 
(Code 1960, § 13-12; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 6682, § 1, 9-30-2003; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 14-4-34. - Duration; refunds; assignments; changed locations. 
(a)  Term. All licenses issued under this division shall terminate one (1) year from the date of issuance. 
(b)  Refunds. No refunds of any license fee paid hereunder shall be made by the City for any cause whatsoever. 
(c)  Nonassignable. Licenses issued hereunder shall be deemed personal to the Licensee, and shall not be assignable. 
(d)  Transfers or location. Licenses for the Establishment only issued hereunder may be transferred from one (1) location or place of business to another location or place of business upon application approved by the Building Official, provided there is no change in the use classification of the occupancy. 
(e)  License a privilege; restrictions. Any licenses issued under the terms of this division shall be purely a personal privilege revocable in the manner and for the causes herein provided, subject to appeal as herein provided, and shall not constitute property, nor shall it be subject to execution nor shall it descend by the laws of the testate or intestate, devolution, but shall cease upon the death of the Licensee. 
(Code 1960, § 13-13; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 6682, § 1, 9-30-2003) 
Sec. 14-4-35. - Violation; revocation of license; injunction. 
(a)  If a Topless Establishment is not being conducted in accordance with this article, the laws of the State, or other ordinances of the City, or offenses described in section 14-4-21(3) occur on the premises, then the Building Official may at any time give notice in writing to such Operator or Licensee of the Topless Establishment that the permit or license issued for the operation of the Topless Establishment has been revoked and cancelled. 
(b)  The notice of revocation and cancellation shall become a final revocation and cancellation after the expiration of ten (10) days from the date of service unless on or before the expiration of the ten (10) days the Licensee or Operator of the Topless Establishment shall file with the City Secretary a written appeal as provided in section 14-4-33. 
(c)  The appeal, if made and filed as prescribed herein, shall be according to the provisions of section 14-4-33. 
(d)  Every day of operation after notice of revocation and cancellation shall become final, shall become a separate violation of this article and shall constitute an offense punishable in accordance with section 14-4-18. 
(e)  A person who operates or causes to be operated a Topless Establishment without a valid license or in violation of this article is subject to a suit for injunction. 
(Code 1960, § 13-18; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 6682, § 1, 9-30-2003) 
Sec. 14-4-36. - Location Requirements for Topless Establishments. 
    The location for Topless Establishments shall be in accordance with Chapter 4-10, Article IV, Division I, Section 4-10-82, Part E of the Schedule of Uses of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 6682, § 1, 9-30-2003) 
Sec. 14-4-37. - Nonconforming Uses and Structures. 
    A Topless Establishment which is in operation on the effective date [October 24, 2003] of this article which does not conform to the location requirements pertaining to a Topless Establishment shall be a Nonconforming Use which may continue in operation until the occurrence of one (1) of the following: 
(1)  A change in (i) the ownership of the real estate upon which the Topless Establishment is located or (ii) the tenant which operates a Topless Establishment on the premises, either or both of which occurs after September 30, 2007; or 
(2)  Cessation of doing business as a Topless Establishment for a continuous period of one hundred eighty (180) days or more; or 
(3)  Destruction of the Topless Establishment by fire, the elements, or other causes that exceeds fifty (50) percent of the Structure's value as shown of the current tax rolls. 
(Ord. No. 6682, § 1, 9-30-2003) 
Secs. 14-4-38-14-4-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SHOWS AND CIRCUSES 

Sec. 14-4-51. - Applicability. 
    This article shall apply to all shows, performances, exhibitions, medicine shows, panoramic or view shows, menageries, carnivals, circuses, wild west or rodeo shows, acrobatic performances, wax shows, moving picture shows, dramatic or theatrical productions or skating rinks held in or exhibited upon the Streets, under any tent, in any airdrome, hall or building within the City limits. 
(Code 1960, § 13-20; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-4-52. - Violations. 
    Any person who shall conduct, aid or assist in conducting of, participate in or perform in any way in any show or circus or part of a show or circus, conducted or held or exhibited in violation of this article or who in any manner violates any of the provisions of this division, shall be subject to the penalty in section 1-1-5 of this Code. 
(Code 1960, § 13-21; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-4-53. - Requirements of site-Buildings; sewer connections; fire escapes; permit. 
(a)  No person shall give, conduct, exhibit or maintain any show, performance, exhibition or place of amusement of any character whatsoever for more than two (2) consecutive days within the City limits, save and except in a regularly constructed and conducted auditorium, place of amusement, opera or theater Building having adequate toilet facilities permanently attached to the sanitary sewer system of the City and with adequate exits and fire escapes as required by State law. 
(b)  No person shall conduct a show or circus as regulated herein without a permit issued by the City. Application shall be made to the Building Official who shall charge a permit fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Code 1960, § 13-22; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-4-54. - Same-Lot, tract or parcel of land; conditions. 
    In lieu of the auditorium, opera or theater Building required in section 14-4-53. A Lot, Tract or Parcel of land may be used if: 
(1)  The Premises have adequate toilet facilities connected with the City sanitary sewer system capable of suitably providing for attending crowds. 
(2)  The Premises have at least two (2) fire plugs, annexed to the City water system, for protection against fire, within three hundred (300) feet of the place of exhibition. 
(3)  The Premises have adequate parking facilities within the Premises for automobiles of the visiting public, or in lieu thereof, adjacent parking lots properly policed and protected. 
(4)  The Premises are equipped with adequate Sidewalks of cement or other hard-surfaced material around the place of amusement, all other side shows and various exhibitions forming and used in connection with the show. Where the show contains many various sideshows, the grounds shall contain Sidewalks that connect all shows together to the end that the patrons and pedestrians can stay out of mud and dust. 
(5)  In case the show or exhibition is of such size as permits motor vehicles to drive into the show grounds used by patrons and customers, the Streets so used shall be hardsurfaced and paved. 
(6)  The premises shall not be used without first obtaining the written consent of the landowner. 
(7)  A consent in writing be first obtained from all residents within three hundred eighty (380) feet of the Tract of land. 
(Code 1960, § 13-23; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
Secs. 14-4-55-14-4-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ADULT BUSINESSES 

Sec. 14-4-76. - License required; fees. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct, operate, or permit to be operated for his benefit, an Adult Business as defined by section 4-10-83 of the Amarillo Municipal Code without first having obtained a license as required herein, which license shall at all times be displayed in some conspicuous place within the licensed Premises. 
(b)  The annual license fee for each Adult Business is two hundred dollars ($200.00), which shall be paid before a license may be issued. 
(Ord. No. 5863, § 1, 6-12-90) 
Sec. 14-4-77. - Application and issuance. 
(a)  A license for an Adult Business shall be obtained from the Chief of Police by completing an application and meeting the requirements of this article. 
(b)  The application shall be sworn to and acknowledged and shall state: 
(1)  The street address of the Premises to be licensed; 
(2)  The full name, date of birth, driver's license number and residence address of the applicant; 
(3)  If the Premises are leased, the names of the lessor and lessee; 
(4)  If the application is on behalf of a partnership of an Adult Business, the partners' names, dates of birth, drivers' license numbers and residence addresses shall be listed. 
(5)  If the application is on behalf of a corporate owner of an Adult Business, the name of the corporation, the name and address of the registered agent, and the name and address, date of birth and driver's license number of the person who is primarily responsible for the management of the Adult Business. 
(6)  Whether or not the applicant, any partner who is an owner of an Adult Business, or any person who is or will be primarily responsible for the management of the Adult Business has ever been convicted of a crime involving sex. 
(c)  Any misrepresentations of the facts required by the license application shall be cause for revocation or refusal to issue a license. 
(d)  Upon the filing of an application for an Adult Business license, the Chief of Police shall promptly investigate the Premises to determine whether or not the Premises meets the requirements of the Amarillo Municipal Code concerning construction, plumbing, electricity, fire safety, sanitation, Zoning and the requirements of this article. 
(e)  If the Chief of Police shall determine that the application meets the requirements and that the persons listed in (b)(6) above have not been convicted of a crime involving sex, he shall issue a license to the applicant within eleven (11) days of filing the application. Should the Chief of Police find a deficiency in the application or the premises, he will notify the applicant before the expiration of said eleven (11) day period, who will have five (5) working days (of City Hall) to correct the deficiency and request a reinspection. Reinspection will occur within three (3) working days, and upon correction of the noted deficiencies having been found a license will be issued on the following working day. The applicant will be required to pay twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per reinspection per application. 
(f)  An applicant who is denied a license may appeal the denial to District Court as authorized by law. 
(Ord. No. 5863, § 1, 6-12-90; Ord. No. 5942, § 1, 12-24-91) 
Sec. 14-4-78. - Duration, nonassignable, nontransferable. 
(a)  A license issued under this article shall terminate one (1) year from the date of issuance. 
(b)  No refund of any license fee paid hereunder shall be made. 
(c)  A license issued under this article may not be assigned or transferred to another location, and shall terminate upon the death or bankruptcy of the licensee or transfer of ownership of the business. 
(Ord. No. 5863, § 1, 6-12-90) 
Sec. 14-4-79. - Viewing booth requirements for an Adult Business. 
(a)  Viewing Booths in an Adult Business shall be configured in such a manner that there is an unobstructed and unobstructable view of the interior area of the Viewing Booth from outside the entrance to the Viewing Booth at all times. 
(b)  Walls or partitions of Viewing Booths between two (2) feet and six (6) feet above floor level shall have no holes or voids in such walls or partitions. 
(c)  A Viewing Booth shall at all times be illuminated with not less than that amount of light provided by a twenty-watt bulb. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the person accepting payment from customers of an Adult Business to ensure that the Viewing Booth requirements in this section are in compliance at all times. 
(Ord. No. 5863, § 1, 6-12-90) 
Sec. 14-4-80. - Inspections; violations; revocation of license. 
(a)  As a condition of issuance, the applicant for a license under this article shall agree to maintain the Premises in compliance with the requirements of the Amarillo Municipal Code and to authorize the agents and employees of the City of Amarillo to inspect the Premises or any portion thereof at any time during business hours. 
(b)  The person in control of an Adult Business shall not authorize or allow any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years to enter or patronize such Adult Business. A single violation of this requirement shall constitute an offense and cause for revocation of the license for the Adult Business. 
(c)  Should the Chief of Police determine that an Adult Business is not in compliance with the requirements of the Amarillo Municipal Code, he may at any time give notice in writing to the licensee, or the person in control if the licensee cannot be easily located, of the violation and that the license is in jeopardy of revocation if the violation is not corrected by the following business day. Should the violation be not corrected by the following business day, the Chief of Police may revoke and cancel the license. 
(d)  The licensee may abate the revocation by filing an appeal with a district court and obtaining a Temporary Restraining Order. 
(e)  Every day of operation of an Adult Business after cancellation and revocation of a license shall constitute an offense punishable by a fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(f)  Any person, corporation or partnership who has had a license revoked for a violation of the license or zoning requirements regulating Adult Businesses shall not be granted a license for a period of ten (10) years from the date of revocation. 
(Ord. No. 5863, § 1, 6-12-90; Ord. No. 5942, § 1, 12-24-91) 
CHAPTER 14-6. - TRANSIENT AND OCCASIONAL SALES[1] 
  
Art. I. In General, §§ 14-6-1-14-6-15 Art. II. Transient Retail Businesses, §§ 14-6-16-14-6-50 Div. 1. Generally, §§ 14-6-16-14-6-26 Div. 2. License, §§ 14-6-27-14-6-50 Art. III. Occasional Sales, §§ 14-6-51-14-6-54 Art. IV. Door to Door Sales, §§ 14-6-55-14-6-61  
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- General authority to license, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 215.075. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 14-6-1-14-6-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TRANSIENT RETAIL BUSINESSES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-6-16. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Fixed Business Location: A location within the City which complies with the Zoning and Building Codes of the City and which is occupied by the same business for thirty (30) consecutive days or more. 
    Transient Retail Business: The sale or offering for sale of any goods, wares, services or merchandise, including food products, to the general public without utilizing a Fixed Business Location. 
(Code 1960, § 13-34(a)(1), (2); Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
Cross reference- Definitions to apply throughout Code, § 1-2-1. 
Sec. 14-6-17. - Parking or stopping for purpose of selling. 
(a)  No person shall park or stop any truck or vehicle upon any Street or Alley within the City for the purpose of offering for sale or selling cattle feed, produce or other products or merchandise from the vehicle or truck so parked or stopped. 
(b)  Subsection (a) above shall not prohibit the stopping or parking of trucks or other vehicles in the Streets or Alleys of the city for the purpose of delivering cattle feed, produce or other products or merchandise to the Occupants of any business, Residence or other Structure not specifically prohibited by some other ordinance or statute. 
(Code 1960, § 13-36; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-6-18. - Street peddlers. 
    No person shall peddle or in any manner sell, barter or exchange, or offer to sell, barter or exchange any goods, wares, merchandise, groceries, patent medicines or nostrums of any character upon any Street, Sidewalk, Alley or other public ground. 
(Code 1960, § 13-37; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
Secs. 14-6-19-14-6-26. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 14-6-27. - Required. 
    No person shall operate a Transient Retail Business in the City without a license issued by the City. Each location shall constitute a separate business. 
(Code 1960, § 13-34(a); Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-6-28. - Application. 
    Application for a Transient Retail Business license shall be made to the Building Official and shall contain: 
(1)  The name, permanent Street and mailing address, and telephone number of the principal owner of the business. If an assumed name is used for the principal owner of the business, then the name and permanent Street and mailing address of the chief executive officer of the business shall also be supplied; 
(2)  The principal occupation of the business and identity of the goods or services, or both, to be offered for sale by the business; 
(3)  The State sales tax permit number; 
(4)  The name, local address and local telephone number of the local supervisor or person in charge of the Transient Business; 
(5)  The name, local address and local telephone number of each agent, representative or consignee of the Transient Business who will be transacting business in Amarillo; 
(6)  If the business is to be conducted on Premises owned by a person other than the business to be licensed, then the application shall contain the name and address of the property owner and show that the applicant has the express written permission of the owner of the Premises to conduct business at such location. 
(Code 1960, § 13-34(b); Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-6-29. - Fee; term; reapplication upon change in information. 
    A Transient Retail Business license issued under this division shall require a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each issuance. A license issued to a Transient Retail Business shall expire at the end of thirty (30) days from its issuance. Any change in the information required in the application shall require the reissuance of the license by submitting a new application. 
(Code 1960, § 13-34(c); Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 7688, § 24, 9-12-17) 
Sec. 14-6-30. - Properly zoned location required. 
    Before a license may issue to an applicant under this division, the Building Official shall certify that the business is to be conducted in a properly Zoned location. In the case of a Transient Retail Business to be conducted in a temporary location, the Building Official shall certify that the location has adequate parking for customers and agents exclusive of any Public Right-of-way. 
(Code 1960, § 13-34(d); Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-6-31. - Display; issuance of receipts. 
    A license issued under this division shall be conspicuously displayed. A Transient Retail Business shall, if requested by the customer, issue such customer a receipt in the name of such business as shown on the license application. 
(Code 1960, § 13-34(e); Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
Secs. 14-6-32-14-6-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OCCASIONAL SALES 

Sec. 14-6-51. - Definition. 
    In this article "Occasional Sale" means a sale of tangible personal property (exclusive of Transient Retail Business) in a Zoning District which does not allow business by a person whose occupation does not include the sale of such property. 
(Code 1960, § 13-35(a); Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 5692, § 1, 7-7-87) 
Sec. 14-6-52. - Sale hours limited. 
    Occasional Sales shall be limited to the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m. in no more than three (3) consecutive days. 
(Code 1960, § 13-35(b); Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 5692, § 1, 7-7-87) 
Sec. 14-6-53. - Number restricted; signs. 
    No more than two (2) Occasional Sales may be held in any twelve-month period. One (1) unlighted Sign not to exceed twelve (12) square feet in area located on the Premises shall be permitted during the duration of the Occasional Sale. 
(Code 1960, § 13-35(b); Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86; Ord. No. 5692, § 1, 7-7-87) 
Sec. 14-6-54. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DOOR TO DOOR SALES 

Sec. 14-6-55. - Limited scope and purpose. 
(a)  This article applies only to residential door to door peddling activity as defined herein. The requirements of this article do not apply to persons going door to door for any other purpose, such as: expressing religious, political, civic, or philosophical messages, canvassing, distributing hand bills, polling, pamphleteering, social conversation, and similar types of non-commercial communication. 
(b)  The requirements of this article are intended as one means to discourage those who would use residential door to door commercial peddling in the City of Amarillo as an opportunity for crime, fraud, exploitation of children, and disturbing residents. 
(c)  Registration in accordance with this article does not constitute any guarantee, warranty, endorsement, or assurance of the honesty or legitimacy of any individual or group, or the value, quantity, or other character of the goods and services offered by door to door peddlers. 
(Ord. No. 6709, § 2, 1-27-2004) 
Sec. 14-6-56. - Definitions. 
    In this article, the following terms have the meanings shown: 
(a)  Adult is a person eighteen (18) years old or older. 
(b)  Child (children) is a person younger than eighteen (18) years. 
(c)  Door to door peddler, salesman, sales person, solicitor (and the verb form of those nouns): is a person (and the acts of such person) who goes from residence to residence in an attempt to make personal contact with a resident, without prior invitation or appointment, for the purpose of attempting to sell, trade, or rent (or soliciting an order for any such transaction), any goods or services for consideration. This term also includes a supervisor of such a one, who will be in the immediate vicinity of the residence(s) to be solicited. 
(d)  Residence: a house, apartment, mobile home, or other habitation for humans. 
(e)  Resident: any human present at or in a residence.
