(f)  Local Youth organization: an organization that meets all of these requirements: (i) is a charitable or non-profit entity holding a valid 501(c)(3) certification by the Internal Revenue Service, or a public or private primary or secondary school, or a program unit authorized by any such school (such as a band, athletic team, student club, etc.); and, (iii) which raise funds for the organization by door to door peddling as defined herein, predominantly uses children; and, (iv) which presently maintains and has maintained for at least the five (5) years preceding date of application, an office in Potter or Randall County; and, (v) has not been accused by any law enforcement agency of fraud, child labor law violations, or other crime against residents in the course of door to door selling. 
(Ord. No. 6709, § 2, 1-27-2004) 
Sec. 14-6-57. - Required registration and fee; duration. 
    Except as may be exempted or qualified elsewhere in this article, each individual person who desires to engage in the activity of or be a door to door peddler must, before commencing door to door peddling within the City, register in person at the Amarillo Police Department (Monday through Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 3:30 p.m.) and, pay the fee in accordance with Section 14-6-58. The police department shall issue the registration to a qualified applicant the same day as it receives a completed application and fee. Each registration shall be valid for a period of thirty (30) days from the date of issuance. 
(Ord. No. 6709, § 2, 1-27-2004; Ord. No. 7144, § 1, 12-2-2008) 
Sec. 14-6-58. - Procedures and exemption. 
(a)  Each individual person desiring to engage in door to door peddling shall complete a written application at the police department, in person, by providing the following information and documents: 
(1)  Full legal name; date of birth; height; weight; color of hair and eyes; social security number; state issued drivers license or identification card number if the applicant has one; home address and telephone number. The person must produce some form of government issued photo identification that substantiates some or all of this information; and, 
(2)  Whether the applicant has been convicted of or received deferred adjudication for any criminal offense which is classified as a class 'B' misdemeanor or higher offense, including felonies; and if so, then fully state the nature of the charge, the date of disposition, and the county and state of the court. This applies to offenses in other states which, if it had been committed in Texas, would be classified as described above. 
(3)  General description of the goods or service to be offered; name of company or entity for whom the peddler works (without regard to the nature of that business relationship, i.e., employee, agent, independent contractor, franchisee, etc.); address and telephone number of the company; and, the name of the peddler's supervisor or other management point of contact person at the company. 
(4)  Description of each motor vehicle the peddler or a supervisor may use in the course of the peddling activity. 
(5)  Pay a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for each individual registration. 
(b)  Provided however, a local youth organization must either have each child register in accordance with subsection (a) or, in the alternative, an authorized adult sponsor or representative of the local youth organization may appear at the police department and register the local youth organization as a group, as follows: 
(1)  The adult must provide all of the registration information required by subsection (a) as to that adult and, in addition, provide the name, office address, and office telephone number of the local youth organization. 
(2)  Pay a single fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for registration of the local youth organization. 
(c)  Any adult who desires to engage in door to door peddling, whether for a local youth organization or otherwise shall register and pay the fee per subsection (a). 
(d)  A child who desires to engage in door to door peddling, for other than a registered local youth organization, is subject to and must register and pay the fee as required in subsection (a). Moreover, such child must be accompanied for the registration process by a parent, legal guardian, or other adult who presents written, notarized permission from the child's parent or legal guardian for the child to engage in door to door peddling in Amarillo, Texas. 
(e)  A parent or adult sibling of a child who is present with that child while the child is engaged in door to door peddling for a local youth organization, is not required to register under this article. 
(f)  An applicant is not qualified to receive registration as a door-to-door solicitor if it is found that the applicant: 
(1)  Is currently or within the ten (10) years preceding date of permit application, been on parole, probation, or deferred adjudication for any of these offenses: sexual assault, armed robbery, kidnapping, burglary, assault (Class A and above), weapons violation (Class A and above) or felony theft (each as defined in the Texas Penal Code and includes offenses of a different name in another state but with similar elements and penalties), unless the applicant has had no subsequent conviction or deferred adjudication for a period of ten (10) or more years (excluding class 'C' offenses) following the applicant's release from prison or completion of probation, community supervision, or parole, whichever is later; 
(2)  Is currently a registered sex offender or a person subject to registration; 
(3)  Has affiliation, membership, or associates with a known street gang or criminal enterprise. 
(Ord. No. 6709, § 2, 1-27-2004; Ord. No. 7144, § 2, 12-2-2008) 
Sec. 14-6-59. - Display of registration. 
    A peddler registered under Section 14-6-58(a), or an adult sponsor of a local youth organization registered as a group under Section 14-6-58(b), or other adult or child individually registered under Section 14-6-58(c) or (d) shall, upon the request of any peace officer or a resident who the peddler has contacted, immediately display both a copy of the registration and the government-issued photo identification used for registration. (The obligation to carry and display photographic identification does not apply to a child who has been registered individually but has not been issued any such identification by any governmental agency.) 
(Ord. No. 6709, § 2, 1-27-2004) 
Sec. 14-6-60. - Hours. 
    In order to preserve the peace of residents and to reduce the likelihood of child labor exploitation, no door to door peddler shall enter upon the property of any residence prior to ten o'clock in the morning (10:00 a.m.) or after seven o'clock in the evening (7:00 p.m.), Central Time or Central Daylight Savings Time, as applicable. This limitation applies to and includes all categories of peddlers, local youth organizations, other youth organizations, exempt persons, and any registered child, as described in any subpart of Section 14-6-57. 
(Ord. No. 6709, § 2, 1-27-2004) 
Sec. 14-6-61. - Enforcement and offenses. 
(a)  Any peace officer may briefly detain any person observed going door to door of residences, to verify whether such person is engaged in door to door peddling regulated by this article (or is engaged in activity outside the scope of this regulation) and if so, then to verify compliance with the requirements of this article. 
(b)  It is an offense for a person to engage in door to door peddling as defined herein without first registering with the police department, as required in Section 14-6-57, unless specifically exempted herein. 
(c)  It is an offense for a person to provide false or deceptive information when registering under this article pursuant to Section 14-6-57, whether as an individual or as a sponsor of a local youth organization. 
(d)  It is an offense for a person required to register to engage in door to door peddling without carrying both a government issued photographic identification and copy of a valid registration issued as required by Section 14-6-58. 
(e)  It is an offense for any person to engage in door to door peddling at a time other than the hours allowed by Section 14-6-60. 
(Ord. No. 6709, § 2, 1-27-2004; Ord. No. 7144, § 3, 12-2-2008) 
Sec. 14-6-62. - Registration denial, revocation; appeal. 
(a)  The police chief may deny or revoke a registration if it is found that an applicant or registrant: 
(1)  Provided false, misleading, or incomplete information in an application; or, 
(2)  Fails or refuses to pay the required fee; or, 
(3)  Is disqualified under any provision or requirement of this Article; or, 
(4)  Has been convicted of violating this ordinance within one (1) year prior to the date of the application or has two (2) or more charges of violating this ordinance then pending in court as of the date of application. 
(b)  In the event an applicant or registrant desires to challenge the validity of this article, any action or omission taken, or decision made by any employee or official in the course of implementing or enforcing this article, then such person may file a written protest with the City Secretary that clearly states a specific complaint about the ordinance, procedures used to implement it, or an alleged error by an employee or official in implementing or enforcing this Article. The City Council shall hear the matter at its next regular meeting (subject to compliance with open meeting laws). The City Council shall make a decision on the appeal not later than seven (7) days after the hearing. After exhausting this appeal, the aggrieved may file suit in a court of appropriate jurisdiction located in Potter County, Texas. 
(Ord. No. 7144, § 4, 12-2-2008; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
CHAPTER 14-7 - JUNK AND SECONDHAND DEALERS[1] 
  
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate businesses, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 215.075. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-7-1. - Record books-Required; daily entries. 
(a)  Any person who deals in secondhand goods, wares or merchandise within the City, and who is required to obtain a sales tax permit from the Comptroller of Public Accounts of the State, shall keep a record book in which he shall make accurate daily entries of any and all secondhand articles received by him in the course of his business. 
(b)  Record books required by this chapter may be furnished by the City upon application to the Police Department or may be provided by the dealer. Any record book provided by the dealer must be approved by the Chief of Police, such approval to be based upon the book's compatibility with the Police Department record and filing system. If record books are furnished by the City, a cost and handling fee shall be charged to the dealer. 
(Code 1960, § 13-38; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-7-2. - Same-Contents. 
    The record books required by this chapter shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Description of the secondhand articles received by him in the course of his business; 
(2)  The name, address, date of birth, sex, race, nationality, approximate height and weight and identification number of the person from whom he receives such articles. "Identification number" is defined as a driver's license number or social security number, or both; 
(3)  The disposition made by him of such article; 
(4)  If an article is sold, the dealer shall state to whom sold and the price received therefor; unless he has had the article in his possession for thirty (30) days or more, or unless its sales price is under ten dollars ($10.00), in which case the record shall so state. 
(Code 1960, § 13-39; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-7-3. - Same-Alterations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to alter, change or obliterate any entry in a record book required by this chapter. 
(Code 1960, § 13-40; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-7-4. - Same-Accessible to police. 
    The record books required to be kept by this chapter shall be accessible at any and all reasonable times to the Police Department of the City. 
(Code 1960, § 13-41; Ord. No. 5651, § 1, 12-16-86) 
Secs. 14-7-5-14-7-14. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CRAFTED PRECIOUS METALS 

Sec. 14-7-15. - Definitions. 
    As used in this Article the following words and phrases have the meaning indicated: 
    Chief or police chief means the chief of the City of Amarillo Police Department 
    Crafted precious metals means and includes jewelry, watches, silverware, art objects, or any other thing or object made, in whole or in part, from precious metal or metals. 
    Dealer means a person who engages in the business of purchasing and selling crafted precious metals. 
    Department means the City of Amarillo Police Department. 
    Person means an individual, association, corporation, or any other legal entity. 
    Precious metal or metals means and includes gold, silver, platinum, palladium, iridium, rhodium, osmium, ruthenium, or their alloys, excluding coins and commemorative medallions. 
    Temporary location means a place where business is conducted for a period shorter than ninety (90) days. 
(Ord. No. 6659, § 1, 7-21-2003) 
Sec. 14-7-16. - Purchases from minor. 
    A dealer may not purchase precious metals or crafted precious metals from a person under eighteen (18) years of age unless the seller delivers to the dealer before the purchase a written statement from a parent or legal guardian of the seller consenting to the transaction. The dealer shall preserve the statement with the records required to be kept under this Article. The dealer may destroy the statement one year from date of purchase or until the item is sold, whichever occurs later. 
(Ord. No. 6659, § 1, 7-21-2003) 
Sec. 14-7-17. - Report of purchasing. 
(a)  Not later than forty-eight (48) hours after the time it is received, each dealer shall report in accordance with this section, all identifiable precious metals and crafted precious metal that the dealer purchases, takes in trade, accepts for sale on consignment, or accepts for auction. 
(b)  Each dealer, before the time any crafted precious metal is offered for sale or exchange, shall notify each person intending to sell or exchange the crafted precious metal that the person must file with the dealer, before the dealer may accept any of the person's property, a list describing all of the person's precious metal and crafted precious metal to be accepted by the dealer. The list must set forth: 
(1)  The name and address of the proposed seller; 
(2)  A complete and accurate description of each crafted precious metal; 
(3)  A certification by the proposed seller that the information is true and complete; and 
(4)  The driver's license number or DPS identification card number of the seller, as recorded by the dealer upon being physically presented the driver's license or DPS identification card by the seller. 
(c)  On demand the dealer shall provide the list required by Subsection (b) of this section to any peace officer and shall mail or deliver a complete copy of each list to the chief of police not later than forty-eight (48) hours after it is filed with the dealer. 
(d)  Each report required by this Article must be filed in accordance with this section unless a similar report is required by other state law such as the Pawnshop Act. If such a report is required, the report must comply with and be submitted in accordance with the applicable law or ordinance. 
(e)  The report shall be submitted on forms prescribed by the Department and submitted to the office of police chief. 
(f)  The dealer shall retain a copy of the report and list until the third anniversary of the date on which the report is filed. 
(Ord. No. 6659, § 1, 7-21-2003) 
Sec. 14-7-18. - Retention and inspection of property. 
(a)  A dealer may not melt, deface, alter, or dispose of crafted precious metal for which a report is required under this Article before the 20th day after the day on which the report is filed, unless: 
(1)  Prior written approval by the Department is issued for good cause; or 
(2)  The dealer is a pawnbroker and the disposition is the redemption of pledged property by the pledgor. 
(b)  The purchased property must be made available by the dealer for inspection by any police officer during regular business hours while the property is in the dealer's possession. 
(Ord. No. 6659, § 1, 7-21-2003) 
Sec. 14-7-19. - Purchases at temporary locations. 
    A dealer who conducts business from a temporary location may not engage in business of buying precious metal or used items made of precious metal unless the person has filed a registration statement with the department within a twelve-month period at least thirty (30) days preceding the date on which each purchase is made and the person has filed, within the same period, a copy of the registration statement with the Department. A registration statement must set forth: 
(1)  The name and address of the person, or if the dealer is an association or corporation, the statement must set forth the name and address of each member of the association or each officer and director of the corporation, respectively; 
(2)  The location where business is to be conducted; and 
(3)  Other relevant information required by the department. 
(Ord. No. 6659, § 1, 7-21-2003) 
Sec. 14-7-20. - Purchase of melted items. 
    A dealer, in the course of business, may not purchase an object that is formed as the result of the melting, welding, or other alteration of crafted precious metal unless the object is purchased from a manufacturer of or a regular dealer in crafted precious metal. 
(Ord. No. 6659, § 1, 7-21-2003) 
Sec. 14-7-21. - Application of article. 
(a)  This section applies only to the crafted precious metals that have been sold or used primarily for personal, family, or household purposes. This Article does not apply to any person whose purchases and sales of precious metals and products made thereof are merely incidental to its business of extracting, recovering, or salvaging precious metals from industrial by-products and industrial waste products nor does this Article apply to dental, pharmaceutical, or medical applications of crafted precious metals. 
(b)  This section does not apply to crafted precious metal that have been: 
(1)  Acquired in good faith in a transaction involving the stock in trade of another dealer in the City of Amarillo who previously made the reports required by this Article or who has complied with any similar reporting required by ordinance or statute in the jurisdiction of the selling dealer, if: 
(i)  The selling dealer delivers to the acquiring dealer a written document that states that the reports have been made; 
(ii)  The acquiring dealer submits a copy of the statement to the Department; and 
(iii)  Each dealer involved in the transaction retains a copy of the statement required by this subdivision in his place of business until the third anniversary of the date of the transaction. 
(2)  Acquired in a nonjudicial sale, transfer, assignment, assignment for the benefit of creditors, or consignment of the assets or stock in trade, in bulk, or a substantial part of those assets, of an industrial or commercial enterprise, other than a dealer, for the voluntary dissolution or liquidation of the seller's business, or for disposing of an excessive quantity of personal property, or property that has been acquired in a nonjudicial sale or transfer from an owner other than a dealer, his entire household of personal property, or a substantial part of that property, if: 
(i)  The dealer gives written notice to the Department that exemption from reporting is being claimed under this subdivision; and 
(ii)  The dealer retains in his place of business, until the third anniversary of the date of the transaction, a copy of the bill of sale, receipt, inventory list, or other transfer document as a record, which shall be made available for inspection by any peace officer; 
(3)  Acquired in a sale made by any public officer in his official capacity as a trustee in bankruptcy, executor, administrator, receiver, or public official acting under judicial process or authority, or acquired in a sale made on the execution of, or by virtue of, any process issued by a court; 
(4)  Acquired in good faith as part or complete payment for other crafted precious metal by a person, partnership, firm, or corporation whose principal business is primarily that of selling directly to the consumer crafted precious metal that has not been subject to a prior sale; 
(5)  Acquired as surplus property from the United States or a state, subdivision of a state, or municipal corporation; or 
(6)  Reported by a dealer as an acquisition or a purchase, or reported as destroyed or otherwise disposed of, to: 
(i)  A state agency in accordance with another law of this state; or 
(ii)  A city or county office or agency in accordance with another law of this state or a city ordinance. 
(7)  Acquired by a person licensed and regulated under the Texas Pawnshop Act. 
(Ord. No. 6659, § 1, 7-21-2003) 
CHAPTER 14-8. - MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS[1] 
  
Art. I. In General, §§ 14-8-1-14-8-25 Art. II. License, §§ 14-8-26-14-8-34  
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Regulation of sexually oriented businesses, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 243.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-8-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Massage: Any process consisting in kneading, rubbing or otherwise manipulating the skin of the body of a human being, either with the hand or by means of electrical instruments or apparatus, or other special apparatus. 
    Massage Establishment: Any Building, room, place or establishment other than regularly licensed hospital where manipulated Massage or manipulated exercises are practiced upon the human body by anyone not a duly licensed physician, whether with or without use of mechanical, therapeutic or bathing devices, and shall include Turkish bathhouses. 
(Code 1960, § 13-161(a); Ord. No. 5651, § 1(13-42), 12-16-86) 
Cross reference- Definitions to apply throughout Code, § 1-2-1. 
Sec. 14-8-2. - Exemptions. 
    This chapter shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  A licensed physical therapist, a licensed massage therapist, a licensed athletic trainer, a licensed cosmetologist, or a licensed barber performing functions authorized under the license held, a licensed physician or chiropractor, or any individual working under the direct supervision of a licensed physician or chiropractor, while engaged in practicing the healing arts; 
(2)  The administration of Massage for therapeutic purposes in a hospital, nursing home or other health care facility; 
(3)  A Massage Establishment operated by a nonprofit corporation, provided that such Massage Establishment is not the sole or principal activity of the nonprofit corporation. 
(Code 1960, § 13-161(b); Ord. No. 5651, § 1(13-42), 12-16-86; Ord. No. 6009, § 1, 5-11-93) 
Sec. 14-8-3. - Right of inspection, interference with inspectors. 
(a)  The officers of the Police and Health Departments of the City are hereby authorized and empowered to enter, for the purpose of inspection, and to inspect at any time Massage Establishments in the City, for the preservation of law and order and decency and further empowered to, at any time, make such examinations through the licensed physicians of the Department of Health of the City as are necessary to determine whether or not such employees are infected with any infectious disease. 
(b)  It shall be grounds for the revocation of licenses issued under this chapter to interfere with the inspection of such Premises. 
(Code 1960, § 13-172; Ord. No. 5651, § 1(13-53), 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-8-4. - Hours of operation; living, sleeping quarters prohibited. 
    No Massage Establishment shall be kept open for any purpose between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. No such establishment shall be operated or conducted in connection with any place used for living or sleeping quarters. 
(Code 1960, § 13-171; Ord. No. 5651, § 1(13-52), 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-8-5. - Employing prostitutes. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person operating a Massage Establishment to employ a known prostitute in any capacity therein. 
(Code 1960, § 13-173; Ord. No. 5651, § 1(13-54), 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-8-6. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7204, § 4, adopted Jan. 26, 2010, amended § 14-8-6, which pertained to employing homosexuals and derived from Code 1960, § 13-174; Ord. No. 5651, § 1(13-55) adopted Dec. 16, 1986. 
Sec. 14-8-7. - List of employees. 
    The manager or person in charge of Massage Establishments shall keep a list of the names and addresses of all employees, both on duty and off duty. Such list shall be shown to all proper authorities of the Police and Health Departments upon request. 
(Code 1960, § 13-175; Ord. No. 5651, § 1(13-56), 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-8-8. - Operation in residential area. 
    It shall be unlawful for any Massage Establishment to be operated in any section of the City which is Zoned for Residential purposes. 
(Code 1960, § 13-176; Ord. No. 5651, § 1(13-57), 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-8-9. - Sanitary requirements. 
    It shall be the duty of every person conducting or operating a Massage Establishment to keep the same at all times in a clean and sanitary condition. All instruments and mechanical, therapeutic and bathing devices, or parts thereof, that come into contact with the human body shall be sterilized by a modern and approved method of sterilization before initial use, and any such instruments and devices, or parts thereof, after having been used upon one (1) patron shall be sterilized before being used on another. All towels and linens furnished for use of one (1) patron shall not be furnished for use of another until thoroughly laundered. 
(Code 1960, § 13-177; Ord. No. 5651, § 1(13-58), 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-8-10. - Administering massage to person of opposite sex. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to administer a Massage in any Massage Establishment to any person of the opposite sex. This section shall not apply to licensed chiropractor, nor shall it apply to any registered physical therapist or registered nurse operating under the direction of a physician. 
(Code 1960, § 13-178; Ord. No. 5651, § 1(13-59), 12-16-86) 
Secs. 14-8-11-14-8-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSE 

Sec. 14-8-26. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a Massage Establishment without first having obtained a license therefor from the City Secretary, in accordance with the provisions of this article, and paying the fee provided for in this article. Such licenses shall only be issued upon the approval in writing of the Director of Public Health and the Chief of Police, and a Certificate of Occupancy from the Building Inspector. 
(Code 1960, § 13-162; Ord. No. 5651, § 1(13-43), 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-8-27. - Investigation of applicant. 
    After an application has been made for an original license or a renewal of an existing license to operate a Massage Establishment, the Chief of Police shall cause an investigation to be made of the applicant's character and whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime involving moral turpitude in any State, municipal or federal court, or whether the applicant is a person of unfit character, or whether the holder of a license for such an establishment, or any employee of such establishment committed any lewd, indecent or other act contrary to common decency during the last licensing period, or such an establishment employs any person convicted of any crime involving moral turpitude in any State, municipal or federal court, or whether such an establishment employs a woman who has been convicted of vagrancy or prostitution or who is a known prostitute. 
(Code 1960, § 13-164; Ord. No. 5651, § 1(13-45), 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-8-28. - Applicant to furnish names of employees; medical certificates for employees. 
    At the time of making application for the license required by this article, the applicant shall furnish to the Health Department of the City the names and addresses of all employees of Massage Establishments. All such employees of Massage Establishments shall be required to secure from the Health Department a medical certificate certifying that such employee has been examined and that such examination discloses the fact that such person employed, or to be employed by such establishment, is free from any infectious or communicable disease. Such medical certificate shall be renewed annually by the Director of Public Health. 
(Code 1960, § 13-165; Ord. No. 5651, § 1(13-46), 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-8-29. - Fee; refund policy. 
    The annual license fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each Massage Establishment. If the license is obtained between January 1 and June 30 of any year, the full amount of such fees shall be paid. If such license is obtained between July 1 and December 31 of any year, the fee shall be one-half of such amount. No refund shall ever be made of any such license fees. 
(Code 1960, § 13-166; Ord. No. 5651, § 1(13-47), 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-8-30. - Refusal to issue or renew. 
    The Chief of Police shall refuse to approve the issuance or renewal of any license required by this article to any applicant who has been convicted of any crime involving moral turpitude in any State, municipal or federal court, or where the applicant is a person of unfit character, or where the holder of a license for such an establishment or any employee of such an establishment committed any lewd, indecent or other act contrary to common decency during the last licensing period, or where any such establishment employs any person convicted of any crime involving moral turpitude in any State, municipal or federal court, or which employs a woman who has been convicted of vagrancy or prostitution, or who is a known prostitute. 
(Code 1960, § 13-167; Ord. No. 5651, § 1(13-48), 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-8-31. - Appeal from denial. 
(a)  If the Chief of Police refuses to approve the issuance of an original license or the renewal of a license to any applicant under this article, the action of the Chief of Police shall be final unless the applicant shall, within ten (10) days after the refusal to approve the issuance of or the renewal of a license, file a written appeal with the City Secretary, addressed to the City Council, requesting a hearing by the City upon the question as to whether or not his application shall be granted. 
(b)  If such an appeal is filed, the Chief of Police shall provide the City Council with a record of all proceedings theretofore had with reference to the application in question, including the written application, together with the action of the Chief of Police and the reasons for such action. The City Council shall, within thirty (30) days, grant a hearing thereon to determine the correctness of the action of the Chief of Police. At such hearing the City Council may make such investigation as it may see fit, whether all the pertinent facts appear in the application or not, and the City Council shall determine whether or not such license shall be granted or refused, and such action as the City Council shall take thereon shall be final and conclusive. 
(Code 1960, § 13-168; Ord. No. 5651, § 1(13-49), 12-16-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 14-8-32. - Display. 
    The license required by this article shall be exhibited at all times in such establishments. 
(Code 1960, § 13-163; Ord. No. 5651, § 1(13-44), 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-8-33. - Revocation. 
    Any Massage Establishment license issued by the City Secretary after approval in writing by the Director of Public Health and the Chief of Police, pursuant to this article, may be suspended or revoked by the Chief of Police when it shall appear that the business of the person to whom such permit was issued has been conducted in a disorderly or improper manner, or in violation of any statute of the State, any provision of this Code or other ordinance of the City, or that the person conducting such business is of unfit character to conduct same, or that the purposes for which such license has been issued is being abused, to the detriment of the public, or that the license is being used for a purpose different from that for which it was issued to the license holder. Such notice of revocation shall be given by the Chief of Police in writing and shall be addressed to the license holder's last known business address. 
(Code 1960, § 13-169; Ord. No. 5651, § 1(13-50), 12-16-86) 
Sec. 14-8-34. - Appeal from decision to revoke. 
(a)  If the Chief of Police revokes the license issued to any license holder under this article, the action of the Chief of Police shall be final unless the license holder shall, within ten (10) days after the receipt of written notice of such revocation, file a written appeal with the City Secretary addressed to the City Council, requesting a hearing by the Council upon the question as to whether or not such license should have been revoked. 
(b)  If such an appeal is filed, the Chief of Police shall provide the City Council with a record of all the proceedings theretofore had with reference to the revocation of the license in question, together with the action of the Chief of Police and the reasons for such action. The City Council shall, within thirty (30) days, grant a hearing thereon to determine the correctness of the action of the Chief of Police. At such hearing the City Council may make such investigation as it may see fit, and the City Council shall determine whether or not the action of the Chief of Police shall be ratified and confined, or should be set aside, and such decision of the City Council, after such hearing, shall be final and conclusive as to all parties. 
(Code 1960, § 13-170; Ord. No. 5651, § 1(13-51), 12-16-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
CHAPTER 14-9. - CABLE TELEVISION 

Sec. 14-9-1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this Chapter is to implement the authority to regulate Cable Television rates and services as authorized by the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992 (the "Act"), within the parameters promulgated in regulations of the Federal Communications Commission (the "FCC") and to administer FCC requirements. 
(Ord. No. 6044, § 1, 11-9-93) 
Sec. 14-9-2. - Compliance and administration. 
    The City will comply with and administer, to the fullest extent practicable, the rules and regulations adopted from time to time by the FCC as well as the FCC Regulations currently in effect and the rules set out in this Chapter. 
(Ord. No. 6044, § 1, 11-9-93) 
Sec. 14-9-3. - Rate regulation. 
(a)  Thirty (30) days following the adoption of this Chapter the Cable Television Franchise (the "Cable Operator") shall submit rate schedules and supporting data for its basic service rate schedule. The basic service tier is that tier which includes all broadcast signals, except those originating to satellites for transmission, delivered by television cable. 
(b)  Within thirty (30) days of receipt the City will: 
(1)  Issue a written order allowing additional time for analysis: 
a.  Not to exceed ninety (90) days if the rate schedules are based on benchmark rates, 
b.  Not to exceed one hundred and fifty (150) days if the rate schedules and supporting data are based on cost of service; 
(2)  Issue a written order allowing the proposed rates to take effect; or 
(3)  Issue a written order disallowing the proposed rate schedule. 
Failure on the part of the City to act within any required time will allow the proposed rates to go into effect by default. Should the City later determine that rates in effect by default are excessive, it may set proper rates and order refunds relating back one (1) year, but in no event earlier than September 1, 1993. 
(c)  Upon receipt of a proposed rate schedule the City may determine the proper level of rates to be charged and enter an order by ordinance setting such rates. 
(1)  If the proposed rate schedule is based on the benchmark formula and calculations, the City may not set rates lower than those prescribed by the FCC's benchmark rate tables or lower than ten (10) percent less than the cable operator's September 30, 1992 per channel rate, whichever is higher. 
(2)  If the proposed rate schedule is based on cost of service, the City may disregard the benchmark rates and the cable operator's September 30, 1992 rates and prescribe rates it finds to be just and reasonable. 
(3)  Should the FCC lower the benchmark rates, the City may reduce the cable operator's rates on its own motion. 
(d)  Rates will not be set by the City without a public hearing which shall be called by resolution passed at least two (2) weeks prior to the public hearing. Notice of such public hearing will be published once one (1) week prior to the public hearing. Formal notice to the cable operator will be required prior to such hearing. Any interested person may participate in the public hearing. Should the cable operator fail to appear for such hearing, its rates may be set at a level the City finds reasonable. The burden of proof shall be on the cable operator to show that its rates conform to the Act and FCC Regulations. 
(e)  The City may hire such rate analysts and consultants as it requires to make recommendation to the City. The cable operator shall have a ministerial duty to provide the City's consultant with any information in whatever detail the consultant requires to make the required recommendation. The City shall adopt the report of such consultant before the consultant's recommendations can be relied on by the City. Upon adoption of the consultant's report and approval of the consultant's fees and charges, the cable operator shall reimburse the City for the reasonable expenses relating to the consultant's work. 
(f)  Rate making is a quasi judicial function of the City, and rates may not be enacted as a result of a settlement. 
(g)  Should the City determine that rates being charged by the cable operator are excessive it may order the cable operator to refund the excessive portion of such rates to subscribers. The cable operator shall maintain an accounting of customer billings for at least one (1) year at all times on which such refunds shall be based. The cable operator's liability for refunds shall be limited to one (1) year and shall not extend prior to September 1, 1993. Within sixty (60) days of a refund order the cable operator shall submit a refund recapitulation to the City detailing the refund calculation, the interest calculation and when the refund was made. Refunds shall be a ministerial duty of the cable operator. 
(Ord. No. 6044, § 1, 11-9-93) 
Sec. 14-9-4. - Equipment and customer charges. 
(a)  The cable operator may not impose charges for use of equipment by subscribers that exceed the reasonable costs of providing such equipment based on amortization of initial equipment purchases over a reasonable time. Amortization periods employed by the cable operator for Federal Income Tax purposes shall be presumed reasonable. The cable operator may recover a reasonable level of profit above the cost recovery. 
(b)  The cable operator may not impose charges for customer services which exceed the incremental costs of providing such services plus a reasonable level of profit on such costs. 
(1)  No charge will be imposed on a customer for changing levels of service based on the cable operator's re-tiering of service if such changes are requested by the customer within thirty (30) days of notice of re-tiering. 
(2)  The cable operator shall not implement or use a negative billing option which tells the customer, in effect, "we will provide you the following service unless you tell us you do not want the service." 
(Ord. No. 6044, § 1, 11-9-93) 
Sec. 14-9-5. - Confidentiality of information. 
    Should the cable operator assert or contend that any information submitted to the City or required by the City or its consultants is confidential and should be protected from disclosure under the Texas Open Records Act or the Freedom of Information Act, it shall be incumbent on the cable operator to submit to the City a legal brief supporting its assertion of confidentiality. The City will not rule on the confidentiality but will request a ruling from the appropriate decision-making authority using solely as justification the cable operator's brief. The City will be bound by the decision of the appropriate decision-making body. The cable operator may pursue whatever remedies from such decision it deems advisable. 
(Ord. No. 6044, § 1, 11-9-93) 
Sec. 14-9-6. - Customer service standards. 
(a)  FCC Regulations require specific standards for customer service by cable operators. The cable operator will file with the City Secretary its written procedures for compliance with FCC customer service standards. 
(b)  Should the City receive a customer service complaint it will transmit details of the complaint to the cable operator by telephone or facsimile transmission. The cable operator will give the city its response to the complaint within the time prescribed by the FCC Regulations for responding to the type of complaint. If the cable operator is unable to respond to the complaint within the prescribed time it will notify the City in writing of the reason for its inability and the expected time of response. 
(c)  Failure of the cable operator to respond to customer complaints as required may result in a complaint being filed with the FCC. 
(Ord. No. 6044, § 1, 11-9-93) 
Sec. 14-9-7. - Severability. 
    Should any word, clause, phrase, sentence or portion of this ordinance, or of the provisions adopted hereby be determined invalid due to conflict with or lack of enabling authority such portion shall be severable and shall be severed from these provisions and shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof. 
CHAPTER 14-10. - CREDIT ACCESS BUSINESSES 

Sec. 14-10-1. - Short title and purpose. 
(a)  This article may be known and cited as the "Credit Access Businesses Regulation." 
(b)  The purpose of this article is to protect the welfare of the citizens of the City of Amarillo by monitoring credit access businesses in an effort to reduce abusive and predatory lending practices. To this end, this article establishes a registration program for credit access businesses, imposes restrictions on extensions of consumer credit made by credit access businesses, and imposes recordkeeping requirements on credit access businesses. 
(Ord. No. 7486, § 1, 9-16-2014) 
Sec. 14-10-2. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
(1)  Certificate of registration means a certificate of registration issued by the director under this article to the owner or operator of a credit access business. 
(2)  Consumer means an individual who is solicited to purchase or who purchases the services of a credit access business. 
(3)  Consumer's language of preference is the language the consumer understands best. 
(4)  Credit access business has the meaning given that term in § 393.601 of the Texas Finance Code. 
(5)  Deferred presentment transaction has the meaning given that term in § 393.601 of the Texas Finance Code. 
(6)  Director means the director of the department designated by the City Manager to enforce and administer this chapter. 
(7)  Extension of consumer credit has the meaning given that term in § 393.001 of the Texas Finance Code. 
(8)  Motor vehicle title loan has the meaning given that term in § 393.601 of the Texas Finance Code. 
(9)  Person means any individual, corporation, organization, partnership, association, financial institution, or any other legal entity. 
(10)  Registrant means a person issued a certificate of registration for a credit access business under this chapter and includes all owners and operators of the credit access business identified in the registration application filed under this chapter. 
(11)  State license means a license to operate a credit access business issued by the Texas Consumer Credit Commissioner under ch. 393, subch. G of the Texas Finance Code. 
(Ord. No. 7486, § 1, 9-16-2014) 
Sec. 14-10-3. - Violations; penalty. 
(a)  A person who violates a provision of this chapter, or who fails to perform an act required of the person by this chapter, commits an offense. A person commits a separate offense for each and every violation relating to an extension of consumer credit, and for each day during which a violation is committed, permitted, or continued. 
(b)  An offense under this chapter is punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(c)  A culpable mental state is not required for the commission of an offense under this article and need not be proved. 
(d)  The penalties provided for in subsection (b) are in addition to any other remedies that the city may have under city ordinances, charter, or state law. 
(Ord. No. 7486, § 1, 9-16-2014) 
Sec. 14-10-4. - Applicability; defenses. 
(a)  This article applies only to those persons and transactions required to be licensed by the state as a credit access business under ch. 393, subch. G, of the Texas Finance Code. It is a defense to prosecution under this article that at the time of the alleged offense the person was not required to be licensed by the state as a credit access business under ch. 393, subch. G, of the Texas Finance Code. 
(b)  This article does not apply to those persons and transactions described in Texas Finance Code § 393.002 (as amended) or the Texas Pawnshop Act. 
(Ord. No. 7486, § 1, 9-16-2014) 
Sec. 14-10-5. - Registration required; offense. 
    A person commits an offense if the person acts, operates, or conducts businesses as a credit access business without a valid certificate of registration. A certificate of registration is required for each physically separate credit access business. 
(Ord. No. 7486, § 1, 9-16-2014) 
Sec. 14-10-6. - Registration application. 
(a)  To obtain a certificate of registration for a credit access business, a person must submit an application on a form provided for that purpose to the director. The application must contain the following: 
(1)  The name, street address, mailing address, facsimile number, and telephone number of the applicant. 
(2)  The business or trade name, street address, mailing address, facsimile number, and telephone number of the credit access business. 
(3)  The names, street addresses, mailing addresses, and telephone numbers of all owners of the credit access business, and the nature and extent of each person's interest in the credit access business. 
(4)  A copy of a current, valid state license held by the credit access business pursuant to ch. 393, subch. G, of the Texas Finance Code. 
(5)  A copy of a current, valid certificate of occupancy showing that the credit access business is in compliance with this Code of Ordinances. 
(6)  A non-refundable application fee of forty dollars ($40.00). This fee is due for both an original application and a renewal. 
(b)  An applicant or registrant shall notify the director within forty-five (45) days after any material change in the information contained in the application for a certificate of registration, including, but not limited to, any change of address and any change in the status of the state license held by the applicant or registrant. 
(Ord. No. 7486, § 1, 9-16-2014) 
Sec. 14-10-7. - Issuance and display of certificate of registration; presentment. 
(a)  The director shall issue to the applicant a certificate of registration upon receiving a completed application under section 14-10-6. 
(b)  A certificate of registration issued under this section must be conspicuously displayed to the public in the credit access business. The certificate of registration must be presented upon request to the director or any peace officer for examination. 
(Ord. No. 7486, § 1, 9-16-2014) 
Sec. 14-10-8. - Expiration and renewal of certificate of registration. 
(a)  A certificate of registration expires on the earliest of: 
(1)  One (1) year after the date of issuance: or 
(2)  The date of revocation, suspension, surrender, expiration without renewal, or other termination of the registrant's state license. 
(b)  A certificate of registration may be renewed by making application and paying the fee in accordance with section 14-10-6. A registrant shall apply for renewal at least thirty (30) days before the expiration of the registration. 
(Ord. No. 7486, § 1, 9-16-2014) 
Sec. 14-10-9. - Non-transferability. 
    A certificate of registration for a credit access business is not transferable. 
(Ord. No. 7486, § 1, 9-16-2014) 
Sec. 14-10-10. - Maintenance of records. 
(a)  A credit access business shall maintain a complete set of records of all extensions of consumer credit arranged or obtained by the credit access business, whether an original transaction or refinancing or renewal of an extension of consumer credit, which must include the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the consumer. 
(2)  The principal amount of cash actually advanced. 
(3)  The length of the extension of consumer credit, including the number of installments and renewals. 
(4)  The fees charged by the credit access business to arrange or obtain an extension of consumer credit; and 
(5)  The documentation used to establish a consumer's income under section 14-10-11(c). 
(b)  A credit access business shall maintain a copy of each written agreement between the credit access business and a consumer evidencing an extension of a consumer credit (including, but not limited to, any refinancing or renewal granted to the consumer). 
(c)  A credit access business shall maintain copies of all quarterly reports filed with the Texas Consumer Credit Commissioner under § 393.627 of the Texas Finance Code. 
(d)  The records required to be maintained by a credit access business under this section must be retained for at least three (3) years after date of an extension of credit (whether in the form of an original, refinance, or renewal transaction) expires, terminates, or is cancelled. Such records at each registered location shall be made available for inspection by the Director or his designee, agent, contractor, at that location, upon request during the usual and customary business hours of the credit access business. 
(Ord. No. 7486, § 1, 9-16-2014) 
Sec. 14-10-11. - Restriction on extension of consumer credit. 
(a)  The cash advanced under an extension of consumer credit that a credit access business obtains for a consumer or assists a consumer in obtaining in the form of a deferred presentment transaction may not exceed twenty (20) percent of the consumer's gross monthly income. 
(b)  The cash advanced under an extension of consumer credit that a credit access business obtains for a consumer or assists a consumer in obtaining in the form of a motor vehicle title loan may not exceed the lesser of: 
(1)  Three (3) percent of the consumer's gross annual income; or 
(2)  Seventy (70) percent of the retail value of the motor vehicle. 
(c)  A credit access business shall retain a copy of one (1) or more of the following documents used to establish or determine a consumer's income: a paycheck issued to the consumer and dated within the same month as the consumer applies for extension of consumer credit; an IRS Form W-2 issued to the consumer for the preceding tax year; the consumer's personal income tax return for the preceding tax year; or, a signed letter from the consumer's employer signed and dated within the month in which an extension of consumer credit is sought, which states the length of the employer's payroll period and the total wages that the employer pays or expects to pay to the consumer per payroll period. 
(d)  An extension of consumer credit that a credit access business obtains for a consumer or assists a consumer in obtaining and that provides for repayment in installments may not be payable in more than four (4) installments. Proceeds from each installment must be used to repay at least twenty-five (25) percent of the principal amount of the extension of consumer credit. An extension of consumer credit that provides for repayment in installments may not be refinanced or renewed. 
(e)  An extension of consumer credit that a credit access business obtains for a consumer or assists a consumer in obtaining and that provides for a single lump sum repayment may not be refinanced or renewed more than three (3) times. Proceeds from each refinancing or renewal must be used to repay at least twenty-five (25) percent of the principal amount of the original extension of consumer credit. 
(f)  For purposes of this section, an extension of consumer credit that is made to a consumer within seven (7) days after a previous extension of consumer credit has been paid by the consumer will constitute a refinancing or renewal. 
(Ord. No. 7486, § 1, 9-16-2014) 
Sec. 14-10-12. - Requirement of consumer understanding of agreement. 
(a)  Every agreement between the credit access business and a consumer evidencing an extension of consumer credit (including, but not limited to, an original transaction and any refinancing or renewal) and each required notice, disclosure, and other forms must be written in and available for use in English and Spanish at that location. The consumer shall select which of those language versions shall be used for the transaction. This section does not restrict or prevent a credit access business from having and using agreements and other documents that are written in other languages that are commonly encountered at that location, for use by consumers who choose to use forms in such other language(s), if available. 
(b)  For a consumer who cannot read, every agreement between the credit access business and that consumer evidencing an extension of consumer credit (including but not limited to, an original transaction, any refinancing or renewal), disclosure, and notice required by law must be read orally to the consumer in English or Spanish. The consumer must provide for any additional or further interpretation into another language, if needed or desired. 
(Ord. No. 7486, § 1, 9-16-2014) 
Sec. 14-10-13. - Referral to consumer credit counseling. 
    A credit access business shall provide a form, to be prescribed by the Director, to each consumer seeking assistance in obtaining an extension of consumer credit which references non-profit agencies that provide financial education and training programs and agencies with cash assistance programs. The form will also contain information regarding extensions of consumer credit, and must include the information required by section 14-10-10(a)(1)-(4) specific to the loan agreement with the consumer. If the Director has prescribed a form in the consumer's language of preference, the form must be provided in the consumer's language of preference. 
(Ord. No. 7486, § 1, 9-16-2014) 
Title XVI - TRANSPORTATION 
CHAPTER 16-2. - AIRPORTS AND AIRCRAFT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Airport board, § 2-6-41 et seq.; airport height hazard and zoning regulations, Ch. 4-9. 
State Law reference- Municipal Airports Act, V.A.C.S. art. 46d-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-2-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Aircraft: Any airplane, helicopter, gasbag, flying machine, balloon, or any contrivance now known or hereafter invented, used or designed for navigation or flight in the air, except as parachute or other contrivance used primarily as safety equipment. 
    Airport Department: The department charged with the administration, planning and protection of the aviation interests of the City and the maintenance of the City's property used for airport purposes. 
    Airport Manager: The duly appointed head of the City's Airport Department. 
    Air Terminal: Any and all real property held by the City, together with its facilities, appurtenances and improvements used for municipal airport purposes. 
    Air Terminal Building: The Building located at 10801 Airport Boulevard, Amarillo, Texas, which is used to transfer passengers and cargo from land to air travel and vice versa. 
    Contract: Agreements entered into between the City and a second or third party, granting rights and privileges to engage in commercial activities at the Air Terminal. 
    FAA: The Federal Aviation Administration. 
    Landing Area: That portion of the Air Terminal lying within one thousand (1,000) feet of the centerline of any designated Runway and including that area lying within one thousand (1,000) feet beyond the end of any designated Runway. Landing area includes Runways within the definition of Movement Area. 
    Movement Area: The taxiways, aprons and other areas of the Air Terminal used or intended to be used for surface maneuvering of Aircraft. 
    Vehicles: Every description of carriage, vehicle or other conveyances. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-1; Ord. No. 5576, § 1, 3-13-86) 
Cross reference- Definitions to apply throughout Code, § 1-2-1. 
Sec. 16-2-2. - Standards to be observed. 
    All activities at the Amarillo Air Terminal which are of an aeronautical nature shall be conducted in conformity with current FAA regulations, authorized orders issued by the Airport Manager, and the provisions of this chapter which are not in conflict with FAA regulations. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-2) 
Sec. 16-2-3. - Parachuting. 
    No person shall make a nonemergency parachute jump from an Aircraft onto the Air Terminal without prior written approval of the Airport Manager, application for which must be accompanied by the necessary certificate of waiver from the FAA. Except as provided herein, the pilot of an Aircraft shall not permit jumping from any Aircraft over or within the traffic pattern or boundaries of the Amarillo Air Terminal. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-3; Ord. No. 5867, § 1, 7-10-90) 
Sec. 16-2-4. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this chapter or any rules or regulations promulgated by the Airport Manager shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and punished as provided in section 1-1-5 of this Code. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-109) 
Secs. 16-2-5-16-2-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AIR TERMINAL REGULATIONS 

Sec. 16-2-21. - Restricted areas. 
    All areas of the Air Terminal except those areas normally open to the public are restricted; no person shall enter upon the Landing Area, Movement Area or into hangars except: 
(1)  Persons possessing an identification badge issued or approved by the Airport Manager; 
(2)  Persons assigned to duty therein with the proper identification; 
(3)  Authorized FAA representatives; 
(4)  Passengers under appropriate supervision entering such areas for the purpose of enplaning or deplaning; 
(5)  Persons engaged in the operation of any Aircraft; 
(6)  Emergency personnel, vehicles and equipment. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-16; Ord. No. 5576, § 1, 3-13-86) 
Sec. 16-2-22. - Powers of airport manager. 
(a)  The Airport Manager is expressly authorized and empowered to promulgate rules and regulations supplementing this chapter, to protect the aviation interest of the City. Violations of such rules and regulations shall be punishable as provided in section 1-1-5. 
(b)  The Airport Manager is hereby empowered to employ in the interest of public safety such measures as are deemed necessary to minimize hazards which endanger life or property. 
(c)  The Airport Manager is hereby empowered to appoint and employ such airport security personnel as the City Council may authorize in the budget of the City. Such personnel shall be commissioned as peace officers and shall exercise the authority thereof. Their qualifications and duties shall be prescribed by the Airport Manager. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-17; Ord. No. 5907, § 1, 3-12-91; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 16-2-23. - Preservation of air terminal property. 
    No person shall alter, add to, or erect any Building or Sign or make any excavation at the Air Terminal without proper authorization. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-18) 
Sec. 16-2-24. - Wrecked or disabled aircraft. 
(a)  Subject to the rules pertaining to release of Aircraft contained in the National Transportation Safety Board Regulations, which reads as follows: 
"Subpart C-Preservation, Access to and Release of Aircraft Wreckage, Mail, Cargo and Records 
"(a)  The operator of an Aircraft is responsible for preserving to the extent possible any Aircraft wreckage, cargo and mail aboard the Aircraft, and all records, including those of flight recorders, pertaining to the operation and maintenance of the Aircraft and to airmen involved in an accident or incident for which notification must be given until the Board takes custody thereof or a release is granted. 
"(b)  Prior to the time the Board or its authorized representative takes custody of Aircraft wreckage, mail or cargo such wreckage, mail and cargo may be disturbed or moved only to the extent necessary: 
"(1)  To remove persons injured or trapped; 
"(2)  To protect the wreckage from further damage; or 
"(3)  To protect the public from injury. 
"(c)  Where it is necessary to disturb or move Aircraft wreckage, mail or cargo, sketches, descriptive notes, and photographs shall be made, if possible, of the accident locale including original position and condition of the wreckage and any significant impact marks." 
The pilot or operator of any Aircraft involved in any accident at the Amarillo Air Terminal shall be responsible for the prompt disposal of Aircraft or disabled at the Amarillo Air Terminal and parts of such Aircraft as directed by the Airport Manager. In the event of the pilot's or operator's failure to comply with such directions, such wrecked or disabled Aircraft or part thereof may be removed by the Airport Manager at the Operator's expense without liability for damage which may result in the course of such removal. 
(b)  As a last resort, if wreckage is an immediate detriment to safety, and neither the National Transportation Safety Board nor the Federal Aviation Administration can be contacted, the Airport Manager should record all available evidence and take steps to have the Aircraft removed. 
(c)  If the disabled Aircraft, because of its location, jeopardizes the safety of other flights, the Airport Manager is hereby authorized to close all or part of the Amarillo Air Terminal and to take immediate steps to notify the Federal Aviation Administration. 
(d)  Witnesses to and participants in Aircraft accidents shall make a full report thereof to the appropriate FAA flight standards office and to the Airport Manager. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-19) 
Sec. 16-2-25. - Abandoned property. 
    No person shall abandon any property on the Air Terminal Premises. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-20) 
Secs. 16-2-26-16-2-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LANDING AND MOVEMENT AREA 

Sec. 16-2-41. - Application. 
    The rules and regulations in this article apply to the operation of Vehicles and Aircraft on the Landing and Movement Areas of the Air Terminal. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-32; Ord. No. 5576, § 1, 3-13-86) 
Sec. 16-2-42. - Lawful order and direction. 
    Every person operating a Vehicle at the Air Terminal shall obey the lawful orders, signals or directions by voice, hand or otherwise of the Amarillo Control Tower, the Air Terminal security police or the Airport Manager. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-33) 
Sec. 16-2-43. - Dangerous materials. 
(a)  Vehicles. No person shall operate, stop or park, on the Landing or Movement Area, any Vehicle transporting any dangerous materials at such time or place in or such manner or condition so as to endanger persons or property. 
(b)  Aircraft. Aircraft transporting dangerous materials will be held on the runup pads for Runway 04 or Runway 22 or no closer than seven hundred (700) feet from the Air Terminal Building on the southwest apron, pending inspection by the Airport Manager or his authorized representative. 
(c)  Department of Energy. Dangerous materials handled by the Department of Energy shall be loaded or unloaded on the alert apron at pad 5. 
(d)  Definition. For purposes of this section the term "dangerous materials" shall mean any explosive, flammable, combustible, corrosive, poisonous or radioactive substance or material, or any compressed gasses, or any other material which, in the opinion of the Airport Manager, constitutes a hazard to persons or property. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-34; Ord. No. 5576, § 1, 3-13-86) 
Sec. 16-2-44. - Operating permission. 
    No person shall operate any Vehicle on the Landing Area or on the Movement Area without first obtaining permission from the Amarillo Control Tower, the Airport security police or the Airport Manager. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-35; Ord. No. 5576, § 1, 3-13-86) 
Sec. 16-2-45. - Emergency right-of-way. 
    All ground self-propelled Vehicles except emergency equipment responding to an alarm shall yield the Right-of-way to any Aircraft in motion. All Aircraft shall hold their position during an emergency unless otherwise directed by the Amarillo Control Tower. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-36) 
Secs. 16-2-46-16-2-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TRAFFIC REGULATIONS 

Sec. 16-2-61. - Application. 
    The rules and regulations in this article shall apply only to vehicular and pedestrian traffic outside the Landing and Movement Areas of the Air Terminal. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-37; Ord. No. 5576, § 1, 3-13-86) 
Sec. 16-2-62. - Airport manager. 
(a)  The Airport Manager shall have the power to promulgate and supervise traffic regulations pertaining to vehicular and pedestrian traffic at the Air Terminal. 
(b)  All rules and regulations promulgated pursuant to subsection (a) shall be subject to approval by the City Manager. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-38) 
Sec. 16-2-63. - Enforcement; violations. 
(a)  Rules and regulations pertaining to vehicular and pedestrian traffic, parking, loading and unloading shall be enforced by the Police Department or by the airport security personnel of the City. 
(b)  Violations of traffic rules and regulations at the Air Terminal shall be handled in the same manner and carry the same penalty assessed or prescribed for similar violations of other City traffic ordinances. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-39) 
Sec. 16-2-64. - Pedestrian traffic control. 
    Pedestrian traffic at the Air Terminal shall be limited to the walkways, traffic lanes and areas of land or Buildings of the Air Terminal designated by the Airport Manager. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-39; Ord. No. 5907, § 1, 3-12-91) 
Sec. 16-2-65. - Airport roadways. 
    All persons entering upon any roadway on the Air Terminal property shall comply with the regulations governing the use of such roadways and shall obey all posted traffic-control Signs. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-41) 
Sec. 16-2-66. - Traffic signs. 
(a)  When proper Signs are posted and in place designating the restrictions or limitation of any parking space for use of Vehicles at the Air Terminal, the Signs shall be prima facie evidence of the restrictions applicable to such areas or space. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any parking restriction or limitations set forth in accordance with subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-42) 
Sec. 16-2-67. - Ground vehicle speed limits. 
(a)  Vehicles shall be operated on established roadways in strict compliance with speed limits posted on traffic Signs, and in conformity with all motor vehicle laws of the State. 
(b)  On passenger loading ramps, no Vehicles shall exceed a speed of ten (10) miles per hour. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-43) 
Sec. 16-2-68. - Parking restrictions, air terminal building. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, no Vehicle used for private, public or commercial purposes shall be parked or permitted to stand on the first and second level drives adjacent to the Air Terminal Building. 
(b)  Vehicles shall be permitted to be parked on the first and second level drives adjacent to the Air Terminal Building only in the marked passenger loading and unloading zone, and then only for the period of time marked by appropriate signs. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-44) 
Sec. 16-2-69. - Airport ground transportation regulations and fees. 
    The City hereby adopts the following regulations and fees to apply to any and all commercial ground transportation operators operating at the Rick Husband Amarillo International Airport: 
(a)  Texas Occupations Code, Chapter 2402, Transportation Network Companies, (as amended) is adopted by the City of Amarillo and shall govern all Transportation Network Company operations at the Rick Husband Amarillo International Airport. 
(b)  The City of Amarillo shall have the right and authority to impose fees upon Transportation Network Companies for the right to operate on the Rick Husband Amarillo International Airport. 
(c)  The City of Amarillo shall have the right and authority to impose fees upon taxi cab company operators, limousine company operators, and any other commercial ground transportation company operators for the right to operate on the Rick Husband Amarillo International Airport. 
(d)  The City of Amarillo shall have the right and authority to impose fees upon offairport hotel shuttle bus operators and off-airport rental car shuttle bus operators for the right to operate on the Rick Husband Amarillo International Airport. 
(e)  All fees imposed on Transportation Network Companies, taxi cab company operators, limousine company operators, other commercial ground transportation company operators, off-airport hotel shuttle bus operators, or off-airport rental car shuttle busoperators shall beapproved by the Amarillo CityCouncil. 
(f)  All commercial ground transportation company operators operating upon the Rick Husband Amarillo International Airport shall be required to utilize the commercial traffic drive lane, the commercial traffic staging area, and any and all physical controls that control access to those areas at the airport. 
(g)  All commercial ground transportation company operators, including but not limited to, taxi cab company operators, limousine company operators, off-airport rental car shuttle bus operators, transportation network company operators, and off-airport hotel shuttle bus operators operating upon the Rick Husband Amarillo International Airport shall be required to remit a commercial ground transportation fee of one dollar ($1.00) per trip. Said fee shall be paid in accordance with applicable Airport Rules and Regulations and at the direction of the Airport Manager. 
(Ord. No. 7712, § 1, 2-27-2018; Ord. No. 7742, § 1, 7-11-2018) 
Secs. 16-2-70-16-2-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - FUELING REGULATIONS 

Sec. 16-2-81. - Safety precautions. 
(a)  No Aircraft shall be fueled or defueled while the engine is running or while the Aircraft is in any hangar or enclosed area. 
(b)  No Aircraft shall be fueled or defueled unless such Aircraft, the fuel truck and the fueling hose nozzle are all properly grounded for fuel flows which exceed twenty-five (25) gallons per minute. Airline refueling will be accomplished in accordance with Federal Aviation Administration approved procedures. 
(c)  No passenger or passengers will be permitted in or around any Aircraft during fueling or defueling unless properly supervised. 
(d)  No person shall use any material during fueling or defueling of Aircraft which could cause a static discharge. 
(e)  The Airport Fire Department shall be called to assist in flushing fuel spillage of any hazardous amount. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-56) 
Sec. 16-2-82. - Fueling equipment. 
(a)  Fueling and defueling equipment shall be maintained in a safe, nonleaking condition. 
(b)  Trucks containing flammable liquids must be equipped with proper ground straps. All ground connections will be in proper working order. 
(c)  Any flammable liquid truck found to be in unsafe operating condition shall be placed out of service by the Fire Marshal. No truck so placed out of service shall be operated on the Air Terminal until it has been placed in safe and serviceable condition and approved by the Fire Marshal. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-57) 
Sec. 16-2-83. - Fire extinguishers. 
    Adequate fire extinguishers of an approved type shall be within ready reach of persons engaged in fueling and defueling operations. There shall be maintained on all fuel trucks at all times at least one (1) fully charged, approved, portable fire extinguisher of not less than ten (10) pounds carbon dioxide (CO 2 ) or ten (10) pounds dry gas capacity, or its equivalent, in a readily accessible place. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-58) 
Sec. 16-2-84. - Fuel spills. 
    No person shall start the engine of any Aircraft when there is fuel on the ground under any such Aircraft. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-59) 
Sec. 16-2-85. - Oil heating. 
    The heating of oil shall be restricted to steam, hot water, hot air or approved electrical heaters. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-60) 
Sec. 16-2-86. - Fuel storage areas. 
(a)  No fuel truck shall be left unattended at any fuel storage area during the loading or unloading process. Loading and unloading shall not be considered complete until the delivery hose is detached from such Vehicle and the fuel storage tanks. 
(b)  Every fuel truck must have the tank and nozzle properly grounded before loading or unloading. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-61) 
Secs. 16-2-87-16-2-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - HELISTOPS AND HELICOPTERS 

Sec. 16-2-101. - Rooftop fueling or service facilities prohibited; exception. 
    A helistop may be established on a rooftop, but no fueling, refueling or service facilities shall be permitted on a rooftop, except in case of emergency. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-73) 
Sec. 16-2-102. - Permit required for maintenance of helistop. 
    No helistop shall be established, constructed or maintained in the City without first securing a permit therefor from the Building Official of the City and complying with the terms of this article. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-74) 
Sec. 16-2-103. - Compliance with FAA regulations. 
    A helistop must be established, maintained and operated in strict accordance with all provisions of the Federal Aviation Administration of the United States Government. This requirement includes compliance with, but is not limited to, FAA Heliport Design Guide, AC 150/5390-1, November, 1964, or the latest revision thereof or other applicable FAA regulations or advisory circulars. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-75; Ord. No. 5576, § 1, 3-13-86) 
Sec. 16-2-104. - Area requirements. 
    Area requirements for helistops shall be as follows: 
(1)  Landing area. The minimum clear area for landing of helicopters shall be a square having sides equal to 2.0 times the maximum length of the largest helicopter using the facility. In no event shall the landing area be less than that required by Federal Aviation Administration regulations. 
(2)  Touchdown area. The minimum helicopter touchdown area, located with the landing area, shall be a square having sides equal to 0.8 times the maximum length of largest helicopter using the facility. 
(3)  Approach profile. The approach to a helistop must be sufficiently clear of obstructions to provide a slope of 1:8 (approximately seven (7) degrees measured from the horizontal plane). If necessary a curved approach may be used. Two (2) such approaches shall be available at least ninety (90) degrees removed from each other. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-76; Ord. No. 5576, § 1, 3-13-86) 
Sec. 16-2-105. - Development standards. 
    Development standards for helistops shall be as follows: 
(1)  The landing area for helistops shall be aligned to give maximum into the wind operation. 
(2)  The landing area for helistops shall be made of such material that will be free of loose ground and particles of concrete or other solid material which may be blown about by the down-blast of air of the rotor. 
(3)  The landing area for helistops shall be surrounded by a fence or wall at least three and one-half (31/2) feet high and constructed in such a manner as to minimize the effects produced by the horizontal wind velocities caused by the rotation of the rotor blades. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-77) 
Sec. 16-2-106. - Safety precautions and equipment. 
    The following safety precautions and equipment shall be installed at each helistop: 
(1)  Rooftop helistops. 
a.  On all touchdown or landing areas, whether elevated or flush with the roof, provision shall be made for collecting fuel which may be spilled in event of any emergency. Separator or clarifier tanks for collecting spilled fuel shall be installed under approval and supervision of the Fire Department. 
b.  The rooftop shall have at least two (2) conforming exits and they shall be located in such a manner as to permit safe exit from the roof area in the event one (1) of the exits is blocked. 
c.  A wind-indicating device shall be installed. A flag, banner or similar device is acceptable. 
d.  Two (2) or more wet standpipes shall be provided and equipped with one-and-one-half-inch rubber-lined fire hose not over one hundred (100) feet in length. Hose shall be equipped with combination fog nozzles. Sufficient pressure shall be available to afford a good fog pattern. Hose cabinets or racks shall be located near the separate exits. Standpipe outlets shall be so located that all portions of the roof area shall be within one hundred twenty (120) feet of the outlet. 
e.  Two (2) fire extinguishers of at least sixteen (16) BC rating shall be provided, and be located remotely from each other. 
f.  No light standards, roof vents, guy lines, TV antennae or other similar rooftop obstructions which may be difficult to see from the air shall be permitted within the required glide slope on three (3) sides, or within a two hundred seventy-degree arc. 
g.  Such lights as are installed shall illuminate and be directed onto the touchdown pad only, and in such a manner that the light rays cannot interfere with the helicopter pilot's vision. 
h.  No persons shall be permitted in the general landing area in any location where any portion of their bodies will be higher than the touchdown area surface while landing or takeoff operations are under way. 
i.  Approved means of communication such as telephone, radio, fire alarm box, or signaling device shall be provided adjacent to the landing area. 
j.  If the roof has no parapet wall, a three-and-one-half-foot-high fence shall be provided around the perimeter of the roof to ensure the safety of all persons. The fence shall be designed to effectively prevent the falling of the helicopter from the roof of the Building. 
(2)  Ground-level helistops. 
a.  All lights installed shall illuminate and be directed onto the touchdown pad only, and in such a manner that the light rays cannot interfere with the pilot's vision. 
b.  A wind-indicating device shall be installed. A flag, banner or similar device is acceptable. 
c.  Unauthorized persons shall not be permitted in the general landing area during flight operations.
