d.  Two (2) fire extinguishers of at least sixteen (16) BC rating shall be provided and be located remotely from each other. 
e.  Where Buildings or Structures in proximity to the landing area present a fire exposure hazard, there shall be provided at least two (2) one-and-one-half-inch wet standpipe outlets equipped with one-and-one-half-inch fire hose, not over one hundred (100) feet in length, and a combination fog nozzle. 
f.  Approved means of communication such as telephone, radio, fire alarm box or signaling device shall be provided adjacent to the landing area. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-78) 
Sec. 16-2-107. - Insurance. 
    Any person holding a permit for a helistop facility shall, as a condition for such permit remaining in effect, carry or cause to be carried in full force and effect at all times insurance insuring against all liabilities, judgments, costs, damages and expenses which may accrue against or be charged to or recovered from such permit holder by reason of or on account of damage to the property of, injury to or death of any person arising from use and occupancy of and operations at the helicopter landing or operational site by the permit holder or others. This insurance shall be carried with a bona fide insurer authorized to do business in the State. The policy or policies shall be presented to the City Secretary and shall be kept up to date and on file with the City Secretary. They shall be in the following kinds and minimum amounts: 
(1)  Comprehensive public liability insurance: 
a.  One hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) per person; 
b.  One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per accident. 
(2)  Comprehensive property damage insurance, one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per accident. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-79) 
Sec. 16-2-108. - Permit for operation of helicopters from temporary landing site-Required. 
    No person shall land or operate a helicopter at or from any location in the City, other than a regular established Airport approved by the Federal Aviation Administration of the United States government or a helistop approved by the City without first securing from the Airport Manager a permit for the landing and operation of a helicopter to and from a temporary landing site. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-80; Ord. No. 5576, § 1, 3-13-86) 
Sec. 16-2-109. - Same-Duration; appeal from decisions of airport manager. 
    The Airport Manager may issue a permit for the landing and takeoff of helicopters at temporary locations for one (1) time or temporary operations of helicopters, provided that no permit issued by the Airport Manager shall exceed a period of ten (10) days. Any decision of the Airport Manager may be appealed by any person to the Airport Board of the City for a hearing and determination by the Airport Board. No permit shall be issued by the Airport Manager if in the opinion of the Airport Manager the operation of helicopters from a temporary site would endanger life or property. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-81) 
Sec. 16-2-110. - Same-Submission of request; form. 
    A written request for permission to land and take off a helicopter from a temporary landing site shall be submitted to the Airport Manager a minimum of seven (7) days prior to the time of intended operation. The request must contain the following specific information: 
(1)  Exact location of the proposed landing site; 
(2)  A description of the landing surface, i.e., concrete, asphalt, sod, etc.; 
(3)  Date or dates of operation; 
(4)  Type and size of helicopter or helicopters to be used; 
(5)  Reasons for the request; 
(6)  Safety precautions to be enforced at the landing site, such as spectator and vehicle control, approach and descent path of the helicopter, and the type of wind-indicating device. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-82) 
Sec. 16-2-111. - Evaluation of temporary landing site. 
    The Airport Manager shall consider the following factors in evaluating a request for an off-heliport landing site: 
(1)  Stabilization of the surface; 
(2)  Absence of abrupt grade changes; 
(3)  Proximity of flight obstructions such as Buildings, poles and utility lines; 
(4)  A minimum approach and takeoff angle of eight (8) feet horizontally to one (1) foot vertically (8:1) will be required; 
(5)  Wind-indicating devices; 
(6)  Control of persons and vehicles close to the landing and takeoff site; 
(7)  Reasons for a one-time or temporary operation. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-83) 
Sec. 16-2-112. - Compliance of temporary landing site with FAA regulations. 
    All operations into and out of a temporary landing site must comply with the Federal Aviation Administration Air Traffic and General Operating Rules. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-84; Ord. No. 5576, § 1, 3-13-86) 
Sec. 16-2-113. - Exemption of rescue and humanitarian actions. 
    All scheduled helicopter operations for rescue and humanitarian actions are exempt from the provisions of this article; however, the Airport Manager shall be informed as soon as practical of the place and type of mercy flights flown. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-85) 
Sec. 16-2-114. - Emergency landings. 
    A helicopter landing made at a nondesignated helistop or Airport due to mechanical or engine difficulty shall be immediately reported to the Airport Manager and the Federal Aviation Administration, Flight Standards District Office. The aircraft shall not be flown or removed from the land site (other than the distance required for emergency or humanitarian purposes) until permission is granted by the FAA and the Airport Manager. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-86; Ord. No. 5576, § 1, 3-13-86) 
Sec. 16-2-115. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be subject to the penalty provided for in section 1-1-5. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-87) 
Secs. 16-2-116-16-2-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - EMERGENCY PROCEDURES 

Sec. 16-2-126. - Emergency operations plan in effect. 
    Emergency situations will be handled as outlined in the emergency operations plan of the Amarillo International Airport Emergency Plan. 
(Code 1960, § 3A-98; Ord. No. 5576, § 1, 3-13-86) 
CHAPTER 16-3. - TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic commission, § 2-6-81 et seq.; traffic in parks, § 12-7-3. 
State Law reference- Uniform Act Regulating Traffic on Highways, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-3-1. - Citation; applicability. 
    This chapter shall be known as the traffic code of the City and shall apply within the jurisdiction of the City. 
(Code 1960, § 23-1; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases shall for the purpose of this chapter have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section: 
    Alley: A minor way which is used primarily for installation of public utilities and for vehicular service access to the back or the side of properties otherwise abutting a Street. 
    Chief of Police: The Chief of Police of the City or his duly authorized agent. 
    Commercial Motor Vehicle: Every motor vehicle, other than a motorcycle or passenger car, designed or used primarily for the transportation of property, including any passenger car which has been reconstructed so as to be used, and which is being used, primarily for delivery purposes with the exception of passenger cars used in the delivery of the United States mails. 
    Curb: The line adjacent to the edge of the roadway which may be either a raised or lowered surface, marked or understood. 
    Divided Roadway or Highway: A highway divided into two (2) roadways by leaving an intervening space, or by a physical barrier, or by a clearly indicated dividing section between the two (2) roadways. 
    Fire Lane: Any area, either on a Street or public place, upon which parking is restricted or prohibited by the Traffic Engineer to facilitate the use or passage of equipment of the fire department, or as an escape route for persons from a public place. 
    Limit Lines: Boundaries of parking areas, loading zones, safety or danger zones, crosswalks and lines marked for purpose of excluding traffic and parking. 
    Loading Zones: A space adjacent to a Curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers or materials. 
    Motor Home: A motor vehicle which contains, as an integral part of such vehicle, a unit designed primarily as temporary living quarters for recreational, camping or travel use, excluding any vehicle of three-fourths-ton size or less. 
    One-way Street: Any Street or highway on which traffic is restricted to movements in one (1) direction only. 
    One-Way Traffic: Traffic restricted to movement in one (1) direction only on any particularly designated Street or Thoroughfare, and signposted as such. 
    Operator: Any person in control of or assuming control of a vehicle or railroad train. 
    Parade: Any procession, march, demonstration, public assemblage, ceremony, show, exhibition, or pageant of any kind, in or upon any Street, Alley or other public Thoroughfare in the City. 
    Parade Permit: A permit required by this chapter. 
    Parkway: That portion of a Street between either the Curbline of the lateral line of a roadway and the adjacent property line. 
    Public Place: A place where people are assembled, or to which people commonly resort for purposes of business, amusement, recreation or other lawful purposes. 
    Race: Any pedestrian, bicycle or vehicle competition in or upon any Street, Alley or other public Thoroughfare in the City. 
    Race Permit: A permit required by this chapter. 
    Time Standard: Whenever certain hours are named herein they shall mean central standard time or central daylight time. 
    Traffic Engineer: The Traffic Engineer of the City or his duly authorized agent. 
    Traffic Impact Study: A study which assesses the effects on traffic that a particular project or development will have on the transportation network in the neighborhood or city. These studies vary in their range of detail and complexity depending on the type, size and location of the project or development. The purpose of such study is to assist in helping to evaluate whether the project or development is appropriate for the site and what type of traffic improvements may be necessary. To be valid it must bear the seal of a Texas-licensed engineer in good standing with the State of Texas. 
    Transportation Plan: The master Street development plan for the City. 
(Code 1960, § 23-5; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 7321, § 1, 3-27-2012) 
Cross reference- Definitions to apply throughout Code, § 1-2-1. 
Sec. 16-3-3. - Compliance required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to do any act prohibited by, or fail to perform any act required in this chapter. 
(Code 1960, § 23-3; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-4. - Conflicts with state or interstate regulations; additional requirements. 
    Should there be a conflict between any of the provisions of this chapter and the Uniform Act Regulating Traffic on Highways, as amended [V.A.C.S. art. 6701d], of the orders, rules, regulations and requirements of the Interstate Commerce Commission or the Railroad Commission of Texas relating to the equipping and other safety requirements of vehicles, motor vehicles, truck-tractors, trucks, buses, trailers, compliance by the owners or Operators of such vehicles with such statute orders, rules and regulations of the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Railroad Commission of Texas, shall be deemed in compliance with this chapter; except that any requirement of this chapter in addition to, but not in conflict with the state statutes or the requirements of the Interstate Commerce Commission or the Railroad Commission shall be complied with. 
(Code 1960, § 23-4; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Secs. 16-3-5-16-3-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic commission, § 2-6-81 et seq. 

GENERALLY 

Secs. 16-3-21-16-3-30. - Reserved. 
TRAFFIC ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 16-3-31. - Created. 
    An administrative department is hereby created and established to be known as the Traffic Engineering Department. 
(Code 1960, § 23-6; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-32. - Traffic engineer. 
(a)  The Traffic Engineer of the City shall be the director of the Traffic Engineering Department. 
(b)  The Traffic Engineer shall be appointed by and under the supervision of the Director of Public Works Division. 
(Code 1960, § 23-7; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 7321, § 2, 3-27-2012) 
Sec. 16-3-33. - Administrative authority. 
    The Traffic Engineer shall exercise administrative authority as provided for in this chapter in accordance with accepted traffic engineering practices. 
(Code 1960, § 23-8; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-34. - Authority; duties. 
(a)  Authority to control and direct. The Traffic Engineer shall have control and direction of all traffic signals, the marking of all traffic zones, and the installation of signals and road markers relating to direction and control of traffic. 
(b)  Studies and recommendations. The Traffic Engineer shall make continuous studies of the movement of traffic on the Streets and Thoroughfares of the City and shall make periodic recommendations to the City Manager as to necessary regulation practices and controls for the safe and efficient movement of traffic in the City. 
(c)  Testing under actual conditions. The Traffic Engineer may test all forms of traffic-control devices under actual conditions of traffic. 
(d)  Other duties. The Traffic Engineer shall perform such other duties as may be required of him by the City Manager. 
(Code 1960, § 23-9; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-35. - Emergencies, special conditions and experiments. 
(a)  The Traffic Engineer is hereby empowered to make temporary or experimental regulations to cover emergencies or special conditions. 
(b)  No such temporary or experimental regulations shall remain in effect more than ninety (90) days, except that for road construction projects, the regulations may remain in effect for the duration of the project, as determined by the Traffic Engineer. 
(Code 1960, § 23-10; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Secs. 16-3-36-16-3-45. - Reserved. 
Division 3. - Traffic-Control Signs, Signals, Devices and Markings[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Personnel administration, Ch. 2-5. 
State Law reference- Traffic-control signs, signals, etc., V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 29 et seq. 

Sec. 16-3-46. - Installations authorized. 
(a)  The Traffic Engineer shall place and maintain traffic-control signs, signals and devices when and as required under this chapter. 
(b)  The Traffic Engineer may place and maintain such additional traffic-control devices as he may deem necessary to regulate traffic under the provisions of this chapter, under the state law, or to guide or warn traffic. 
(Code 1960, § 23-11; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate traffic by means of traffic-control devices, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 27(a)(2). 
Sec. 16-3-47. - Authority to designate crosswalks, safety zones and traffic lanes. 
    The Traffic Engineer is hereby authorized to: 
(1)  Designate and maintain, by appropriate devices, marks or lines upon the surface of the roadway, crosswalks at intersections and at such other places as he may deem necessary where in his opinion there is particular danger to pedestrians crossing the roadway. 
(2)  Mark lanes for traffic or Street pavements at such places as he may deem advisable, consistent with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Code 1960, § 23-12; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-48. - Standards. 
(a)  State highway commission; City Council. All traffic-control signs, signals, pavement markings and devices shall conform to the Texas State Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices as heretofore or hereafter amended, specifications of the State Department of Highways and Public Transportation, or resolution adopted by the City Council. 
(b)  Uniformity. All signs, signals and pavement markings required hereunder for a particular purpose shall so far as practicable be uniform as to type and location throughout the City. 
State Law reference- Compliance with state manual and specifications required, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 31. 
(c)  Official rating. All traffic-control devices erected in compliance with this section and not inconsistent with the provisions of State law or this chapter are hereby designated official traffic-control devices. 
(d)  Ratification. All traffic-control signs, signal devices and markings heretofore placed or erected by the Traffic Engineering Department and now in use for the purpose of regulating, warning or guiding traffic that are consistent with the provisions of State law or this chapter are hereby affirmed, ratified and declared to be official traffic-control devices. 
(Code 1960, § 23-13; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 16-3-49. - Unauthorized possession of official devices or railroad signs or signals. 
    No person shall, without lawful authority, knowingly have in his possession any official traffic-control device of the City, the State or any governmental agency of the State of Texas, or any railroad sign, signal or warning device or any part thereof. 
(Code 1960, § 23-14; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
State Law reference- Display of unauthorized signs, signals or markings, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 36. 
Sec. 16-3-50. - One-way streets and alleys. 
(a)  Authorized; erection of signs. 
(1)  The City Council may designate any Alley, Street or highway for One-way Traffic. 
(2)  It shall be the duty of the Traffic Engineer to erect upon any roadway so designated appropriate Signs giving notice thereof. 
(b)  Signs necessary for enforcement; direction indicators at intersections. 
(1)  Whenever any ordinance or resolution of the City designates any Street or Alley for travel in one (1) direction only, the Traffic Engineer shall place and maintain Signs giving notice thereof, and no such regulations shall be in effect until such Signs have been installed. 
(2)  Signs indicating the direction of lawful traffic movement shall be placed at every intersection where movement of traffic in a direction is prohibited. 
(c)  Authority to designate. The Traffic Engineer shall have the authority to designate One-way Traffic and erect appropriate Signs giving notice thereof for: 
(1)  Any section of roadway specifically designed for one-way operation such as interchange roadways in the vicinity of a Grade separation and roadways which are remotely separated for overpass purposes. 
(2)  Those access drives having physical characteristics which require one-way operation for convenience or safety. 
(Code 1960, §§ 23-67-23-69; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
State Law reference- Authority to designate one-way streets, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 27(a)(4); one-way roadways, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 59. 
Sec. 16-3-51. - Turning, backing movements. 
(a)  The Traffic Engineer is authorized to place markers, buttons or signs within or adjacent to intersections indicating the course to be travelled by vehicles turning at such intersections. 
(b)  When authorized markers, buttons or other indications are placed within an intersection indicating the course to be travelled by vehicles turning thereat, no driver of a vehicle shall disobey the directions of such indications. 
(Code 1960, § 23-71; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate turning movements, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, §§ 23(a)(8), 670. 
Sec. 16-3-52. - Restricted turns. 
(a)  The Traffic Engineer is hereby authorized to restrict those intersections at which drivers of vehicles shall be prohibited from making turns at such intersections. The making of such turns may be prohibited between certain hours of any day and permitted at other hours, in which event the same shall be plainly indicated on Signs. 
(b)  Whenever a Sign is erected restricting a turn, the Operator of a vehicle shall obey the directions of any such Sign. 
(Code 1960, § 23-72; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
State Law reference- Turning movements generally, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d § 67 et seq. 
Secs. 16-3-53-16-3-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OBSTRUCTIONS IMPAIRING VISIBILITY 

Sec. 16-3-76. - Prohibited Structures and Growth. 
(a)  Maximum Height; pruned Trees excepted. On no corner Lot which abuts an open intersection or intersection controlled by yield Signs, within a triangular area described by the intersection of the adjacent Curblines, or if none exists the normal Curblines, and a point on each Curbline forty-five (45) feet from the intersection, shall there be erected or maintained any wall, fence or other Structure, or any hedge, shrub or other growth higher than two and one-half (21/2) feet from the top of the adjacent Curblines or if there is no Curb then from the top of the normal Curbline, except Trees which are pruned to a height of eight (8) feet or any vehicle parked in the Parkway portion of the triangle; provided, however, this provision shall not apply at intersections controlled by stop Signs or by official traffic-control signals. 
(b)  Through Streets. On no corner Lot which abuts an intersection of a Through Street and an intersecting Street shall there be erected or maintained any obstruction described in subsection (a) of this section, within a triangular area described by the intersection of the adjacent Curblines, or if none exists, the normal Curblines, and a point ten (10) feet from the intersection on the intersecting Street and one hundred (100) feet from the intersection on the through Street; provided, however, this provision shall not apply at intersections controlled by official traffic-control signals. 
(c)  Arterial and Collector Streets. On no Lot which abuts an Arterial or Collector Street, as shown on the Transportation Plan of the City, shall there be erected or maintained any obstruction described in subsection (a) of this section, within a triangular area described by the intersection of the adjacent Curbline, or if none exists, the normal Curbline, with a line perpendicular to the Curbline passing through the edge of any adjacent Driveway, and a point ten (10) feet from the intersection on the intersecting line and one hundred (100) feet from the intersection on the Street Curbline. 
(Code 1960, § 23-58; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 2-26-86; Ord. No. 5771, § 3, 9-27-88) 
Sec. 16-3-77. - Obstructing view of traffic-control device. 
    No wall, fence or other Structure, or any hedge, Tree, shrub or other growth, shall be erected or maintained in any location so as to cause an obstruction of the view of an official traffic-control device from the adjacent Street. 
(Code 1960, § 23-59; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-78. - Declaration of nuisance; notice. 
(a)  Any obstruction prohibited by this article is hereby declared a public nuisance in violation of this article. 
(b)  Each day's violation after the Traffic Engineer gives notice by depositing a written notice of the violation in the mail, properly stamped and directed to the last known address, shall constitute a separate offense, and for each offense the person shall be subject to the penalty in section 1-1-5. 
(Code 1960, § 23-60; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-79. - Obstructions on private property; notice to abate; failure to comply; remedial action. 
(a)  The maintenance of any obstruction prohibited by this article shall be called to the attention of the owner of the Premises in writing by the Traffic Engineer or his agent. The notice may be given by personal delivery or by depositing it in the United States mail properly stamped and addressed to the owner's last known address. 
(b)  If the obstruction has not been removed within ten (10) days from the date the notice was delivered or mailed, the Traffic Engineer or his agent is hereby authorized and directed to go on the Premises and summarily remove the obstruction. 
(c)  A bill for the actual costs, in no case to be less than one hundred dollars ($100.00), incurred by the City resulting from the abatement of the condition existing by reason of the owner's failure to comply with the notice provided above, shall be mailed to the owner of the Premises and must be satisfied within thirty (30) days of the date of mailing of the bill. 
(d)  If the bill has not been satisfied within the period specified in (c) of this section, the Traffic Engineer may file a statement with the county clerk of Potter or Randall County of the expenses incurred in the abatement of the above-described conditions. 
(e)  The City shall have a privileged lien on any Lot upon which expense is incurred, second only to tax liens and liens for Street improvements, for the cost and ten (10) percent on the amount from the date such payment is due as stipulated in subsection (c) of this section. 
(f)  For any such expenditure and interest as specified, suit may be instituted and recovery and foreclosure had in the name of the City. 
(g)  The statement made by the Traffic Engineer as provided in subsection (d) of this service, or a copy thereof shall be prima facie of the cost incurred in any such work performed by the City. 
(Code 1960, § 23-61; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 6726, § 1, 5-19-2004) 
Secs. 16-3-80-16-3-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - VEHICLE OPERATION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-3-101. - One-way streets. 
    Upon those Streets and parts of Streets designated in the schedule of One-way Streets and in those Alleys designated in the schedule of One-way Alleys set out in schedule A, and upon those additional Streets and Alleys which may hereafter be designated as such by the City Council, vehicular traffic shall move only in the direction indicated. 
(Code 1960, § 23-70; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
State Law reference- Authority to designate one-way streets, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 27(a)(4); one-way roadways, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 59. 
Sec. 16-3-102. - Backing limitations. 
(a)  Intersections; crosswalks. The Operator of a vehicle shall not back into an intersection or over a crosswalk. 
(b)  Safety; interference with traffic. The Operator of a vehicle shall not back a vehicle unless such movement can be made in safety and done without interfering with other traffic. 
(c)  Proof of violation. Proof that the driver of a vehicle backed upon or in a Street and interfered with another vehicle or with a pedestrian shall constitute prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. 
(Code 1960, § 23-79; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
State Law reference- Limitations on backing, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 173. 
Sec. 16-3-103. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6919, § 1, adopted Mar. 14, 2006, deleted § 16-3-103, which pertained to bicycle lanes and derived from Ord. No. 6654, § 7, adopted July 1, 2003. 
Sec. 16-3-104. - Penalty. 
    It is an offense to violate any part of this Article, punishable upon conviction in accordance with Section 1-1-5 of the Amarillo Municipal Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 6654, § 8, 7-1-2003) 
Secs. 16-3-105-16-3-115. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SPEED[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate speed, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, §§ 27(a)(9), 169; speed generally, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 166 et seq. 

Sec. 16-3-116. - Streets generally; alleys. 
(a)  Reasonable and safe speed generally. Where no special hazard exists that requires lower speed for compliance with State law, it is hereby determined upon the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation that the maximum reasonable and prudent safe speed for the operation of vehicles upon the streets of the City is thirty (30) miles per hour, and any speed in excess of thirty (30) miles per hour shall be prima facie evidence that the speed is not reasonable or prudent and that it is unlawful. 
(b)  Maximum speed in Alleys. Where no special hazard exists that requires lower speed for compliance with State law, it is hereby determined upon the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation that the maximum, reasonable and prudent safe speed for the operation of vehicles upon the Alleys of the City is fifteen (15) miles per hour, and any speed in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour shall be prima facie evidence that the speed is not reasonable or prudent and that it is unlawful. 
(c)  Failure to control speed. No person shall drive a vehicle on a Street, highway or Alley at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions and having due regard to the actual and potential hazards then existing. In every event speed shall be so controlled as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person, vehicle, other conveyance or object upon such Street or highway. 
(d)  Exceptions. This section shall not apply at specific locations in the City where the City Council upon the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation shall have found and declared by ordinance a different speed to be the maximum, reasonable and safe speed. 
(e)  It is an offense for a person to operate a motor vehicle upon a city street or alley exhibiting sudden vehicle speed or acceleration which produces noise, smoking tires, or causes one (1) or more tires to lose contact with the surface of the street or alley. 
(Code 1960, § 23-62; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 6920, § 1, 3-14-2006; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 16-3-117. - School zones. 
(a)  Where no special hazard exists that requires lower speed for compliance with State law, it is hereby determined upon the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation that: during the hours and days that a school zone is in effect, the maximum, reasonable and prudent safe speed for the operation of vehicles upon the Streets of the City shall be twenty (20) miles per hour or as otherwise posted and any speed in excess of the posted speed shall be prima facie evidence that the speed is not reasonable or prudent and that it is unlawful. The posting of maximum speed and hours of effect for each school zone may be by either a posted sign, an electronic display, or other technological manner or means that gives drivers notice of effective times of, and maximum speed in, a school zone. 
(b)  No vehicle shall at any time be driven to the left side of the roadway when driving in a school zone. 
(Code 1960, § 23-63; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 7338, § 1, 7-24-2012) 
Sec. 16-3-118. - Specific locations of speed zones. 
    When no special hazard exists that requires lower speed for compliance with State law, it is hereby determined upon the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation that the maximum, reasonable and prudent safe speed for the operation of vehicles upon the Streets set out in the speed zone schedule in schedule B, are those speeds which are set out in connection with the specific Streets, and any speed in excess of such speeds shall be prima facie evidence that the speed is not reasonable or prudent and that it is unlawful. 
(Code 1960, § 23-64; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-119. - Minimum limits. 
    Whenever the Traffic Engineer shall determine upon the basis of traffic engineering and investigation that a minimum speed limit is required for the operation of vehicles under the conditions found to exist on a particular Street the City Council may by ordinance describe such Street and state what is found to be the minimum reasonable speed on such Street and no person shall drive a vehicle at a lesser rate of speed on such portion of the Street after the Street has been signposted advertising the minimum speed. Such Streets are listed in schedule C. 
(Code 1960, § 23-65(a); Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 16-3-120. - Ambulances. 
    It shall be unlawful to drive an Ambulance upon an emergency call within the City limits in violation of the following provisions: 
(1)  At a rate of speed in excess of forty-five (45) miles per hour; 
(2)  Without first notifying the Police Department of such emergency call; 
(3)  Unless the driver thereof sounds audible signal by bell, siren or exhaust whistle. 
(Code 1960, § 23-66; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate speed of ambulances, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 172. 
Secs. 16-3-121-16-3-127. - Reserved. 
Division 3. - Turning Movements[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate turning movements, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 27(a)(8); turning movements generally, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 65 et seq. 

Sec. 16-3-128. - Required position and method of turning at intersections. 
    No person shall turn a vehicle at an intersection unless the vehicle is in the position upon the roadway required in this section. The Operator of a vehicle intending to turn at an intersection shall comply with the following provisions: 
(1)  Right turn. Both the approach for a right turn and a right turn shall be made as close as practical to the right-hand Curb or edge of the roadway. 
(2)  Left turns. 
a.  Where both Streets are two-way Streets: Approach for a left turn shall be made in the left turn lane, or if none, in that portion of the right half of the roadway nearest the centerline thereof and after entering the intersection the left turn shall be made so as to enter the intersection to the right of the centerline of the roadway being entered. 
b.  From two-way Street into One-way Street: Approach for a left turn from a two-way Street into a One-way Street shall be made in the left turn lane, or if none, in the portion of the right half of the roadway nearest the centerline thereof and by passing to the right of such centerline where it enters the intersection. 
c.  From One-way Street into two-way Street: Approach for a left turn from a One-way Street into a two-way Street shall be made as close as practicable to the left-hand Curb lane and by passing to the right of the centerline of the Street being entered upon leaving the intersection. 
d.  Where both Streets are One-way Streets: Where both Streets or roadways are One-way, both the approach for a left turn and a left turn shall be made as close as practicable to the left-hand Curb or edge of the roadway. 
(3)  Dual left or right turns. Dual lane left or right turns from two (2) lanes of traffic are hereby permitted at those specified intersections set out in schedule D. The Traffic Engineer is hereby authorized to designate the manner in which such dual left or right turns shall be made by the installation of traffic-control devices. 
(Code 1960, § 23-73; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 65. 
Sec. 16-3-129. - Alleys and private driveways. 
    The operator of a vehicle emerging from an Alley or private Driveway within the Central Business District as described in the following section shall proceed straight ahead or make a right-hand turn onto the Street, and any vehicle turning to enter an Alley or private Driveway shall do so by making a right-hand turn except in the case of One-way Streets where a left-hand turn is required by the one-way regulations. 
(Code 1960, § 23-74; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-130. - Central business district. 
    It shall be unlawful and an offense to make a left-hand turn upon emerging from or entering into an Alley or Driveway except on One-way Streets within the Central Business District being formed by the following Street lines: 
    Beginning at a point on the west line of Van Buren Street at its intersection with the Right-of-way of the FW & D R.R.; thence in a southerly direction along the west line of Van Buren Street to the south line of 11th Avenue; thence in an easterly direction along the south line of 11th Avenue to the West Boundary of the P & SF R.R. Right-of-way; thence in a northerly direction along the west boundary line of the P & SF R.R. Co. Right-of-way to its intersection with the FW & D R.R. Right-of-way; thence in a westerly direction along the south boundary line of the FW & D R.R. Right-of-way to the point of beginning. 
(Code 1960, § 23-75; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-131. - Exit and entrance of parking establishments in central business district; required signs. 
    Each operator, owner or lessee of a parking lot, garage or other establishment where cars are parked or stored, within the Central Business District set out in the preceding section, shall place and maintain in conspicuous view at the entrance and exit appropriate Signs advising the public whether a left turn or a right turn, or both, is allowed on leaving or entering the parking establishment. 
(Code 1960, § 23-76; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 7667, § 1, 5-16-2017) 
Sec. 16-3-132. - Turning around-Where and when permitted. 
(a)  The Operator of a vehicle shall not turn such vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any Street except at an intersection. 
(b)  The Operator of a vehicle shall not turn such vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction unless such movement can be made in safety and without interfering with other traffic. 
(Code 1960, § 23-77; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-133. - Same-Prohibited in business district, at traffic signals. 
    The operator of a vehicle shall not turn such vehicle so as to proceed in the opposite direction upon any Street in a business District or at an intersection controlled by traffic signals. 
(Code 1960, § 23-78; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-134. - Dual turns. 
    When a dual left or right turn is permitted, the driver of a vehicle shall proceed in the manner designated by the officially installed traffic-control device. Streets on which dual left or right turns are permitted are listed in Schedule D. 
(Code 1960, § 23-79; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Secs. 16-3-135-16-3-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - REQUIRED STOPS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Right-of-way V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 71 et seq.; special stops, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 86 et seq. 

Sec. 16-3-141. - Entering intersection without creating obstruction. 
    No Operator of a vehicle shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic-control signal indication to proceed. 
(Code 1960, § 23-80; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-142. - Buses taking on, discharging passengers. 
    The Operator of a vehicle overtaking upon the right any bus stopped or about to stop for the purpose of receiving or discharging any passenger shall stop such vehicle at least five (5) feet to the rear of the bus and remain standing until all passengers having boarded such bus, or upon alighting the bus have reached a place of safety. 
(Code 1960, § 23-81; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-143. - Railroad gates, barriers. 
    No person shall operate any vehicle through, around or under any crossing gate or barrier at a railroad grade crossing while such gate or barrier is closed or is being opened or closed. 
(Code 1960, § 23-82; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
State Law reference- Stops at railroad crossings, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, §§ 86-90. 
Secs. 16-3-144-16-3-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - FUNERAL PROCESSIONS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate or prohibit processions or assemblages on the highways, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 27(a)(3). 

Sec. 16-3-151. - Manner of driving in. 
    Each driver in a funeral or other procession shall drive as near to the right-hand edge of the roadway as practical and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practical and safe. 
(Code 1960, § 23-83; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-152. - Method of identification. 
    Each driver in a funeral procession shall turn the headlights of the vehicle on and it shall be the duty of the undertaker having charge of a funeral procession to notify each operator of a motor vehicle of this method of identification. 
(Code 1960, § 23-84; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-153. - Driving between vehicles. 
(a)  No Operator of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles comprising a funeral or other authorized procession while they are in motion and when such vehicles are conspicuously designated as required in this division. 
(b)  This provision shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles. 
(Code 1960, § 23-85; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
DIVISION 6. - USE OF WIRELESS COMMUNICATION DEVICES 

Sec. 16-3-154. - Definitions; offense. 
(a)  Definitions. All terms and definitions used in Texas Transportation Code, section 545.425 are hereby adopted and incorporated into this section by this reference. Further, the following additional definitions are found to be consistent with the provisions of said statute and supplemental in nature, and same shall inform every peace officer who enforces this section within the city limits of Amarillo: 
(1)  Hands-free Device shall mean use of speakerphone or voice activated capability of a Wireless Communication Device or, an attachment or accessory to such Device, regardless of whether such is permanently installed in the motor vehicle, that allows the use of a Wireless Communication Device without the use of the hands of a motor vehicle operator, other than to press necessary buttons in order to initiate, answer, or terminate a telephone call. 
(2)  Official capacity shall mean conduct occurring in the course or immediate furtherance of official government business, public safety, or during emergency or disaster operations. 
(3)  Park or Parked shall mean for the operator to completely cease movement of a motor vehicle in a lawful manner and location. For purposes of this Division, "Parked" does not include or mean a vehicle stopped in a lane of traffic due to either a lawful traffic control device, or the conditions on the roadway, or traffic congestion patterns then existing. 
(4)  Text message means a two-way communication (whether real-time or asynchronous) in which data (composed in whole or in part of text, numbers, images, or symbols) is composed, sent, entered, or received by a method other than by voice and transmitted through either a short message service (SMS) or a computer network. 
(5)  Use a Wireless Communication Device and all grammatical variations of that phrase, shall mean and refer to the use of any function, application, or task of a Wireless Device, including but not limited to: talking; text messaging, electronic mail; use of geographical positioning system, map, internet, calendar, game, social media, appointments, task list, notes, calculator, camera; any and all other applications, tasks, uses or functions of a Wireless Communication Device; it also includes: composing, sending, reading, or viewing a text message, pictures, drawings, video, or written text, whether transmitted or received by internet or other electronic means; and, to engage in gaming. Provided however, this term does not include or mean the Use of a Wireless Device that is conducted with or as a Hands- free Device to initiate, answer, or terminate a telephone call. 
(6)  Wireless Communication Device shall mean a device that uses a commercial mobile service, as defined by 47 U.S.C. Section 332, which includes but is not limited to: mobile telephone, cell phone, personal digital assistant, or other device by which the user communicates either by voice, text entry or receipt, or by any other means of electronically transferred data. 
(7)  Wireless Telephone Service means two-way, real time voice telecommunications service that is interconnected to a public switched telephone network and is commonly referred to as cellular service or personal communication service. 
(b)  Offense. It is an offense for the operator of a motor vehicle upon a public road, street, highway, or alley within the city limits to Use a Wireless Communication Device. 
(Ord. No. 7366, § 2, 9-18-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7366, §§ 1, 2, adopted September 18, 2012, amended the Code by repealing former § 16-3-154, and adding a new § 16-3-154. Former § 16-3-154 pertained to enforceable state offenses and definitions, and derived from Ord. No. 7271, adopted March 8, 2011. 
Sec. 16-3-155. - Signs; defense and affirmative defenses; non-reportable. 
(a)  Signs. The Traffic Engineering Department shall erect and maintain official signs giving notice of the existence of this section to motor vehicle operators: 
(1)  Upon each public street and highway that enters or crosses the boundary of the city limits; 
(2)  At all exits from the Rick Husband International Airport; 
(3)  At school zones within the city limits; and, 
(4)  Such other places as may be recommended by the Traffic Engineer and approved by the City Manager. 
(b)  Defense and Affirmative Defenses. It is an absolute defense to the offense described in Sec. 16-3-154 that the Wireless Device is used with or as a Hands-Free Device to initiate, answer, or terminate a telephone call. Moreover, it is an affirmative defense that the use of the Wireless Device was: 
(1)  While the vehicle is lawfully Parked; 
(2)  To communicate with an emergency response operator, a fire department, a law enforcement agency, a hospital, physician's office, or health clinic regarding a medical or other bona fide emergency; 
(3)  In the reasonable belief that a person's life or safety is in immediate danger; 
(4)  By a government employee, designated first responder, or volunteer while acting in Official Capacity and having an immediate need to send, receive, or retrieve official information or communication that is necessary for such person's immediate duty or task; or, 
(5)  By an operator who is licensed by the Federal Communications Commission while operating a radio frequency device other than a Wireless Communication Device. 
(c)  Not reportable. An offense under this Division 6 is hereby deemed to be not a moving violation and may not be made a part of a person's driving record or insurance record, unless otherwise required by law. 
(Ord. No. 7366, § 2, 9-18-2012) 
Secs. 16-3-156-16-3-158. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- General authority to regulate stopping, standing or parking, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 27(a)(1); stopping, standing and parking generally, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 93 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-3-176. - Illegally parked vehicle-Responsibility for permitting. 
(a)  No person shall allow or permit any vehicle registered in his name or any vehicle of which he is the owner to stand or be parked in any Street in the City in violation of any provision of this chapter regulating the standing or parking of vehicles. 
(b)  When any person is charged with having parked or left standing a vehicle in violation of any provision of this chapter, proof that the vehicle was, at the date of the offense alleged, owned by the person charged with the offense shall constitute prima facie evidence that the vehicle was parked or left standing at the placed charged by the owner, but the owner shall have the right to introduce evidence to show that the vehicle was not parked by him as charged in the complaint. 
(Code 1960, § 23-34; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Cross reference- Prima facie evidence in parking violations, § 2-8-90. 
Sec. 16-3-177. - Same-Unattended; nuisance; prima facie evidence of guilt. 
(a)  If a vehicle is found unattended or unoccupied upon a Street, highway, Alley or other Public Place, in violation of any provision of this chapter regulating the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles, the same is hereby declared a nuisance. 
(b)  The fact that such vehicle is unattended or unoccupied by any person shall be prima facie evidence that the owner unlawfully stopped, placed or parked such vehicle. 
(Code 1960, § 23-35; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-178. - Compliance. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or traffic-control device. 
(Code 1960, § 23-15; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-179. - Parking unregistered or disabled vehicles. 
    No person shall park or allow to remain parked a vehicle which bears no current license plate or registration sticker tag or is so disabled that its normal operation is impossible or impractical on any Street or highway within the City. 
(Code 1960, § 23-16; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 7518, § 3, 3-3-15) 
Sec. 16-3-180. - Prohibited parking in certain places. 
(a)  It is an offense for any person to stop, stand, or park a vehicle except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with law, or the directions of a police officer or traffic-control device, in any of the following places: 
(1)  In any clearly marked lane for vehicular traffic movement on any lane roadway unless specially allowed by official signs. 
(2)  Beside any Curb painted red in color or in an otherwise designated Fire Lane. 
(3)  On any Parkway in the Central Business District except as provided in sections 16-3-211 and 16-3-212 or where the Traffic Engineer shall otherwise have designated a safe parking area after having made an engineering and traffic investigation. 
(4)  On any Parkway in any business district except as provided in sections 16-3-211 and 16-3-212. This provision shall supersede and take precedence over all other provisions of this chapter having to do with parking or Parkways in business districts. 
(5)  In any manner or location that prevents access to a mailbox, postal drop box, or similar postal receptacle used by the United States Postal Service, during the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday. It is an exception to and not a violation of the prohibition stated in this subparagraph that a vehicle stops or parks momentarily to engage in loading or unloading passengers or cargo, or is parked or standing near a mailbox after the mail has been delivered for that day. 
(6)  In a manner or location that prevents access to a trash container by a trash collection truck which is attempting to empty the trash container. 
(7)  In a manner or place where stopping, standing, or parking is prohibited by the authority of a temporary or experimental traffic regulation issued by the Traffic Engineer to address a special condition or emergency, pursuant to Section 16-3-35 or other applicable law authorizing such traffic regulation. 
(b)  For purposes of this Chapter, it shall be presumed that the owner of record of the improperly parked, standing or stopped vehicle did so, and in the absence of evidence identifying another person in control of such vehicle, the complaint alleging a violation of this section shall be filed against such owner of record. 
(c)  In addition to the issuance of a parking citation or summons for an offense committed under this section, the police department is hereby authorized to immediately impound, at the owner's expense, a vehicle found parked, standing or stopped in a prohibited place described in this section. The minimum fine for conviction of a violation described in subsection (a) (5) or (6) shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Code 1960, § 23-17; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 6020, § 1, 8-10-93; Ord. No. 6788, § 1, 11-23-2004; Ord. No. 7241, § 1, 9-14-2010) 
Sec. 16-3-181. - Unauthorized reserved parking-Placement of signs, etc. 
    No person shall without lawful authority place, maintain or display upon or in view of any public Sidewalk, Curb or Street, any Sign, signal, marking or device which indicates reserved parking space or is designed to reserve parking space for the adjoining property owners or for customers of the adjoining property owners. 
(Code 1960, § 23-18; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-182. - Same-Removal of signs by city. 
    The Traffic Engineer is hereby empowered to remove any unauthorized Sign, signal or marking or cause it to be removed without notice. 
(Code 1960, § 23-19; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-183. - Hazardous and congested areas. 
(a)  Notwithstanding the provisions of this article, after a determination by an ordinance passed by the City Council, the Traffic Engineer is hereby authorized and required to designate that parking is prohibited by proper Signs placed at the edge of any roadway, Street or highway in which the parking of vehicles, either angular, parallel or both, would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic. 
(b)  When official Signs are erected at hazardous or congested places as authorized herein, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Code 1960, § 23-42; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 16-3-184. - Blocking streets and crossings. 
    No person shall obstruct any Street, Alley, Sidewalk, crossing or other Thoroughfare of the City by allowing to stand thereon any car or rolling stock for a longer time than five (5) minutes. 
(Code 1960, § 23-20; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-185. - Bus discharging or receiving passengers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any bus to stop within an intersection or on a crosswalk for the purpose of receiving or discharging passengers. 
(Code 1960, § 23-21; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-186. - Adjacent to schools. 
(a)  The Traffic Engineer is hereby authorized to erect Signs indicating no parking upon that side of any Street adjacent to any school property when such parking would interfere with traffic or create a hazard. 
(b)  When official Signs are erected indicating no parking upon that side of a Street adjacent to any school property, no person shall park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Code 1960, § 23-22; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-187. - In front of entrances to certain buildings. 
    No person shall stand or park a vehicle in front of any entrance which provides access to Hotels, to Theaters or to the upper floors of any Building four (4) or more stories in Height. Such entrances shall remain open for fire or other emergency purposes. 
(Code 1960, § 23-23; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 88-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-188. - Narrow streets. 
(a)  The Traffic Engineer is hereby authorized to erect Signs indicating no parking upon any Street when the width of the roadway does not exceed twenty (20) feet, or upon one (1) side of a Street as indicated by such Signs when the width of the roadway does not exceed thirty (30) feet. 
(b)  When official Signs prohibiting parking are erected upon narrow Streets as authorized herein, no person shall park a vehicle upon any such Street in violation of any such Sign. 
(Code 1960, § 23-24; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-189. - One-way roadways. 
    If a highway includes two (2) or more separate roadways and traffic is restricted to one (1) direction upon any such roadway, no person shall stand or park a vehicle upon the left-hand side of such one-way roadway unless Signs are erected to permit such standing or parking. The Traffic Engineer is authorized to determine when standing or parking may be permitted upon the left-hand side of any such one-way roadway and to erect Signs giving notice thereof. 
(Code 1960, § 23-25; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-190. - Leaving less than minimum unobstructed passage width. 
    No person shall park any vehicle upon a Street, other than an Alley, in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten (10) feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1960, § 23-26; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-191. - Hazardous or congested places. 
(a)  The Traffic Engineer is hereby authorized to determine and designate, by proper Signs, places not exceeding one hundred (100) feet in length in which the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles would create an especially hazardous condition or would cause unusual delay to traffic. 
(b)  When official Signs are erected at hazardous or congested places as authorized herein, no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle in any such designated place. 
(Code 1960, § 23-27; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-192. - Streets under repair. 
    In any case where any Street in the City is being repaired or paved where work being done necessitates the regulation of traffic thereon, the Traffic Engineer is hereby authorized to prevent parking for any certain period of time that may be necessary, or to close the Street to traffic altogether for such period of time by erecting thereon official Signs with the parking restrictions clearly stated on such Signs. 
(Code 1960, § 23-28; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-193. - Alleys. 
(a)  Minimum free width. No person shall park a vehicle within an Alley in such a manner or under such conditions to leave available less than ten (10) feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic. 
(b)  Blocking entrances. No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an Alley in such position as to block the Driveway entrance to any abutting property. 
(c)  Central business district. No person shall park a vehicle which is not a Commercial Motor Vehicle or is not a vehicle clearly identified for use as a business vehicle, within an alley situated in the Central Business District. Parking of any such vehicle must be for the purposes of loading or unloading. 
(d)  One-way Alleys. Upon the Alleys described in the schedule of One-Way Alleys as set out in schedule A, the driver of a motor vehicle shall not park except on the left half of the Alley, and shall not park so as to obstruct any Fire Lane or fire escape. 
(Code 1960, § 23-29; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 6349, § 1, 6-9-98) 
Sec. 16-3-194. - Parking restrictions for certain vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to leave, park or stand any motor home, truck tractor, road tractor, truck, semi-trailer, Mobile Home, Travel Trailer, boat trailer, stock trailer, pole trailer, bus, or any Commercial Motor Vehicle with a rated capacity in excess of one (1) ton according to the manufacturer's classification, or any other type of trailer not specified above, upon any public Street, Alley, Parkway, boulevard, or Public Place (excluding the driveway of a residence) within or adjacent to any area zoned as a single-family Dwelling District, two-family Dwelling District, multiple-family Dwelling District, townhouse Dwelling District, moderate density Dwelling District or Mobile Home District as established by the Zoning Ordinance of the City. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall prevent, and it is an exception to the prohibitions stated in subsection (a), that: 
(1)  The parking or standing of the above-described vehicles or trailers in such zoned areas is for the purpose of expeditiously loading and unloading passengers, freight or merchandise. Any such vehicle unlawfully parked, and after having been placarded with a notice by the City of the violation of the foregoing prohibition on any previous occasion may be towed from its location or detained at the operator's expense. 
(2)  The owner or Occupant, or an invited guest, owning or occupying real property within or abutting of any single-family Dwelling District, two-family Dwelling District, multiple-family Dwelling District, townhouse Dwelling District, moderate density Dwelling District or Mobile Home District may leave, park, stand, permit or allow any motor home, Travel Trailer, or boat trailer, which is owned by such owner, Occupant or guest on that portion of any public Street, Alley, Parkway or boulevard abutting the real property owned or occupied by such owner or Occupancy for a continuous period of time no longer than seventy-two (72) hours. Removal or other movement of such vehicle for any period of time less than twenty-four (24) hours shall not interrupt the continuous seventy-two-hour period for purposes of determining a violation under this section. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person or at any time to leave, park or stand for any period of time any of the vehicles or trailers described in subsection (a) hereof, upon any public Street, Alley, Parkway or boulevard in such a manner as to block the normal flow of traffic upon such public Street, Alley, Parkway or boulevard. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to leave, park or stand between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. any of the vehicles or trailers described in subsection (a) hereof, in any alley within the Central Business District, for a longer continuous period of time than thirty (30) minutes. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to leave, park or stand between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 5:00 a.m. any motor home, truck tractor, road tractor, trailer, semitrailer, pole trailer, house trailer, bus or any other Commercial Motor Vehicle with a manufacturer's rated capacity of one (1) ton or more on any street in the Central Business District. 
(Code 1960, § 23-30; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 6054, § 1, 12-7-93; Ord. No. 6640, § 1, 1-21-2003; Ord. No. 7204, § 2, 1-26-2010) 
Sec. 16-3-195. - Same-Exceptions. 
    The provisions in section 16-3-194 shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Street construction and maintenance: Street construction, maintenance and repair, trucks, rollers and implements. 
(2)  Public service utilities: Truck equipment, trailers and vehicles used by public service utility companies engaged in repairing or extending public service utilities. 
(3)  Buses: Motorbuses when taking on or discharging passengers at the customary bus stops. 
(4)  Loading Zones: All other vehicles designated in section 16-3-194 when actually parked at a designated Loading Zone in those areas of limited parking where Loading Zones are designated. 
(5)  Emergency repairs: Any vehicle defined or designated in section 16-3-194 which develops a mechanical defect after such vehicle has commenced to operate en route, making it unsafe to proceed further. In such event it shall be lawful to stand or park the vehicle during the time necessary to make emergency repairs. 
(Code 1960, § 23-31; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-196. - Vehicles hauling livestock. 
(a)  Except within three hundred (300) feet of a stockyard, slaughterhouse or meat packing house no person shall park a vehicle: 
(1)  Which contains one (1) or more head of livestock; 
(2)  Which has been used for transporting one (1) or more head of livestock in which there is manure or other fecal matter or until all manure and fecal matter has been removed therefrom. 
(b)  Any person traveling upon a Street may park a vehicle carrying one (1) or more head of livestock for a period not to exceed one (1) hour for the following purposes only: 
(1)  To refuel the vehicle; 
(2)  To enable the driver to obtain food; 
(3)  In emergencies when mechanical failure of the vehicle occurs. 
(Code 1960, § 23-32; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-197. - Prohibited for certain purposes. 
    No person shall park a vehicle upon any Street for the principal purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying such vehicle for sale or rent; 
(2)  Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle except repairs necessitated by an emergency; 
(3)  Displaying for sale or rent or selling or renting any merchandise. 
(Code 1960, § 23-33; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-198. - Handicapped parking. 
    It is an offense for any unauthorized person to park on public or private property in any parking space or area for the disabled designated in compliance with the identification requirements of V.A.C.S. art. 6675a-5e.1. 
(Code 1960, § 23-36; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-199. - Veteran's parking fee exemption. 
    The City hereby adopts the exemption from payment of fees or penalties imposed by the City of Amarillo for parking in a public parking garage or lot or in a space with a limitation on the length of time for parking provided to certain Veterans and Military Award Recipients by Section 681.008(b) of the Texas Transportation Code, and provides that the exemption shall apply to a vehicle in display of: 
(1)  Disabled Veterans license plates issued under Section 504.202 of the Texas Transportation Code or by another state of the United States. 
(2)  World War II Veteran license plates issued under Section 504.310 of the Texas Transportation Code. 
(3)  Bronze Star Medal, Bronze Star Medal with Valor, Air Medal, Air Medal with Valor, Distinguished Service Medal, Former Prisoner of War, Pearl Harbor Survivor, Congressional Medal of Honor, Legion of Valor, Purple Heart and Silver Star Medal license plates issued under Section 504.315 of the Texas Transportation Code. 
(4)  Legion of Merit Medal license plates issued under Section 504.316 of the Texas Transportation Code. 
(5)  Defense Superior Service Medal license plates issued under Section 504.319 of the Texas Transportation Code. 
When the vehicle is being operated by or for the registrant of the vehicle. The person claiming the exemption will, upon request, provide picture identification and either vehicle registration or insurance to confirm that the vehicle is eligible for exemption. 
(Ord. No. 7556, § 1, 9-29-2015) 
Secs. 16-3-200-16-3-210. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - METHOD OF PARKING, ANGLE PARKING, ETC. 

Sec. 16-3-211. - Specifications for angle parking areas; parking within lines. 
    The Traffic Engineer may approve the installation of angle parking areas only on minor Streets where angle parking already exists in the vicinity and where such installations would not create a hazard to or interfere with adjacent Street traffic. All such angle parking areas must be installed in compliance with the following provisions: 
(1)  Where normal Curbs are moved from the edge of certain designated roadways for angle parking of vehicles, such parking areas shall have a minimum depth of twenty (20) feet from the line of normal Curb. 
(2)  A Sidewalk shall extend the length of such parking area and shall be a minimum of six (6) feet in width, in addition to the requirements of paragraph (1) above. 
(3)  The property owner so moving the Curb shall install suitable permanent pavement markers approved by the Traffic Engineer, clearly designating the parking spaces so provided, in the entire parking area. Markers shall be installed in such a manner that drivers of any vehicle, proceeding in the direction of the normal regulated flow of traffic when preparing to park or parking any vehicle in such parking area as described above. 
(4)  No person shall stand or park any vehicle in such parking areas as described above except by standing or parking the entire vehicle completely within such marked spaces. 
(Code 1960, § 23-37; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
State Law reference- Angle parking, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 96. 
Sec. 16-3-212. - Angle parking in existing areas; reexamination of feasibility. 
(a)  The Traffic Engineer may reexamine existing areas used for angle parking and areas which comply with the requirements contained in section 16-3-211 shall be retained upon compliance with the provisions of section 16-3-211(3) by the adjacent owner. 
(b)  Areas in the Central Business District which do not comply with the requirements of section 16-3-211 shall be discontinued and the Traffic Engineer shall cause to be erected in the areas Signs designating the area as a parallel parking area. After parallel parking Signs have been erected, no person shall angle park a vehicle in the area. 
Exception: Angle parking on both sides of East Fifth Avenue between Taylor Street and Fillmore Street is hereby excepted, from the provisions of this subsection and section 16-3-215. 
(c)  Areas outside of the Central Business District and having minimum depth of more than twelve (12) feet from the normal Curbline shall be continued after the property owner has installed suitable permanent pavement markers as approved by the Traffic Engineer, clearly designating the parking spaces so provided. The markers shall be installed in such a manner that the Operator of any vehicle proceeding in the direction of the normal regulated flow of traffic will not be required to execute more than a thirty-degree angle turn from the direction of the normal regulated flow of traffic when preparing to park or when parking any vehicle in such parking area. 
(Code 1960, § 23-38; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-213. - Approach to parking space. 
    A driver preparing to occupy a parking space being vacated shall stop the vehicle behind the space being vacated and shall not pass the space until it is vacant. 
(Code 1960, § 23-39; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-214. - Starting movement of parked vehicle. 
(a)  No person shall start a vehicle which is stopped, standing or parked unless and until such movement can be made with safety. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 67. 
(b)  The Operator of a vehicle which is stopped, standing, parked or double-parked shall not put the vehicle in motion without caution. The driver shall yield normal regulated flow of traffic will not be required to execute more than a thirty-degree angle turn from the direction of the normal regulated flow of traffic when preparing to park or when parking any vehicle in such parking area. 
(b)  The Operator of a vehicle which is stopped, standing, parked or double-parked shall not put the vehicle in motion without caution. The driver shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians and vehicles lawfully approaching so closely as to constitute an immediate hazard. 
(Code 1960, § 23-40; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-215. - Length of vehicle not to exceed space. 
    No operator shall angle park a vehicle which exceeds the length of the designated parking space. 
(Code 1960, § 23-41; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Secs. 16-3-216-16-3-225. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TIME LIMITATIONS AND RESTRICTIONS 

Sec. 16-3-226. - Application. 
    The provisions of this division prohibiting the standing or parking of a vehicle shall apply at all times or at those times herein specified or as indicated on official Signs or Curb markings except when it is necessary to stop a vehicle to avoid conflict with other traffic. The provisions of this division shall not apply when it is necessary to comply with the directions of a police officer or official traffic-control device. 
(Code 1960, § 23-43; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-227. - Regulations not exclusive. 
    The provisions of this division imposing a time limit on parking shall not relieve any person from the duty to observe other and more restrictive provisions prohibiting or limiting the stopping, standing or parking of vehicles in specified places or at specified times. 
(Code 1960, § 23-44; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-228. - Limiting parking on certain streets. 
(a)  The Traffic Engineer shall investigate the flow of traffic upon all Streets and, when the flow of traffic is impeded or when traffic hazards may be reduced by limiting parking, he shall recommend to the City Council the limitation of parking either at all times or during specified hours. When a traffic engineering survey has revealed that limiting the length of time a vehicle may remain parked will better serve the area, the Traffic Engineer shall recommend to the City Council the limitation at all times or during specified hours. The City Council may approve or modify the recommendation by resolution. 
(b)  The Traffic Engineer shall cause Signs to be erected or Curbs marked giving notice of the approved parking restriction, and no person shall park a vehicle at any time nor for any longer length of time upon a Street in violation of the parking restrictions stated upon the Sign or other marking. 
(Code 1960, § 23-45; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 16-3-229. - Overtime parking. 
    If a vehicle shall remain parked in any parking space beyond the designated parking time limit for such parking, the vehicle shall be considered as parked overtime and shall be in violation of this chapter. 
(Code 1960, § 23-46; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-230. - Parking permits-Authority to issue. 
    Where it is necessary for employees of construction firms to have their vehicles near the job site or for employees of firms providing emergency repair services to be able to park in a time-restricted zone without regard to the restriction, the Traffic Engineer shall have the authority to issue a parking permit for each vehicle which would allow that vehicle to be parked in a one-hour or two-hour time-restricted zone. The permit may be issued on a weekly, monthly or yearly basis with the annual permit only being available for emergency repair firms. 
(Code 1960, § 23-47; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-231. - Same-Fees. 
    Where the Traffic Engineer has approved the issuance of a parking permit, he shall collect a fee for each permit issued, at the time of issuance, according to the following fee schedule: 
Duration 
of permit One-hour 
zone Two-hour 
zone Weekly   7.00   5.00 Monthly  25.00  15.00 Yearly 100.00 100.00  
(Code 1960, § 23-48; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Secs. 16-3-232-16-3-240. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - FREIGHT AND PASSENGER LOADING 

Sec. 16-3-241. - Reexamination of existing designated areas. 
    The Traffic Engineer may reexamine existing Loading Zones, bus stops and Taxicab stands. Such zones which impede or burden the flow of traffic and which create traffic hazards may be eliminated in accordance with this division. 
(Code 1960, § 23-49; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-242. - Freight zones-Designation; signs; hours. 
(a)  Location. The Traffic Engineer is authorized to determine the location of freight curb Loading Zones and shall place and maintain appropriate Signs indicating the same. 
(b)  Signs and markings. A Loading Zone shall be designated by upright Signs. Painted yellow Curb markings may be used in support of the upright Signs if the Traffic Engineer deems it necessary. 
(c)  Hours operative. These zones shall be operative from 7:00 a.m. to 6:30 p.m., except Sundays. 
(Code 1960, § 23-50; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-243. - Same-Use not exclusive. 
    Loading Zones shall be available to anyone who may have loading or unloading to do in the immediate vicinity. 
(Code 1960, § 23-51; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-244. - Same-Limitation on purpose, time of stops. 
(a)  Stops for loading and unloading only. No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time other than for the immediate unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials in any place marked as a Loading Zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect. 
(b)  Time limit; special exception. In no case shall the stop for loading and unloading of materials exceed fifteen (15) minutes except on written permission from the Traffic Engineer. 
(Code 1960, § 23-52; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-245. - Backing vehicle to curb. 
(a)  The Traffic Engineer is hereby authorized to issue any owner of a vehicle used to transport merchandise or materials a special permit, renewable annually, stating therein the terms and conditions, allowing the operator of such vehicle the privilege of loading and unloading while the vehicle is backed against the Curb if in his opinion such privilege is reasonably necessary in the conduct of the owner's business and will not seriously interfere with traffic. 
(b)  When any six-wheeled articulated vehicle is backed to the Curb for the purpose of unloading or loading, the front or tractor portion shall, as far as is physically possible, be turned parallel to the Curb and headed in the direction of traffic. 
(Code 1960, § 23-53; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-246. - Passenger loading and unloading-Zones designated; signs. 
(a)  The Traffic Engineer is authorized and required to establish bus stops and Taxicab stands and stands for other passenger common carrier motor vehicles on such public Streets and in such places and number as he shall determine to be of the greatest benefit and convenience to the public. 
(b)  Every such bus stop, Taxicab stand or other stand shall be designated by appropriate Signs, and shall be used only for such purpose. 
(Code 1960, § 23-54; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-247. - Same-Stopping purpose and time limitations. 
    No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or period of time other than for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers in any place marked as a passenger curb Loading Zone during hours when the regulations applicable to such Curb Loading Zone are effective, and then only for a period not to exceed two (2) minutes. 
(Code 1960, § 23-55; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-248. - Buses and taxicabs-Parking. 
(a)  The driver of a bus shall not park upon any Street in any place other than a bus stop. 
(b)  The driver of a Taxicab shall not park upon any Street in any business district at any place other than at a Taxicab stand, except that this provision shall not prevent the driver of any such vehicle from temporarily stopping in accordance with other stopping or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers. 
(Code 1960, § 23-56; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-249. - Same-Restricted use of stands. 
(a)  No person shall at any time stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop or a Taxicab in a Taxicab stand where, by appropriate sign, parking is expressly prohibited. 
(b)  At such bus stops or Taxicab stands where parking is prohibited during specified hours on certain days by appropriate signs, parking shall be permitted at all other times not so specifically prohibited. 
(Code 1960, § 23-57; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Secs. 16-3-250-16-3-274. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SPECIAL STREET USES[9]

Editor's note- Ord. No. 6625, § 1, adopted Sept. 24, 2002, amended Art. VI in its entirety to read as set out herein. Former Art.
