State Law reference- Authority to regulate or prohibit processions or assemblages on the highways, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 27(a)(3). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-3-275. - Definitions and offenses. 
(a)  For purposes of this article, the following words and terms have the meaning shown below: 
(1)  Block Party means a small social or recreational gathering of two hundred (200) or fewer persons, for which a public street, alley or sidewalk is temporarily closed within an area zoned for or predominantly used as residential and, in which all participants reside within the area of the street closure or are a guest of such a resident. 
(2)  Event is a cumulative term that means and refers to any or all of a Block Party, Festival, Race, Parade, or any combination thereof. 
(3)  Festival means a large social or recreational gathering of over two hundred (200) persons for which a public street, alley or sidewalk is temporarily closed within an area that is both zoned and used for commercial or industrial use, or within the Central Business District. A Festival shall not deny admission to any person desiring to participate in it, based on the person's race, sex, age, religion, national origin, or disability. 
(4)  Parade means any march, motorcade, or procession consisting of people, animals, vehicles of any type, or a combination thereof, upon any public street, sidewalk, or alley or combination thereof, which does not comply with normal and usual traffic regulations or controls. 
(5)  Race means a competition or series of competitions of speed or endurance between humans, motorized or other vehicles, or animals over a specified course or distance. 
(b)  It is an offense for a person to: 
(1)  Conduct, participate in or commence a Parade, Race, Block Party, or Festival unless a Permit shall have been obtained for the Event in accordance with the provisions of this article; 
(2)  Provide false, misleading, or incomplete information on a permit application; 
(3)  Conduct, allow, or participate in Parade, Race, Block Party, or Festival in such a manner that it does not comply with the conditions of the permit issued for it or the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 6625, § 1, 9-24-2002) 
Sec. 16-3-276. - Exceptions to provisions. 
    This article shall not apply to: 
(1)  Funeral processions; 
(2)  Students participating in educational activities, under the immediate direction and supervision of the proper school authorities and not interfering with the normal movement of traffic; 
(3)  A governmental agency acting within the scope of its function, including but not limited to, activities on the streets within a City park, which are sponsored or approved by the Parks and Recreation Department. 
(Ord. No. 6625, § 1, 9-24-2002) 
Sec. 16-3-277. - Interference with participants. 
    No person shall hamper, obstruct or impede, or interfere with any Parade, Race, assembly, Block Party or Festival, or with any person, vehicle or Animal participating or used in same except as directed by the Chief of Police. 
(Ord. No. 6625, § 1, 9-24-2002) 
Sec. 16-3-278. - Driving through. 
    No operator of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles or persons comprising a Parade, Race, or drive into an area closed for a Block Party or Festival when such Parade or Race participants are in motion and are conspicuously designated as a Parade or Race, or the street is conspicuously closed for a Block Party or Festival, except as directed by a police officer or other authorized person directing traffic. 
(Ord. No. 6625, § 1, 9-24-2002) 
Sec. 16-3-279. - Parking en route. 
    The Chief of Police with the approval of the Traffic Engineer shall have the authority, when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles along a Street or highway or part thereof constituting a part of the route of a Parade or Race or the area of a Block Party or Festival. The Traffic Engineer may post Signs to such effect, and it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 6625, § 1, 9-24-2002) 
Sec. 16-3-280. - Conflict with open container ordinance. 
    Any Festival Permit that is issued for an area within the Central Business District as provided for in the Open Container Ordinance must be issued subject to and contain the restrictions and conditions stated in section 10-3-44(b) of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 6625, § 1, 9-24-2002) 
Secs. 16-3-281-16-3-285. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 16-3-286. - Authority to issue Event permit. 
(a)  The Traffic Engineer, in coordination with the Police Chief, shall have the authority to issue a permit for an Event as provided in this Article, which allows closure of a prescribed portion of a public street, alley or sidewalk during the time and under the public safety conditions prescribed by the permit. The person or entity which obtains the Permit must strictly comply with the requirements and conditions of any permit granted. 
(b)  The issuance of a permit for an Event authorizes only the closure of a public street, alley, or sidewalk; it does not authorize, waive, excuse, or exempt the permittee from obeying the provisions of any other state law or local ordinance, unless specified herein or in the other state law or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 6625, § 1, 9-24-2002) 
Sec. 16-3-287. - Application. 
(a)  The following general provisions apply to all applications for any permit issued under this article: 
(1)  A person seeking a permit shall complete an application for such on a form provided by the Traffic Engineer. The application shall inquire about: name, address and telephone number of applicant and any co-applicant; date, hours, location or route of the Event; expected number of participants; if a Race or Parade, then the number of vehicles, floats, units and persons to be involved, with a description of the assembly and disbanding areas; and, such other reasonable information which the Traffic Engineer or Police Chief may deem necessary for making an informed decision for the welfare of the general public or participants in the Event. 
(2)  A completed application for a Festival, Parade or Race Permit must be filed with the Traffic Engineer not less than thirty (30) calendar days before the proposed date. A completed application for a Block Party must be filed no later than fourteen (14) days before the activity date. A "complete application" is one that has all blanks filled-in, plus any required supplementary documents are complete and attached and a fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) is paid by the applicant. 
(3)  The Traffic Engineer, with approval of City Manager where good cause is shown, may consider an application filed after the deadline prescribed above. 
(4)  The Traffic Engineer and Police Chief, or their respective designee, shall complete the administrative review and note on the application their decision to grant or deny it, not later than the 14 th calendar day after the day a complete application is filed. 
(b)  In addition to the above general provisions, the following specific provisions apply to and are required of an application for a Parade or Race permit: 
(1)  The applicant shall deposit an amount necessary to compensate off-duty police personnel at hourly rates established by the Chief of Police. 
(2)  The permit shall not be issued if the Parade or Race is for the sole purpose of advertising any product, goods, wares, merchandise or event designed to be held or offered for private profit. 
(c)  In addition to the above general provisions, the following specific provisions apply to and are required of an application for a Block Party or Festival permit: 
(1)  The street, alley, or sidewalk segment to be closed shall not include or be within one hundred fifty (150) feet of a property line for a premises licensed for the sale or consumption of alcohol or liquor, unless such premises is within the Central Business District. 
(2)  The application for a Block Party must seek closure of a public street, alley, or sidewalk that is within a residential area. The applicant must be an individual whose primary private residential domicile is within the area to be closed. 
(3)  The application for a Festival permit must seek closure of a street, alley, or sidewalk that is within the Central Business District or within an area zoned for commercial or industrial uses. The applicant must be a nonprofit organization or association and, attach to the application acceptable proof of its status as a bona fide nonprofit entity. The application must have attached to it signed letters, petition, or a combination thereof, from seventy (70) percent or more of the residents, be they private, commercial, or other fronting on the block proposed for closure, agreeing to the Festival. The petition or letters must legibly state the date, hours and location of the proposed closure, and the resident's address. In the case of a private residence, there must be a legible signature of an adult who resides there. In the case of a commercial or business resident, there must be a legible signature of a manger, owner, or officer authorized to sign for the company. For purposes of calculating the "majority of residents" in this subsection, only one (1) adult signature per residential unit or one authorized signature per commercial or business resident is required. 
(4)  The application for a Festival permit must have attached to it proof of adequate insurance to repair or replace any damage to publicly owned property within or adjacent to the closed area. Such insurance policy must be evidenced by a certificate showing it is valid for the date(s) of the Event, lists the City as an Additional Insured, be in the face amount of not less than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), and issued by a company licensed to issue such policy in Texas, with an A.M. Best Co. rating of B+ or better. This provision may be satisfied by either a special policy issued solely for the Event or, by a standing liability policy maintained by the applicant year round, so long as it meets the requirements of this subsection. 
(Ord. No. 6625, § 1, 9-24-2002; Ord. No. 7363, § 18, 9-18-2012) 
Sec. 16-3-288. - Standards for issuance and conditions. 
(a)  The Traffic Engineer and Police Chief shall uniformly treat each application for an Event permit in a just, fair and nondiscriminatory manner bearing in mind that the time, place, duration and manner of use of the public Streets and other public ways and places for Events shall be subordinate to the public safety, comfort and convenience, as well as the maintenance of order and avoidance of congestion. The Traffic Engineer must issue a Permit upon finding, (i) from a consideration of the application materials, (ii) review of the area sought to be closed, and (iii) consultation with the Police Chief, that: 
(1)  The submitted application documents are complete and truthful in all material aspects, and the proposed location complies with the applicable requirements stated in section 16-3-287 for the type of Event proposed. 
(2)  The conduct of the Event will not substantially interrupt the safe and orderly movement of other traffic near the Event route or site. 
(3)  The conduct of the Event will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the City to properly police the Event and the areas near there, as to prevent normal police protection to other areas of the City. 
(4)  The conduct of the Event will not require the diversion of so great a number of Ambulances as to prevent normal Ambulance Service to other portions of the City. 
(5)  The concentration of persons, animals or vehicles at the Event or the assembly points will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of or the Ambulance Service to areas near by. 
(6)  The conduct of such Event will not substantially interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to a fire. 
(7)  The conduct of the Event is not likely to cause injury to persons or property, to result in or to provide disorderly conduct, or create a disturbance. 
(8)  In the case of a Parade or Race, it is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point of termination without unreasonable delays en route. 
(9)  A prior Event sponsored or promoted in whole or in part by applicant resulted in conduct that required the diversion of so great a number of police officers or ambulances as to prevent normal police protection or ambulance service in other areas of the City. 
(10)  A prior Event sponsored or promoted in whole or in part by the applicant was conducted in violation of the terms of the prior permit. 
(11)  A prior permit for an Event sponsored in whole or in part by applicant was later found to be based on an application containing false, misleading, or deceptive information. 
(b)  An application may be denied on the basis of reasons (9) through (11) inclusive, only during the twenty-four (24) calendar months next following the date of the prior Event. 
(c)  If an application is approved and the permit is issued, then: 
(1)  It may be subject to reasonable conditions imposed in writing by either the Traffic Engineer or Police Chief, to protect health, safety, comfort or convenience of persons or property participating in the Event or in the immediate vicinity of it. 
(2)  The permittee shall provide its own cones, sawhorses, or other type of barricades. Any device used by the permittee to block the street must be capable of being quickly removed to facilitate emergency vehicles. If the Event will occur from thirty (30) minutes prior to sunset or later, then all barricades must be adequately lighted or reflective to alert drivers of motor vehicles to their presence. 
(3)  A Block Party permit shall not allow closing a street earlier than 7:00 a.m. or later than 10:00 p.m. 
(4)  A Festival permit shall not allow closing a street earlier than 7 a.m. or later than midnight, except that a Festival in the Central Business District is subject to the provisions of subsection 10-3-44(b). 
(Ord. No. 6625, § 1, 9-24-2002) 
Sec. 16-3-289. - Notice of denial and appeal. 
(a)  An application may be denied for the causes listed in, or failure to meet any requirement of, either section 16-3-287 or subsection 16-3-288(a). If the Traffic Engineer does not approve the application, then on the day of such decision, the Traffic Engineer shall mail a letter to the applicant which: (i) states each reason the application was denied; and, (ii) informs the applicant of the right to appeal the decision to the City Council by delivering a letter to the City Manager that states why the Traffic Engineer's decision is improper or why a condition of the permit is unreasonable or unnecessary. 
(b)  Upon receipt of an appeal, the City Manager shall place such on the agenda for either the next or the next following regular meeting of the City Council (unless the City Manager first determines the application should be granted or a condition modified or repealed, in which case the City Manager shall so instruct the Traffic Engineer and the appeal is moot.) 
(c)  Failure of the Traffic Engineer to either make a timely decision on an application or to timely mail a notice of denial shall be treated as grounds for appeal. Any person aggrieved shall have the right to appeal the denial of an Event permit, in the manner provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 6625, § 1, 9-24-2002; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 16-3-290. - Alternative permit. 
    The Traffic Engineer may, in consultation with the Police Chief, and within the fourteen (14) days allowed for review, suggest to the applicant an alternative date, hour, site or route, for an Event, in lieu of denying the application. The Traffic Engineer may suggest the alternative to the applicant by mail, electronic mail, or verbally (if Traffic Engineer notes the date, time, phone number called and details of the alternative on the application.) An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit shall, within three (3) business days after notice of the Traffic Engineer suggested alternative, file a written acceptance of the alternative with the Traffic Engineer. An alternate permit shall conform to the requirements of and, shall have the effect of any other permit issued under this article. The applicant's failure or refusal to timely accept a suggested alternative, shall result in a deemed denial of both the application and the alternative, and shall require the Traffic Engineer to mail the notice required in section 16-3-289. 
(Ord. No. 6625, § 1, 9-24-2002) 
Sec. 16-3-291. - Duties of permittee. 
    A permittee under this article shall comply with all Permit directions, limitations, and conditions and with all other applicable laws and ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 6625, § 1, 9-24-2002) 
Sec. 16-3-292. - Revocation. 
    The Traffic Engineer shall have the authority to revoke a Parade or Race Permit issued hereunder upon application of the standards for issuance as set forth in section 16-3-288. 
(Code 1960, § 23-93; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Secs. 16-3-293-16-3-310. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PEDESTRIANS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
State Law reference- Pedestrians, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 76 et seq. 

Sec. 16-3-311. - Operators to exercise due care. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of this article, every Operator of a vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any roadway. 
(Code 1960, § 23-102; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 79. 
Sec. 16-3-312. - Use of crosswalks. 
(a)  Between consecutive traffic-signal-controlled intersections, pedestrians shall not cross a Street at any place except in a marked crosswalk. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 78(c). 
(b)  No pedestrians shall cross a roadway other than in a crosswalk in any business district. 
(Code 1960, § 23-99; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-313. - Manner of walking along roadways. 
(a)  Where Sidewalks are provided it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to walk along and upon an adjacent roadway. 
(b)  Where Sidewalks are not provided any pedestrian walking along and upon a highway shall when possible walk only on the left side of the roadway or its shoulder facing approaching traffic. 
(c)  No person shall stand on or in proximity to a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride, contributions, employment or business from the occupant of any vehicle. 
(d)  No pedestrian shall cross or use freeway lanes of any expressway. 
(e)  The Traffic Engineer may determine that a special hazard exists to pedestrians using part of a roadway and may erect Signs restricting pedestrian traffic. No person shall walk along any part of a roadway which is so restricted. 
(Code 1960, § 23-100; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 7204, § 1, 1-26-2010) 
State Law reference- Pedestrians on roadways, V.A.C.S. art. 6701d, § 81. 
Sec. 16-3-314. - Conduct while awaiting bus, standing on sidewalk. 
(a)  Pedestrians shall stand on Sidewalks or islands while waiting for a bus. 
(b)  Pedestrians shall stand on the side of a Sidewalk either at or near the Curb or the property line, so as not to interfere with other pedestrians. 
(Code 1960, § 23-101; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Secs. 16-3-315-16-3-325. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - BICYCLES[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate bicycles, V.T.C.A. ch. 551 (Vernon 1999); bicycles generally, V.T.C.A. ch. 541, 544, and 545; and § 552.006. 

Sec. 16-3-326. - Riding on roadways, bicycle lanes in designated roadways, and hike and bike paths. 
(a)  Definitions. In this article, the following words shall have the meanings indicated: 
(1)  Bicycle lane means an area within a roadway specifically designated for the use of bicycles on public roadways designated in the current Hike and Bike Master Plan. 
(2)  Hike and Bike path means an area not on a roadway, that is designated as such a path in the current Hike and Bike Trail Master Plan. 
(b)  Where a bicycle lane has been provided within a roadway, bicycle riders shall use such lane and shall not use the roadway, except when: (1) the bicyclist is executing an immediate left-hand turn in compliance with Texas traffic regulations; (2) entry into the roadway is necessary due to an obstruction in the bicycle lane or path; or (3) other circumstances exist that require the bicyclist to enter the roadway to preserve the safety of the rider or another. 
(c)  When using a designated Hike and Bike path, all bicycle riders shall comply with regulations established for such paths by the Amarillo Parks and Recreation Department. 
(d)  No person shall operate a bicycle on or across the freeway lanes of any expressway. 
(e)  Bicycle riders on public roadways that do not have a designated bicycle lane shall comply with Texas state laws applicable to motor vehicles. 
(Code 1960, § 23-105; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 6654, § 2, 7-1-2003) 
Sec. 16-3-327. - Speed. 
    No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions then existing, but under no circumstances at a speed greater than the existing posted speed limit. 
(Code 1960, § 23-106; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-328. - Emerging from alley or driveway. 
    The Operator of a bicycle emerging from an Alley, Driveway or Building shall upon approaching a Sidewalk or the Sidewalk area extending across any Alleyway, yield the Right-of-way to all pedestrians approaching on the Sidewalk or Sidewalk area, and upon entering the roadway shall yield the Right-of-way to all vehicles approaching on the roadway. 
(Code 1960, § 23-107; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-329. - Parking. 
    It is an offense to park a bicycle in a public place except as described in this section. A bicycle may be parked against a Street Curb. A bicycle may only be parked upon a Sidewalk, if it is properly placed in a rack to support the bicycle. A bicycle may only be parked against a Building in a manner that does not inhibit or obstruct pedestrian and vehicular traffic. No bicycle shall be parked within or between marked lines denoting parking spaces for motor vehicles, and no bicycle shall be attached or secured to public or private property in such a manner as to damage, impair, or render such property inaccessible or inoperable. 
(Code 1960, § 23-108; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 6654, § 3, 7-1-2003) 
Sec. 16-3-330. - Riding on sidewalks. 
(a)  No person shall ride a bicycle upon a Sidewalk within a business district. 
(b)  Whenever any person is riding a bicycle upon a Sidewalk, such person shall yield the Right-of-way to any pedestrian and shall give an audible signal before overtaking and passing such pedestrian. 
(Code 1960, § 23-109; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-331. - Certain turns. 
    Where authorized signs indicate that a right, left, or "U"-turn is not permitted, a person operating a bicycle shall obey the direction of such sign, unless the bicycle operator dismounts from the bicycle to make such turn, in which event the person shall then obey the regulations pertaining to pedestrians, including but not limited to Ch. 552 of the Texas Transportation Code. 
(Ord. No. 6654, § 4, 7-1-2003) 
Sec. 16-3-332. - Application of other laws. 
    All state laws pertaining to the operation of bicycles are hereby adopted, including but not limited to, Ch. 541, Ch, 545, and Ch. 551 of the Texas Transportation Code, and any future amendments thereto. To the extent that any provision in this Article conflicts with state law, state law prevails. 
(Ord. No. 6654, § 5, 7-1-2003) 
Sec. 16-3-333. - Motor vehicles excluded; exception. 
    It is an offense for the driver of a motor vehicle to enter a designated bicycle lane, except when a bicyclist is not present and the action is necessary for the driver to execute a turn or to preserve the safety of the driver or another. 
(Ord. No. 6919, § 2, 3-14-2006) 
Sec. 16-3-334. - Penalty. 
    It is an offense to violate any part of this Article, punishable upon conviction in accordance with Section 1-1-5 of the Amarillo Municipal Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 6654, § 6, 7-1-2003; Ord. No. 6919, § 2, 3-14-2006) 
Secs. 16-3-335-16-3-345. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - MISCELLANEOUS RULES 

Sec. 16-3-346. - Riding in vehicle space intended for passengers. 
    No person shall ride on any bus or vehicle upon any portion thereof not designed or intended for the use of passengers. This provision shall not apply to an employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty or to persons riding within truck bodies in space intended for merchandise. 
(Code 1960, § 23-94; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-347. - Vehicles used for advertising. 
    No person shall operate or park any vehicle on any street right-of-way or public property nor shall any owner permit any vehicle belonging to him to be so operated or parked for the purpose of advertising. A vehicle displaying advertising messages and left unattended shall be presumed to have been so parked for the purpose of advertising. Common sense governs enforcement. If the owner or person in control of such vehicle cannot be found in or near such vehicle and requested to remove it, such vehicle will be towed at the owner's expense. The minimum fine for the second and subsequent offenses within one (1) year shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(Code 1960, § 23-95; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86; Ord. No. 6278, § 1, 4-8-97) 
Sec. 16-3-348. - Wrecked vehicles; removing debris. 
    Any person removing a wrecked or damaged vehicle from a highway shall remove any glass or other debris dropped upon the highway from such vehicle. 
(Code 1960, § 23-96; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-349. - Trucks prohibited on certain streets; exception. 
    The Traffic Engineer is hereby authorized after having made an engineering and traffic investigation to erect Signs prohibiting any truck-tractor, road-tractor, semi-trailer, truck or other Commercial Motor Vehicle having a gross weight in excess of fifteen thousand (15,000) pounds from using certain Streets when such use would create a hazard. This prohibition shall not apply to vehicles having a trip origin or destination on such Streets. 
(Code 1960, § 23-97; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-350. - Accident; driver to notify police, remain at scene. 
    The driver of a vehicle involved in an accident resulting in injury to or death of any person, or damage to any vehicle or other property to an apparent extent of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or more, shall immediately give notice of such accident to the Police Department of the City and shall, unless physically disabled, remain at the scene of the accident until released by the investigating police officer. 
(Code 1960, § 23-98; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-351. - Coasters, rollerskates, etc. 
    No person upon rollerskates or riding in or by means of any coaster, toy vehicle or similar device, shall go upon any roadway except while crossing a Street on a crosswalk. When so crossing such person shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to pedestrians. 
(Code 1960, § 23-103; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
Sec. 16-3-352. - Boarding or alighting from vehicles. 
    No person shall board or alight from any bus or vehicle while such bus or vehicle is in motion. 
(Code 1960, § 23-104; Ord. No. 5620, § 2, 8-26-86) 
ARTICLE X. - DRIVEWAY AND PARKING PERMITS, SPECIFICATIONS AND RULES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-3-353. - Purpose. 
    The efficiency and safety of a roadway facility without control of access depends to a large extent upon the amount and character of roadside interference, most of which originates in vehicle movements to and from businesses, residences, or other development along the roadway. Interference resulting from indiscriminate roadside development and uncontrolled driveway connections results in lowered capacity and increased hazard. Accordingly, regulation and overall control of driveway connections are necessary to provide efficient and safe operation of the roadway. 
(Ord. No. 6726, § 2, 5-19-2004) 
Sec. 16-3-354. - Authority and Adoption of Driveway and Parking Manual; Process; Publication; and Effective date. 
(a)  Authority; Adoption of manual. The City Traffic Engineer is hereby authorized and directed to promulgate a manual pertaining to the administration, design, construction, and maintenance of driveways and parking within the city. Such manual shall, at a minimum, specify definitions, required permits, fees, frequency of driveways, construction and design standards, parking layout guidelines, layout, and access, figures, tables, and diagrams, together with such other provisions as the Traffic Engineer may propose from time to time. Such manual shall be known as the "Driveway & Parking Manual." 
(b)  Process. Upon both the initial adoption of and each subsequent amendment or supplement of the Driveway & Parking Manual, the following process shall be followed: 
(1)  The Traffic Commission shall conduct at least one (1) public hearing for the adoption of and each subsequent amendment or supplement, so that the Traffic Engineer may hear further comments and questions from the public, interested persons the Traffic Commission, and other City staff. At the public hearing the Traffic Engineer shall report to the Traffic Commission any comments received during the thirty-day comment period. The Traffic Engineer shall carefully consider each comment, weighing same against the engineer's professional knowledge, experience, and the goals of the manual and the proposed amendment or supplement. 
(2)  The Traffic Engineering Department shall publicize and receive comments upon every proposed amendment and supplement by the means described in subsection (c) below, for a period of not less than thirty (30) days prior to the date on which the Traffic Commission conducts the public hearing. 
(3)  Each amendment or supplement shall become effective no sooner than fifteen (15) days after the date of it is issued in final form by the Traffic Engineer. A proposal or plan for a driveway or parking project submitted for review during the fifteen-day period shall be subject to the new manual or amendment or supplement thereto. However, an amendment or supplement shall not apply to or be effective as to any project or location that was already approved or issued a permit by the Traffic Engineering or Building Safety departments under a prior version of the Driveway & Parking Manual, provided that such prior approval or permit has not lapsed or expired. 
(4)  The manual shall not be amended or supplemented more often than once every twelve (12) months, from the date of the last amendment or supplement, unless such is required sooner in order to comply with changes in other laws or regulations. 
(c)  Publication. Upon proposing both the initial adoption of and each subsequent amendment or supplement of the Driveway & Parking Manual, the affected text, drawings, and tables shall be disseminated to the general public and interested persons by reasonable means, including but not limited to: posting on the City's internet website; mailing to parties who have enrolled on a mailing list with the Traffic Engineering Department; and, having a copy available for public review in the City offices of Traffic Engineering, Building Safety, and the City Secretary. These publication efforts shall be promptly repeated if the final adopted version of an amendment or supplement is materially different from the proposal that was first publicized. 
(Ord. No. 6726, § 2, 5-19-2004; Ord. No. 7321, § 3, 3-27-2012) 
DIVISION 2. - DRIVEWAYS 

Sec. 16-3-355. - Permit required; coordination with State; appeal. 
(a)  In accordance with the Driveway & Parking Manual as adopted and amended in accordance with Division I of this Article, a driveway permit must be obtained from the Traffic Engineering Department of the City of Amarillo before any person removes, alters, or constructs any curb, approach, or gutter on any public property. If the driveway is part of new construction, the driveway permit may be considered as part of the building permit obtained from the Building Safety Department as provided for in the Driveway & Parking Manual. 
(b)  In accordance with the Texas Department of Transportation's (TxDOT) Access Management Manual, the City accepts responsibility as the permitting authority for access to the state highway system. 
(1)  Where curb and gutter exist on state highways and drainage and hydraulics have already been addressed, the City Traffic Engineering Department will permit and inspect all driveways. The Traffic Engineer will issue permits under TxDOT's Access Management Manual. Permitting will be in compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Texas Accessibility Standards (TAS), environmental requirements, wetland considerations if appropriate, and follow all applicable state and federal laws, rules, and regulations. Associated fees will be the same as those for residential and commercial driveway permitting on City streets. 
(2)  Where curb and gutter do not exist and thus drainage and hydraulics have not been addressed on state highways, the City Traffic Engineering Department will permit and inspect all driveways. The Texas Department of Transportation will be responsible for sizing culverts. Permitting will be in compliance with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) and Texas Accessibility Standards (TAS), environmental requirements, wetland considerations if appropriate, and follow all applicable state and federal laws and regulations, and the current version of the Driveway and Parking Manual as adopted and amended in accordance with Division 1 of this Article. 
(c)  The Traffic Engineer is authorized to prohibit a driveway in a requested location when there is adequate access to the property, or when the applicant does not comply with the provisions of this Article, including the Driveway & Parking Manual. 
(d)  An applicant who is denied a permit by the City Traffic Engineering Department or who desires to contest a determination made under this Article or the application of the Driveway & Parking Manual, may appeal the matter to the Traffic Commission. A written notice of appeal must be submitted to the Traffic Engineering Department within ten (10) calendar days of the denial or determination to be contested. The notice must state the specific reason for the appeal and point out with particularity the alleged error of the Traffic Engineering Department. The Traffic Commission shall consider the appeal at its next regular meeting and render a decision. The appeal may be tabled the next regular meeting to allow for review and investigation, if the Traffic Commission deems it necessary. The decision of the Traffic Commission may be appealed to the City Council by filing a notice with the City Secretary within ten (10) days after the decision of the Traffic Commission. The notice must state with specificity the alleged error of the Traffic Commission and the applicant's reasoning. The City Secretary shall place the appeal on an agenda for a regular City Council meeting to occur within three (3) weeks after receipt of the notice. 
(Ord. No. 6726, § 2, 5-19-2004; Ord. No. 7321, § 4, 3-27-2012; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 16-3-356. - Prohibited Locations; Driveway Frequency; Design Standards; Construction. 
    Shall be as stated in and comply with the current version of the Driveway & Parking Manual adopted pursuant to Division 1 of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 6726, § 2, 5-19-2004; Ord. No. 7321, § 4, 3-27-2012) 
Sec. 16-3-357. - Existing driveways; appeal. 
    All driveways existing at the time of adoption of this Article will be allowed to remain, subject to remediation to correct safety hazards. If an existing driveway is deemed hazardous to the driving public, the property owner will be given notice by the City of Amarillo or TxDOT at least fifteen (15) calendar days prior to closing the driveway. Reasonable effort will be made to relocate driveway as closely as possible to its current location. The City of Amarillo or TxDOT will be responsible for all costs associated with closing and relocating the driveway. The property owner may appeal the removal to the Traffic Commission by the procedures stated in Section 16-3-355 (d). 
(Ord. No. 6726, § 2, 5-19-2004; Ord. No. 7321, § 4, 3-27-2012) 
Secs. 16-3-358-16-3-364. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7321, § 4, adopted Mar. 27, 2012, repealed Div. 3. §§ 16-3-358-16-3-360, which pertained to design standards; construction; existing driveways, respectively, and derived from Ord. No. 6726, § 2, adopted May 19, 2004. 
DIVISION 3. - PARKING 

Sec. 16-3-365. - Purpose. 
    The internal circulation and parking patterns on a piece of property are very important considerations in properly locating driveways to provide adequate access to that property. Therefore, parking shall be designed, laid out, permitted, and constructed in accordance with the Driveway & Parking Manual as adopted, amended and supplemented in accordance with Division 1 of this Article. 
(Ord. No. 6726, § 2, 5-19-2004; Ord. No. 7321, § 5, 3-27-2012) 
Sec. 16-3-366. - Permit required. 
    A building permit must be obtained for any new parking space or change in any existing paved off-street parking space in accordance with the current version of the Driveway & Parking Manual as adopted and amended in accordance with Division [1] of this Article. For new construction, this permit may be considered part of the building permit for the structure. 
(Ord. No. 6726, § 2, 5-19-2004; Ord. No. 7321, § 5, 3-27-2012) 
Sec. 16-3-367. - Parking Layout. 
(a)  Shall be as stated within and in accordance with the current version of the Driveway & Parking Manual as adopted and amended pursuant to Division 1 of this Article. 
(b)  Nothing in this Division shall be construed to either: 
(1)  Waive or remove the requirement of any other ordinance or law applicable to parking or the location of a parking facility; or, 
(2)  To relieve the property owner of the obligation to comply with all other such ordinances and laws. 
(Ord. No. 6726, § 2, 5-19-2004; Ord. No. 7321, § 5, 3-27-2012) 
Sec. 16-3-368. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7321, § 5, adopted Mar. 27, 2012, deleted § 16-3-368, which pertained to parking layout; specific and derived from Ord. No. 6726, § 2, adopted May 19, 2004. 
Sec. 16-3-369. - Reserved. 
Sec. 16-3-370. - Parking design standards; appeal. 
(a)  The minimum standards and requirements for parking spaces and handicapped accessible parking spaces for the City of Amarillo shall be as stated within and in accordance with the current version of the Driveway & Parking Manual as adopted and amended pursuant to Division 1 of this Article. 
(b)  The Traffic Engineer or designee shall have the authority to override the parking design standards if warranted by specific traffic conditions documented in the official records of the Traffic Engineer. Any applicant whose parking design is denied by the City Traffic Engineer may appeal to the Traffic Commission as provided for in Subsection 16-3-355 (d). 
(Ord. No. 6726, § 2, 5-19-2004; Ord. No. 7321, § 5, 3-27-2012) 
ARTICLE XI. - ANIMAL-DRAWN VEHICLE 

Sec. 16-3-372. - Definitions. 
    As used in this Article, the following words and terms shall have the meaning stated in this section. 
    "Animal-drawn vehicle" shall mean any cart, coach, trailer, carriage, wagon, or other vehicle drawn by an animal, by which any person is or may be transported upon a public way, street, road, highway or alley. 
    "Operate" or "Operating" shall have the meaning ascribed by Section 16-3-2 and shall also include the act of waiting for or offering to transport persons in an Animal-drawn vehicle, whether or not a passenger is actually then occupying such vehicle or not. 
(Ord. No. 6930, § 1, 4-18-2006) 
Sec. 16-3-373. - Offense. 
    It is an offense for any person to Operate an Animal-drawn vehicle on a public street, alley or highway: 
(a)  Without a permit issued under this Article; or 
(b)  In violation of any term or condition of an issued permit; or 
(c)  Without complying with any other requirement of this Article; 
    It is an exception to this section and not offense that an Animal-drawn vehicle operates on a public street an entry in an authorized parade, movie production, or similar special event involving restricted access or use of public streets. 
(Ord. No. 6930, § 1, 4-18-2006) 
Sec. 16-3-374. - Equipment. 
(a)  Animal-drawn vehicles shall meet all requirements of the State of Texas applicable to such vehicles, including but not limited to front and rear electric lamps on the vehicle ([V.T.C.A.] Texas Transportation Code, § 547.326) and reflectors on the animal; tires or wheels ([V.T.C.A.] Texas Transportation Code, § 547.612); and, slow moving vehicle emblem ([V.T.C.A.] Texas Transportation Code, § 547.703). 
(b)  Animal-drawn vehicles must have hydraulic or mechanical brakes in good working order installed on the two (2) rear wheels, capable of safely stopping the vehicle in an emergency. 
(c)  All animal excrement falling onto the roadway shall be cleaned up at the completion of rides for that day or evening. 
(Ord. No. 6930, § 1, 4-18-2006) 
Sec. 16-3-375. - State law requirements. 
    All statutory references in this Article shall be a reference to the law in existence on the day a permit is applied for and, includes any amendments, re-codifications, or successor statutes adopted after the date this Article is adopted. Further, in the event the State should adopt any statute or agency rule applicable to Animal-drawn vehicles on public streets, then those requirements shall also be applied by the City per this section. 
(Ord. No. 6930, § 1, 4-18-2006) 
Sec. 16-3-376. - Animals and drivers. 
(a)  Animals used to draw a vehicle upon a public street shall be: 
(1)  Healthy, of sufficient size and strength to draw the vehicle, and docile temperament; 
(2)  Accustomed to urban traffic; and, 
(3)  Properly shod for paved streets. 
(b)  Each driver or operator of an Animal-drawn vehicle shall be: 
(1)  At least eighteen (18) years of age and have demonstrated knowledge of traffic laws and rules of the road, as evidenced by possession of a valid motor vehicle driver's license issued by any State. 
(2)  Experienced and competent to handle the Animal-drawn vehicle in urban traffic. 
(3)  Not impaired by alcohol or drugs, in accordance with the state laws applicable to either public intoxication or driving under the influence. 
(Ord. No. 6930, § 1, 4-18-2006) 
Sec. 16-3-377. - Permit process and requirements. 
    Prior to Operating any Animal-drawn vehicle on a public street or alley, the owner of an Animal-drawn vehicle must obtain a permit in accordance with the procedure stated in this section: 
(a)  Complete an application form provided by the City Traffic Engineering Department. The form shall require: 
(1)  the name, physical address and phone number of the owner of the Animal-drawn vehicle and each person who may operate such vehicle; 
(2)  a description of each animal to be used and reasonably explain how the animal meets the requirements of this Article; 
(3)  a description of the days, hours, route, or area, of operations proposed for approval. 
(b)  Submit with the application: 
(1)  A photocopy of the valid driver's license for each person who may Operate the Animal-drawn vehicle; and, 
(2)  An application fee payment of one hundred dollars ($100.00) to defray the cost of application review, vehicle inspection, and monitoring of operations; and, 
(3)  Proof of public liability and property damage insurance, naming the City as an additional insured, in the minimum amounts shown below, issued by an insurance company authorized to issue such insurance in this State with minimum financial reserves of not less than one hundred million dollars ($100,000,000.00) in reported capital, surplus, and conditional reserve funds. Any insurer or re-insurer which is rated shall have an A.M. Best Company rating of B+ or higher or an equivalent rating by another insurance rating company: 
A.  For damages arising out of bodily injury to or death of one (1) person in any one (1) accident: One hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00); 
B.  For damages arising out of bodily injury to or death of two (2) or more persons in any one (1) accident: Three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00); 
C.  For property damage in any one (1) accident: Fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00); and 
D.  General liability: One million dollars ($1,000,000.00). 
(4)  A veterinarian certificate attesting that the animal is in good health and capable of drawing the vehicle loaded with passengers and Operator. 
(c)  Present the vehicle for an equipment compliance inspection under the provisions of this Article and all applicable provisions of the Texas Transportation Code. This inspection shall be performed by either the City Traffic Engineer or designee, or the Superintendent of the municipal garage or designee. 
(d)  The Traffic Engineer or designee shall review all of the above-described documents for completeness. In determining whether to approve or disapprove the proposed dates, hours, and route or area of operation, these factors shall be considered: width of street, motor vehicle volume, time of day, and any other factor reasonably related to public health, safety, or convenience. The Traffic Engineer or designee may prohibit operation of Animal-drawn vehicles upon arterial streets or impose other reasonable requirements to protect the health, safety, or welfare of the passengers, motorists, or the animal, such as but not limited to, requiring a crossing guard where the operation will involve crossing an arterial street after dark. 
(e)  Upon satisfactory completion of all application requirements and approval of the proposed dates, hours, and route(s) of operation, the Traffic Engineer or designee shall issue an Animal-drawn vehicle permit to the owner, which shall be valid for a term of sixty (60) days, whereupon it expires if not previously suspended or revoked as provided below. 
(f)  If the Traffic Engineer refuses to issue a permit, then the applicant may appeal such decision by using the same appeal procedure stated in Section 16-3-289 (appeal of parade permit). 
(Ord. No. 6930, § 1, 4-18-2006) 
Sec. 16-3-378. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Criminal: Violations of this Article are a class C misdemeanor offense. All provisions of this Article may be enforced by any peace officer, by citation or arrest. In addition, the provisions of Section 16-3-376(a) may be enforced by any City Animal Control Officer. 
(b)  Administrative: Upon learning that any document submitted to obtain a permit may not be truthful or complete, or that an Animal-drawn vehicle, equipment, animal, or operator is not otherwise in compliance with any requirement or duty imposed by this Article, then the Traffic Engineer shall immediately serve the operator and owner a letter (by hand delivery or certified mail) describing each alleged violation and summoning such persons to a hearing before the Traffic Engineer, to be conducted within three (3) business days after delivery of the letter. The owner and operator have the right to call witnesses and cross-examine witnesses. The Traffic Engineer may be a witness. At the conclusion of the hearing, the Traffic Engineer shall announce his findings based on a preponderance of the evidence. If a violation is found, then the permit shall be either suspended for a stated period of time not to exceed one-half of the remaining time on the permit, or be revoked, depending upon: the seriousness of the violation, whether any animal or person was injured, property damaged, and any history of violations. The owner or operator may appeal the Traffic Engineer's decision to the City Manager by sending a letter within three (3) business days after the Traffic Engineer issues his decision, describing the alleged errors in the Engineer's decision or procedure. The City Manager or designee shall promptly review the matter and may seek additional evidence as necessary to make a just and final determination of the matter. This administrative proceeding is independent and cumulative of any criminal enforcement. All findings, decisions, and any permit suspension or revocation is not admissible in municipal court due to the lower evidentiary threshold of the administrative proceeding, although the Traffic Engineer may be called as a witness if he has personal knowledge pertinent to a criminal charge apart from anything he learned or heard while acting as a hearing officer. 
(Ord. No. 6930, § 1, 4-18-2006) 
ARTICLE XII. - PHOTOGRAPHIC TRAFFIC SIGNAL ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 16-3-379. - Definitions. 
    In this Article the following terms have the meaning stated unless context indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Owner shall mean the titled owner of a motor vehicle as shown on the registration records of the Texas Department of Transportation or the analogous department or agency of another state or country. 
(2)  Photographic Traffic Signal Enforcement System shall mean a system that: 
a.  Consists of a camera system installed to work in conjunction with an electrically operated traffic-control signal; and 
b.  Is capable of producing at least two (2) recorded images that depicts the license plate attached to the rear of a motor vehicle that is not operated in compliance with the instructions of the traffic-control signal. 
(3)  Recorded Image means an image recorded by a photographic traffic monitoring system that depicts the rear of a motor vehicle and is automatically recorded on a photograph or digital image. 
(4)  System location means the approach to an intersection toward which a photographic traffic enforcement system is directed and in operation. 
(5)  Traffic control signal shall mean a traffic control device that displays alternating red, amber and green lights that directs traffic when to stop at or proceed through an intersection. 
(Ord. No. 7091, § 1, 4-22-2008) 
Sec. 16-3-380. - Imposition of civil penalty for violations. 
(a)  It is hereby declared to be a nuisance against public health, safety, and welfare for a motor vehicle to proceed into an intersection when the traffic control signal for that vehicle's direction of travel is emitting a steady red signal. Such an event damages the public by endangering motor vehicle operators and pedestrians alike, by decreasing the efficiency of traffic control and traffic flow efforts, and by increasing the number of serious accidents to which public safety agencies must respond at the expense of the taxpayers. 
(b)  Except as provided in (c) and (d) below, the Owner of a motor vehicle is liable for a civil penalty of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) if the motor vehicle proceeds into an intersection at a System Location when the traffic control signal for that motor vehicle's direction of travel is emitting a steady red signal. 
(c)  An Owner who fails to timely pay the civil penalty shall be subject to a late payment fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(d)  An Owner who fails to either timely pay the civil penalty, or to timely contest liability by requesting an administrative hearing in accordance with this Article, or to timely perfect an appeal to municipal court in accordance with this Article, is deemed to have admitted liability for the full amount of the civil penalty stated in the notice of violation, and to have waives the right to a hearing and appeal. 
(e)  A civil penalty imposed by this section is due and payable not later than the 30 th day after the notice of violation is issued, unless within that period the Owner contests the notice by making written request for an administrative hearing. 
(Ord. No. 7091, § 1, 4-22-2008) 
Sec. 16-3-381. - Enforcement; procedures. 
(a)  A notice of violation will not be issued until the Amarillo Police Department has first reviewed the Recorded Image and found there is cause for the notice to be issued. If the reviewing police officer determines that circumstances constituting an affirmative defense or other extenuating conditions are plainly visible, then a notice shall not be issued. 
(b)  The City or its contractor shall mail a notice of violation to the Owner of the motor vehicle liable for the civil penalty not later than the 30 th day after the date the violation is alleged to have occurred to the Owner's address as shown on the registration records of the Texas Department of Transportation or as shown on the records of the analogous department or agency of another state or country when the suspect license plate is from another jurisdiction. 
(c)  A notice of violation issued under this Article shall contain the following: 
(1)  A description of the violation alleged; 
(2)  The date, time, and location of the violation; 
(3)  A copy of the Recorded Image of the vehicle license plate and violation involved and an internet URL where the Recorded Image of the violation may be viewed; 
(4)  The amount of the civil penalty to be imposed for the violation; 
(5)  The date by which the civil penalty must either be paid or the matter contested by a written request for an administrative hearing, and that failure to pay or contest the civil penalty within the time allowed shall result in imposition of a late fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00); 
(6)  A statement that the person named in the notice of violation may pay the civil penalty in lieu of appearing at an administrative hearing; 
(7)  Information that informs the person: 
a.  Of the right to, manner of, and time for contesting the imposition of the civil penalty in an administrative hearing; and 
b.  That failure to timely pay the civil penalty or to contest liability is an admission of liability; and, 
c.  That the notice of violation and penalty are civil in nature, not criminal, and will not be reported to any insurance company or any state agency that maintains driving records or issues driver licenses. 
(8)  A statement that the Recorded Image is evidence in a proceeding for the imposition of a civil penalty; and, 
(9)  Nonpayment of penalty and any late fee, with or without a hearing or appeal may be reported to the Texas Department of Transportation and a county may subsequently refuse to register the suspect vehicle until the delinquent sum is paid. 
(d)  A notice of violation under this Article is presumed to have been received on or before the 5 th day after the date the notice is mailed. 
(Ord. No. 7091, § 1, 4-22-2008) 
Sec. 16-3-382. - Administrative hearing; affirmative defenses. 
(a)  A person who receives a notice of violation may contest the imposition of the civil penalty by a written request for administrative hearing within thirty (30) days after issuance of the notice of violation. Upon receipt of such request, the Office of Civil Administrative Hearings shall notify the person of the date, time, and location of the administrative hearing. Such hearing shall be set for a date no sooner than seven (7) and no longer than thirty (30) days after the request is received. 
(b)  All procedures and aspects of a civil administrative hearing shall be in accordance with Chapter 2-8, Article VI, except where a procedure is provided in this section that pertains specifically to photographic traffic signal enforcement, in which case the hearing officer shall observe such provisions of this section in addition to those of Chapter 2-8, Article VI. 
(c)  Notwithstanding anything in this Article to the contrary, a person who fails to pay the amount of a civil penalty or to contest liability in a timely manner is entitled to an administrative hearing if the person files an affidavit with the hearing officer stating the date on which the person actually received the notice of violation that was mailed to the person, provided that the person files said affidavit within thirty (30) days after actual date of receipt of the notice of violation. 
(d)  The reliability of the Photographic Traffic Signal Enforcement system used to produce the Recorded Image of the violation may be attested to by affidavit of an employee of the city or the entity with which the city contracts to install, maintain, inspect, and operate the system. An affidavit of a city employee or the contractor that alleges a violation, based on an inspection of the Recorded Image, is admissible in a proceeding under this Article and is evidence of the facts contained in the affidavit. 
(e)  It shall be an affirmative defense to the imposition of civil liability under this Article, to be proven by a preponderance of the evidence, that: 
(1)  The traffic-control signal was faulty; 
(2)  The operator of the motor vehicle was acting in compliance with the lawful order or direction of a police officer or other person directing traffic at the request of a police officer, or was a participant in an authorized funeral procession or parade that had the right-of-way through the intersection in disregard of the red signal; 
(3)  The operator of the motor vehicle disregarded the traffic control signal to safely yield the right-of-way to and make a path for an immediately approaching authorized emergency vehicle; 
(4)  The suspect motor vehicle was operating as an authorized emergency vehicle; 
(5)  The presence of ice, snow, unusual amounts of rain or other unusual hazardous road condition existed that would make compliance with this Article more dangerous under the circumstances than disregarding the traffic control signal and, the disregard of such signal did not cause an accident or require evasive maneuver by another driver or pedestrian. 
(Ord. No. 7091, § 1, 4-22-2008; Ord. No. 7781, § 1, 3-26-2019) 
Sec. 16-3-383. - Appeal. 
(a)  A person who is found liable after an administrative hearing may appeal that determination of civil liability to the municipal court, by filing a written notice of appeal with the clerk of the municipal court not later than the 31 st day after the date on which the administrative hearing officer entered the written finding of civil liability. Collection or enforcement of the civil penalty is stayed during the period allowed for perfecting an appeal and during the pendency of the appeal. 
(b)  To perfect the appeal, the person must also file with the notice of appeal, a notarized statement of personal financial obligation (that is, either post a bond or sign a promissory note that is immediately due and payable upon entry of a judgment of liability by the municipal court and providing for recovery of city's reasonable attorney fees and court costs for collection of the note, and providing for waiver of notice, presentment, and demand) in the amount of the civil penalty and, pay the applicable civil court costs to the court clerk, being the sum of twenty-seven dollars ($27.00). 
(c)  The clerk of the municipal court shall set the matter for a trial-by judge as expeditiously as possible on the court's docket and issue notice of the date, time and place of the trial to the appellant and the City attorney's office. The appeal shall be conducted as a civil trial de novo and all issues determined by the judge upon a preponderance of the evidence. The affidavits submitted under Section 16-3-382 shall be admitted into evidence by the municipal judge. 
(d)  At the conclusion of the trail, the trial judge shall enter a written judgment declaring whether the person is liable for the nuisance and civil penalty stated in this Article or is not liable for same. A person found liable in the municipal court trial shall immediately pay the civil penalty prescribed by this Article. The court is authorized to immediately collect the civil penalty by cash, credit card, or by immediately proceeding against any bond posted by the person. If the person is exonerated, then the statement of personal financial obligation required to perfect the appeal shall be immediately released. 
(Ord. No. 7091, § 1, 4-22-2008) 
Sec. 16-3-384. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7781, § 2, adopted March 26, 2019, repealed § 16-3-384, which pertained to nature of liability; collection; no double violations and derived from Ord. No. 7091, § 1, 4-22-2008. 
Sec. 16-3-385. - Safety & Traffic Fund. 
    The civil penalties and late fees collected under this Article shall be deposited in a traffic management account established by the City Council. Funds from the traffic management account may be expended only for; the costs of Photographic Traffic Signal enforcement under this Article, traffic or pedestrian safety programs, public safety, traffic enforcement, intersection improvements, or payments to the State of Texas required by law for operating a Photographic Traffic Signal Enforcement System. 
(Ord. No. 7091, § 1, 4-22-2008; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 16-3-386. - Statute incorporated. 
    It is the intention of the City that all applicable provisions of Texas Transportation Code, Chapter 707, as amended, are addressed in this Article either as expressly stated hereinabove or incorporated here by this reference. In the event of a conflict or omission between this Article and Chapter 707, then the applicable provision of said statute shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 7091, § 1, 4-22-2008) 
ARTICLES XIII-XX. - RESERVED 

Secs. 16-3-387-16-3-1000. - Reserved.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - AMBULANCES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Emergency Medical Services Act, V.A.C.S. art. 4447o; municipal regulation of emergency medical services vehicles, V.A.C.S. art. 4447o, § 3.10. 

Sec. 16-4-16. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ambulance: Every motor vehicle built, equipped and attended as required by the laws of the State for the purpose of transporting sick, injured or deceased persons for hire. 
    Ambulance Service: The transportation of sick, injured or deceased persons for hire within the City limits in an Ambulance. The term "Ambulance Service" shall not include the use of Ambulances or other vehicles for the purpose of picking up, upon request of the families or municipal or other authorities or in the case of persons whose families cannot be located, dead bodies either at a home, hospital or other place for the purpose of transporting such bodies to a mortuary, nor shall it include the use of an Ambulance or other vehicle for the purpose of transporting such deceased persons for funeral and burial purposes. 
    Permit: The authority granted by the City Council to any person to use the Streets of the City for the purpose of providing Ambulance Service. No such Permits shall be granted to any person except upon a finding by the City Council that Public Convenience and Necessity require it. 
    Public Convenience and Necessity: A public convenience which is fitting and suited to a public need and a public necessity which embraces a great and urgent public convenience. This term as applied to an Ambulance Service proposed and offered to the public by a person shall mean that the person is fit, able and willing to perform the Ambulance Service in the City in accordance with the requirements of this article and that Public Convenience and Necessity require the Ambulance Service proposed by the person. 
    Street: Any Street, Alley, Avenue, Boulevard, drive, public way or highway commonly used for the purpose of public travel within the City limits. 
(Code 1960, § 24-1; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Cross reference- Definitions to apply throughout Code, § 1-2-1. 
Sec. 16-4-17. - Public convenience and necessity; determining factors. 
    No Permit to operate an Ambulance Service shall be granted by the City Council to any person until the City Council shall have had an opportunity, after due notice and hearing, to investigate and find that Public Convenience and Necessity, require the proposed Ambulance Service. In determining whether Public Convenience and Necessity require the granting of the Permit to any person the City Council shall take into consideration the following: 
(1)  Public demand: Whether the demands of Public Convenience and Necessity require such proposed Ambulance Service within the City. 
(2)  Financial responsibility. The financial responsibility of the person applying for the Permit. 
(3)  Equipment. The number, kind and type of equipment owned or proposed to be used by the person seeking a Permit. 
(4)  Danger to public. Whether safe use of the Streets of the City by the public, both by vehicles and pedestrians, may be unduly endangered by the granting of the Permit. 
(5)  Applicant's qualifications. Whether the person seeking the permit is fit, able and willing to render adequate Ambulance Service to the people of the City. 
(6)  Other relevant factors. Such other relevant facts as the City Council may deem advisable or necessary in order to pass upon the existence or nonexistence of Public Convenience and Necessity. 
(Code 1960, § 24-2; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 16-4-18. - Permit-Required; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate an Ambulance Service upon and over the public Streets, Alleys or public ways of the City unless and until such person has been granted a Permit by the City Council authorizing the operation of the Ambulance Service. 
(b)  Exceptions. 
(1)  A governmental entity having coterminous boundaries with the City, with the express consent of the City Council, may operate an Ambulance Service within the City without a Permit. 
(2)  No permit or fee for use of Streets is required for the operation of an Ambulance Service by a hospital or health system located within the City of Amarillo, licensed and operating under Texes Health & Safety Code Chapter 241 (as amended and any successor statutes), so long as such Ambulance Service is licensed under authority of the Texas Department of Health and the operations are solely limited to the transfer of non-emergency patients between such hospital and a hospice under common ownership with the hospital or health system. 
(Code 1960, § 24-3; Ord. No. 6734, § 2, 6-1-2004; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 16-4-19. - Same-Filing application; notice published; public hearing. 
(a)  Any person who desires a Permit for the purpose of rendering Ambulance Service shall make application therefor, in writing, to the City Council by filing an application within the City Secretary. 
(b)  The application shall state the following: 
(1)  Name of the applicant and whether the applicant is an individual, a corporation, a partnership or an association; 
(2)  The number, kind and type of the vehicles proposed to be operated as Ambulances, and the manner in which they are to be equipped; 
(3)  A financial statement, together with such other pertinent information as the City Council may deem necessary. 
(c)  The City Secretary, upon receipt of such application, shall cause a notice to be published in a daily newspaper published in the City once each day for three (3) consecutive days, the cost of which shall be paid in advance by the applicant. The publication shall constitute notice to the public that a public hearing will be held before the City Council at a specified time and place. 
(d)  The public hearing shall not be held less than five (5) days after the date of the last publication of the notice. 
(e)  Contesting; applicant's burden of proof. All persons, including the holders of existing Permits, shall be entitled to contest the application. The applicant shall be required to establish by clear and convincing evidence that Public Convenience and Necessity require the Ambulance Service proposed to be offered to the public and that he is fit, able and willing to render safe and efficient Ambulance Service. 
(Code 1960, § 24-4; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 16-4-20. - Same-Application for renewal; presumption. 
    When the application is for renewal of an existing Permit to operate an Ambulance Service it shall be presumed, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, that a Public Convenience and Necessity exists and that the applicant is fit, able and willing to render Ambulance Service. 
(Code 1960, § 24-5) 
Sec. 16-4-21. - Same-Granting or refusing; resolution. 
    The granting of a Permit shall be evidenced by a resolution of the City Council properly entered upon the minutes by the City Secretary, who shall issue a Permit to the applicant on such form as may be prescribed by the City Council. The refusal to grant a permit to any person shall likewise be evidenced by a resolution properly recorded. 
(Code 1960, § 24-6; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 16-4-22. - Same-Transfer. 
    Permits granted under the provisions of this article shall not be sold, transferred or assigned to any person without the approval of the City Council first having been obtained. 
(Code 1960, § 24-8; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 16-4-23. - Same-Revocation. 
    The City Council may revoke a permit after due notice and hearing upon a finding that: 
(1)  Public Convenience and Necessity no longer require the service; 
(2)  The Permit holder is no longer fit, able and willing to render adequate Ambulance Service to the public; 
(3)  The Permit holder has failed to file an annual report or failed to pay the annual Street rental charge required in section 16-4-25; 
(4)  The Permit holder has been guilty of other willful violations of the terms of this article. 
(Code 1960, § 24-9; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 16-4-24. - Public liability insurance. 
(a)  Prior to exercising the privileges granted by any Permit issued under the provisions of this article, the grantee shall deposit with the City Secretary evidence that he has in force a public liability, bodily injury and property damage insurance policy with such limits as may be fixed by the City Council. 
(b)  The minimum liability coverage provided by such policy shall be two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for any single injury to one (1) person, five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for personal injuries in any single accident and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for damage to property in any single incident. 
(Code 1960, § 24-10; Ord. No. 6199, § 1, 10-31-95; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 16-4-25. - Records; annual audit; street rental charge. 
(a)  Each person holding a Permit granted under this article shall keep an accurate set of books and records which shall, at all reasonable times, be made available for the purpose of auditing by the City Council or some person authorized by the City Council. 
(b)  Within ninety (90) days after the end of the Permit holder's fiscal year, the Permit holder shall file with the City Secretary a finance statement for the Ambulance Service within the City for the just ended fiscal year and shall simultaneously pay ten (10) percent of net profit as a rental charge for the use of the Streets of the City for the Ambulance Service. Such finance statement shall be filed and the rental charge paid annually, beginning after the close of the first fiscal year in which a Permit is issued and continuing thereafter, so long as the Permit is in existence. 
(Code 1960, § 24-13; Ord. No. 6734, § 1, 6-1-2004; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 16-4-26. - Equipment maintenance. 
    A Permit holder under this article shall maintain his equipment in good operating condition so as to ensure safety. All accessory equipment for rendering emergency treatment to sick and injured persons shall at all times be in operating order. 
(Code 1960, § 24-14) 
Sec. 16-4-27. - Director of transportation; inspections, investigations, reports. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the Director of Transportation of the City to cause the equipment of the Permit holder to be inspected at least every ninety (90) days and as often as he deems it appropriate. The director shall report the result of the inspections to the City Council. 
(b)  The Director of Transportation shall investigate any violations of this article and any complaints relating to service against any Permit holder and make reports and recommendations thereon to the City Council. 
(Code 1960, § 24-15; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 16-4-28. - Fraudulent intent not to pay for service. 
    It shall be a violation of this article for a person to use an Ambulance with the fraudulent intention of not paying to the franchise holder the rate approved. 
(Code 1960, § 24-16) 
Secs. 16-4-29-16-4-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TAXICABS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6746, § 1, adopted June 29, 2004, amended the former Art. III, §§ 16-4-41-16-4-44, 16-4-56-16-4-64, 16-4-74-16-4-84, 16-4-96-16-4-99, 16-4-11116-4-116, 16-4-124-16-4-126, 16-4-128, 16-4-129, and enacted a new Art. III as set out herein. The former Art. III pertained to similar subject matter. For complete derivation see the Code Comparative Table at the end of this volume. 
Cross reference- Smoking regulations re taxicabs, §§ 8-4-285, 8-4-287 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-4-41. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this Article, the following words have the meaning indicated: 
    Depot: The location where the taxicab fleet (whether one (1) or more) is parked when the vehicle is out of service. 
    Driver: An individual who drives any taxicab (regardless of who may be the owner, leaser, operator, or renter of the taxicab vehicle). 
    Operator: An individual, corporation, partnership, any other business entity, or a combination thereof which owns, leases, rents contracts for, otherwise controls or possesses taxicabs or by any combination thereof, one (1) or more taxicabs for the purpose of the operator and/or others to drive as a taxi service. 
    Taxicab: Any chauffeured motor vehicle for general passenger use with a rated passenger capacity including the driver of nine (9) or less which typically operates on irregular routes and schedules and provides call-on-demand transportation for passengers in return for a fee (payable by any tangible or intangible medium of exchange, credit, currency, barter, sight order, token, or thing of value). The term shall not apply to motor vehicles operating under a permit or certificate of the Railroad Commission of the State or the Interstate Commerce Commission, nor to vehicles operating within the City under a contract granted by the City Council, nor to Limousines and Touring Vehicles as defined in Article IV of this chapter. 
    Taxicab stand: A public place alongside the Curb of a Street or elsewhere, in the City which has been designated by the Traffic Engineer as reserved exclusively for the use of Taxicabs awaiting passengers. 
    Vehicle for Hire: Any chauffeured motor vehicle designed for general passenger use, providing call-on-demand transportation for passengers in return for a fee (payable by any tangible or intangible medium of exchange, credit, currency, barter, sight order, token, or thing of value), which typically operates on irregular routes and schedules and that may be summoned by telephone, computer, mobile phone, radio, other electronic device, or other means. The term shall not apply to motor vehicles operating under a permit or certificate of the Railroad Commission of the State or the Interstate Commerce Commission, nor to vehicles operating within the City under a contract granted by the City Council, nor to Limousines and Touring Vehicles as defined in Article IV of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 6746, § 1, 6-29-2004; Ord. No. 7480, § 1, 9-2-2014; Ord. No. 7658, § 2, 3-14-2017) 
Sec. 16-4-42. - Tripcard. 
    Every driver shall maintain a legible daily tripcard upon which are recorded all trips made each day, showing time and place of origin and destination of each trip and amount of fare. All completed trip cards shall be returned to the operator by the driver at the conclusion of his tour of duty. The operator shall retain and preserve the completed trip cards in a safe place for not less than two (2) calendar years following the date of the trip, and shall make same available to the police chief or designee for inspection and copying within one (1) business day after request. The tripcard forms shall be furnished to each driver by the operator and shall be of a character approved by the Chief of Police. 
(Ord. No. 6746, § 1, 6-29-2004) 
Sec. 16-4-43. - Advertising. 
    It shall be unlawful for any operator or driver to affix or allow advertising matter to be affixed to or installed in or on any Taxicab which obstructs the driver's vision or otherwise interferes with the safe operation of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 6746, § 1, 6-29-2004) 
Sec. 16-4-44-16-4-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OPERATOR'S PERMIT 

Sec. 16-4-56. - Required permit. 
    Any person who owns, leases or rents one (1) or more Taxicabs to be operated upon the Streets of the City shall obtain a Taxicab operator's permit pursuant to the provisions of this division irrespective of whether or not the Taxicab is subleased, rented or used by or to a Taxicab driver or leased to another operator for dispatching or other operating services. If a person is himself both the operator of a taxicab service and the driver of the taxicab, such person must obtain an operator's permit under this division. 
(Ord. No. 6746, § 1, 6-29-2004) 
Sec. 16-4-57. - Application. 
    An application for a Taxicab operator's permit shall be filed with the Chief of Police upon forms provided by the City. The application shall be verified under oath and shall furnish the following information: 
(1)  The applicant's personal name, telephone, and address and, the phone number, which the public shall call to obtain taxicab service and, address of the depot, if different from the operator's personal phone number or address; 
(2)  If the operator is a business entity, then provide the above personal information for the general manager of the company who will be responsible for day-to-day operations; name and address for each partner, officer, director, and member, as is applicable to the business entity; 
(3)  Any unpaid judgments or taxes of any type owed by the applicant; 
(4)  The number of vehicles to be operated or controlled by the applicant and the location of proposed depots; 
(5)  The assumed or trade name under which the operator will do business and, the color scheme, lettering, and insignia to be used on taxicabs to designate the operator's vehicle or vehicles; 
(6)  Such further information as the City may reasonably require on the application. 
(Ord. No. 6746, § 1, 6-29-2004) 
Sec. 161-4-58. - Issuance or denial and appeal.
